text: From the editorial page

headline: In Performance: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
text: A scene from Theater for a New Audience’s production of Shakespeare’s romantic comedy, with Jonathan Cake as Benedick and Maggie Siff as Beatrice.

headline: Daily Report: TV Pilots Turn to Internet, Not Networks
text: Internet-delivered TV, which until recently was unready for prime time, is the new front in the war for Americans’ attention spans, Brian Stelter reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Houses of Worship
text: It can be hard to get a moment of solitude in a city like Mumbai or New York, where the workplace is often competitive and chaotic, the commute is overcrowded, homes are cramped and the streets are teeming with a bustling populace. In both cities, places of worship often serve as a serene respite.

headline: Still-Unhappy Southeastern Seeks Dell Shareholder List
text: It appears that despite Dell Inc.’s efforts to the contrary, Southeastern Asset Management remains unconvinced that the computer maker’s $24.4 billion sale to its founder is the last best hope for shareholders.

headline: China’s Balancing Act
text: In his final report to China’s national legislature on March 5, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao highlighted the country’s “unbalanced” economic and social development.

headline: Bad Signs (New York Trivia)
text: Not a policy post, just a tiny public service intervention from a concerned citizen. So, a plea to Penn Station management: fix your signs! Not for my sake, since I know my way around, but for visitors.

headline: LaFerrari: The New Supercar From Maranello
text: GENEVA — Ferrari finally took the wraps off its secrecy-shrouded new supercar, to be called LaFerrari, on Tuesday at the 83rd International Motor Show here.

headline: Bad Breath on Broadway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Tuesday Reading: Exercises for Shoulder Pain
text: Exercises for shoulder pain, how to prevent falls and manage the fear of falling, users rate their phones and other consumer focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Chanel: As the World Turns
text: Karl Lagerfeld called the latest Chanel collection, simply, “Globalization.” That’s thinking big. And he planted a giant wooden replica of the planet in the middle of the Grand Palais on Tuesday, with pin lights denoting cities and little red flags for the 300 Chanel boutiques around the world. So Chanel rules.

headline: Microsoft Faces Fine in Europe After Breaking a Deal
text: BRUSSELS — Europe’s antitrust regulators are preparing to deliver a strong message: a deal is a deal, and if a company fails to live up to a settlement agreement, there will be consequences.

headline: Chanel: Fall 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Some Things You May Not Have Known About Adam Davidson
text: If you read Adam Davidson’s “It’s the Economy” column, you might think that he is a pretty smart guy who knows a lot about how the exchange of money and ideas shapes our thinking. What you wouldn’t know, however, is that Adam isn’t interested in only beer mergers or finding a nanny for his 1-year-old. He also likes to sing Kelly Clarkson songs at the top of his lungs, make henna designs and watch endless loops of “Full House” reruns. He also wore only green clothing for an entire year when he was 38.

headline: Why Don’t We Have Deflation?
text: Whenever you see a piece suggesting that the US economy has entered a “new normal” of slow growth, you’re likely to see someone making the argument that if the economy actually had lots of excess capacity, we should be seeing deflation. And the question of why we don’t have deflation is a good one. It is, however, a question that people like me have answered repeatedly; unfortunately, it seems that this analysis hasn’t been making it to, say, a number of current and former Fed officials.

headline: A Promising Debut at Ungaro
text: Ever since Emanuel Ungaro retired, in 2005, and the Avenue Montaigne house was sold to Asim Abdullah, an affable Silicon Valley entrepreneur with no experience in fashion, the company has floundered. Five or six designers have come and gone (I’m not sure whether to count Lindsay Lohan, who laughably served as artistic adviser). The most recent was Giles Deacon, a London designer, who initially seemed a good choice but couldn’t make anything happen.

headline: British Regulators Slow to Respond to Libor Scandal, Audit Says
text: LONDON – British authorities failed to spot interest-rate manipulation by big banks because they were narrowly focused on responding to the financial crisis, according to an internal review by the country’s financial watchdog released on Tuesday.

headline: Anadarko and Videocon to Sell Mozambique Gas Stakes
text: LONDON — Anadarko Petroleum of the United States and Videocon of India have put 20 percent of an important natural gas field off the coast of Mozambique up for sale, according to Videocon’s chairman and others with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Town & Country: The urbane maître d’hôtel of Daniel, John Winterman, bemoans the unsightly legions of “baggy trench coats, oversized shopping bags and damp umbrellas” cluttering his dining room, as more customers refuse to check their belongings. — Pete Wells

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: TV Pilots Move to the Web and Fox Prepares to Take On ESPN
text: TV shows like “House of Cards,” “Hemlock Grove” and the latest iteration of “Arrested Development” are debuting regularly on streaming services like Netflix, signaling a departure from traditional networks and a sea change in the way television is viewed, Brian Stelter writes. Amazon.com and Microsoft are also commissioning original shows for their millions of subscribers. The shows’ production values now rival those of network television, and their proliferation is seen as a good thing for viewers that may inflame cable companies’ concerns about cutting the cord.

headline: As Fears Recede, Dow Industrials Hit a Milestone
text: The economy may be struggling to recover, but by one closely watched measure the fear that not long ago paralyzed the markets has lifted.

headline: The Life Expectancy Zombie
text: So, one of the moments in my debate with JoScar — which wasn’t as bad as I felt, but should have gone much better — was my “wow” when JS raised the old line that life expectancy was 62 when Social Security started, so the program was no big deal.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Saint Laurent
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Yes, Even Young College Graduates Have Low Unemployment
text: I’ve written recently about the job prospects for college graduates versus those without bachelor’s degrees, noting that the unemployment rate for college graduates is about half that for workers with no more than a high school diploma (3.7 percent versus 8.1 percent as of January). Several readers wrote me to take issue with the fact that I was looking at the whole universe of workers with these credentials, rather than just the recently graduated. Perhaps college graduates from generations past are more protected than those just entering the work force, they wrote, and it is misleading to say that young graduates are equally secure.

headline: In Women’s Basketball, a Season of the Powerhouses
text: If there was ever a year when men’s and women’s college basketball were more different, well, it’s hard to remember it, and Monday summed it up in one nice little package. The women’s game is all about powerhouses, about Baylor’s Brittney Griner’s being one in and of herself, scoring 50 points and dunking on Kansas State; about Notre Dame elbowing Connecticut out of its usual spot atop the Big East hill; about UConn hyperventilating because it hasn’t won a national title in three whole years. Gasp.

headline: Hakaan: Fall 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: More People Commute to Manhattan Than Any Other County
text: Updated, 1:47 p.m. | No wonder so many people in New York seem to be coming or going. Manhattan draws more commuters than any other county in the country, while more people leave Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx to work than any other counties.

headline: What Parental Leave Does Your Employer Offer?
text: Between Marissa Mayer’s new full-time face-time policy at Yahoo, new numbers showing America’s support for breast-feeding — as long as we don’t have to pay for it — yet more news regarding the dismal state of family leave in the United States, and now, a discussion of whether even graduate schools support new mothers (let alone new parents), family leave has been a big topic here in the past few weeks. With no national paid leave policy (and only 40 percent of employees eligible for unpaid leave under the Family Medical Leave Act), whether workers have access to leave depends largely on where and for whom they work.

headline: Net Over Network
text: The Times's Brian Stelter discusses the new, high-quality programming that shuns traditional broadcast TV for the Web.

headline: HSBC Sells U.S. Loan Portfolio for $3.2 Billion
text: LONDON – The British bank HSBC made some progress on Tuesday in shrinking its consumer loan portfolio in the United States, which has been a drag on its earnings.

headline: The Costs of Underconfidence
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: The Gun Report: March 5, 2013
text: One of the problems with guns is that there are too many people who simply don’t take seriously their killing potential. Either that or they don’t care. Last Friday, for instance, a woman named Mary Frances Alday, 61, went into a Walmart in Crawfordville, Fla., and when she got to the checkout line, demanded that the store redeem a “dollar off” coupon she procured online. She became furious when told the store would not honor Internet coupons, and after lashing out at the store clerk and other Walmart employees – and hurling a shopping cart at them – she went to her car, where she pulled out a loaded Smith & Wesson .38 Special and waved it in the direction of the Walmart staff. After she fled the parking lot, Alday was pulled over by the sheriff’s department and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

headline: Don’t Tear Down This Wall
text: BERLIN — One quarter of a century after Ronald Reagan called on Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall, a new generation of Berliners is taking to the streets to preserve it.

headline: Colonel Shaw’s Drummer Boy
text: African-American volunteers poured into the ranks of the 54th Massachusetts Infantry from across the Bay State during the early months of 1863; conspicuous among the patriotic towns that sent their black sons off to war was New Bedford. The seafaring city, with its large population of escaped slaves, had been targeted early on as a prime spot for recruits, and among those who enrolled in the new regiment was Alex Johnson, a 16-year-old sailor with a passion for percussion.

headline: Occupy Rice Paddy
text: ALWAN SOK, Myanmar — “Nostalgia” is one way to translate the name of this small farming village 25 kilometers south of Yangon. Nostalgia is also one way to describe the way the farmers who live here feel about their land and the time, many years ago, when they were sure it was theirs.

headline: Lamb of God Singer Acquitted in Fan’s Death
text: A municipal court in Prague on Tuesday acquitted the lead singer of the heavy metal band Lamb of God of causing a teenage fan’s death at a concert in the Czech Republic, The Associated Press reported. A court spokeswoman, Marketa Puci, said that the court had ruled that what Mr. Blythe did was not a crime and that the concert organizers were to blame for the incident.

headline: Liz Magic Laser’s Armory Show Souvenirs
text: The European avant-garde crashed onto American shores with the 1913 Armory Show, introducing New York’s art-going public to many of today’s most revered modern painters, among them Cézanne, Kandinsky, Matisse and Picasso. With radical works like Marcel Duchamp’s “Nude Descending a Staircase,” the exhibition both fascinated and disturbed; many visitors regarded the paintings, with their brash colors, warped perspectives and semi-abstract figures, as assaults on the virtues of classical beauty.

headline: When James Becomes Janice: What Not to Ask a Transgender Friend
text: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Kennedy Center Season Will Include ‘Swan Lake’ and Hip-Hop
text: With the Mariinsky Ballet’s “Swan Lake,” Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” and a weeklong hip-hop festival, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington is offering a mix of classics and contemporary pop culture in its 2013-2014 season.

headline: In Video Series, Wall St. Leaders Reflect on Their Careers
text: Hamilton E. James, the president and chief operating officer of the Blackstone Group, is one of the most powerful figures on Wall Street, overseeing an alternative investment empire from offices on Park Avenue on Manhattan. But it was not always so.

headline: The Lightness of Being Above the Arctic Circle
text: For this past weekend’s Voyages issue, the photographer Simon Norfolk traveled to the Lofoten Islands in Norway in search of the aurora borealis. He first learned about the Lofotens while researching an earlier project he shot for the magazine on rocket launches. He then encountered the northern lights on a separate assignment to photograph radio equipment in Norway:

headline: North Korea Threatens to Attack U.S. With ‘Lighter and Smaller Nukes’
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Tuesday that it would cut off a hot line with the United States military in South Korea, calling the truce that stopped the Korean War in 1953 null and void and threatening to strike the United States with “lighter and smaller nukes.”

headline: London Theater Journal: Memory Plays
text: LONDON — One thing, at least, is certain in both the fascinating new versions of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times” that are keeping audiences in a rapt state of perplexity here: The man loses.

headline: With Isolation Looming, Mets Look for Company on Florida’s East Coast
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When the Mets set up training camp here in 1988, Keith Hernandez and some of his teammates took to calling the city Port St. Lonesome because it was so sleepy.

headline: Image of the Day: March 5
text: Pigeons being cremated in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: Back Pain Unrelieved by Steroid Shots
text: A pinched nerve in the back, or lumbar spinal stenosis, is often treated with epidural injections of steroids when exercise and physical therapy are ineffective. Now a small study suggests that the injections may do more harm than good.

headline: A Truck Strikes a Child, and a Doctor Can’t Help
text: Melanie M. Canon, a family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem, happened upon the scene last Thursday moments after a 6-year-old boy, Amar Diarrassouba, was struck by a turning truck and tried to save his life. She sent City Room this account.

headline: Baseball Statues Aplenty, Many of Them in Unexpected Places
text: If you are looking for a statue of Babe Ruth, you will not find one at Yankee Stadium. The Sultan of Swat may have been the most dominant player in the game’s history, but the Yankees seem to consider that more worthy of a monument than a sculpture.

headline: Deconstructing ‘World’s Friendliest People’
text: Which country has the world’s friendliest people?

headline: Nominee to Lead C.I.A. Clears Hurdle After Release of Drone Data
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday voted 12 to 3 to confirm John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency after the White House agreed to provide more information on the legal basis for targeted killings of Americans abroad who are believed to pose a terrorist threat.

headline: Pilot Says Drone Flew Past Jet Nearing J.F.K.
text: Updated, 4:00 p.m. |Flocks of geese are not the only airborne hazards pilots will be watching for around New York City’s airports, after one captain reported passing a drone on Monday afternoon.

headline: Living in His Van, Trying to Rebuild a Life Upended by a Bullet
text: Update, March 14 | Many readers have written wondering how to donate to Mr. Leonik. You may send a check made out to him to:Andrzej LeonikP.O. Box 863697Ridgewood, N.Y. 11386

headline: For Times Environmental Reporting, Intentions May Be Good but the Signs Are Not
text: Judging by appearances, things are not looking good for environmental reporting at The Times.

headline: Sweetheart Rates for Corporations
text: At any other time, the news that Chevron Corporation received a federal tax subsidy to expand a refinery in Mississippi would register as just another example of corporate welfare.

headline: Oooohs Turn to Boos as Bieber Shows Up Late for Concert
text: Justin Bieber, who usually enjoys an adulation bordering on worship among his fans, was forced to apologize on Tuesday to concertgoers and their angry parents after he took the stage almost two hours late for a show at the 02 Arena in London, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2013 RTW

headline: Revisiting the Story of ‘A Harlem Family’
text: In 1968, the Life magazine photographer Gordon Parks riveted the nation with a photo essay on the grinding daily struggles of the Fontenelles, a desperately poor family in Harlem.

headline: Blame It on Bad Data
text: Amazon.com can’t seem to stay out of trouble these days. First it hired a shadowy group accused of having neo-Nazi sympathies — not exactly the sort of people you want to be called out for using in Germany, no matter how much trouble you have keeping your warehouse workers in line. Now the giant retailer is under fire in Britain for selling T-shirts that say things like, “Keep Calm and Rape Me” and “Keep Calm and Hit Her a Lot.”

headline: Sonos Does Television
text: Sonos is no longer ignoring the TV. The company’s new Playbar begins shipping Tuesday, allowing customers to improve the sound of their televisions while also connecting them to Sonos speakers throughout the house.

headline: Ask Well: Can Weather Affect Mail Order Drugs?
text: Question:

headline: Rich and Proud of It, Saudi Billionaire Prefers Bloomberg’s To Forbes
text: It’s report card time for the world’s billionaires and one contender is balking about his grades. But as journalism about the world’s wealthy grows, this billionaire now can take his complaints to a competitor.

headline: ‘Downton’ Destinations
text: Fans of “Downton Abbey” feeling wistful after the season finale won’t have to wait until new episodes air next year to get their fix. The drama — and its success — has sent travel outfitters and tourism boards scrambling to come up with ways to explore the lives of the noble classes and their servants, on both sides of the Atlantic. Below are a few options, ranging from high end to low.

headline: Trading Hits a High
text: The Times's Peter Lattman on what's behind a record moment for the Dow Jones industrial average.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Fringe
text: A flapper-style fringe melded with modern Parisian silhouettes: Akris created a smoking suit; Dries Van Noten transformed a champagne confection into a daytime staple; and Ann Demeulemeester kept things light with an ombre effect.

headline: Study: Facebook Users More Protective Even as They Reveal More About Themselves
text: Facebook users became much more protective about who sees sensitive information about them, even as they were urged to share more about themselves on the social network, according to an unusual seven-year study by researchers at Carnegie Mellon University.

headline: Relational Urges Hess to Talk With Elliott
text: 3:56 p.m. | Updated with Hess’ letter to Relational

headline: Incoming, From the North, a Blizzard of Fresh Dance
text: The Nordic nations’ cultural scene hasn’t wanted for attention lately. Stieg Larsson’s crime novels and “Nordic noir” television series like “The Killing” have inspired almost cultlike followings, to say nothing of all that oh-so-sleek, oh-so-expensive furniture.

headline: Vivienne Westwood: At 71, Still Not Done Provoking
text: Punk is back in the fall collections — spikes at Donatella Versace and Anthony Vaccarello, garbage bag dresses at Gareth Pugh — which is not surprising given that the impact of the punk movement in fashion is the subject of an upcoming Costume Institute exhibition. It all goes back to Vivienne Westwood, who designed for the Sex Pistols and whose collaborations with Malcolm McLaren in the 1970s will feature prominently at the Met. At 71, she remains as provocative as ever while continuing to design collections shown in London and Paris.

headline: Jimmie Johnson: From Track to Surf to Track
text: FONTANA, Calif. — Jimmie Johnson, the five-time Nascar Sprint Cup champion, tossed and turned last Sunday night. His wakefulness didn’t derive from frustration about finishing second earlier that day in the Subway Fresh Fit 500 at Phoenix International Raceway.

headline: Facebook News Feed Draws More Criticism
text: In my column this week, I wrote about how content I shared on Facebook saw a paltry amount of interaction unless I paid Facebook to highlight it on the company’s signature news feed. Other reporters and bloggers said they had seen a similar drop in connection.

headline: A Well-Heeled Candidate Runs Political Season’s First Radio Ad
text: It is a scrappy, somewhat corny political ad (click to listen) featuring a stilted exchange about a New York City mayoral candidate that ends with a woman asking, “How do you pronounce his name again?”

headline: The Bullying Pulpit
text: Next Monday I’m scheduled to be on a panel at the South by Southwest mediafest in Austin, discussing the ways in which our digital culture is changing how our children grow up. My role is apparently to make the more expert members of the panel – Emily Bazelon of Slate, Danah Boyd of Microsoft Research and Jason Rzepka of MTV – look brilliant by comparison. Given Bazelon’s timely new book on bullying, I expect that much of the conversation will explore whether the Internet contributes to a rising tide of meanness.

headline: Jazz Hall of Fame Opens Voting to Fans Online
text: As part of a broader effort to harness the Internet to engage more jazz fans, Jazz at Lincoln Center is inviting the general public to vote online for the 2013 inductees to the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame.

headline: Consumer Groups Urge Scrutiny of Car Title Loans
text: As payday loans come under more scrutiny, consumer advocates are also urging a closer look at a similar type of short-term loan often marketed to the poor: car title loans.

headline: Private Equity and Venture Capital Investments Rise in Latin America
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Private equity and venture capital firms committed $7.9 billion last year to invest in Latin America, a substantial jump of 21 percent over the previous year, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said Tuesday.

headline: From Lot 2 in Brooklyn, Pecorino Fried Bread With Broccoli
text: Is there a restaurant dish that haunts you? Something that makes your mouth water and your stomach growl whenever you start to describe its manifold charms? A dish you’d love to have the recipe for if it were readily available?

headline: First Round of Programming Announced for Tribeca Film Festival
text: New features from Rachel Boynton, Laurie Collyer and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason are among the 46 works announced on Tuesday for the 2013 Tribeca Film Festival, which unveiled its selections for the competitive world narrative and documentary categories, as well as its noncompetitive Viewpoints series.

headline: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Disavowal of Drone Strikes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military on Tuesday denied suggestions by American officials quoted in an article in The New York Times that Pakistan had used the C.I.A. drone program as cover for its own military operations in the tribal belt.

headline: Telling Secrets
text: After a long delay, the White House has agreed to send the Senate and House intelligence committees all 11 secret legal memos that it has relied on to kill suspected terrorists, including American citizens, in other countries without judicial oversight.

headline: Victory Gardens Theater to Shrink Its 2013-14 Season
text: Facing years of budget deficits, uneven ticket sales and other financial challenges, the leaders of Victory Gardens Theater of Chicago announced on Monday that they will produce only three shows during the 2013-14 season – instead of the usual five – while trying to generate more revenue by renting out the space to several of the city’s renowned storefront theaters.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Talley’s Folly’
text: Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson in the Roundabout Theater’s revival of the Lanford Wilson play.

headline: Planes, Trains and Automobiles: 8 Tips for Keeping Adult Children Close
text: After each of our children was born, the “other biological clock” we faced as new parents was that there are only 940 Saturdays between a child’s birth and her leaving for college. Although many days raising our young children  felt like they would never end, the years flew by fast, and suddenly our precious newborn was saying goodbye to us in her new dorm room. Now what? What happens after kids graduate from high school and leave home for young adulthood? How can a close family stay close?

headline: Gaza Marathon Canceled After Women Are Barred From Participating
text: GAZA — Gaza’s third marathon run, an annual fund-raising event planned for April 10, was canceled after the Palestinian territory’s Islamic leaders barred women from participating, the organizer, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said on Tuesday.

headline: Jon Stewart to Direct Serious Film, Will Take Hiatus From ‘Daily Show’
text: LOS ANGELES — Jon Stewart, serious film director?

headline: Southern Cal Interviews Floyd
text: When Pat Haden was hired as Southern California’s athletic director in 2010, the emphasis was on cleaning up the place. His ousted predecessor, Mike Garrett, had presided over N.C.A.A. scandals in both the football and basketball programs that brought stiff sanctions to the school.

headline: Mark Cuban May Face S.E.C. Insider Trading Trial
text: With the Dallas Mavericks having a subpar season, it is unlikely that the basketball team’s charismatic owner, Mark Cuban, will find himself courtside during the N.B.A. finals in June.

headline: Living Along Central Park West
text: Tony residential buildings look out onto an oasis of green along one of New York City’s grandest stretches.

headline: Eye Candy, Structural and Natural
text: Architectural grandeur lines one side, 1.32 square miles of natural splendor the other; in these you have the virtues that validate Central Park West’s pride of place among city attractions. It certainly isn’t the shopping — there is no sidewalk-level retail on the entire 51-block stretch, beyond a dry cleaner, a tax preparer and a deli (unless you count doctors’ offices).

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Dismissing Science
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sports Illustrated Lands New Armstrong Interview
text: 4:17 p.m. | Updated Lance Armstrong thought about bypassing the media and making a confessional video for the Web that would have detailed his substance abuse and included an apology to his fans. But instead he sat down with Oprah Winfrey, and he doesn’t regret the choice, Mr. Armstrong told a writer for Sports Illustrated in a column that was published online on Tuesday.

headline: Guest Lesson | Espionage Everywhere: Spying in the News and Popular Culture
text: When the International Spy Museum approached us about doing a guest lesson, we were immediately intrigued, especially when they pointed out how much of the news The Times reports every day is based on intelligence gathering.

headline: Former Wells Fargo Broker Is Sentenced to 2 Years
text: A federal judge in California has sentenced Philip Horn, a former Wells Fargo broker who pleaded guilty to defrauding more than a dozen clients, to two years in jail.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Backs Mideast Efforts to Arm Syrian Rebels
text: DOHA, Qatar — Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday that the Obama administration supported efforts by Middle Eastern nations to send arms to the opposition in Syria, and had had discussions with foreign officials to emphasize that those arms should go to moderate forces rather than to extremists.

headline: Moldova’s Pro-Western Government Falls
text: MOSCOW — The pro-Western government of Moldova fell on Tuesday when Parliament passed a no-confidence motion, shattering a fragile political alliance that had put the former Soviet republic on a path toward integration with the European Union.

headline: Manhattan Theater Club to Stage Play by Amanda Peet
text: The actress Amanda Peet will get her first professional credit as a playwright next season when Manhattan Theater Club stages “The Commons of Pensacola,” her work about a family grappling with the fallout from the financial crisis.

headline: Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque
text: Inside the East Village barbecue restaurant that serves Flintstonian beef ribs.

headline: BrisketTown and Fletcher’s Brooklyn Barbecue
text: Inside two of Brooklyn’s new barbecue restaurants.

headline: Concerns About Politics Overshadow an Auto Show
text: GENEVA — Such is the state of the European car industry that one of the main topics at the Geneva auto show on Tuesday was the political situation in Italy. While automakers continued to show new models with extravagant events, almost everything is overshadowed by the economic crisis in Europe and the risk that political turmoil in Italy will undermine any recovery.

headline: Officer Won’t Testify, Ending Defense Side in Cannibal Case
text: Lawyers for Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women, rested their case on Tuesday, shortly after the officer said he would not take the witness stand in his own defense.

headline: Big League BBQ Arrives
text: Chase the scent of great barbecue in New York City, and you are rooting for a team that will, sooner or later, let you down. You are a Red Sox fan in any season from 1919 to 2003. There will be enough victories to keep the dream flickering, and there will be nights when you watch the ball hop between the first baseman’s legs.

headline: Charges Against Florida A&M Band Members Are Changed to Manslaughter
text: The charges against 12 former band members at Florida A&M have been upgraded to manslaughter in the beating death of drum major Robert Champion in 2011, Florida prosecutors informed the accused on Monday.

headline: Chávez Dies, Leaving Sharp Divisions in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela died Tuesday afternoon after a struggle with cancer, the government announced, leaving behind a bitterly divided nation in the grip of a political crisis that grew more acute as he languished for weeks, silent and out of sight, in hospitals in Havana and Caracas.

headline: Lip-Smackin’ Sips to Wash the Barbecue Down
text: Any discussion of barbecue is likely to become an argument. Why should a discussion of what to drink with it be different?

headline: The Tsunami Killed Her Family. She Tells of What Came Next.
text: “This is the saddest story I have ever heard.” So goes the first sentence of Ford Madox Ford’s 1915 masterpiece, “The Good Soldier.”

headline: Photo Replay: March 5
text: A look at the day in sports from the Paris-Nice cycling race to baseball spring training camp games.

headline: Hermès: Fall 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Video Games May Aid Children With Dyslexia
text: Playing action video games may improve reading in children with dyslexia, Italian researchers have found.

headline: Teen Angst Leavened by Goofiness
text: First, let’s change the title to “B.F.F.’s in the Forest of Arden.”

headline: Take Part in Our Recipe Lab Video Chat
text: Today we posted our first installment of Recipe Lab, a monthly feature by Julia Moskin in which you, our readers, will play a central role. On March 14 at 3:30 p.m. Eastern, the cookbook author Nigella Lawson will join Ms. Moskin for a live video conversation, via Google+ Hangout, about cooking, her new book, “Nigellissima,” and her recipe for whole wheat pasta with brussels sprouts, cheese and potato.

headline: Making Pasta With Nigella Lawson
text: It takes just two good recipes for a new cookbook to earn a place on my shelf. But which recipes to try first? In Recipe Lab, a new monthly online feature, I make the book’s author choose its essential recipes for us. I’ll select one for you, our readers, to make at home. As you cook — or even if you don’t — you’ll be able to post comments and questions for the author here on Diner’s Journal. The author will then join me, and three of you, in a live video chat that everyone can watch.

headline: Composer Can’t Complain About the Piano Player
text: It is hard for concertgoers today to imagine what it must have been like in the early decades of the 20th century, when towering composers who were also extraordinary pianists, like Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev and Bartok, performed their own works. We have some invaluable recordings, of course. But hearing these composers playing their music when it was new must have been overwhelming.

headline: Martha Stewart Back in Court in Contract Dispute
text: It was a familiar scene for Martha Stewart’s day in court: photographers camped at the back and front entrances of a Manhattan courthouse, members of the news media lining up for seats, spectators buzzing about what she might say.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner Terminal 4, Kennedy Airport

headline: White House Tours Halted Over Cuts; Congress Says, ‘We’re Open’
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration told members of Congress on Tuesday that it was canceling all White House tours beginning on Saturday because of the $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts that went into effect last week.

headline: Kissinger Briefly Hospitalized After Fall
text: Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, was admitted to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital on Tuesday after a fall at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. Mr. Kissinger, 89, was released Tuesday afternoon, the hospital said. No details were released about his injuries.

headline: Surveys Quantify Loss of Elephants in Africa
text: Sixty percent of the forest elephants in Africa were killed from 2002 to 2011, scientists reported on Monday, putting a number to the rampant slaughter of both forest and savannah elephants for their ivory.

headline: A Two-Man Team’s Songs, Too Big for Just Those Two
text: In his Broadway score for “Next to Normal” the composer Tom Kitt did more than anyone since Jonathan Larson in “Rent” to advance the inevitable integration of rock sound, rhythm and attitude into the Broadway musical. That’s a tricky challenge, since the louder music becomes, and the more obtrusive its beats, the more that intelligibility and melodic subtlety tend to fall by the wayside.

headline: Who Really Hates Anne Hathaway?
text: To the surprise of absolutely no one with a Twitter feed, a new Pew study finds that tweeted reaction “to major political events and policy decisions often differs a great deal from public opinion as measured by surveys,” and reports that more than partisanship, it’s “the overall negativity” of Twitter reactions that really stand out. I could write a thumbsucking post about how this phenomenon probably influences our politics for the worse, by encouraging journalists — most of whom (myself included) now watch crucial moments of political theater with their fellow scribes’ snark scrolling in the background — to let their natural solipsism and their natural cynicism intertwine, and pretend that what they see on Twitter is the political world entire. But I think I can get at the same idea by talking about Anne Hathaway instead.

headline: Hugo Chávez, 1954-2013
text: Simon Romero, The Times’s former Caracas bureau chief, reflects on the presidency of Hugo Chávez.

headline: It’s Still Winter, Unless You’re a Fall TV Pilot
text: The terror gripping broadcast television as viewers continue to run away — 8.6 million to “Duck Dynasty,” 13.1 million to “The Bible,” who knows how many to “House of Cards” — has meant boom times for TV’s most ephemeral product: the network pilot.

headline: Flash of Red Leaves United Speechless
text: MANCHESTER, England — Cristiano Ronaldo nudged the ball over the goal line from a sharp angle, then slid past the post and behind the net. As the small Real Madrid section of fans at Old Trafford roared, Ronaldo, who twirled his magic for Manchester United for six seasons before departing for Spain, held up his hands and asked for restraint.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, West Bank, Kenya and Italy.

headline: U.S. Relaxes Air Travel Carry-On Prohibitions
text: The Transportation Security Administration said on Tuesday that it would allow airplane passengers to bring pocketknives, golf clubs and other sports items aboard in carry-on bags, loosening some of the restrictions created after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Kickstarter Undressed and Evernote’s Ambition
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 5
text: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: The Payoff in Delaying Retirement
text: It’s remarkably difficult to find an economist who thinks the spending cuts ripping through the budget since last Friday amount to a good idea.

headline: A Polarizing Figure Who Led a Movement
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Hugo Chávez, who died on Tuesday at 58, rose from poverty in a dirt-floor adobe house to unrivaled influence in Venezuela as its president, consolidating power and wielding the country’s oil reserves as a tool for his Socialist-inspired change.

headline: Former SAC Trader Gets More Time to Prepare Defense
text: A federal judge on Monday granted a former employee of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors additional time to review the government’s evidence in an insider trading case brought against him.

headline: Jeb Bush Enters Debate, and Possibly 2016 Race
text: WASHINGTON — As political re-entries go, Jeb Bush’s has been rocky.

headline: 10 Memorable Hugo Chávez Moments
text: Mr. Chávez was known for his grand overtures and bold attacks. An exceptionally gifted orator who relished media attention, he continually came up with show-stealing lines.

headline: Obama Recruits Republicans for Budget Talks With Personal Calls
text: For most of his presidency, Barack Obama has viewed outreach to Congress as a chore rarely to be touched, and rank-and-file Republicans largely a contact point of last resort.

headline: The Daily Do | Valentino
text: The Valentino girl, sweet and feminine this season in lace baby doll dresses and T-strap shoes, flaunted hair parted down the middle, braided to the side and topped with a satin ribbon. The look evoked schoolgirl charm with a woman’s sophistication.

headline: Where You Go to Get Away
text: A gallery of readers’ local escapes.

headline: Paris Lands in Brooklyn, for a Day
text: Just outside the Cantor Auditorium at the Brooklyn Museum, curators have hung Henri Fantin-Latour’s “Portrait of Madame Léon Maître.” The painting’s subject seems both quietly pleased and a little disengaged.

headline: Venezuela Without Chávez
text: A senior fellow for the Council on Foreign Relations discusses a country left in flux after the death of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: A Sports Complex Shows Its Brains and Brawn
text: Columbia University, busily expanding into Harlem, has meanwhile opened the Campbell Sports Center, a $30 million athletic building in Inwood, the neighborhood at the northern tip of Manhattan.

headline: Model Diary | Esther Heesch
text: Esther Heesch, 16 years old and from the city of Lübeck in northern Germany, was scouted just over a year ago on the streets of Hamburg. The young newbie rocked the runway today in sophisticated Valentino, edgy Chanel and showstopping Alexander McQueen.

headline: D’Angelo and Ahmir Questlove Thompson at Brooklyn Bowl
text: D’Angelo and Ahmir Questlove Thompson played to a sold-out crowd on Monday night.

headline: Resonant Oldies With a Tongue-in-Cheek Subtext
text: The long tease continues.

headline: Missing German Reporter Released by Syrian Government
text: The Syrian government released a German journalist who went missing more than two months ago on Tuesday, saying the man had entered the country illegally but would be turned over to the Russian ambassador and sent home.

headline: A Lyrical Tour Through Europe Starts on the West Coast
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is living a jet-setter’s life: On two consecutive Fridays two of his works had their world premieres on prestigious stages more than 5,000 miles apart. On Feb. 24 at the Royal Opera House in London, he joined eight Royal Ballet dancers onstage after the first performance of his “24 Preludes.” On Friday, at the War Memorial Opera House here, he similarly joined the 12 San Francisco Ballet dancers who had just delivered the premiere of his “From Foreign Lands.”

headline: A Work in Progress, From the Inside Out
text: An alternate title for “Gut Renovation,” Su Friedrich’s cranky, sarcastic documentary polemic about the gentrification of a Brooklyn neighborhood, might be “The Rape of Williamsburg.” Ms. Friedrich, an independent filmmaker, moved there in 1989 when it was an artists’ haven and a multiethnic, working-class neighborhood with a vibrant street life. After the City Council passed a rezoning ordinance in 2005, an area 6 blocks wide and 17 blocks long became the site of a frantic real estate boom.

headline: Americans on Terror Threats
text: Results from a New York Times/CBS News poll in which a growing number of Roman Catholics in the United States say that the Vatican and bishops are out of touch.

headline: U.S. Catholics in Poll See a Church Out of Touch
text: Roman Catholics in the United States say that their church and bishops are out of touch, and that the next pope should lead the church in a more modern direction on issues like birth control and ordaining women and married men as priests, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: In Herbalife ‘Short War,’ Hedge Funds Miss the Target
text: A star-studded battle among hedge fund titans over the nutritional supplements company Herbalife became the talk of Wall Street when it erupted. But when the barbs eventually fall silent and the klieg lights dim, how will the Herbalife war end? And what truth will emerge?

headline: U.S. Catholics Welcome a Papal Change
text: In a New York Times/CBS poll, the majority of Catholics said Pope Benedict XVI made the right decision to step down and hope for a more liberally focused leadership.

headline: Police Wait After Pledge to Surrender in Fatal Crash
text: The man suspected of fleeing the scene of a devastating car crash that claimed the lives of a young Brooklyn couple and their prematurely born son was still being sought by the police on Tuesday evening, as his stated intention to turn himself in went unfulfilled.

headline: Each Facebook Post Seen by One-Third of Friends, on Average
text: It’s hard to know who saw that picture you posted on Facebook of your Friday night escapade or that screed you wrote about how so-and-so looked during the Oscars.

headline: Regis Philbin Returns, This Time on Fox’s Answer to ESPN
text: Regis Philbin sat beside Michael Strahan on Tuesday in a Manhattan hotel ballroom but it was not a gathering of Kelly Ripa’s past and present co-hosts of the morning show formerly called “Live! with Regis and Kelly.”

headline: Custom Colors for a School, New Opportunities for Students
text: John Flores was the one who spotted the spot. “Somebody painted red on the blue door,” he said.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Lunchroom Called Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — All American cities have their lunch spots where deals are sealed and careers are upgraded over Cobb salads and tuna rolls. On Capitol Hill, the powerful eat in.

headline: Chanel Demands a Closer Look
text: PARIS

headline: Federal Budget Cuts Will Hit J.F.K. Passengers, Homeland Security Secretary Warns
text: With the federal Department of Homeland Security facing a 5 percent budget cut in the budget battle, passengers at Kennedy International Airport might have to schedule extra hours for travel, the homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, said on Tuesday.

headline: Attendance and Revenue Fall at Citi Field
text: Consistent fourth-place finishes by the Mets are not helping finances at Citi Field.

headline: Deadly Bacteria That Resist Strongest Drugs Are Spreading
text: Deadly infections with bacteria that resist even the strongest antibiotics are on the rise in hospitals in the United States, and there is only a “limited window of opportunity” to halt their spread, health officials warned Tuesday.

headline: General Says 20,000 Troops Should Stay in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The American commander in the Middle East said on Tuesday that he had recommended that 13,600 United States troops remain in Afghanistan after the combat mission ends in 2014, a number slightly higher than the one being considered by NATO and Pentagon officials.

headline: For Floridian, Murder Trial Beats Self-Defense Hearing
text: MIAMI — George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, is all but certain to take his case directly to a jury on June 10 and skip a highly anticipated pretrial self-defense hearing, his lawyer said Tuesday.

headline: Futures Agency’s Leader Is Expected to Remain
text: Gary Gensler, one of the top regulators of Wall Street, is assuring officials that he plans to remain in the Obama administration through at least December even as he weighs other options, according to three people briefed on the matter.

headline: Geneva Notebook: The Revenge of the Customizers
text: GENEVA — If the Hollywood director Tim Burton designed cars, he would save his most twisted creations for the Geneva motor show. When Geneva rolls around on the international auto salon calendar each March, consider the styling envelope about to be folded, spindled and mutilated. To tell a designer with something on display here that his work is wildly impractical would be to bestow the highest sort of compliment.

headline: Roy Brown Jr., Edsel Designer, Dies at 96
text: Roy Brown Jr., a car designer for Ford Motor whose signature creation, the supposedly futuristic but ultimately ill-fated Edsel, became a synonym for bold, bad ideas not long after it was introduced in 1957, died on Feb. 24 in Michigan. He was 96.

headline: Teixeira Likely to Be Out Two Weeks
text: 11:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: California, on Brink of Recovery, Braces for Setback on Federal Aid
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of ballooning budget deficits, California finally seemed on firmer footing. Unemployment remained high, but revenues and housing prices were up. Taxpayers even voted themselves a tax increase to bring deficits down.

headline: A Tailor Admits Underpaying on His Taxes by the Millions
text: Whether cutting suits or paying taxes, Mohanbhai Ramchandani, of Mohan’s Custom Tailors, displayed a knack for making all sorts of figures fit.

headline: In the End, an Awful Manager
text: IN Caracas, Venezuela, you could tell a summit meeting mattered to Hugo Chávez when government workers touched up the city’s rubble. Before dignitaries arrived, teams with buckets and brushes would paint bright yellow lines along the route from the airport into the capital, trying to compensate for the roads’ dilapidation with flashes of color.

headline: Turkey Renews Focus on Ending Its Long Conflict With Kurds
text: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — When three prominent Kurdish women activists were murdered in Paris in January, analysts worried that the killings would derail the fledgling peace talks, begun late last year. Just the opposite appears to have happened, as both sides have moved forward with more determination to end one of the region’s most intractable conflicts, which has claimed almost 40,000 lives over nearly three decades.

headline: Home Is Where the Harm Is
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Country That Stopped Reading
text: EARLIER this week, I spotted, among the job listings in the newspaper Reforma, an ad from a restaurant in Mexico City looking to hire dishwashers. The requirement: a secondary school diploma.

headline: Coroner Disputes Family’s Account of Mississippi Mayoral Candidate’s Death
text: CLARKSDALE, Miss. — A Mississippi mayoral candidate who was found dead last week was not killed by being beaten, burned or dragged, the coroner said on Tuesday, challenging a statement from the victim’s family that the official said was misleading.

headline: Team M.V.P. (Most Valuable Preserver): Historians Are Fans’ Link to Past
text: BOSTON — On a concourse behind third base at Fenway Park, silent but for the periodic whoosh of the frigid wind, Dan Rea recently approached a display case devoted to the 1930s-era Red Sox. A ledger inside the case was opened to a page where an accountant once entered players’ salaries.

headline: Condemnation but Some Praise for Chávez From Washington
text: Not long after the death of Hugo Chávez was announced in Venezuela, a variety of major figures in American politics in Washington and beyond released statements offering their reactions. While his death was welcomed by some, others praised the Venezuelan leader for his efforts to help the poor.

headline: Dow Companies See an Uneven Recovery
text: Behind the bull market that drove the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high on Tuesday is a startling gulf in the fortunes of some of the nation’s largest corporations.

headline: Ford Foundation Head Steps Down
text: The president of the Ford Foundation, Luis A. Ubiñas, will leave in September after six years at the nation’s second-largest philanthropic organization. Mr. Ubiñas engineered an overhaul intended to streamline Ford’s operations and led Ford through the worst of the recession. “One of the hardest things for a leader is to know when to step down,” he wrote to the staff.

headline: Confirm Caitlin Halligan for the Federal Bench
text: The Senate is scheduled to vote Wednesday on the long-stalled nomination of Caitlin Halligan for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. This will show whether there are Republicans who care enough about the proper functioning of the federal courts to help defeat their party’s filibuster attempt.

headline: Extreme Grief
text: One year later, even on film, the words are as chilling as they were that fateful day on the snow-covered mountain.

headline: 2 Conflicting Legislative Agendas Arise From Gun Safety Task Force in Connecticut
text: HARTFORD — A week past their original goal for passing gun legislation, Democratic and Republican members of a legislative task force on Tuesday released competing gun-safety agendas in response to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Another Round of Sanctions on North Korea
text: China’s decision to join the United States in proposing tougher sanctions on North Korea is a welcome step. The new resolution, introduced at the United Nations on Tuesday, would seek to curtail North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs by making it more difficult for that country to move money around the world and explicitly banning the sale of items coveted by its elite, like yachts. It would also increase scrutiny of North Korea’s diplomats.

headline: Missouri: Jail After Years of Hiding
text: A British man who spent nearly two decades hiding in the United States after driving off with an armored van with $1.5 million in England was sentenced Tuesday in London to five years in jail. Edward J. Maher was a guard for a security company in 1993 when he took off with the van as a colleague was making a delivery. He was arrested in Ozark, Mo., in 2012 on a tip from his estranged daughter-in-law. In the United States, Mr. Maher often used a brother’s name or the alias Stephen King.

headline: Free Speech on the Street Corner
text: They trim trees, mow lawns, care for the elderly, clean up and rebuild after hurricanes and floods — and they defend the Constitution, too. Immigrant day laborers, who are so often the targets of local laws meant to sweep them off street corners, keep battling in court to defend their right to seek work, and they keep winning.

headline: Obama Visits Wounded as Afghanistan Casualties Continue
text: President Obama is winding down the war in Afghanistan, but the casualties continue. So on Tuesday afternoon, he made the first trip of his second term, and the 12th of his presidency, to visit wounded service men and women at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

headline: ‘Shoot One, Please’
text: Last October, New York State for the first time held a three-day season for 14- and 15-year-olds to use guns to hunt deer. The State Department of Environmental Conservation had proposed the Youth Firearms Deer Hunt as a way to engage more young people in nature and outdoor recreation and to protect against deer overpopulation. The number of hunting licenses sold in New York has fallen by about one-quarter since peaking in the 1980s, the department said.

headline: Shoot One, Please
text: This short documentary follows a 15-year-old from Stamford, N.Y., in the Catskills, as he hunts his first deer with his father.

headline: Yahoo Says New Policy Is Meant to Raise Morale
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When Marissa Mayer took over as chief executive at Yahoo last summer, she confronted a Silicon Valley campus that was very different from the one she had left at Google.

headline: Two Enlistees in the Climate Wars
text: In 2009, President Obama pledged to reduce America’s greenhouse gas emissions by 17 percent from 2005 levels by 2020. Thanks to several factors, the country is halfway there. On Monday, Mr. Obama announced the appointment of two seasoned officials who could fulfill that pledge — but only if the president himself helps them navigate the formidable political obstacles ahead.

headline: Hazing Arrests Prompt a Debate Over Student Conduct at Bronx Science
text: For a school with “science” in its name, whose graduates have won more than a dozen Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes, a string of successes in another arena showed the Bronx High School of Science to be more than a collection of academic geeks.

headline: Venezuela After the Death of Chávez
text: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, talks with Shannon O’Neil of the Council of Foreign Relations about the ramifications of Hugo Chávez’s death on Venezuela, Latin America and the world.

headline: Arkansas: Abortion Law Survives Veto
text: The State Senate voted 20 to 14 Tuesday to override Gov. Mike Beebe’s veto of a bill that would establish the country’s most stringent limits on abortion, banning the procedure after 12 weeks of pregnancy. The governor and most legal experts said the measure would quickly be struck down by federal courts as unconstitutional. The Supreme Court has ruled that women have a right to an abortion up to when the fetus is viable outside the womb, generally around 24 weeks into pregnancy. The motion to override now passes to the House, where a vote is expected to be close.

headline: A Courtship Ritual Performed Early
text: THE calendar says early March, but efforts by major media companies to attract advertising dollars, once reserved for the spring, are already in full swing.

headline: The Dow’s Movers
text: Change in each company’s stock price since the Dow’s previous high on Oct. 9, 2007.

headline: Trying to Revive Talks, Obama Goes Around G.O.P. Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — With Republican leaders in Congress forswearing budget negotiations over new revenues, President Obama has begun reaching around them to Republican lawmakers with a history of willingness to cut bipartisan deals.

headline: Dominican Judge Calls for Menendez to Appear at a Court Hearing
text: A judge in the Dominican Republic called on Tuesday for Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey to appear in court in a legal battle as charges and countercharges flew over the veracity of allegations that the senator had patronized prostitutes in that country.

headline: Of Flies and Philosophers: Wittgenstein and Philosophy
text: “To show the fly the way out of the fly bottle ”— that, Wittgenstein once said, was the aim of his philosophy. While it is perhaps unclear whether anyone — philosopher or fly — should be flattered by this comparison, his overall point is clear enough, as Paul Horwich notes in his recent piece, “Was Wittgenstein Right?” When we get curious about philosophical problems we are drawn into puzzles by the promise of sweet enlightenment, only to find ourselves caught in frustration (and banging our heads against the same wall over and over again). What we need, Wittgenstein thinks, is liberation — liberation from the prison of pseudo-problems we have brought upon ourselves; liberation from traditional philosophy.

headline: As Tourist, Hughes Got an Earful of England
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Phil Hughes has never sat in the bleachers at Yankee Stadium, but having warmed up in the bullpen below, he has a good sense of the raucous atmosphere there during some games.

headline: Police Unsure of Klan Garb at Troubled College
text: The police in Oberlin, Ohio, have been unable to confirm a report of a person wearing a white robe and hood that caused Oberlin College to cancel classes on Monday and plunged the campus in to a day of soul-searching.

headline: Walking the Line Between Offputting and Illegal
text: What’s the difference between protected speech (like online fantasies) and threats that warrant legal action?

headline: The Knicks Are Still Struggling to Get Their Stars to Align
text: For 22 minutes Monday night, Amar’e Stoudemire was a man without limitations. He sprinted. He leapt. He dunked, repeatedly.

headline: Hugo Chávez’s Rise to Power
text: Mr. Chávez rose from poverty to unrivaled influence in Venezuela as its president, consolidating power and wielding the country’s oil reserves as a tool for his Socialist-inspired change.

headline: Construction That Focuses on Health of Residents
text: Doctors, social agencies and community groups that have long been frustrated by the inability to alleviate environmental conditions that contribute to ailments like heart disease and obesity are promoting the idea that a shift in land-use planning and design can stanch some of the harmful influences.

headline: Stuart C. Eisenberg
text: Mr. Eisenberg, 50, is a partner and the national director of the real estate practice for the accounting firm BDO USA. The practice provides consulting and advisory services to real estate companies, including REITs, pension funds and other institutions that invest in commercial property.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Mar. 6, 2013
text: “In regimes that are so person-based, the moment that the person on which everything hangs is removed, the entire foundation becomes very weak because there was nothing else supporting this other than this figure.”

headline: Repent, Dick Cheney
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Professors’ Big Stage
text: I just spent the last two days at a great conference convened by M.I.T. and Harvard on “Online Learning and the Future of Residential Education” — a k a “How can colleges charge $50,000 a year if my kid can learn it all free from massive open online courses?”

headline: For Zubaz, Plans Change, Not the Stripes
text: Dan Stock got a phone call last week from a friend who saw a news item about some funky new basketball shorts that Adidas was unveiling for the N.C.A.A. tournament. Stock said his friend advised him to go online and check it out.

headline: Corrections: March 6, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: High Roller’s Pair
text: Administrivial Early Post Alert! The Wednesday, March 6 post for the Thursday, March 7 puzzle will appear a bit early (approximately 9:45 p.m. Eastern) so that we can feed and shampoo the emus at our regularly scheduled time of 10 p.m. This will not affect your ability to discuss the puzzle, but please watch out and don’t slip on any of the soap bubbles.

headline: Fending Off an Antic Suitor Who Came Late to Hope
text: That most seductive of notions, the dream that one enchanted evening can change the course of two lives, takes beguiling dramatic form in “Talley’s Folly,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Lanford Wilson that has been lovingly revived by the Roundabout Theater Company at the Laura Pels Theater. Portraying a pair of mismatched mates trying to find a mutual rhythm for a waltz that at least one is hoping will last forever, Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson infuse this gossamer two-character play with a warm, slightly spiky humanity that breathes vital life into material that might in lesser hands feel creaky or sentimental.

headline: Long Isolated Behind a Freeway, Santa Monica’s Civic Center Rejoins Its City
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In contrast to many other places in the Los Angeles area, this small city along the Pacific Ocean has long been easy for pedestrians to navigate — except when it comes to its Civic Center. City Hall, the courthouse and the Civic Auditorium are isolated from the city’s vibrant and walkable downtown, separated by the Santa Monica Freeway, overly wide streets and a dreary expanse of parking lots.

headline: A City Reunites
text: The Civic Center in Santa Monica, Calif., long separated from the city’s vibrant and walkable downtown by the Santa Monica Freeway, is about to be reunited with the city’s heart through a residential development and parkland.

headline: Fingers Are Pointed After Truck Kills Boy
text: For years, the debate over the safety of New York City’s streets has roiled without pause, from the highest corridors of elected office to the zealous corners of social media, inflamed whenever a pedestrian is fatally struck by a vehicle.

headline: Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Spokesmanship Over, Ex-Obama Aide Now Feels Free ... to Speak
text: WASHINGTON — Last Thursday, the night before he left the White House, Tommy Vietor issued the last of countless carefully worded statements about a foreign-policy flare-up, this one deploring an inflammatory remark about Zionism made by Turkey’s prime minister.

headline: South Africans Seek Meaning in a Shooting
text: JOHANNESBURG — The day before Reeva Steenkamp died, she was getting ready to give a speech on a subject that she had known first hand and that is endemic in South Africa: violence against women.

headline: Investors’ Quandary: Get In Now?
text: So is it too late for investors to join the party?

headline: Canada’s North, Home to Bears, and Once, Camels
text: OTTAWA — Though camels are usually associated with the searing heat of the desert, a group of scientists reported on Tuesday that they had found fossilized remains of a giant camel, with a shoulder height of perhaps nine feet, in Canada’s frigid high Arctic.

headline: On Social Networks, Mourning and Division After Chávez’s Death
text: With expressions of mourning and calls for peace and stability, Venezuelans took to the streets and social networks on Tuesday after the announcement of the death of President Hugo Chávez. Messages came from all over the country and around the world, as supporters and critics of Mr. Chávez grappled with the news and tried to figure out what was next for the deeply divided country.

headline: You May Now Kiss the Computer Screen
text: With a red embroidered veil draped over her dark hair, Punam Chowdhury held her breath last month as her fiancé said the words that would make them husband and wife. After she echoed them, they were married. Guests erupted in applause; the bride and groom traded bashful smiles.

headline: North Carolina to Give Some Immigrants Driver’s Licenses, With a Pink Stripe
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — In a move some are calling a modern-day scarlet letter and others say is the best way to manage changing federal immigration policy, North Carolina this month will begin giving some young immigrants driver’s licenses marked with a bold pink stripe and the words “no lawful status” printed in red.

headline: Venezuelan Expatriates See a Reason to Celebrate
text: DORAL, Fla. — First the car horns blasted the news on street corners here, a town so packed with Venezuelans that it is nicknamed “Doralzuela.” Then came dozens of yellow, blue and red flags, floating in celebration, followed by bursts of singing.

headline: Anger and Kudos as Florida Governor Tacks Left
text: MIAMI — A few days after Gov. Rick Scott of Florida endorsed a Medicaid expansion, a U-turn so sharply executed that it flabbergasted his supporters, the head of a local Tea Party group typed up a “breakup note.”

headline: How The New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 23 to 27 with 1,585 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were conducted in English and Spanish.

headline: Chinese Premier’s Parting Words Include Warning
text: BEIJING — Wen Jiabao, in his final address as China’s prime minister, warned on Tuesday of the growing divisions between rich and poor, the hazards of unchecked environmental degradation and the risks posed by unbalanced economic growth.

headline: Nash and His 2 Goals Power Rangers Over Flyers
text: The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers were tied at 2-2 entering the third period; time for Rick Nash to electrify the Madison Square Garden crowd again with his speed, stickhandling skills and will to score.

headline: Around the World in 80 Days for Cuba’s Most Famous Dissident Blogger
text: WASHINGTON — Yoani Sanchez, Cuba’s most famous dissident blogger, arrived in Brazil looking like a ’60s hippie, her hair falling below her waist, her dark ankle-length skirt floating under a summery flower-child top. It was the first stop on Ms. Sanchez’s 80-day tour of South America, Europe and the United States.

headline: Barefoot Running Can Cause Injuries, Too
text: When Dr. Douglas Brown, a radiologist in Orem, Utah, noticed an uptick recently in the number of barefoot runners he was seeing with heel and foot problems, he wondered if there might be a connection between their unshod training and their sore feet. But he couldn’t find any scientific studies that had examined the issue.

headline: Report Details Mistakes Made by U.S. in Improvement Projects for Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — Before he left his Pentagon post, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta concluded that the inability of the Obama administration to complete an agreement providing for an American military presence in Iraq after 2011 had deprived the United States of important political leverage in Iraq.

headline: News Corp. Has a Tablet for Schools
text: For nearly two years, Joel I. Klein helped Rupert Murdoch and News Corporation weather a phone-hacking scandal at the company’s British tabloids with the promise that he would eventually be able to return to the role the company hired him for: to spearhead News Corporation’s new venture into the public school market. That day has finally come.

headline: Word of the Day | flick
text: flick •\ˈflik\• verb and noun

headline: Financing for Colleges Declines as Costs Rise
text: State and local financing for higher education declined 7 percent in fiscal 2012, to $81.2 billion, according to the annual report of the State Higher Education Executive Officers Association, and per-student support dropped 9 percent from the previous year, to $5,896, in constant dollars, the lowest level in at least 25 years.

headline: Report on Iraq Reconstruction
text: A report by Stuart W. Bowen Jr., the special inspector general for Iraq reconstruction, covers the more than $60 billion in American aid that was used to carry out projects in Iraq.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE RACHEL ZOE PROJECT Ms. Zoe has expanded her empire in Los Angeles and New York to include a line of women’s clothing and accessories, a celebrity-styling department, a digital media team and a blow-dry salon, all on top of mothering her toddler son, Skyler. In this Season 5 premiere, Ms. Zoe (above right, with the actress Jaime King) prepares to unveil her spring collection at New York Fashion Week but is thrown off balance when a gossip columnist writes that her clothing line isn’t selling. In the Season 2 opener of “It’s a Brad, Brad World,” at 10, Brad Goreski, a former assistant to Ms. Zoe, styles looks for Kate Spade’s runway presentation while juggling clients like the actress Minka Kelly. And “Dukes of Melrose,” a new series at 10:30, follows Christos Garkinos and Cameron Silver, the owners of the Decades boutique in Los Angeles, as they raid closets and scour auctions for vintage couture.

headline: Chávez’s Death May Challenge China, a Friend
text: BEIJING — Domestic politics trumps international politics, in China as everywhere. So even though China lost a friend in President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who died in Caracas on Tuesday, the homepage of the Xinhua News Agency online today is mostly filled with news of the National People’s Congress meeting in Beijing, where important appointments will be made, such as naming a new president (certain to be Xi Jinping, barring an extraordinary and unforeseen event.)

headline: News Quiz | March 6, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Russian Police Say Dancer and Two Others Confess to Bolshoi Attack
text: MOSCOW — A dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet and two other men have confessed to carrying out an acid attack in January on the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, a crime that gripped Moscow and left one of Russia’s most revered institutions in turmoil, the police announced on Wednesday.

headline: Vietnam Allows Visit by Amnesty International
text: HONG KONG — The Vietnamese government has opened a dialogue with Amnesty International, allowing the human rights group to meet with crucial dissidents and government officials in the first such contacts since the end of the Vietnam War, Amnesty said Wednesday.

headline: India’s Record on Terror Attacks Holds Lessons for Hyderabad
text: NEW DELHI —A special court in Delhi on Tuesday issued arrest warrants for 10 members of the Indian Mujahideen, a banned terrorist organization, including its founder, Riyaz Bhatkal, in connection with the Feb. 21 Hyderabad blasts.

headline: Number of Syrian Refugees Hits 1 Million, U.N. Says
text: GENEVA — The relentless exodus of Syrians fleeing two years of increasingly violent conflict pushed the number of refugees in neighboring countries past the million mark on Wednesday, the United Nations Refugee Agency said, warning that resources for helping them are dangerously thin.

headline: Seeing Red Over Nani: Was the Referee Right?

headline: Runoff Set in Race for Los Angeles Mayor
text: LOS ANGELES — After finishing first and second in Tuesday’s nonpartisan mayoral primary, City Councilman Eric Garcetti and City Controller Wendy Greuel will face each other in a May 21 runoff to take over a city that faces a $216 million budget gap and rising pension costs that could cripple municipal finances.

headline: Dead But Alive
text: MONTREAL — Hugo Chávez’s death, following a battle with cancer, has left Venezuela teetering on the edge. The relentlessly divisive leader left power in the hand of a dauphin, Nicolás Maduro, who is also wedded to the kind of aggressive rhetoric that was the cornerstone of his mentor’s government.

headline: South Korea Pushes Back on North’s Threats
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean military warned on Wednesday that if it was provoked by North Korea, it would strike the North’s “command leadership,” escalating a war of words and hinting at an attack on a North Korean headquarters.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 6
text: NEWS President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela died Tuesday afternoon after a struggle with cancer, the government announced, leaving behind a bitterly divided nation in the grip of a political crisis that grew more acute as he languished for weeks, silent and out of sight, in hospitals in Havana and Caracas. William Neuman reports from Caracas.

headline: Of Cockroaches and Commissioners
text: Kevin O’Rourke points me to the FT’s Brussels blog, which passes on the news that various officials at the European Commission are issuing outraged tweets against yours truly. You see, I’ve been mean to Olli Rehn.

headline: Oh, Canada?
text: After a summer on the road, Naomi Harris pulled into her parents’ driveway in Toronto in September 2011 and photographed her odometer. She had driven just over 22,000 miles — more than four times the distance across Canada. Ms. Harris, a self-described “professional hobo,” had traveled the country in a car she bought on eBay, taking portraits of people she met along the way. Having lived in the United States for many years, she was seeking to capture her beloved homeland, asking herself an all-too-common question:

headline: What’s the Most Impressive Sports Moment You’ve Seen?
text: A leaping catch in the back of the end zone. A bottom-of-the-ninth, come-from-behind grand slam. A perfect landing off the balance beam.

headline: Taliban Kill 17 Afghan Soldiers in Once-Quiet Area
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents killed as many as 17 Afghan National Army soldiers in a single episode in northern Badakhshan Province, an area that has been generally quiet and far from insurgent strongholds until recent months, according to accounts from Afghan officials on Wednesday.

text: On March 23, when students and prominent Indians meet at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania for the India Economic Forum, one person will be conspicuous by his absence: Narendra Modi.

headline: House G.O.P. Plans a Budget That Retains Tax Increases and Medicare Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans will preserve Medicare cuts that their presidential nominee loudly denounced last year and accept tax increases they sternly opposed just months ago in a new tax-and-spending blueprint that would bring the federal budget into balance by 2023, senior Republicans said Wednesday.

headline: Malaysians Kill 13 Filipino Fighters Amid Fears of Wider Conflict
text: MANILA — An air and ground assault by Malaysian forces killed at least 13 of the nearly 200 militants seeking to reclaim part of Borneo Island for a Filipino sultan, Malaysian police officials said Wednesday.

But in a highly unusual mea culpa, the European Union’s top antitrust regulator said that his department bore some of the responsibility for Microsoft’s failure to respect a settlement that caused the fine.

headline: Are Big Clients Worth the Effort for This Web Start-Up?

Because my days at AbesMarket.com are filled with e-commerce decisions, I appreciate the value of baseline data, and knowing how visitors act on other sites helps me gauge our performance. I hope you, too, can benefit from these ideas and statistics.

headline: Nora Ephron’s Final Act
text: At 10 p.m. on a Friday night in a private room on the 14th Floor of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital on 68th and York Avenue, my mother was lying in her bed hallucinating, in that dream space people go on their way to being gone.

headline: Denon’s New Receiver: Saving Time on Setup?

headline: Drum Roll for a Summer Festival of the New
text: MANCHESTER, England—Kenneth Branagh was there with the director Rob Ashcroft. The actress Maxine Peake was there. Josie Rourke, the artistic director of London’s Donmar Warehouse, was there. The occasion? The announcement of this year’s Manchester International Festival program by its director, Alex Poots.

headline: Cautious Mood as Stocks Rise
text: The nominal high that the Dow Jones industrial average reached on Tuesday prompted few cheers on Wall Street, in contrast to the recoveries of years past. Even as the gain capped nearly five and a half years of progress since the depths of the financial crisis, there were questions about whether the forces that fueled the rally — in large part, the Federal Reserve’s stimulus and strong corporate profits — would be enough to keep it going, Peter Eavis writes in The New York Times. James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, cautioned that “prudent investors would be well served to tread carefully and look for improving economic evidence to support any moves to higher levels.”
