headline: Microsoft Faces Fine in Europe After Breaking a Deal
text: It would be the first time that regulators in the European Union have punished a company for failing to follow through on an antitrust settlement, James Kanter writes in The New York Times.

headline: London Theater Journal: Follow the Money
text: LONDON — It felt like a good day to go to a funeral for the financial system that rules the Western world. My reading on the subway had been the Evening Standard (now a giveaway), which featured a lead story with blaring headlines about bankers’ bonuses and money laundering. (The next day I would awaken to a grim front-page essay in the Guardian on the same subject with the no-win headline “Too big to fail – and too big to manage.”)

headline: The Singer Who Fell to Earth
text: On “The Stars (Are Out Tonight),” the new single from David Bowie’s comeback album, “The Next Day,” one line jumps out: “We will never be rid of these stars.” In the video Mr. Bowie and the actress Tilda Swinton play an elderly couple persecuted by a pair of vampiric stars, who stalk them, invade their house and manipulate them like marionettes. But the song itself is less literal. It portrays celebrities as members of an overlord class who “burn you with their radiant smiles” but also as faintly pitiable creatures, jealous of the quiet, grounded lives of ordinary folk. “But I hope they live forever,” Mr. Bowie sings, a nod to the notion of fame as immortality, a compensation for all the damage and delusion that comes with the territory.

headline: Opinion Report: Caitlin Halligan
text: From the editorial page

headline: Secrecy Vow and Leaks Complicate Interaction of Cardinals and News Media
text: VATICAN CITY — Journalists from around the world packed the daily briefings, relishing the rare opportunity to pose questions to the cardinals who will vote in the conclave to elect the next pope. The sessions, led by American cardinals, were a far cry from the elliptical approach favored by the Vatican.

headline: Bangalore Drivers Plead Cases in ‘Court of Instant Traffic Justice’
text: When a motorcycle rider rammed his car from behind in peak Bangalore traffic some weeks ago, Nagaraju Mariankiah, a 37-year-old cab driver, responded as he usually did when he got into an accident. He immediately stopped the car on the busy street and got out to inspect the damage.

headline: What the Mullahs Are Mulling
text: ISTANBUL — Midday in Istanbul’s historical Beyazit district and the air suddenly fills with the call to prayer from the many royal mosques nearby. It is a reminder that a part of the city that now bustles with shoppers, university students and tourists was once the heart of a great Islamic empire.

headline: Mama Whales on the Run
text: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and is studying trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters.

headline: If You Like the Animals, Try the Rubens
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Crowdfunding Clean Energy
text: If you wanted to get large numbers of people actively engaged in helping to solve global warming, how might you go about it? For years, the main approach in the environmental movement has been to sound the alarm bell and implore people to consume less, switch to green products, recycle, and speak up to companies and politicians. It hasn’t always been an easy sell. However, if the approach of a promising Oakland-based start-up takes hold, there may be another line of action that could become available to ordinary people: directly financing renewable energy.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: News Corp. Wants a Place in School, and Upfronts Are Not Just for Spring Anymore
text: Joel I. Klein, the former chancellor of New York City’s schools, will introduce News Corporation’s Amplify, the company’s fledgling education division coupled with a new tablet of the same name, at the SXSWedu conference in Austin, Tex., on Wednesday, Amy Chozick reports. The tablet, a 10-inch Android made by Asus, will run Amplify’s curriculum and provide storage for students’ data. It couples a touch screen with education-specific features, like an “eyes on teacher” warning when attention wanders and quizzes that use sad and smiley emoticons so teachers can ascertain whether students grasp new material. It will also have education-based games for students when they’re not in class, including one in which Tom Sawyer battles the Brontë sisters.

headline: Chávez Transformed the Way Venezuelans View Themselves
text: LA GUAIRA, Venezuela — Ever since her home was washed away in the devastating mudslides that killed thousands along Venezuela’s coast in 1999, during President Hugo Chávez’s first year in office, Graciela Pineda waited for him to carry out his vow to rebuild.

headline: Paul Capital Takes Stake in Brazilian Venture Fund
text: RIO DE JANEIRO – Paul Capital, a private equity firm focused on secondary market transactions, has acquired 18.2 percent of a fund managed by the Brazilian technology venture capital firm Ideiasnet, paying 79 million reais ($40 million).

headline: Bye-Bye, Bumbo and Boppy (With Reservations)
text: It seems like an instant ago, that sweltering summer I spent scouring Craigslist and tag sales, possessed by a frenzied, pre-baby urge to nest. I scooped up gently used Ergos and Bjorns — words that were foreign to a first-time mother’s tongue but promised parental salvation. Eventually, all the essential gear was acquired, along with a few items that in hindsight (yes, that would be you, wipes warmer) were anything but.

headline: Endangered or Not, but at Least No Longer Waiting

headline: Crowds Throng Caracas Streets to Salute Chávez
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — In a modest brown wood coffin covered in a Venezuelan flag, President Hugo Chávez was carried through the capital, Caracas, on Wednesday morning as crowds thronged the streets, cabinet ministers and top military officials walked alongside his black hearse, while hundreds of soldiers in green fatigues and other supporters followed in the yellow, blue and red caps of the national colors.

headline: Toyota Brings a GT-86 Convertible Concept to Geneva
text: GENEVA – Almost lost in the hype around the introduction of the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible at the Geneva motor show here on Tuesday was the unveiling of another, nearly as significant convertible.

headline: Brave Girls
text: Books about girl power are easy to find in March, National Women’s History Month, though not all of them feel timeless or universal. Two new picture books, both with origins in Israel, tell stories about young girls whose bravery and endurance reap great rewards, in ways that transcend the specific circumstance of a people and place.

headline: Threatened Species Have a Chance for Protection
text: As many species facing extinction have waited for years to be protected by the United States, the Fish and Wildlife Service has pledged to decide the fates of all the backlogged candidates by 2018.

headline: The Gun Report: March 6, 2013
text: Last night, Jon and Rebecca Bond, the founders of Evolve, which I wrote about in Saturday’s column, were on Piers Morgan’s CNN interview show. Their emphasis was about how they hope their new organization will become a bridge that links gun owners and non-gun owners, and how they hope it can help bring about the same kind of cultural change with guns that we have already made with two other dangerous behaviors: smoking and drunk driving. Here is the link to their appearance.

headline: High Speed, Lower Price
text: The French national rail company SNCF is starting an economy high-speed rail service called Ouigo on April 2. It will operate between the Paris suburb Marne-la-Vallée (home to Disneyland Paris) to points south, including Lyon, Marseille and Montpellier. Fares for the single-class, no-frills service (with no food or drink) range from 10 to 85 euros (about $12.50 to $107).

headline: Sam Mendes Says He Won’t Direct Next James Bond Movie
text: With any luck, the next James Bond movie will have a better title than “Skyfall” — yes, “Skyfall” — the 23rd official entry in that long running spy-thriller franchise, which featured an Academy Award-winning title song performed by Adele, the detachable jaw of Javier Bardem and Albert Finney in a supporting role that seemed almost surely designed for Sean Connery.

headline: Former Defense Officials Urge Using Budget Cuts to Shape Military Strategy

headline: Harpers Ferry, Redux
text: A raid into the South was afoot. So reported The New-York Tribune, which sketched out a few details of a plot to surprise Southerners “not with the phantom, but the reality of servile insurrection.” At the behest of a radical white abolitionist, a group of free African-Americans had laid the groundwork for the clandestine incursion by preparing enslaved populations, who waited, ready “to rise in thousands.” After capturing a Southern town, the abolitionist and his colleagues, black and white, planned to establish a base from which to organize and arm a force of escaped slaves. The raid would be the opening salvo in a war on slavery.

headline: With Legal Reserves Low, Bank of America Faces a Big Lawsuit

headline: Ahmadinejad Says Chávez Will Rise Again

headline: For Obama and Senate Republicans, an Opportunity to Dine and Deal
text: As President Obama ratchets up his outreach effort to Congressional Republicans on Wednesday with a dinner date at the Jefferson Hotel, his guests will include some of his fiercest critics in the Senate, some conciliators and some lawmakers who hardly have made a ripple in the public debate over how to tackle the federal debt.

headline: Schools, and Syllabuses, Designed With the Environment in Mind
text: Schools can play an important role in fostering environmental and energy awareness not only through how they teach, but also their physical structures and grounds. I’ve been getting familiar with the remarkable, and growing, range of “green school” designs and initiatives around the country. Here’s an initial survey, spurred in part by invaluable input from Veronique Choa Pittman of the Green Schools Alliance and from my visit last week to the engaging new Green Schools exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington.

headline: City Life Takes a Toll on China’s Children
text: BEIJING — Life in China isn’t cheap any more, despite its reputation as a low-cost center. While many families have prospered from economic liberalization, others struggle to get by. And that includes many considered to be doing fairly well.

headline: Targeted Killing in the U.S.A.
text: The Obama administration finally answered a simple question today: Does the president think he has the power to authorize lethal force, such as a drone strike, against an American citizen, in the United States, without trial.

headline: WGBH to Partner on Children’s Pilot for Amazon
text: One of the biggest suppliers of programming for PBS, WGBH, is the latest to climb aboard Amazon’s television pilot process.

headline: Dyson’s Bladeless Fan: A Little Cooler
text: The Dyson AM05 bladeless fan and heater is much cooler than its predecessor. Its new motor spins 33 percent faster, moving more air, hence: cooler.

headline: As You Travel, Making Money Work for You
text: When the travel blogger Matt Kepnes, a k a Nomadic Matt, set off on a six-and-a-half-year backpacking trip that would take him to a staggering 70 countries, the relative merits of his bank account and credit card were an afterthought, he said. Two years into his journey, he realized he was needlessly racking up bank fees and missing out on free flights, so he sat down and figured out how to manage his personal finances abroad. These tips and others he shares in his new book, “How to Travel the World on $50 a Day: Travel Cheaper, Longer, Smarter.” Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Kepnes on which bank accounts and credit cards help you stick to your budget.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Valentino
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Hotel Review: Gradiva in Istanbul
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Brindillas in Vistalba, Argentina
text: In Argentina, the peso is written with a dollar sign. So when we were presented with the menus at Brindillas, an unassuming but highly touted little restaurant about 20 minutes from downtown Mendoza, and saw a five-course tasting menu for what looked like $135, or seven courses for $175, we felt ambushed but undaunted. But after our meal — which cost about $100 (that’s U.S. dollars) for two, wine included — we were pleasantly surprised, a feeling enhanced by food that had a sophisticated, modernist outlook that went well beyond the borders of Argentina.

headline: Unreported Side Effects of Drugs Are Found Using Internet Search Data, Study Finds
text: Using data drawn from queries entered into Google, Microsoft and Yahoo search engines, scientists at Microsoft, Stanford and Columbia University have for the first time been able to detect evidence of unreported prescription drug side effects before they were found by the Food and Drug Administration’s warning system.

headline: Musical Version of ‘Beaches’ Finds a Home
text: The wind beneath the wings of the musical adaptation of the film “Beaches” has landed the show a home. This week the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., announced that it would produce the show as part of its 2013-14 season. Eric Schaeffer, Signature’s artistic director, will direct the production, which has been talked about for a Broadway run. Casting is still to be announced.

headline: Talking N.C. State and the M.A.A.C. Tournament
text: Thirty years ago, Dereck Whittenburg won a national basketball championship as a player at North Carolina State. More recently he coached at Wagner and Fordham, where he was fired midseason in December 2009.  Whittenburg still lives in the New York area and works for ESPN as a television analyst. Among the games he covers are those played in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

headline: Warner Music Owner Bets on Competing Digital Services
text: Len Blavatnik, the Russian-born billionaire investor who bought the Warner Music Group two years ago, has placed big bets on multiple digital music services as the streaming model grows around the world.

headline: McIlroy Says of Midround Withdrawal, ‘I Should Have Stayed Out There’
text: DORAL, Fla. — The public apology thinly veiled as a news conference opened Wednesday as the moderator turned to Rory McIlroy and said, “Just go straight into the heart of the matter here.” Pause. “How disappointed were you with Manchester United’s score yesterday?”

headline: German Riesling’s Turn in the Spotlight
text: La Paulée de New York, Daniel Johnnes’s adaptation of the Meursault harvest festival, begins this week, signifying the apogee of a remarkable month of wine in the city. La Paulée, a mélange of seminars, discussions and tastings culminating in a grand dinner in which producers and collectors share precious bottles, has been so successful that it has inspired similar events celebrating other wines.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Second Base Preview
text: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Recalling a ‘Writer’s Paper’ as a Name Fades
text: Ghostly vestiges of the gothic Herald Tribune logo still survive on the eastern facade of 230 West 41st Street in Midtown Manhattan, camouflaged by a faded Group Health Insurance emblem, and, more recently, dwarfed by the towering headquarters of The New York Times next door.

headline: Rangers Claim Hamrlik Off Waivers
text: The Rangers claimed the veteran defenseman Roman Hamrlik off waivers from Washington, the team confirmed Wednesday. It was unclear whether the acquisition indicated a long-term injury to defenseman Marc Staal, who was struck in the right eye by a shot in a game Tuesday.

headline: A Government LGBT Site
text: The State Department created a Web portal for LGBT travelers last month that includes advice and links for gay people traveling abroad. In addition to steering travelers to country-specific pages that outline which governments give gay travelers legal protections, and which criminalize same-sex relations, the portal also suggests precautions, like carrying documents verifying custody of any children.

headline: The Small Picture: Grab a Shovel
text: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Time Warner Ends Talks With Meredith and Will Spin Off Time Inc. Into Separate Company
text: 9:14 p.m. | Updated What do you do with a group of celebrated magazines that no one seems to want?

headline: The Sequester App
text: Gail Collins: David, I’ve been pretty calm about all the fiscal-cliff crises, but now I’m really getting ticked off. I hate this sequester thing.

headline: Back in Brooklyn | Karkula
text: The design store Karkula has returned to its Brooklyn roots: its new home in Williamsburg officially opens tomorrow, at 98 South 4th Street, with an exhibition of chandeliers by Michelle James and jewelry by Monica Castiglioni. The store’s owner, the designer John Erik Karkula, co-founded the Brooklyn design object shop Breukelen in 1996 before moving to Manhattan and opening Karkula, where he was an early supporter of emerging talent like Jim Zivic and Lindsey Adelman, first in the meatpacking district, and later in TriBeCa. The new shop, which was designed by Karkula and the Brooklyn-based architect Philipp Mohr, now represents European brands like e15, Bocci and Nanimarquina, as well as its owner’s designs. Karkula maintains that he has always kept a low profile on New York’s design scene. “I thought it was cool to be under the radar,” he said. But that might not be so easy now.

headline: Senators Press Holder on Use of Military Force
text: WASHINGTON — Senators of both parties on Wednesday criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for the secrecy surrounding the Justice Department legal memorandums justifying drone strikes aimed at American citizens, while pushing him to say more about when the Obama administration believes it can use military force on United States soil.

headline: Syrian Rebels in Golan Region Hold U.N. Peacekeeping Team
text: Insurgent fighters from Syria seized a group of United Nations troops on patrol in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel on Wednesday and threatened to treat them as prisoners of war, an abrupt escalation in the Syrian conflict that entangled international peacekeepers for the first time.

headline: Rodriguez, Set to Face Mets, Hopes for Return
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -– When Francisco Rodriguez was traded to Milwaukee midway through the 2011 season, he left the Mets with the label of overpriced failure on his back. He notched 83 saves in 165 appearances over two and a half years, but also suffered through injuries and an ignoble tantrum in which he punched his father-in-law after a blown save.

headline: Software and Side Effects
text: Scientists find that analyzing online queries provides valuable insight into drug interactions.

headline: A Young Woman’s Choice, and Its Consequences
text: Not since that incident at Boston Harbor in 1773 has tea been as central to a dispute as it is in “Katie Roche,” the third Teresa Deevy play to be examined in recent years by the Mint Theater Company, whose mission is to shine new light on neglected works.

headline: With Worries for Its Economic Future, Cuba Bids a Sad Goodbye to a Generous Ally
text: HAVANA — The death of Hugo Chávez sent a ripple of sadness and uncertainty across this island on Wednesday as Cubans mourned the loss of an ideological son and generous ally, and worried about the economic pain that could lie ahead if the new Venezuelan leadership cut off hefty oil subsidies.

headline: ‘Smash’ Ratings Hit a New Low on NBC
text: Can “Smash” stay on the air? The enormously publicized — and enormously expensive — NBC drama crashed to a new ratings low Tuesday night, hitting a level that only a few weeks ago caused another NBC drama, “Do No Harm,” to be yanked off the air.

headline: Stranger Than We Can Imagine: David Toomey Talks About ‘Weird Life’
text: In “Weird Life,” David Toomey writes about the search for life that is not just strange, but in fact, like nothing we’ve discovered. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Toomey discussed the origins of life on Earth, the porous line between science and philosophy, his favorite science fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Anthony Questionable for Game Against Pistons
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. – The Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony remains questionable for tonight’s game against the Detroit Pistons, because of stiffness and soreness in his right knee.

headline: Sallie Mae Lowers Top Loan Rates for Graduate Students
text: Graduate students may now be able to qualify for private student loans at lower interest rates from Sallie Mae, the education finance company announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Nets' Ongoing Identity Crisis
text: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks' shadow. It hasn't exactly worked out that way.

headline: Video: The Nets’ Continuing Identity Crisis
text: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks’ shadow. It hasn’t exactly worked out that way.

headline: Content Lives On, Even if Web Site Doesn’t
text: 11:01 a.m. | Updated Some journalists just can’t stop working.

headline: Familiar Names Join the List for the Tribeca Film Festival
text: New movies from Richard Linklater, Neil Jordan, David Gordon Green, Mira Nair, Neil LaBute and Clark Gregg; and documentaries about Elaine Stritch, Richard Pryor, Gore Vidal and —  from Whoopi Goldberg — Moms Mabley  were among the latest announced for the Tribeca Film Festival by its organizers on Wednesday.

headline: Last Stop Before the Outlet Center
text: Everything you love will eventually become a mall. It will be unearthed, polished, commodified and disseminated. It will be silver-platter-delivered to the next generation in a way that will make your earnest passion and curiosity seem infantile. “Remember when?” you will say, and nobody will.

headline: Subscribing to Office, Now and Forever
text: It must be tough to be on the Microsoft Office team. Year after year, you’re given the same assignment: add new features to Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook. New features that people will pay for, but that won’t turn Microsoft’s cash cow into a bloated, sloshing mess.

headline: Rand Paul Leads Filibuster of Brennan Nomination
text: 4:59 p.m. | Updated Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, began an old-school, speak-until-you-can-speak-no-more filibuster on Wednesday just before noon, and was still going strong hours later.

headline: With Positions to Fill, Employers Wait for Perfection
text: American employers have a variety of job vacancies, piles of cash and countless well-qualified candidates. But despite a slowly improving economy, many companies remain reluctant to actually hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.

headline: The Roots of Dennis Hopper’s Style
text: It’s a peculiar brand of American voodoo, a mix of Pabst Blue Ribbon and white Stetson hats and weather-beaten Levis. And a gas mask. It has a lot to do with being dirty.

headline: Skiing Kashmir’s Snow-Swept Peaks
text: On a frigid night in Gulmarg, a Himalayan outpost deep in Kashmir, a friend and I sipped sweet tea and warmed ourselves next to a wood stove while a local ski guide named Javed stood in front of us, roaring like a bear. “Baah! Baah!” he shouted, his hands outstretched like claws. “I thought it was going to kill us,” Javed said of the Asiatic black bear he had encountered a few days before while skiing in the backcountry.

headline: Where Skiing Is Only Part of the Adventure
text: A journey to rugged Kashmir.

headline: Honey, We Barely Shrunk the Financial System
text: The global financial system isn’t dead. But it might be shrinking.

headline: A Weather Report That’s Colorful, With a Chance of Fun
text: I’ll bet that one of the first apps you downloaded onto a smartphone or tablet was for weather. These apps are more appealing than weather forecasts on television, because they provide interactive weather reports you can hold in your hand.

headline: Suspect in Crash That Killed 3 Turns Himself In
text: The manhunt ended at a roadside minimart.

headline: A Call for a National Strategy on Veterans
text: Stand on the corner of H Street and Vermont Avenue in Washington, D.C., and in every direction you’ll see the ways and means of American government — the White House in front, the Treasury to the left and the huge Office of Management and Budget building down the street and to the right. This vista is both symbolic of — and essential to running — our system of governance “by the people, for the people.”

headline: German Museum Returns Painting to Jewish Estate
text: A German museum has returned a 15th-century Renaissance painting to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced to sell it under duress in 1935.

headline: Groom’s Letter to Parents, Remembered After Fatal Hit and Run
text: Updated, Monday, March 11 | The young groom took some moments on his wedding day to write a letter thanking his parents for never sparing time or money if he needed, say, a tutor or an eye doctor, and for sending him to yeshiva “to learn your values, religious and worldly, until I reached to this current lucky moment.”

headline: Artist Quits Superman Project After Outcry Over Writer’s Marriage Views
text: “Adventures of Superman,” a digital anthology from DC Comics, is scheduled to begin on April 29. But it will not feature the work of Chris Sprouse, an artist who has decided to drop out of the project because of a controversy surrounding the opposition to gay marriage by the novelist Orson Scott Card, one of the writers.

text: Question:

headline: Young Poets Society
text: Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and — most elusive of all — money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.

headline: Bruno Mars, Discounted Online, Tops Album Chart
text: Never doubt the selling power of a deep, well-publicized sale.

headline: Arkansas Adopts a Ban on Abortions After 12 Weeks
text: Arkansas adopted what is by far the country’s most restrictive ban on abortion on Wednesday — at 12 weeks of pregnancy, when a fetal heartbeat can typically be detected by abdominal ultrasound.

headline: New Bruce Norris Play Will Be Part of Steppenwolf Season
text: New plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris (“Clybourne Park”) and Mona Mansour (“Urge for Going”) are among the productions in the 2013-14 season at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theater, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: March 7
text: Carson Street Clothiers, a new men’s store in SoHo; Chloé celebrates 60 years; and the casual wear of 194t makes being comfy look good.

headline: Free Throws and High-Fives: A Routine Within a Routine
text: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

headline: The Benefits of Working in the Office
text: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, inspired much debate and rebuke when she recently abolished Yahoo’s work-at-home policy. In academia, “working from home” is a treasured euphemism for heading home after your morning class to have lunch, read the newspaper and take a nap. I hate to see anything that would endanger this hallowed tradition.

headline: Northwestern’s Road to Success Getting Tougher
text: EVANSTON, Ill.–It can be lonely at the top.

headline: They’re Not Quite ’N Sync
text: Muscles, Mozart and marketing: following the strippers’ dictum from “Gypsy,” “You Gotta Have a Gimmick,” the four stars of “Well-Strung: The Singing String Quartet” present themselves as a buff, gay, pop-classical hybrid of juicy boy band and staid chamber group with a vocal component.

headline: Obstruct and Delay
text: As of 3:30 p.m. Wednesday, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been speaking on the Senate floor for about three-and-a-half hours, self-indulging in an old-school filibuster against John Brennan, President Obama’s choice to run the C.I.A. At 3 p.m., Senator Mike Lee of Utah jumped in to help him, asking Mr. Paul questions so he could keep the floor. Then Ted Cruz of Texas and Jerry Moran of Kansas joined in the tirade. It’s a C-Span spectacle, but make no mistake: this isn’t the real filibuster of Mr. Brennan.

headline: Europe’s Carmakers Look Forward to U.S. Trade Pact
text: GENEVA — As the industry convenes here for the Geneva auto show amid the worst European car market slump in decades, there is at least one ray of hope: the green light President Barack Obama recently gave to negotiations for a U.S.-E.U. free-trade pact.

headline: Sequencing the Stages: Understanding H.I.V. Infection at the Molecular Level
text: The Complicated AIDS Battle: There is some (qualified) good news in the fight against H.I.V. infections around the world. Go to related article »

headline: Why Vodafone Should Head for a Verizon Exit
text: Vodafone should dash for a United States exit if it’s open. Shares of the British telecommunications company soared on Wednesday on hopes that Verizon Communications could buy it out of their $250 billion-plus joint venture. Ending a long standoff while American assets are at high valuations makes sense — as long as Vodafone doesn’t squander the proceeds on a costly makeover.

headline: A Traveling Violation?
text: Call it basketball diplomacy or stunt journalism. But the bromance between former National Basketball Association star Dennis Rodman and Kim Jong-un, the repressive leader of North Korea, was simply bizarre. Mr. Rodman’s less-than-eloquent appearance on ABC’s “This Week” did little to shed light on the North Korean trip. Twitter users, luckily, had more to say.

headline: If a Rabbit Wore a Mini
text: THIS HAS BEEN the season of the fur skirt.

headline: Is Poetry Good For Pigs?
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Vionnet
text: It was all about M.A.C. Silver Dusk Iridescent Powder for extra sheen on the fresh-faced models at Vionnet. The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury dusted some over the T-zone, “taking one brush and literally going straight down” from the bridge of the nose to the cupid’s bow, and then lightly over the lips. The iridescent powder was also used as a highlighter in the corner of the eyes.

headline: On ABC Family, an Episode in Sign Language
text: On Monday night, ABC Family did something that no commercial television outlet in the United States had ever done: it broadcast an entire episode of a show in sign language, with closed captioning turned on by default.

headline: The (Historical) Clothes Make the Reality Show
text: Other fashion-related reality shows tart themselves up with the histrionics of designer competitions or workplace friction, formats that now seem tired. So purists might find “L.A. Frock Stars” to be a refreshing change. In this engaging series, which begins Thursday on the Smithsonian Channel, the clothes really are the main attraction.

headline: Open Houses on Sunday Afternoons Long Ago
text: After the members of the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra strolled onstage at the American Academy of Arts and Letters on Sunday afternoon, they arranged themselves into a formation that mirrored the image projected overhead — an early-18th-century painting by Marco Ricci called “Rehearsal of an Opera.”

headline: Lessons From the Stratosphere, and How to Get There
text: Fifty years after “The Feminine Mystique” identified the depression and stir-craziness of suburban housewives, another rallying cry for women has come along. It was written by Sheryl Sandberg, a mother of two who works outside the home. Ms. Sandberg addresses 21st-century issues that never entered Betty Friedan’s wildest dreams, and she is a walking advertisement for women’s empowerment. As a former vice president of Google who is now chief operating officer of Facebook, she writes about how women can best rise to the top of the corporate world.

headline: At Shooting Site, Giffords Urges Lawmakers to Act on Gun Safety
text: TUCSON – “Fight, fight, fight” were the first words by Gabrielle Giffords during a news conference on Wednesday from the same supermarket parking lot where a gunman opened fire on Jan. 8, 2011, wounding her and 12 others and taking six lives.

headline: Bolshoi Intrigue
text: The Times’s Ellen Barry offers the latest updates from Moscow regarding the acid attack on a ballet company’s artistic director.

headline: Sandberg Takes Her Message to Wall St.
text: Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, is heading to Wall Street with her message about women in the workplace.

headline: Disney Shareholders Endorse Pay of Chief Executive
text: LOS ANGELES – As expected, two shareholder resolutions challenging how the Walt Disney Company is managed were defeated on Wednesday at the entertainment conglomerate’s annual meeting in Phoenix.

headline: French Ministry Posts Online Full File on ‘Dreyfus Affair’
text: PARIS — The entire secret military file that was used to wrongly convict Capt. Alfred Dreyfus of spying for Germany in 1894 has been posted online by the historical department of the French Ministry of Defense.

text: A three-bedroom house built in 1841, in Germantown, N.Y.,; a house on a golf course in Durham, N.C.; and a midcentury ranch house in Oklahoma.

headline: Follow Our Environmental Coverage
text: As we wind down this blog, readers have asked how best to follow The Times’s ongoing coverage of the environment.

headline: The Republican Party’s “Donorism” Problem
text: Politico’s Jonathan Martin has a good piece today about the divide between conservative policy writers and Republican politicians, and the absence (which I’ve touched on recently) of any actual G.O.P. elected officials willing to champion the various reformist ideas that have been floating around right-of-center journals and magazines and blogs recently (and really for years now). I agree with most of the people quoted in the piece — and particularly Bill Kristol and Ramesh Ponnuru, who both bemoan the absence of domestic policy entrepreneurism among the party’s backbenchers. But Martin’s conversation the American Enterprise Institute’s Jim Pethokoukis seemed particularly worth highlighting:

headline: Scene City: A Parisian Ball with Fashion Week MVP’s
text: Carine Roitfeld and Stephen Gan hosted a black-tie ball for CR Fashion Book.

headline: After the Shows, It’s Shangri-La
text: It was half past midnight when Kate Moss landed with a thud right next to my feet.

headline: Republicans Block Judicial Nominee’s Confirmation for a Second Time
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked the confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to become a federal appeals court judge in the District of Columbia, the second time in two years Republicans have filibustered her nomination.

headline: Rehearsals for the Revolution
text: “Neva” may be set in a Russia on the verge of explosion, but the Chilean playwright Guillermo Calderón still calls it “my American play” because “it was born here.” As a graduate student in film at the City University of New York a decade ago he prowled Manhattan’s bookstores, where he found Janet Malcolm’s “Reading Chekhov,” which stimulated an interest in Russian culture and politics that led him to “A People’s Tragedy: The Russian Revolution 1891-1924” by Orlando Figes.

headline: House Tells Postal Service to Keep Six-Day Delivery
text: WASHINGTON - A spending measure passed by the House on Wednesday to keep the government operating through September requires that the Postal Service maintain a six-day mail delivery schedule, a potential setback for the agency, which announced last month that it planned go to five-day deliveries to cut costs.

headline: Ford Recalling 196,500 Minivans for Corrosion Problem
text: 4:44 p.m., March 7 | Updated Ford is recalling about 196,500 of its 2004-7 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans to fix a corrosion problem that prevents the fold-down third-row seats from locking safely into place, Kelli Felker, a spokeswoman for the automaker, said today.

headline: Going Once, Going Twice
text: If you are one of the many individuals who has been mourning the loss of Charlotte Moss’s treasure trove of design gems ever since she shuttered her Upper East Side town house store in 2008, you can now rejoice a bit. On Thursday at 10 a.m., Doyle New York will auction off “The Charlotte Moss Collection,” which includes over 400 objects belonging to the Southern decorator, including leftover inventory from the retail space as well as other design items she’s collected along the way. Pieces range from signed 18th-century art to a set of De Gournay hand-painted Indian tea paper wallpaper panels with an estimated price tag somewhere between $2,000 and $4,000, and the comprehensive catalog is available at doylenewyork.com leading up to the auction.

headline: We’re Through. Check the App.
text: Breaking up has always been excruciating, but at least in the old days lovers could split, move on and retain their dignity. Now, in the age of social media, extrication is nearly impossible. The pain of a breakup is nourished by an endless real-time stream of Facebook status updates, Instagram photos and tweets about one’s ex.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 6
text: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Exhuming the Last of Hendrix’s Studio Sessions
text: When Jimi Hendrix died in September 1970, he left hundreds of session tapes behind. Over the last three decades producers have mined that trove of recordings, putting out a dozen posthumous studio albums, selling millions of copies.

headline: Witches Lose the Warts
text: Lena Duchannes is new in town, exotic and seductive to a handful of bored locals in the Southern community where she lives. But if that weren’t enough to turn her into man bait, her pallid good looks would do the trick.

headline: Reactions to the Death of Hugo Chávez
text: After the death of Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan president whose views and policies were controversial both inside and outside his country, readers discussed his legacy as an economic populist and diplomatic provocateur. Below is a selection of their comments.

headline: Witches Have a Fashion Moment
text: Witchcraft and its moody expressions — long weedy hair, peaked hats and pointy boots — have attained a strange cachet of late.

headline: Gadgets You Need, Even if You Have a Smartphone
text: After I bought my first iPhone, something changed. When I bought a new electronic device, I was often filled with regret rather than joy.

headline: Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
text: At the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational, played two weeks ago, the most famous “am” in the preliminary pro-am event was the husband of Queen Margrethe II of Denmark, Henrik, the prince consort.

headline: Mannequins, Then and Now
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Order and Disorder, as Dawn Casts a Glow Over a Funereal March
text: Paul Taylor has often seemed the greatest of today’s choreographers, the most imaginative and disconcerting in any genre. Tuesday’s opening night gala of his dance company’s three-week season at Lincoln Center didn’t demonstrate enoughof that top quality, but its four works — spanning from 1956 to a world premiere — represented an intelligent retrospective. They showed his diversity, from offbeat idiosyncrasy to poetic orthodoxy and from comic pratfalls to dark, wild force. They also included costumes and designs by Alex Katz and Robert Rauschenberg, and scores from jazz to Offenbach. The season that follows contains 17 other works, many of which are among Mr. Taylor’s most singular masterpieces.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company at Lincoln Center
text: The company presented its opening night gala of its three-week season on Tuesday.

headline: A Paris Quartier Surges
text: New cafes, bars and boutiques are enlivening a stretch of the 10th Arrondissement.

headline: Yanks Lose Another Big Bat to Injury
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Sitting in a wheelchair parked in the middle of the Yankees’ clubhouse, with his broken right leg in a cast, General Manager Brian Cashman delivered the details about the latest injury to befall the Yankees, and it was not his own.

headline: A New Look at What Used to Be Chic
text: Extraordinary dresses have a way of finding William Banks-Blaney. Dresses like the mint condition 1970s Ossie Clark he discovered, along with a floor-length, silk velvet Art Deco cape, in “a random little store on Waiheke Island, off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, when I was there for Christmas last year,” he said recently, sipping a cappuccino in the lobby of the Maritime hotel in Manhattan. “You just never know where a dress will travel to.”

headline: Boxers HK
text: In recent years, the center of LGBT night life has shifted from Downtown to Midtown, with 13 gay bars now clustered in Hell’s Kitchen. The newest one is Boxers HK, the northern branch of the popular Chelsea sports bar, that opened its frosted glass doors in January.

headline: Art-Shopping for Stars, So They Don’t Have To
text: For Maria Brito, the Armory Show, the contemporary art fair that starts Thursday at Piers 92 and 94 on the Hudson River in Manhattan, is kind of like a Stop & Shop. Acting as purchasing proxy for clients like Sean Combs, (“His friends call him Puffy, but I call him Sean,” she said) and Gwyneth Paltrow, Ms. Brito will be looking for works by “established, midcareer and emerging artists,” she said, though her voice ticked up a notch when mentioning younger ones: “Christa Joo-Hyun D’Angelo, Andrea Mary Marshall, Caragh Thuring and Angel Otero.”

headline: Painting Music, and Listening to Art
text: On Monday, Jan. 2, 1911, at half past 7 in the evening, Wassily Kandinsky attended a concert at a hotel ballroom in Munich. The next day he painted it.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Alexander McQueen
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Creative Class Is in Session
text: It was a hot Saturday night last summer, and a pack of scruffy kids, many toting skateboards and backpacks, spilled out onto Canal Street from a shoe-box-size storefront Buddhist temple.

headline: In the Bronx, Where Art Is Still Free
text: How did the Bronx Museum of the Arts, an institution on the Grand Concourse that is far removed from the tourist precincts of Manhattan’s Museum Mile, boost its attendance by 50 percent last year?

headline: Suit Says Sherlock Belongs to the Ages
text: Devotees of Sherlock Holmes are a famously obsessive bunch, and in the 126 years since Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his coolheaded detective they have certainly had plenty of real-world intrigues to ponder alongside fictional ones like “The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle.”

headline: Parsing Motives in Bolshoi Attack
text: MOSCOW — Prosecutors have yet to lay out a possible motive in the January attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, but the revelations of the past few days suggest that it may boil down to a ballerina.

headline: Accessories From Paris Fashion Week
text: A selection of accessories from the Parisian runways.

headline: Pursuing the Men Who Destroy Majestic Lives
text: Sometimes even a dumb show can contain something important. That’s the case with “Battleground: Rhino Wars,” a three-part mini-series that starts Thursday night on Animal Planet.

headline: Past Forward: Hugo Chávez as a ‘Shock Therapist’
text: Revisiting Deborah Sontag’s 2002 article for the magazine about Hugo Chávez.

headline: Sacrament, With Birds
text: Two estimable figures have hovered over the Manton Memorial Organ at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village since that tremendous instrument was inaugurated in May 2011. One is Olivier Messiaen, the visionary 20th-century Frenchman who made the organ a staple of his life’s work as a composer and performer. The other is Jon Gillock, a superb organist born in Oklahoma and based in France who played Messiaen and more to christen the Ascension organ in 2011.

headline: Photo Replay: March 6
text: A look at the day in sports from spring training camp and World Baseball Classic games to the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race.

headline: The New Seats of Power
text: On a recent Monday, Gary Ginsberg, a senior executive at Time Warner, walked into an unremarkable office building on the corner of 57th Street and Sixth Avenue and took the elevator to the eighth floor, entering a windowless door for a 2 p.m. appointment. A couple of hours later, Kenneth Lerer, a founder of The Huffington Post, followed.

headline: Looking for the Right Solution to Hearing Problems
text: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Neil J. DiSarno, chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, and a former chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University. Dr. DiSarno’s first set of answers can be found here. Because more than 200 people wrote in, not all questions can be answered individually; Dr. DiSarno selected representative questions on similar topics. This feature is closed to new questions.

headline: Say, You’re Not the Brother I Thought I Was Marrying
text: There is no missing the sheer effort involved in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Riccardo Zandonai’s “Francesca da Rimini,” which opened on Monday evening for its first Met run in close to 27 years. From the moment the curtain rises you are awed by Ezio Frigerio’s towering, grandly detailed sets, designed for a 1984 resurrection of a work neglected since 1918. Franca Squarciapino’s costumes delight your eyes. Zandonai’s luxuriously orchestrated music caresses your ears.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Spring Awakening

headline: Boeing Plan to Test Fixes on 787 Nears Approval
text: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to approving tests of Boeing’s approach to fixing the batteries on its 787 jets, and the tests could begin next week, federal and industry officials said Wednesday.

headline: Lean, Unfold, Affix or Fold: A Desk for Tight Spaces
text: With Appunto, the Belgian-born designer Laurent Corio has created a versatile piece of furniture for small spaces. His modern escritoire for the French company Eno works as a writing or computing desk: the surface measures 19 by 24 inches to support a laptop. It can also do duty as a ledge for storing items in a kitchen, bathroom, children’s room or foyer. When Appunto is closed, its solid beech legs serve as a place to hang shopping bags, scarves or backpacks, and its reverse side, which is washable, also functions as a message board.

headline: In Brooklyn, Tripping the Plastic Fantastic
text: The latest evidence that Brooklyn is a hotbed of progressive design comes from Souda (pronounced SOH-duh), a Japanese word that translates to “oh, yeah” or “aha!” That’s the name of a design group started by three 2012 graduates of Parsons the New School for Design: Isaac Friedman-Helman, Shaun Kasperbauer and Luft Tanaka.

headline: Basic Zebra Commands: Sit, Stay, Roll Over, Sleep
text: Since 1945, when Flora Scalamandré designed a red zebra wallpaper for the New York restaurant Gino of Capri, the pattern has migrated to umbrellas, china and tote bags. Now it can be found on bedding for people and pets alike. In December Scalamandré introduced a dog bed in the perky stripes, and next month it will follow with a zebra bed skirt and pillow shams for humans.

headline: A Bird in the Hand Is...a Knob
text: The San Francisco-based designer Ted Boerner has teamed up with Rocky Mountain Hardware to create four drawer pulls in the shape of bird heads: a finch, grosbeak, cardinal (shown) and woodpecker. Each one is cast in bronze at the Rocky Mountain foundry in Blackfoot, Idaho, using the centuries-old lost-wax method. (Wax molds are dipped into a liquid ceramic slurry multiple times and hardened. Then the wax is melted out of the shell, liquid bronze is poured in to replace it, and the ceramic shell is cracked off after the metal cools.)

headline: The Daily Do | Louis Vuitton
text: At Louis Vuitton today, Marc Jacobs sent his boudoir-clad ladies out from hotel room doors at the start of the runway. In short, brown Clara Bow-inspired wigs that looked slept-in, the models all appeared to play the same role of a woman in love, or lust.

headline: Sales at Property and Kartell
text: During Property’s sale from Friday through March 23, some furniture and accessories will be up to 60 percent off, and most new orders will be 20 percent off (the Cubica leather lounge chair by Lievore Altherr Molina, which was originally $4,560, will be $1,800; the Booknest pullout sofa by Carlo Colombo, originally $11,070, will be $5,500); 14 Wooster Street (Grand Street), (917) 237-0123, propertyfurniture.com.

headline: A League of One
text: PARIS — One day last week, David Beckham clogged foot traffic on the Champs-Élysées when he made a promotional appearance at the Adidas store. Wearing bright yellow sneakers and his seemingly indefatigable smile, Beckham was like catnip for tourists and locals alike as they walked past the majesty of the nearby Arc de Triomphe and crowded a cramped storefront instead, hoping to snap a camera-phone picture of soccer’s perpetually coifed superstar.

headline: In Defense of Collisions in the Office
text: The latest progressive office playground can be found in the old Stuyvesant Polyclinic, a stately red brick building on Second Avenue near Ninth Street that was once a medical clinic. Inside, its three stories and basement have been reimagined by ?What If!, a self-described “innovation” company that works to expand the markets of businesses like PepsiCo, Pfizer and Virgin.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Venezuela and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Venezuela, Kenya, Myanmar and the Vatican.

headline: Carter Murray Named as Chief of DraftFCB
text: The search for a new leader for the global advertising agency DraftFCB Worldwide, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, ended on Wednesday afternoon with the selection of an outsider from a rival agency owned by WPP.

headline: A House Built for a Family of Individuals
text: A honeycomb of rooms in bold colors in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: It Has Its Points
text: As you approach the Nicol House, you might not realize those are Italian glass ashtrays embedded in the front door or tiny hobby-store mirrors glinting among the shingles. But you would know you were in for something out of the ordinary.

headline: Japan’s New Leader Takes On Old Order to Jolt Economy
text: TAHARA, Japan — Just two months into office, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is showing an increasing willingness to take on some pillars of Japan’s establishment — the central bank and the country’s politically influential farmers — in an aggressive attempt to finally breathe some new life into Japan’s listless economy.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. We have an enclosed, uninsulated porch that we use for storage. Should we renovate to turn it into a usable living space before selling our house?

headline: Casting a Wide Net
text: A new show at MoMA looks at all that design can be.

headline: And to Think I Saw It @ MoMA!
text: Posted above the doorway of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is a question raised in 1911 by the painter Wassily Kandinsky: “Must we not then renounce the object altogether, throw it to the winds and instead lay bare the purely abstract?”

headline: Clues Sought in Burning of Bag Holding 5 Dogs
text: Animal protection authorities are looking for the people who set fire to a bag containing five pit bulls behind a beverage distribution warehouse in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

headline: Engineering Serendipity
text: Why do some parties, companies and cities work, while others don’t? It takes some social engineering to foster serendipity and creativity.

headline: Housewares Through an 8-Year-Old’s Eyes
text: New products from the International Home and Housewares Show.

headline: Robots, Ducks and Awesome Swag
text: CHICAGO — There are few phrases in the English language that bore an 8-year-old more than “trade show.” “Agricultural field trip” might qualify, or maybe “indoor summer camp.” But to draw a truly blank stare, tell a second grader that the two of you are headed to an expo on kitchen, bath and living-room accessories.

headline: The DNA of Cool
text: Michelle Harper has made herself so ubiquitous a subject of the street fashion photographers that she was finally forced to reverse herself and declare “street style so over.”

headline: Michelle Harper, a Woman of Mystery
text: It’s definitively established that in the Age of Instagram and Twitter metrics, it is possible to become pretty darn famous for omnipresence. Case in point: Michelle Harper, an eccentric and modish figure whose image over the last several years has seemed to be everywhere, in both real life and, possibly more important, in the parallel universe that is the Web.

headline: Model Diary | Edie Campbell
text: Edie Campbell wraps up this season’s Model Diary series for T. If you missed her in today’s Louis Vuitton show, you may find the 22-year-old British model and equestrian hanging out around the Marché des Enfants Rouges market before she catches a plane back home to London.

headline: Two Men Scale New York Times Building
text: Alain Robert, a stunt man famous for scaling monuments, hung a bright green banner: “Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week.” Hours later a copycat also made the climb.

headline: Trend Report: Fur Skirts
text: Fur skirts offer a way for designers to explore wider, and wilder, proportions in their fall 2013 collections.

headline: Alberto R. Gonzales’s Tenure
text: President Bush had repeatedly stood by Mr. Gonzales, even as he faced increasing scrutiny for his leadership of the Justice Department.

headline: Helping Immigrants Warm to Winter
text: PORTLAND, Me. — Charlene Masengu left the Democratic Republic of Congo late last year, hoping to get asylum status in the United States after a wave of political violence made life at home unbearably dangerous. She made it to this coastal city last month, just before it was covered in more than 30 inches of snow, and she wondered, briefly, whether she had made a mistake.

headline: A Poetry Reading by Alfred Brendel
text: Mr. Brendel, a pianist, read two selections from his poetry collection, 'Cursing Bagels.' Recorded by James Barron of The New York Times.

headline: Sears and Penney Respond to ‘SNL’ Sketch Complaint
text: So did a comedy sketch on the Feb. 16 edition of “Saturday Night Live” called “Djesus Uncrossed” really lead two companies to ask NBC not to place their ads in future editions of the show?

headline: Where Everything Smells Bad
text: PARIS

headline: Stage Scenes: Alice Ripley
text: A look at some of the actress’s stage performances.

headline: Posters on Teenage Pregnancy Draw Fire
text: The curly-haired baby looks out from the poster with sad eyes and tears dripping down his tawny cheeks.

headline: When Arkansas Travels, Success Doesn’t Follow
text: When Mike Anderson left Missouri to become the men’s basketball coach at Arkansas in March 2011, he said he was going home.

headline: Clothes Worthy of Their Label
text: PARIS — You sometimes think, at the bleary end of a runway season, that fashion would be better off if companies didn’t have labels to sell.

headline: Television’s ‘C.S.I.’ Gets New Financial Partner to Replace Goldman
text: LOS ANGELES — Crime continues to pay, at least where the “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation” television franchise is concerned.

headline: Egypt Court Cancels Parliamentary Elections
text: CAIRO — A top court on Wednesday canceled pending parliamentary elections and referred the election law to the Supreme Constitutional Court, adding to the mounting uncertainty about a vote that had been scheduled to begin as early as April 22.

headline: Video of Syrians With Seized U.N. Vehicles in Golan Heights
text: Updated, Thursday, 9:07 a.m. As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Alan Cowell report, 30 armed rebel fighters kidnapped a group of 20 United Nations peacekeepers in the Golan Heights on Wednesday and gave a 24-hour deadline before they would treat the peacekeepers “as prisoners of war.”

headline: The Struggle for Jihad
text: Two opposing groups battle to define the word jihad on public buses and subways.

headline: In Upgrade, Google Adds to Model for Mobile Marketing
text: GOOGLE executives, declaring themselves pleased with the results of an unusual advertising initiative last year, are bringing out a Version 2.0, again teaming with agencies and marketers to try demonstrating that technology is not incompatible with traditional Madison Avenue sales strategies like emotional storytelling.

headline: A Nascar Driver’s Deeds Fail to Match Her Words
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Nascar, which has long struggled to develop minority and female participants, seemed to have a barrier-breaking athlete in its ranks in recent years: Tia Norfleet, a 20-something driver from Georgia. With a savvy marketing campaign, Norfleet garnered attention in several national publications while promoting her accomplishments as the first African-American woman to race in Nascar.

headline: Using Billboards to Stake Claim Over ‘Jihad’
text: CHICAGO — There is an advertising war being fought here — not over soda or car brands but over the true meaning of the word “jihad.”

headline: A Locust Plague, Shy of Biblical Proportions, in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — For many Israelis, the biblical comparisons were irresistible: locusts were swarming across the border from Egypt three weeks before Passover, like a vivid enactment of the eighth plague visited upon the obdurate Pharaoh. Others with a more modern sensibility said it felt more like Hitchcock.

headline: Killer of Girlfriend and Her Son Is Sentenced to 50 Years to Life
text: A man convicted of strangling his pregnant girlfriend and killing her 2-year-old son in a fire he set at her Queens apartment was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison on Wednesday, the Queens district attorney said.

headline: A Shift Toward Higher Job Vacancy Rates
text: There has been a fundamental shift over the last several years toward more unfilled jobs, even as the unemployment rate has fallen.

headline: Officer’s Trial Has a Jury That Appears Tech-Savvy
text: One day last month, as Judge Paul G. Gardephe was overseeing jury selection for the trial of a New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, he asked prospective jurors about issues that could call their impartiality into question.

headline: Security Council Loosens Somalian Arms Embargo
text: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Wednesday to temporarily rescind part of a 21-year-old arms embargo on Somalia, the East African country once considered synonymous with warlordism, piracy and anarchy, portraying the easing as part of an effort to strengthen the fragile Somalian government’s authority by permitting it to purchase light weapons.

headline: Global Slavery, by the Numbers
text: Here are some chilling statistics: The lifetime profit on a brickmaking slave in Brazil is $8,700, and $2,000 in India. Sexual slavery brings the slave’s owner $18,000 over the slave’s working life in Thailand, and $49,000 in Los Angeles.

headline: Guns and Congress
text: The Times's Mike McIntire on the close relationship between members of Congress and a sportsmen's charity pushing gun rights.

headline: Despite Ranger’s Eye Injury, Union Rejects Calls for Mandatory Visors
text: The puck may have been flying about 75 miles per hour when it exploded off the stick of Flyers defenseman Kimmo Timonen and deflected into the face of Marc Staal near his right eye Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. Staal, a 26-year-old Rangers defenseman, went down as if shot, hands covering his face as he squirmed on the ice and bled profusely.

headline: Microsoft Is Talking About the Future, a Lot
text: REDMOND, Wash. — There are technology companies that won’t say anything about the futuristic inventions they’re tinkering with in their labs — Apple, for instance.

headline: Latin America After Chávez
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil

headline: Pakistan, Under Cultural Siege, Is Buoyed by Book Festivals
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Assailed by jihadist attacks and the moral cudgels of religious conservatives, Lahore’s celebrated cultural vitality has waned somewhat in recent years. A famous kite-flying festival is no more; a performing arts festival vanished after being attacked; and music concerts take place in restricted circumstances.

headline: Latest Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
text: President Obama travels to Connecticut Monday, where lawmakers last week approved stricter gun laws nearly four months after 20 children and six educators were shot and killed in Newtown, Conn.

headline: What Young Republicans Want
text: Why are fewer young people -- the millennial generation -- identifying themselves as conservatives?

headline: How to Start a Good School Day
text: Breakfast is served every weekday morning to 12 million students across the country, courtesy of the Department of Agriculture. Free breakfast reduces hunger and can improve academic performance, but in New York City, too many students do not get the meals they need.

headline: Proposed Dam Presents Economic and Environmental Challenges in Alaska
text: At a time when large dams are being taken down, not put up, the state of Alaska is proposing to construct one of the tallest and most expensive hydroelectric dams ever built in North America.

headline: Face-Lift at Facebook, to Keep Its Users Engaged
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook plans to announce on Thursday a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed at both keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.

headline: Charity Takes Gun Lobby Closer to Its Quarry
text: On a Monday evening in early February, two months into a national debate over gun violence after the massacre at a Connecticut elementary school, representatives of the firearms industry were wining and dining lawmakers in Washington.

headline: Hugo Chávez
text: Hugo Chávez dominated Venezuelan politics for 14 years with his charismatic personality, populist policies and authoritarian methods before his death this week. His redistributionist policies brought better living conditions to millions of poor Venezuelans. But his legacy is stained by the undermining of democratic institutions and the embrace of malevolent foreign leaders like Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

headline: Death in the Forests
text: Day after day, the slaughter of the elephants continues at a record pace — 25,000 killed in 2011, conservationists say, and more than 30,000 last year. A study from the Wildlife Conservation Society shows that 60 percent of all African forest elephants (a slightly smaller subspecies of the African savanna elephant) have been killed in the last decade for their ivory, leaving about 80,000 in their primary habitats in Western and Central Africa.

headline: From One Budget Fight to the Next
text: Unable to stop the sequester’s job-killing spending cuts, President Obama now says he wants to move past the endless wars of budget attrition. Though he still wants a long-term deficit deal, he said last week, it is time to turn to immigration, gun control, universal preschool, a higher minimum wage and voting reform.

headline: Newly Discovered, Nearly Extinct
text: ITHACA, N.Y.

headline: ‘A Big New Power’
text: Years from now, when the Supreme Court has come to its senses, justices then sitting will look back on the spring of 2013 in bewilderment. On what basis, they will wonder, did five conservative justices, professed believers in judicial restraint, reach out to grab the authority that the framers of the post-Civil War 14th and 15th Amendments had vested in Congress nearly a century and a half earlier “to enforce, by appropriate legislation” the right to equal protection and the right to vote. How on earth did it come to pass that the Supreme Court ruled a major provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 unconstitutional?

headline: Cry About the Real Wolf
text: The White House horribly botched its messaging on the sequester.

headline: Talk of the Town
text: Senator Rand Paul has his faults. Who among us can forget the time he ranted at a representative of the Department of Energy about the inadequacy of his bathroom plumbing? (“You busybodies always want to do something to tell us how we can live our lives better. ... I’ve been waiting for 20 years to talk about how bad these toilets are.”)

headline: The Good, Racist People
text: Last month the actor Forest Whitaker was stopped in a Manhattan delicatessen by an employee. Whitaker is one of the pre-eminent actors of his generation, with a diverse and celebrated catalog ranging from “The Great Debaters” to “The Crying Game” to “Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai.” By now it is likely that he has adjusted to random strangers who can’t get his turn as Idi Amin out of their heads. But the man who approached the Oscar winner at the deli last month was in no mood for autographs. The employee stopped Whitaker, accused him of shoplifting and then promptly frisked him. The act of self-deputization was futile. Whitaker had stolen nothing. On the contrary, he’d been robbed.

headline: On Campus, Costly Target of Brazen Thefts: Nutella
text: This has all the makings of a tempest in a Nutella jar, which may not be as appealing as a Nutella milkshake, Nutella fudge or Nutella-stuffed French toast. Or stolen Nutella, which, apparently, has mouthwatering appeal at Columbia University.

headline: Wall Street Ties in a Prospect for Deputy at the S.E.C.
text: Mary Jo White, who appears set to become a top Wall Street regulator, is seeking to allay skepticism about her spins through the revolving door between government service and private practice.

headline: In the Streets of Venezuela, Bidding Farewell to Chávez
text: As Venezuela begins to adjust to life without President Hugo Chávez, questions abound, including how the nation will be run in the coming weeks and when a new election will be scheduled.

text: To the Editor:
