headline: Cuomo Voices Mixed Optimism for Chances of Campaign Finance Proposals
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that he was “cautiously optimistic” that he could push through the Legislature this spring an overhaul of the state’s campaign finance laws, one of the top priorities in Albany for government reformers and progressive groups.

headline: T Men’s Fashion Spring 2013
text: The actor Matthias Schoenaerts, photographed by Bruce Weber, is the cover subject of the spring men’s fashion issue of T. Learn how the Belgian import is dealing with becoming an American sensation. Inside: read Guy Trebay’s essay about how the average male is shedding schlumpiness for style, meet five exceptionally talented young poets (and read their work) and visit the Stockholm studio of the perfumer Ben Gorham. Additional highlights from the magazine include “Sporting Goods,” a round-up of athletic gear, “The Male Bond,” in which Andrew O’Hagan ruminates on male friendships, and “The Modern Man,” a primer on the frank irony to dressing stylishly today. See all from the issue >>

headline: A Restaurant Built on Chickpeas
text: Even though Hummus Elite is mostly about hummus and has only 10 tables, a friend urged me to try it. I did, and was enchanted by almost every dish I ate. In the hummus category, these dishes included hummus with beef, hummus with eggplant, plain hummus and hummus with mushrooms and truffle oil. In the nonhummus category, they consisted of silky, roasted eggplant; ground beef-and-lamb kebabs fragrant with coriander; and, most surprising of all, an eight-ounce hamburger that, like the best backyard burgers, tasted as if it had been cooked over charcoal instead of just gas.

headline: Pango Says Its App Can Cut Waiting Time at Parking Garages
text: For drivers who regularly face the challenges of parking in Manhattan, the age of technology has provided precious few options. The automated, robot-operated garage holds promise down the road and may ease the pain. For now, though, there’s a smidgen of help. It’s called Pango.

headline: The Week in Pictures From Business for March 8
text: The Dow Jones industrial average topped its nominal record high, Martha Stewart took the stand in a trial over sales of her products, and employment data for February suggested the recovery was gaining speed.

headline: A Spot to Sample the Mediterranean Diet
text: In light of recent research showing that a Mediterranean diet — one rich in vegetables, fish and olive oil — lowers the risk of heart disease, Greek restaurants look more appealing than ever these days. Opa Grille, which opened in October in Williston Park, has its share of meat and cheese on the menu, but diners seeking healthful fare can find plenty to enjoy here.

headline: Aiming for the Red Planet
text: Several private companies have plans in the works for missions to Mars.

headline: Florida: Guilty Plea Expected in Hazing Death of Drum Major
text: One of a dozen Florida A&M University students now charged with manslaughter in the hazing death of a drum major plans to plead guilty in the hope of receiving a more lenient sentence, his lawyer said Friday. The student, Caleb Jackson, 24, who is in the Leon County Jail on a probation violation, was on the bus where the drum major, Robert Champion, was beaten in 2011. Mr. Jackson is expected to plead guilty next month in an Orlando court. Chuck Hobbs, his lawyer, said Mr. Jackson was not one of the students who beat Mr. Champion, 26. The guilty plea comes in response to a decision by Jeff Ashton, the newly elected state attorney for Orange and Osceola Counties, to add manslaughter charges to existing felony hazing charges.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 8
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school and a St. Patrick’s Day parade in the Rockaways.

headline: Old World Décor, and a Cosmopolitan Menu
text: Its position along the Aspetuck River on a remote stretch of Route 202 in Marbledale, Conn., a few miles north of New Milford, makes the White Horse very much a country pub.

headline: Ohio: F.B.I. Enters Inquiry at Oberlin
text: The F.B.I. is investigating racist and antigay messages left around Oberlin College in the past month and the possible sighting of someone wearing a Ku Klux Klan-type outfit, a college spokesman said on Friday. A student newspaper, The Oberlin Review, reported that the college removed two students last week in connection with the vandalism; Oberlin would not comment on that report. The newspaper also reported that the recent incidents were probably linked to online racist messages dating back almost a year.

headline: Indian Flavors, Cool, Minimalist and Modern
text: In these days of trendy fusion this and fusion that, diners often have to guess what lies ahead when a restaurant claims modernity. In the case of Coriander, in Larchmont, several factors combine to create a modern feel. The décor is low key: a contemporary beige and charcoal color scheme, brightened by a row of charming white lanterns in the aisle that leads to the dining room. A small handful of cross-legged mustachioed Rajasthani figurines and a dramatic Shiva as Nataraja the cosmic dancer set the Indian theme.

headline: Honoring Prince at Carnegie Hall
text: Performers from Questlove to Elvis Costello celebrated the music of Prince.

headline: Howard Has Broken Bones in Back; Likely Out for Qualifiers
text: Goalkeeper Tim Howard has two broken bones in his back, his English club, Everton, announced Friday, an injury that will almost certainly rule him out of two important World Cup qualifiers for the United States national team later this month.

headline: When Each Stylized Flourish Proclaims Itself
text: On Wednesday night Ballet Flamenco de Andalusia opened a short season at City Center. When the music was live, it was wretchedly overamplified; often the dancers and singers performed to a taped orchestral accompaniment that sounded less like Andalusia than like a Hollywood idea of Spanish sounds. Two star dancers, Pastora Galván and Rubén Olmo, exuded absurd mannerism far more than they did flamenco rhythms. And the third, Rocío Molina, though a marvelous dancer, performed in an idiom that came across as pretentious.

headline: For a Night, at Least, Nothing Compares to Prince
text: One concert could hardly contain the multiplicity of Prince’s enormous songwriting catalog over the 35 years since he released his debut album, “For You,” in 1978. “The Music of Prince,” a tribute concert on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, tried hard. The program strove to capture a broad swath of Prince’s work, through funk and rock and pop, from lust to spirituality to apocalypse to partying. It included hits, rarities and even some of Prince’s dance moves (but alas, no leaping splits). It was the ninth annual “Music of” concert produced by Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, to benefit music programs for underprivileged children.

headline: The Drone Question Obama Hasn’t Answered
text: THE Senate confirmed John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency on Thursday after a nearly 13-hour filibuster by the libertarian senator Rand Paul, who before the vote received a somewhat odd letter from the attorney general.

headline: Rules of Order Dictate Pitching at World Classic
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Tony Pena likes to be involved in the flow of games. He was involved during his major league career as a catcher, and he remains involved as the manager of the Dominican Republic team at the World Baseball Classic. He refuses to be confined to the dugout; that much is clear.

headline: Teaching Viewers to Hear the TV With Eyes Only
text: This week ABC Family did something that no commercial television channel in the United States had ever done: It broadcast an entire episode of a show, “Switched at Birth,” in American Sign Language, with next to no oral dialogue.

headline: Night of the Stars
text: The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 28 at the Richmond Bridge Club in London.

headline: Almost Certainly, the Thief Didn’t Know What Was in the Box
text: Ring! Ring! Ring! The man pushed buzzer after buzzer outside the building on Prospect Park West on a February afternoon. Either he knew someone in every apartment and had picked the wrong day to visit, or he was doing some homework for his Burglary 101 class.

headline: The Darkness of an Irish Morning
text: MY father came from Ireland and he had the gift of the gab. Part of the reason the Irish developed the gift of the gab was simple. They lived on an island. They had to get along. Not that they did get along. But they had to try. So a style of speaking developed that allowed them to say awful things. With charm.

headline: A Small Stable’s Bridge to the Derby
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The bloodlines that are part of the Kentucky Derby contender Verrazano’s story run deep, and not just with the horses.

headline: Visions of Drones Swarming U.S. Skies Hit Bipartisan Nerve
text: WASHINGTON — The debate goes to the heart of a deeply rooted American suspicion about the government, the military and the surveillance state: the specter of drones streaking through the skies above American cities and towns, controlled by faceless bureaucrats and equipped to spy or kill.

headline: A Former Hostage Worries for Those Left Behind in the Desert
text: NÎMES, France

headline: An Entry Reserved for Those With Guns
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — At the State Capitol here, a legal concealed gun is the equivalent of an E-ZPass.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Italy Uneasy as Government and Vatican Drift, Rudderless
text: ROME — The leader has resigned. There are scandals over sex and corruption. Finances are in disarray. And no one knows who will step in to try to clean up the mess.

headline: Blocked Bids to Fill Judgeships Stir New Fight on Filibuster
text: WASHINGTON — A fresh feud over federal judgeships has again begun to agitate the Senate, with Republicans so far blocking President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most prestigious and important appeals court.

headline: A Lifetime of Portraits and Shots of Graffiti
text: TRENTON — Preparing to lead a reporter through the exhibition “Jon Naar: Signature Photography” at the New Jersey State Museum here, Mr. Naar paused before starting into what he called “a fast-forward” through his life.

headline: Off the Path to Recovery
text: The February employment report shows some notable improvements that, if sustained, would herald a real recovery. Partly boosted by increased employment in the construction industry, the number of new jobs jumped to 236,000 last month, continuing a gradual upward trend.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: As Police Strike, Egypt Tensely Awaits Verdicts in Soccer Riot
text: As my colleague in Cairo David Kirkpatrick reported, a quickly spreading strike among the police force has added to a growing sense of chaos and lawlessness in Egypt, where opposition to President Mohamed Morsi has been newly energized in recent days by anticipation of a second round of verdicts over the deaths of more than 70 soccer fans in a stadium riot in Port Said last year.

headline: Congress Gets in the Way
text: If there is any hope for a peaceful resolution of the nuclear dispute with Iran, President Obama needs Congress to support negotiations. But negotiations and compromise are largely anathema in Washington, with many lawmakers insisting that any deal with Iran would be unacceptable — a stance that would make military action by Israel and the United States far more likely.

headline: Doubling Back for the Roadkill
text: Squirrel gravy is such a delicacy in Appalachia that there is a RoadKill Cook-off each year in the hollows of West Virginia. Lawmakers in Montana get the drift. The lower house of the Montana Legislature recently approved a measure that would allow citizens to salvage fresh roadkill and take it home for dinner.

headline: One Way to Cheer Up: Cheer Harder
text: You probably think rabid sports fans are a bunch of lonely, disoriented souls who try to fill the holes in their lives by attaching themselves to a team. And you’re probably wrong.

headline: Curtains, and Hope for Renewal, Going Up
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — When the Suffolk Theater opened as a movie house in 1933, it was heralded by one local newspaper as “a splendidly designed structure, beautifully and modernly equipped and furnished.”

headline: Miles to Go Before He Sings
text: David Steinberger, 41, is the chief executive of ComiXology, sometimes called the iTunes of comics, which has about 33,000 comics in its library and adds about 300 a week. A classically trained singer, he has a master’s degree in performance from the Manhattan School of Music and an Advanced Certificate in performance from Juilliard, as well as an M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Steinberger, who moved to New York from Kentucky in 1994, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Kittson, a graphic designer, and their two cats, Buddy and Sweetheart. On Sundays, he often sings in church and runs with his wife in Central Park; they plan to run the NYC Half on March 17.

headline: Setback to Boeing’s Hopes for Longer Range for 787
text: With the technologically advanced 787, Boeing offered airlines big fuel savings and better comfort for passengers. It also promised something else: the ability to reach just about any airport on the globe without having to stop.

headline: Cautious Approval for a Plan to Merge a City’s Museums
text: LOS ANGELES — For many people in the philanthropic and cultural swirl of Los Angeles, the proposal seems a welcome response to a conflict that has riveted this city’s art world for five years: A merger of its two biggest museums, ending a long-simmering feud, combining two arts collections, and rescuing one of them, the Museum of Contemporary Art, from a spasm of personnel turmoil and fiscal decline.

headline: Saving the Day
text: One way to appreciate the conceptual oddness of daylight saving time is to imagine it as a new idea just cooked up by the Obama administration. An individual mandate to change your clocks twice a year, every year, to enable a government redistribution of sunshine. Or, put another way, the feds’ confiscation of more than 300 million privately held American sleep hours, taken for eight months without interest payments or a penalty. All to make the nation healthier, wealthier and wiser, and for somewhat dubious energy savings. House Republicans would not be pleased — would you? Would you reset the clock radio, or would you demand that the government stay out of your bedroom and leave your dream life alone?

headline: A Dangerous ‘New Normal’ in College Debt
text: We are reaching a crisis point in this country’s higher education system.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Man Who Helped Image of Wal-Mart Steps Down
text: The chief burnisher of Wal-Mart Stores’ reputation is leaving the company as its image is under new strains.

headline: In Cannibal Case, Deliberations Go On
text: The jury in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, rape and cannibalize women, was sent home on Friday after competing its first full day of deliberations without reaching a verdict.

headline: Exercise May Help Protect Children From Stress
text: Physically active children generally report happier moods and fewer symptoms of depression than children who are less active. Now researchers may have found a reason: by one measure, exercise seems to help children cope with stress.

headline: McIlroy Finds His Comfort Zone, but Woods Is Long Gone by Then
text: DORAL, Fla. — Making 17 birdies in the opening 36 holes is a first for Tiger Woods in his PGA Tour career, but it is not the neatest trick he has pulled off at the Cadillac Championship this week. On Friday on the ninth hole of Doral’s Blue Monster, Woods made the thousands of fans following him essentially disappear.

headline: An Installation of Dirty Politics and Illusion
text: In the simplest sense, Deb Sokolow’s “Some Concerns About the Candidate” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford is a clever installation driven by a single conceit: a fictional narrative in which a Congressional candidate hires a campaign consultant to help him get elected. The protagonist, referred to throughout the exhibition as “you,” is a campaign worker who falls under the candidate’s spell — but ends up documenting an unfolding tale of intrigue and deceit.

headline: Queens Congressman Attends Chávez Funeral
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a New York Democrat who developed a little-known but significant relationship with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela over the last decade, attended Mr. Chávez’s funeral on Friday as part of a small United States delegation.

headline: In Parts of Syria, Lack of Assistance ‘Is a Catastrophe’
text: SAWRAN, Syria — The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 8, 2013

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow at Tiny Desk
text: Wow — almost forgot to post tonight. Anyway, this is the best performance I’ve seen yet by this group; no frills, just the three of them, and almost Civil Wars levels of perfection.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 9, 2013
text: "There’s no government, there’s no pope. And now it is snowing in Rome.”

headline: Little Relief in North Syria, Where Need Is Acute
text: International donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on aid for Syrians, but the money has brought anger and resentment in some areas.

headline: Senators Bearing Arms
text: Whenever talk turns to gun control in Congress, lawmakers feel compelled to mention their love of weaponry.

headline: Mets’ Gee Encouraged Despite an Uneven Outing
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Despite looking uneven during his second game facing major league hitters since being shut down last summer, Dillon Gee said he felt that he was near his optimal form for the start of the season.

headline: Pope Material or Not, a Charming, Cheerful Cardinal Gains Notice in Rome
text: VATICAN CITY — He keeps a set of vestments here, at the American seminary, so he does not have to lug the red robes back and forth to New York. He is a practiced frequent flier; last fall, he flew a round trip in a day, borrowing a billionaire’s jet so he could preside at a dinner in Manhattan without missing a meeting in Rome.

headline: Corrections: March 9, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Gets in a Lather
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a very interesting puzzle on quite a few levels: for one thing, with today’s puzzle, co-written by David Steinberg and Barry C. Silk, Mr. Steinberg has hit for the cycle after only his ninth puzzle published in The New York Times. Mr. Steinberg, who is in his mid-teens, has had at least one puzzle published in The Times on each day of the week.

headline: Finding Lovable Humanity in a Bitter Artist
text: Most people don’t like Malcolm Raphelson. Even in his 70s, he is a menacing, arrogant, womanizing, narcissistic artist who has never forgiven Jackson Pollock and the other Abstract Expressionists for stealing his thunder in the 1940s and ’50s. Raphelson has an appetite for destruction, including his own.

headline: Paintings From Garage Find Appreciation in Gallery
text: For years, they languished in a Long Island garage, old canvasses piled in a stack. Then they came close to being thrown into a garbage truck.

headline: As Brodeur Sits, Devils Try to Get Back on Their Feet
text: NEWARK — A back injury to the 40-year-old goaltender Martin Brodeur, a mainstay during the Devils’ three Stanley Cup triumphs, is providing the franchise a glimpse of what life could be like without him. It may not be pretty.

headline: Dwindling Production Has Led to Lesser Role for Venezuela as Major Oil Power
text: HOUSTON — President Hugo Chávez relished using Venezuela’s oil wealth to project power internationally, nudging OPEC to raise oil prices when he could, showering allies like Cuba and Nicaragua with subsidized oil shipments, and mocking the United States while selling it his crude.

headline: A Restaurant Was Popular; Its Closing Was Celebrated
text: For years, Saigon Grill on Amsterdam Avenue at 90th Street was an Upper West Side fixture. Its spring rolls and Vietnamese soups were staples of quick dinners, celebratory lunches and takeout meals. Its deliveries were prompt, its waiters happy to take care of small children.

headline: Are Bicycles Allowed in the Subways?
text: Q. Are bicycles allowed in the subways?

headline: Mosby’s Sneak Attack
text: “On the bed we saw the general sleeping,” recalled the memoirist. “There was no time for ceremony, so I drew up the bedclothes, pulled up the general’s shirt, and gave him a spank on his bare back, and told him to get up.” This brief description captured the apex of one military career, and the nadir of another.

headline: Swedes on Both Ends of Ice End Rangers’ Streak
text: Brad Richards made a successful return from injury and Rick Nash scored again, but it was Swedes Night at Madison Square Garden as the Ottawa Senators defeated the Rangers, 3-2, on Friday.

headline: Treasure in the Air Up There
text: Robert A. King, 67, architect, checked in on one of his renovation jobs, a town house on Garfield Place in Brooklyn, and then spent the rest of Wednesday afternoon walking the neighborhood looking up.

headline: Rational Decisions and Heartbreak on School Closings
text: When it comes to school closings, the arguments may make sense on paper, but the reality is much messier.

headline: Filling the D.C. Appeals Court
text: Republicans in the Senate have so far blocked President Obama from filling vacant judgeships in the District of Columbia Circuit of the Unites States Court of Appeals.

headline: Argentina: Ex-President Is Convicted
text: An appeals court in Argentina convicted former President Carlos Saúl Menem on Friday of smuggling contraband weapons in the 1990s. Weapons and munitions officially destined to Panama and Venezuela ended up in Ecuador during its brief war with Peru, violating a bilateral peace agreement, and in Croatia during the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia amid an international weapons embargo. The ruling overturned a lower court’s 2011 acquittal of Mr. Menem, left, whose 1989-1999 presidency was marred by accusations of corruption and graft. Mr. Menem, who denies being part of the arms conspiracy, served six months on house arrest on the same charges in 2001, but was freed following a Supreme Court ruling. As a senator, Mr. Menem, 82, is shielded from further imprisonment and may appeal the conviction before the Supreme Court.

headline: Williams Electrifies From Long Distance
text: Deron Williams’s night began quietly, with a 3-pointer from the left wing that whipped through the net about 90 seconds after the opening tip. Fans were still settling in their seats, and the Nets’ main concern was stopping Washington’s John Wall, a pesky guard who could cause them headaches.

headline: Germany: Airport Project Reorganized
text: A tough manager who turned around Germany’s national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlin’s new international airport on Friday. “We will do everything to speed up the completion of the airport,” said the new leader, Hartmut Mehdorn, 70. Embarrassing budgetary and technical problems have repeatedly pushed the opening of the Berlin-Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport further from its original target of last June, pushed costs to $5.2 billion, turned the project into a national joke, and cost the last manager, Rainer Schwarz, his job. Mr. Mehdorn brought the national railway, Deutsche Bahn, into profitability as its head from 1999 to 2009 and then helped return Air Berlin to competitiveness before leaving as its chief executive in January.

headline: Three Men at Work, Quietly, While Yankees Are Elsewhere
text: TAMPA, Fla. — A team of aspiring Yankees played in a spring training game on the other side of Florida on Friday. Meanwhile, three of the most revered Yankees in team history had their run of the team’s quiet complex, preparing for what is likely to be their last season together after two immensely successful decades.

headline: Britain: 4 Plead Guilty in Selling Information to Tabloids
text: In the latest of dozens of criminal cases stemming from the phone-hacking scandal that led to the closure in 2011 of Rupert Murdoch’s News of the World tabloid, four former public officials pleaded guilty Friday to illegally selling information to another Murdoch-owned tabloid, The Sun. One, Alan Tierney, a former police constable, admitted to selling information in 2009 about the shoplifting arrests of the mother and mother-in-law of the soccer star John Terry. He also admitted selling another story that year about how the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood had been arrested on suspicion of beating up a girlfriend. Mr. Tierney, who prosecutors said was paid $2,600, will be sentenced on March 27. Another defendant, Richard Trunkfield, a former prison officer at a high-security facility, admitted to receiving $5,000 for information about a “high-profile prisoner” in 2010. The two other defendants cannot be named because their alleged co-conspirators have yet to face trial.

headline: After Over a Century at Sea, 2 Sailors Are Laid to Rest
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Older women in hoop skirts and petticoats came together with youthful sailors in their dress blues for a rare public double interment at Arlington National Cemetery on Friday.

headline: In a Private School, Seeds of Dissent
text: No wonder they called it the Little Red School House.

headline: Sailors From the Ironclad Warship Monitor Interred
text: The unidentified remains of two of the 16 men who went down with the ship on Dec. 31, 1862, during the Civil War were interred in Arlington National Cemetery on Mar. 8.

headline: Iraq: Security Forces Open Fire on Sunni Demonstrators in North
text: Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials. The demonstrators were demanding the release of Sheikh Hussain al-Jubori, a local leader of antigovernment protests that have been going on in Iraq for two months. He was arrested early in the day on suspicion of links to Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the homegrown terrorist group. After the shootings, members of the mainly Sunni Iraqiya bloc held a news conference to denounce the government as “reckless,” and the minister of agriculture, Izzeddin al-Dolah, resigned, the second high-profile Sunni to do so this month.

headline: Colorado Takes Up Gun Limits in Senate
text: DENVER — After months of emotional debate, an effort to tighten gun laws in a state haunted by two mass shootings moved toward an uncertain climax on Friday as Colorado’s State Senate began a marathon session on a range of new firearms restrictions.

headline: Capitol Redux
text: A visual tour of the New York State Capitol in Albany. Its renovation was completed in 2012.

headline: Local Stop: 68th and Lexington
text: At Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, Hunter College represents the architectural history of the area as well as the addition of modern amenities.

headline: Modernity Among Classics
text: The corner of Lexington Avenue and 68th Street is beyond busy: the subway and the crosstown bus shuttle students to school, deliver staff to hospitals nearby and take locals home from Lincoln Center. A few blocks east, residents of apartments, town houses and tenements suffer equally from the Second Avenue subway project. Closer to Central Park, the atmosphere quiets, and the streets are rich with cultural and architectural history.

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole in a Rental War
text: On a Sunday night not long ago, my roommate and I were sitting in our apartment in Harlem when we were interrupted by frantic knocking. We opened the door to find our upstairs neighbor standing there, a pink notice in her hand.

headline: Vows: Marguerite and Sean
text: When Sean Anderson heard Marguerite Daniels was a good cook, he invited himself over for Singaporean chili crab. He got more than he bargained for when her cat was sick on their very first date.

headline: U.S. Cancels Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A ceremony in which the American military had planned to hand over full control of the Bagram Prison to Afghanistan was canceled Saturday, throwing into doubt an agreement between the two countries on custody of the remaining Afghan prisoners still being held by American forces.

headline: The Orthodox Fringe
text: At age 6, he was a budding yeshiva student, in white shirt and black hat, with little contact outside the Orthodox Jewish world. At 16, he discovered some things he liked better, punk rock and drugs: marijuana, LSD, eventually crack and heroin. At 26, on the Thursday before the holiday of Purim last month, he was back among the faithful, sort of: side curls flailing, knees jackknifing up around his torso, leaping, crouching, shouting a Scriptural message from the Book of Ramones: “Avraham was a punk rocker.”

headline: Is It Safe to Cross?
text: On a Friday afternoon last month, Martha Atwater went to buy cookies at a bagel shop on Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street in Brooklyn and was struck by a Honda sport utility vehicle that careered onto the sidewalk as she was leaving. According to the Police Department, the driver, John McKinney, lost control when he experienced a blackout related to diabetes. By the time Ms. Atwater was taken to Long Island College Hospital around the block, she was dead, leaving behind a husband, two young daughters and a closely bound community of mourners in Brooklyn Heights, where she had been a vibrant presence.

headline: Thousands Say Farewell to Chávez
text: The death of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela prompted a mass outpouring of grief at his funeral, which also attracted dignitaries from around the world.

headline: A Jewel in Albany Regains Its Luster
text: ALBANY — The Capitol Building here has always been as much a symbol as a building. Soaring, ornate and hand-built over a 32-year span during the industrial heyday of the late 19th century, the Capitol was a testament to the state’s architectural might and the moxie of New Yorkers and their government. It also, of course, spoke to the tendency, sometimes still in evidence, to overspend and procrastinate on big projects. The Capitol’s $25 million price tag, a figure that translates to more than half a billion dollars today, made it one of the most expensive public-works projects in the nation’s history.

headline: Blasts Hit Afghanistan After Arrival of Hagel
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bomber wearing a vest packed with explosives struck outside the Afghan Defense Ministry on Saturday, killing at least 10 people in a blast just hours after Chuck Hagel, the new United States defense secretary, arrived here.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: LONG WEEKENDS Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Edmund Goulding’s “Grand Hotel” (1932), about guests linked by varying forms of desperation at a luxurious Berlin hotel — where, a resident complains, life is “always the same. People come, people go. Nothing ever happens” — is required viewing. Among the reasons: The pioneering use of ensemble star power (Greta Garbo, John and Lionel Barrymore, Wallace Beery and Joan Crawford), promoted by the MGM studio as “the greatest cast ever assembled.” And the words “I want to be alone,” the signature line of the fading, suicidal ballerina played by Garbo, which became synonymous with the mysterious image of the actress throughout her life. “Week-End at the Waldorf,” the 1945 “Grand Hotel” remake starring Ginger Rogers and Walter Pidgeon, above, follows at 10.

headline: United States Can’t Recover After Dickey Struggles Early
text: PHOENIX — R. A. Dickey pitched for the United States at the 1996 Olympics, winning both his starts. Yet he left with a bronze medal and a lingering sense of what could have been.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 9
text: NEWS The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible. David Kirkpatrick reports from Sawran, Syria.

headline: Video of Police Beating in Fiji Prompts Ire
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The nine minutes of shaky cellphone footage are hard to watch, not because of the quality but because of the content. A young man lies handcuffed on the bed of a pickup truck, wailing as he is beaten repeatedly with a thick baton. Later, his assailant switches to a metal rod. A snarling dog drags another victim past his laughing attackers, who punch the man relentlessly.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Punjab:  Ram Singh, a national level boxer, has told the police that he and Vijender Singh, a 2008 Olympics bronze medal-winning boxer, bought heroin from a drug dealer who was arrested near Chandigarh, Punjab, last week, NDTV reported. The interrogation was part of the drug bust that led to the seizure of 26-kilograms of drugs worth 1.3 billion rupees, or $23 million.

headline: The Weekend Word: School Supplies
text: Today’s Times

headline: As Crisis Deepens in Egypt After Ruling on Riot, Calls for a Military Coup
text: PORT SAID, Egypt — Just months ago, demonstrators here and around Egypt were chanting for the end of military rule. But on Saturday, as a court ruling about a soccer riot set off angry mobs, many in the crowd here declared they now believed that a military coup might be the best hope to restore order.

headline: Never Too Many ‘I Love You’s’ for This Couple
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Kenyatta Is Declared the Victor in Kenya, but Opponent Plans to Appeal
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s election commission on Saturday declared Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president and one of the prime suspects in a case involving crimes against humanity, to be the winner of the country’s presidential race amid growing allegations of vote fraud and a refusal by the other leading contender to concede.

headline: Gone Deficit Gone
text: So says the CBO, although not directly.

headline: The English Prisoner
text: “If this plan is working, what would a failing one look like?” So asks Martin Wolf in response to David Cameron’s speech insisting that his austerity policy was right, is right, and is succeeding. Simon Wren-Lewis goes through Cameron’s assertions in some detail, among other things catching him more or less lying about what the Office of Budget Responsibility — roughly speaking the counterpart of the CBO here — ha actually said about the impact of austerity on growth.

headline: Attack on Christians Follows Claim of Blasphemy in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An enraged Muslim crowd attacked a Christian neighborhood in Lahore on Saturday, setting fire to more than 150 houses and 2 churches, in a new display of religious intolerance as Pakistan reels from violent persecution against other minorities.

headline: For Some, Owning Guns Doesn’t Necessarily Mean Liking Them
text: The national debate over firearms regulation is often presented as a battle of extremes: those who view any effort to tighten gun laws as an infringement of rights versus those who see guns as a menace to society.

headline: Unforced Error Is Unloved Statistic Among Tennis Players
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The term unforced error has become a staple of the popular vernacular since its introduction in tennis three decades ago. And though the phrase is still largely identified with the sport, players and coaches have little regard for the statistic. Nor do they care much for the statistical identification of shots as winners or unforced errors, considering them misleading reflections of the flow of a match.

headline: High Tension on the Mountain
text: I was suspended 40 feet in the air on a broken chairlift for 80 bitterly cold minutes last month. My brother-in-law and I had been riding up Mount Snow in Vermont, looking forward to a morning on the slopes without our children, when the lift’s steel cable slipped off its track.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: Getting Started
text: SPECIAL POST — The buzz of excitement begins as you stroll down the hallway outside the ballroom. On Saturday at the A.C.P.T., the Market is home to vendors of all sorts of puzzle-related products, including The New York Times, which is giving away pencils, pens and stickers, as well as a raffle to win one of the New York Times puzzle cookie jars. Those who have filled their arms with puzzle swag mill into the ballroom and find a strategic seat behind one of the many yellow barriers placed around contestants to guard their answers.

headline: Rowdiness Becomes a Business Strategy for the Tour
text: DORAL, Fla. — A color depiction of how the Doral Resort’s Blue Monster will look, post-op, was spread before Donald J. Trump, who could not contain his excitement as he outlined all the spots where the countess of courses will go under the architect’s bulldozer shortly after Sunday’s conclusion of the Cadillac Championship.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: As Big East Basketball Tournament Fades, a Block Remains Fresh
text: The game ended 27 years ago, half a lifetime ago, a few pounds ago, yet Dwayne Washington, known to all as Pearl, cannot forget. He will not forget. It still hurts, still stings, the way his Big East career ended, at the 1986 conference tournament finale, in the final seconds.

headline: Rebels in Syria Release U.N. Peacekeepers to Jordan, Easing Crisis in Border Zone
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Syrian rebels released 21 detained United Nations peacekeepers to Jordanian forces on Saturday, ending a three-day standoff that raised new tensions in the region and new questions about the fighters just as the United States and other nations were grappling over whether to allow more arms to flow to the rebel movement.

headline: Variety: A Timely Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The author of today’s quote is someone to admire, in my opinion. Nina Berberova was a published writer who chronicled the lives of Russian émigrés in Europe, and while this alone was an accomplishment for a woman of her time, she also made some very brave life choices. Ms. Berberova had a spirit and level of self-awareness that I find intriguing. Here is another quote from the same book that sparked today’s puzzle:

headline: U.S. Again Delays Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan Forces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The promised American transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan control collapsed once again on Saturday amid misunderstandings and recriminations between the two allies, punctuated by a deadly bombing outside the Afghan Defense Ministry.

headline: Snow in Colorado. Really?
text: If you happen to be a member of Costa Rica’s national team preparing for the World Cup qualifying match against the United States that will be played outside Denver in less than two weeks, a glance at Saturday’s weather forecast for the area might fill you with dread.

headline: At 43, Yankees’ Rivera Confirms That He’ll Retire in Fall
text: For much of the past 18 years, the Yankees have relied on Mariano Rivera to pitch in the late innings with games on the line.

headline: Yahoo’s Next Big Play: South by Southwest
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A quick spin through the South by Southwest lineup reveals the usual suspects: young start-ups vying to become the next big thing, up-and-coming musical acts, talks by Internet luminaries, and technology meet-ups on topics as varied as learning how to be an angel investor and workshops in 3-D printing.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Science and Politics
text: Is anti-science sentiment threatening public health policy?

headline: China Says It Won’t Forsake North Korea, Despite Support for U.N. Sanctions
text: BEIJING — China’s foreign minister said Saturday that Beijing would not abandon North Korea, reiterating China’s longstanding position that dialogue, not sanctions, is the best way to persuade the North to abandon its nuclear weapons.

headline: Dutch Seek to Extend Their Record of Upsets
text: TOKYO — The Netherlands quietly took batting practice at Tokyo Dome on Saturday. Its sluggers, in orange jerseys and caps, casually peppered balls into the blue seats in left, seemingly unaware that their team was once again sending shock waves through the baseball world.

headline: What Hath Rand Paul Wrought?
text: THE Republican Party built an advantage on foreign policy across generations, and then began demolishing it 10 years ago this month. What the cold war made, the invasion of Iraq largely unmade: beginning in 2003, a party that had long promised — and mostly delivered — peace through strength became identified with an intelligence fiasco, a botched occupation and the squandering of American resources, credibility and lives.

headline: Nets Make Full Effort to Fit Into Brooklyn
text: When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Nets, who invested heavily in putting together a winning team in their first season since their move from New Jersey, the pressure created by the team’s owner Mikhail Prokhorov has seemingly distracted from what has otherwise been a successful move for both the Nets and Brooklyn.

headline: After Rancorous Debate, Colorado Senate Advances Strict New Measures on Gun Control
text: DENVER — Colorado took a major step late Friday toward enacting some of the toughest new gun measures that have been introduced since the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut touched off a national debate about gun control.

headline: No to Keystone. Yes to Crazy.
text: I HOPE the president turns down the Keystone XL oil pipeline. (Who wants the U.S. to facilitate the dirtiest extraction of the dirtiest crude from tar sands in Canada’s far north?) But I don’t think he will. So I hope that Bill McKibben and his 350.org coalition go crazy. I’m talking chain-themselves-to-the-White-House-fence-stop-traffic-at-the-Capitol kind of crazy, because I think if we all make enough noise about this, we might be able to trade a lousy Keystone pipeline for some really good systemic responses to climate change. We don’t get such an opportunity often — namely, a second-term Democratic president who is under heavy pressure to approve a pipeline to create some jobs but who also has a green base that he can’t ignore. So cue up the protests, and pay no attention to people counseling rational and mature behavior. We need the president to be able to say to the G.O.P. oil lobby, “I’m going to approve this, but it will kill me with my base. Sasha and Malia won’t even be talking to me, so I’ve got to get something really big in return.”

headline: As Time Goes Bye
text: AUSPICIOUS my debut at Time was not.

headline: Calmness of Seattle Inspires Second Chances
text: PEORIA, Ariz.

headline: Geraldine Knatz
text: Geraldine Knatz is executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, the nation’s busiest. Encompassing 7,500 acres on 43 miles of waterfront, the port handled more than $273 billion in cargo last year and is responsible for 3 million jobs.

headline: The Dow Jones Emotional Average
text: The Dow Jones closed at a record high last week, leaving investors both richer and further perplexed by a market that continues to exhibit textbook signs of bipolar personality disorder. Herewith, a psycho-diary chronicling the many moods of the Dow Jones.

headline: A Presto, Change-O Opening Night at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Magic was on the streets and on the screen here in Austin on Friday at the opening night of the South by Southwest film festival. This year’s selection, “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone,” featured a starry cast in telling its story about a Vegas-performing magic duo (Steve Carell and Steve Buscemi) and a new kind of magician (Jim Carrey) who threatens to steal their thunder. Olivia Wilde also stars as a magician’s assistant aspiring to be a bigger part of the act.

headline: Yankees Counting Injuries and Pennies
text: These are not George Steinbrenner’s Yankees. Several injuries in spring training, and the team’s response to them, have served to drive home that point.

headline: At Global Showcase, a Blowout and a Brawl
text: PHOENIX — When players stand on the baselines before games in the World Baseball Classic, they hold caps from their countries to exchange with members of the other team. That spirit of good will crumbled Saturday under a tangled pile of players from Canada and Mexico.

headline: Of Fraud and Filet
text: THERE are many lessons a person might rightly or wrongly divine from the horse meat scare in Europe, including this: You should perhaps think twice before buying meatballs from a furniture purveyor, unless those meatballs are humongous and nonperishable, and double as ottomans.

headline: Fan Sees Rivera’s Retirement as the Start of His Own Goodbye to Baseball
text: Watching Mariano Rivera on Saturday announce his plan to retire at the end of the season, after nearly two decades with the New York Yankees, David Quinones said that an era was drawing to a close — not just for Rivera or the sport he so thoroughly dominated, but also for Mr. Quinones’s life as a fan.

headline: The Liberals Against Affirmative Action
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Gun Report: March 9, 2013
text: After Roger Hartley lost his friend Mark Hummels to gun violence in January, he realized Hummels was the ninth person he knew who’d been killed or injured by a gun. So he posed a question to his Facebook friends: “How many people have you known who’ve been the victims of gun violence? Suicide, accidental, murder. No politics. No judgment. Just a number.”

headline: Los Angeles Frets After Low Turnout to Elect Mayor
text: LOS ANGELES — The roughly $19 million spent in the 2013 mayoral primary here made it the most expensive on record. But that is not the number that has people agog. Just 21 percent of registered voters turned out for last week’s election — the lowest rate for a primary without an incumbent since at least 1978.

headline: Don’t Be Afraid of Genetic Modification
text: IF patience is a virtue, then AquaBounty, a Massachusetts biotech company, might be the most virtuous entity on the planet.

headline: Chicago’s Blistering Pace Punctuates Whirlwind First Half
text: How short is this lockout-abbreviated N.H.L. season? After seven weeks, it is half over, and the homestretch is about to begin. Here is a look at the best and worst of the 48-game schedule so far, and what to look for in the second half.

headline: eToys vs. Goldman Sachs: The Documents
text: The following are a selection of documents that are part of the litigation between eToys creditors and Goldman Sachs over the 1999 eToys IPO.

headline:
How a U.S.
    Citizen Came to
    Be in America’s
    Cross Hairs
text: WASHINGTON — One morning in late September 2011, a group of American drones took off from an airstrip the C.I.A. had built in the remote southern expanse of Saudi Arabia. The drones crossed the border into Yemen, and were soon hovering over a group of trucks clustered in a desert patch of Jawf Province, a region of the impoverished country once renowned for breeding Arabian horses.

headline: Rigging the I.P.O. Game
text: ONCE upon a time, in a very different age, an Internet start-up called eToys went public. The date was May 20, 1999. The offering price had been set at $20, but investors in that frenzied era were so eager for eToys shares that the stock immediately shot up to $78. It ended its first day of trading at $77 a share.

headline: Student Debt and the Economy
text: The student loan debt crisis has become a drag on the economy. Younger Americans who are saddled with bankrupting payments — or credit ratings damaged by delinquency — are in no position to buy homes, save for retirement or start businesses.

headline: Putting Corporate Cash to Work
text: What should successful companies do with their growing piles of cash? Apple, which has $140 billion on hand, is being forced to address this question by one of its prominent shareholders.

headline: Malaysia Detains 79 in Fight Against Filipinos
text: MANILA — Malaysian authorities announced Saturday that they had detained 79 people they suspected of being sympathizers of Filipino fighters who recently landed on Borneo in an attempt to re-establish a historic claim to part of the island.

headline: The Right to Counsel: Badly Battered at 50
text: A half-century ago, the Supreme Court ruled that anyone too poor to hire a lawyer must be provided one free in any criminal case involving a felony charge. The holding in Gideon v. Wainwright enlarged the Constitution’s safeguards of liberty and equality, finding the right to counsel “fundamental.” The goal was “fair trials before impartial tribunals in which every defendant stands equal before the law.”

headline: Birth Culture
text: Cultural expectations and practices of birth vary around the world.

headline: Living With Less. A Lot Less.
text: I LIVE in a 420-square-foot studio. I sleep in a bed that folds down from the wall. I have six dress shirts. I have 10 shallow bowls that I use for salads and main dishes. When people come over for dinner, I pull out my extendable dining room table. I don’t have a single CD or DVD and I have 10 percent of the books I once did.

headline: The Danger of Suppressing the Leaks
text: IMAGINE if American citizens never learned about the abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib. Imagine not knowing about the brutal treatment of terror suspects at United States government “black sites.” Or about the drone program that is expanding under President Obama, or the Bush administration’s warrantless wiretapping of Americans.

headline: Life’s Unequal Beginnings
text: FOR the past six years I have been photographing birth, looking at its universal as well as cultural aspects, and the struggle to provide women with safe, respectful care. An estimated quarter of a million women die each year from pregnancy-related causes like pre-eclampsia. Though the number of women who die in pregnancy or childbirth is half what it was 20 years ago, most of these deaths could have been prevented.

headline: Big East Memories: When the Huskies Were Pups
text: Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories.

headline: Repeal the Military Force Law
text: Three days after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, Congress approved the Authorization for Use of Military Force. It was enacted with good intentions — to give President George W. Bush the authority to invade Afghanistan and go after Al Qaeda and the Taliban rulers who sheltered and aided the terrorists who had attacked the United States.

headline: Getting Stuff Done: It’s a Goal, and a Rating System
text: This interview with  Kris Duggan, C.E.O. and a co-founder of Badgeville, which designs game-based programs for businesses, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Revolution Will Be Tweeted!
text: IN the pantheon of world leaders who have embraced 140-character communication, Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s late president, neared the top. Since he first logged on to Twitter three years ago, President Chávez out-tweeted many of his peers with an average of 12 messages each week, nearly all from a BlackBerry. He had more than four million followers and was the second most followed leader on Twitter, after President Obama, whom Mr. Chávez once called a “clown.” In a tweet, Mr. Chávez decried both Mr. Obama and his “gringo imperialist government.”

text: SANIBEL, Fla.

text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, has signed his name to a fund-raising letter for Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor, highlighting how closely the campaign will work with a figure who has, at times, polarized the city’s political world.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: In the Beginning
text: SPECIAL POST — Puzzle 4 has just started, and the big news at the end of puzzle 3 is that computer solver Dr. Fill finished with a mistake. That surely will not help him in his quest to beat reigning champion Dan Feyer.

headline: Keep Calm and Carry On... Buying
text: OUR fully automated, meme-conscious information economy might seem a paradise of reason and rationality. But it also has a seamier, surreal side. Just consider how the phrase “Keep Calm and Rape a Lot” came to appear on T-shirts sold on Amazon.co.uk.

headline: Insomnia and the Poet
text: Insomnia is never far from my thoughts, especially when I am writing. A poor sleeper even as a girl, I spent many nights scribbling diary entries in a notebook on the bathroom floor after our crowded household had gone to bed. As an adult, with three spirited children and a full-time job, I often sought the desk in the wee hours by necessity. Those liminal hours between dark and dawn continue to haunt my praxis even now that my nest is empty. At night the smallest noises, including the surprising veracity of my own breathing, are more apparent and seem to command an acute attention. For me, there is nothing as inimitably private and attuned as nocturnal writing. As I type away at this piece, for example, I find myself grateful that a lifelong habit of insomnia churned me awake at 5 a.m. from my usual choppy spell of semiconsciousness, affording at least a couple of deliciously quiet hours to think and work before even the dog will rouse and the winter windows lighten.

headline: When Customer Service Isn’t Even Half-Baked
text: SOME companies resolve consumer complaints in ways that are both efficient and empathetic, demonstrating not just a grasp of what defines good service but also the ways that brand loyalty is nurtured. Then there is Whirlpool.

text: Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories.

headline: Corralling Mobsters, if Not Many Big Banks
text: EVERYONE knows about the mobsters and terrorists that Mary Jo White successfully put behind bars during her nine years as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Less well-known is Ms. White’s record bringing cases against large financial institutions during her stint as the top criminal prosecutor in New York.

headline: Big East Memories: 6 Overtimes, 1 Memorable Night
text: When I think of the six-overtime Big East tournament quarterfinal between Syracuse and Connecticut that began on March 12, 2009, and ended March 13, I think of Jonny Flynn.

headline: Trained by a Life of Change
text: DURING my earliest years, my father was in the Army and I often spent time with my grandparents, who farmed cotton and raised tobacco in rural Georgia. Later, my father and mother settled in Swainsboro, Ga., where my brother, seven years younger than me, was born.

headline: Yes, We’re Confident, but Who Knows Why
text: THE recovery in housing, the stock market and the overall economy has finally gained sustainable momentum — or so it is said.

headline: 30 Seconds With Stephane Matteau
text: For Rangers fans, Stephane Matteau’s goal in double overtime in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils is a sweet memory. The Rangers went on to defeat the Vancouver Canucks for the Stanley Cup.

headline: A Billion Years of Time and Toil Are Etched in These Old Hills
text: Here’s a musical post honoring a classic March transition in the Hudson Valley from a blast of snow on Friday to a blaze of sunshine and hint of spring today. The sap is running strong in the sugar maples, guaranteeing good times at the “sap to syrup” festivals tomorrow at the Taconic Outdoor Education Center in Fahnestock State Park and on March 24 at Little Stony Point Park, where visitors will likely hear Pete Seeger sing about “maple syrup time.”

headline: N.Y.U.’s Global Leader Is Tested by Faculty at Home
text: Embarking on an ambitious expansion at home, constructing a network of new campuses around the globe, wooing intellectual superstars and raising vast amounts of money, John Sexton of New York University is the very model of a modern university president — the leader of a large corporation, pushing for growth on every front.

headline: Joining the Bandwagon? Don’t Lose Your Balance
text: STOCKS are back. And that could be dangerous.

headline: Online Emotions, in Hundreds of New Flavors
text: TO say that I like to send text messages is like saying Garfield likes lasagna. It is my expressive medium. On Wednesday alone, I sent at least 100 — but I like to send more than just words. I’m a big fan of using emoji, the colorful symbol alphabet that contains nearly a thousand images of cute animals, food items and expressive smiley faces to convey what words cannot.

headline: The Price of Marriage in China
text: FROM her stakeout near the entrance of an H & M store in Joy City, a Beijing shopping mall, Yang Jing seemed lost in thought, twirling a strand of her auburn-tinted hair, tapping her nails on an aquamarine iPhone 4S. But her eyes kept moving. They tracked the clusters of young women zigzagging from Zara to Calvin Klein Jeans. They lingered on a face, a gesture, and then moved on, darting across the atrium, searching.

headline: The Two Venezuelas
text: Claudia Astor and her mother, Norma Astor, were on opposite sides of Venezuela’s political divide as they watched Hugo Chávez’s funeral on their television in Caracas.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: Puzzle 3 Shake Out
text: SPECIAL POST — Six puzzles are part of A.C.P.T. lore now, and with three judged and scanned, there are new standings to report.

headline: Condensation
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I hope you all brought towels, or at least a raincoat. We’re going to get wet today, but depending on how you feel about rebus puzzles, that will either make you feel happy or extremely frustrated. Let’s just say that there is no danger that anyone will CATCH FIRE around this grid.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 10
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida made headlines in the past week after acknowledging he would be open to a run for the White House in 2016. But the renewed attention on Mr. Bush has been mixed. His book on immigration reform is dividing a Republican Party that is trying to connect with Latino voters. Mr. Bush is doing damage control, and will be featured on almost all of this week’s Sunday shows.

headline: The Leading Liberal Against Affirmative Action
text: My Capital Ideas column this week looks at liberals who would see some upsides if the Supreme Court made substantial changes to affirmative-action programs. The justices heard arguments in such a case in October — Fisher v. the University of Texas — and are expected to issue their decision between March 18 and late June.

headline: Buying High and Selling Low
text: Over the long term, investors in equity mutual funds have underperformed the S.&.P. 500.

headline: Venezuelan Election Set for April
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela will hold a special election on April 14 to choose a new president to complete the term of Hugo Chávez, the charismatic socialist who died last week after a battle with cancer.

headline: Homegrown Talent at This Year’s SXSW
text: After last year’s South by Southwest, talk focused largely on a pair of superstars. It’s not every day that Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band and Jay-Z drop into Texas to play relatively intimate venues. Meanwhile, nearly 2,000 other acts were showcased, including Fun., Ed Sheeran and the Lumineers, who all went from being virtual unknowns to Grammy performers just 10 months later.

headline: Step on Toes in Austin, and You Might Get a Slap
text: Only the brave and the foolish go against the legislative pack — even when they are on the side of the angels.

headline: Declared Innocent in a Killing, but Still in a Cell
text: TENNESSEE COLONY, Tex. — In 2008, Ben Spencer’s family bought him clothes in preparation for a day they had prayed for since 1987. A Dallas County judge had declared Mr. Spencer innocent of the robbery and killing that sent him to prison for life.

headline: Recipe for Divided Europe: Add Horse, Then Stir
text: OLOMOUC, Czech Republic — For Zuzana Navelkova, it was just another day at the office. She showed up for work last month and found a two-pound bag of frozen Swedish meatballs awaiting her attention.

headline: U.T.-El Paso President Still Making Waves
text: Days after Diana Natalicio became president of the University of Texas at El Paso in 1988, the first woman to hold that job, a local newspaper ran an illustration of her as Wonder Woman. As she begins her 26th year at the helm — the longest tenure at the head of a Texas public university among current presidents — that depiction remains apt.

headline: Power Struggle on Reforming Vatican Bank
text: VATICAN CITY — Negotiations over the Vatican’s adherence to international banking standards were reaching a delicate point. During a lunch, a European official later recalled, discussion turned to the need for more openness from an institution steeped in centuries of secrecy.

headline: Grandmaster Draws Persist, but So Do Fights to the End
text: Grandmaster draws, the scourge of competition, are unfortunately alive and well.

headline: In Public Eye, Shining Star of Myanmar Loses Luster
text: YANGON, Myanmar — She endured years of house arrest and was steadfast as her political movement was decimated and her colleagues were tortured. But now, as the leader of Myanmar’s opposition in Parliament, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate, is courting her former jailers.

headline: On Questioning the Jewish State
text: I was raised in a religious Jewish environment, and though we were not strongly Zionist, I always took it to be self-evident that “Israel has a right to exist.” Now anyone who has debated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will have encountered this phrase often. Defenders of Israeli policies routinely accuse Israel’s critics of denying her right to exist, while the critics (outside of a small group on the left, where I now find myself) bend over backward to insist that, despite their criticisms, of course they affirm it. The general mainstream consensus seems to be that to deny Israel’s right to exist is a clear indication of anti-Semitism (a charge Jews like myself are not immune to), and therefore not an option for people of conscience.

headline: Neighborhoods Seek to Banish Sex Offenders by Building Parks
text: LOS ANGELES — Parents who pick up their children at the bus stop in this city’s Harbor Gateway neighborhood say they often see men wearing GPS ankle bracelets and tell their children to stay away. Just up the street, 30 paroled sex offenders live in a single apartment building, including rapists and child molesters. More than 100 registered sex offenders live within a few miles.

headline: Moshiach Oi! Performs
text: The city’s top and perhaps only Hasidic hardcore band, Moshiach Oi!, plays to a group at a Brooklyn community center.

headline: Jeter Makes His Debut
text: TAMPA — Derek Jeter returned to game action Saturday for the first time since he broke his ankle in the 12th inning of Game 1 of the American League Championship Series, and it went well.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Competition Heats Up
text: SPECIAL POST — After a particularly devilish puzzle 5 by Patrick Blindauer and a somewhat easier puzzle 6, the top three contenders for the finals are still Dan Feyer, Tyler Hinman, and Anne Erdmann. Francis Heaney is in 4th place and Stella Zawistowski and Kiran Kedlaya are tied for 5th place. The puzzle by Mr. Blindauer is the one that everyone seems to be talking about, and with good cause: puzzle 5 at the A.C.P.T. is notoriously the most difficult solve of the entire tournament. I apologize for not being able to share more about the puzzles, but all details are secret until those solving by mail and online are finished.

headline: Stoudemire Is Out Six Weeks for Knee Operation
text: Knicks forward Amar’e Stoudemire will have surgery on his right knee and is expected to miss six weeks, the team announced Saturday.

headline: With No Tears, Rivera Confirms That This Season Will Be His Last
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Throughout what could have been a highly emotional day, from the morning news conference to the first strains of “Enter Sandman” and the two standing ovations he received from the crowd at a sold-out stadium, Mariano Rivera never shed a tear, at least not publicly.

headline: Newspaper Adds New Obstacle to Tribunal Investigating Lebanese Official’s Death
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The first shock came when a leading Lebanese newspaper published a confidential list of 17 witnesses who may testify in the murder trial of a former prime minister — showing their names, passport pictures, dates of birth and where they work.

headline: Savoring Parting Shots of a Rivalry, the Hoyas Overpower the Orange
text: WASHINGTON — The curtain came down with a thud on one of college basketball’s most storied rivalries Saturday as No. 5 Georgetown trounced No. 17 Syracuse, 61-39, in the final regular-season meeting between the teams before the Orange leave the Big East.

headline: Before a Falklands Vote, Bad Blood Surges Anew
text: LONDON — On Sunday and Monday, the inhabitants of the Falkland Islands, a wind-swept, sparsely populated archipelago that was a final way station for early 20th-century explorers like Ernest Shackleton en route to the icy wastes of Antarctica, will go to the polls in a referendum on the islands’ future.

headline: Menachem Froman, Rabbi Seeking Peace, Dies at 68
text: Menachem Froman, a maverick Orthodox rabbi who helped lead settlers into the territory seized by Israel in its 1967 war with Arab nations, then became a fervent, startlingly unconventional voice for conciliation with the Palestinians, died on Monday in Tekoa in the Israeli-administrated West Bank. He was 68.

headline: Unrelenting Woods Stands Apart, With Field Struggling to Stay in Touch
text: DORAL, Fla. — It would have been easier on Saturday for Graeme McDowell to reel in a marlin off the coast of Florida than Tiger Woods at the Blue Monster. McDowell began the day two strokes behind Woods in the Cadillac Championship, and after playing the front nine in 32 strokes, equaling the low start of the day, he was still one shot behind.

headline: Dirk Coetzee, South African Official Who Led Apartheid-Era Killings, Dies at 67
text: Dirk Coetzee, who led a South African police hit squad that killed antiapartheid activists, and who eventually confessed to his crimes as his country began shifting away from official racial segregation, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Pretoria. He was 67.

headline: Police Shoot Man During a Traffic Stop on Staten Island
text: A police officer shot a man in the torso as he tried to flee during a traffic stop on Staten Island on Saturday, the police said. The man, who was not immediately identified, appeared to have reached for a weapon, the authorities said.

headline: Santana Misses Workout, but Mets Play It Down
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana did not work out with his teammates Saturday morning. Instead, he remained indoors to stretch his arm and receive extra treatment on it.

headline: Den Dekker Comes Up With Another Highlight in Center
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt den Dekker, a Mets minor league center fielder who has already compiled a substantial highlight reel of athletic and improbable catches, made another spectacular catch Saturday.

headline: Threats Sow Concerns Over Korean Armistice
text: North Korea’s latest threats to annihilate its enemies have included a vow to scrap the 1953 armistice, the main legal document that theoretically stands in the way of a resumption of the Korean War, a conflict that by some estimates left nearly five million people dead, including more than 33,700 American soldiers.

headline: Corrections: March 10, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Kings Point, a Magic Kingdom for the Retirement Set
text: I loved my mom very much, but never looked forward to visiting her at Kings Point, a huge, gated retirement community in Delray Beach, Fla.

headline: Too Young to Retire, but These Deals Can’t Wait
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Susan Shapira, who is 58, recently moved into a condominium in Century Village, a gated retirement community here where most residents are almost as old as the name.

headline: Share of Homes With Guns Shows 4-Decade Decline
text: The share of American households with guns has declined over the past four decades, a national survey shows, with some of the most surprising drops in the South and the Western mountain states, where guns are deeply embedded in the culture.

headline: Stoudemire Needs Operation on What Was His Good Knee
text: Amar’e Stoudemire made his season debut for the Knicks on New Year’s Day, and the team embraced his return as a way to breathe fresh life into the roster just as their sensational start began looking more serious.

headline: No Barrage by Williams, but Success Is the Same
text: ATLANTA — One night after his 3-point bonanza, Deron Williams gave the nets a break. He did not try to replicate his record night from beyond the arc, but instead controlled the pace offensively and defensively against one of the fastest teams in the Eastern Conference. Williams was the point guard, not the shooting guard, and his floor game helped make for an impressive 93-80 win over the Atlanta Hawks on Saturday night at Philips Arena.

headline: Harvard Searched E-Mails for Source of Media Leaks
text: Harvard secretly searched the e-mail accounts of several of its staff members last fall, looking for the source of news media leaks about its recent cheating scandal, but did not tell them about the searches for several months, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 10
text: “I would still eat these meatballs. No problem.”

headline: With Loss, Isner Takes a Big Step Down
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — On the court where he had stepped up a year earlier, John Isner stepped down.

headline: Against Puerto Rico, Venezuela Comes Up Short Again
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Luis Sojo arrived in Puerto Rico weeks removed from another championship in a career full of them. Navegantes del Magallanes, the team that Sojo manages in the Venezuelan winter league, took the title over Cardenales de Lara, and Sojo was a central figure. After all, he spent 21 seasons with the Cardenales as a second baseman, collecting five batting titles. In his baseball life, Sojo is intimately familiar with excellence.

headline: Anna Resnick, Ilan Caplan
text: Anna Michelle Resnick, a daughter of Wendy Miller Resnick and Marc A. Resnick of Millersville, Md., is to be married Sunday to Ilan Joseph Caplan, a son of Nancy G. Caplan and Cantor Joel E. Caplan of Caldwell, N.J. The father of the groom, who is the cantor at Congregation Agudath Israel in Caldwell, will officiate at the Grand Lodge of A.F. & A.M. of Maryland, a Masonic lodge in Cockeysville, Md.

headline: Shaina Schallop, Garrett Kamen
text: Shaina Joy Schallop and Garrett Scott Kamen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Michael P. Singer at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla. Cantor Danielle Bensimhon took part in the ceremony.

headline: Alfred Boll and Joost van Hout
text: A Truly International Relationship

headline: Korin Katzen, Neal Cohen
text: Korin Jill Katzen and Neal Jay Cohen were married Saturday evening at the New Synagogue of Fort Lee in Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Meir M. Berger, the synagogue’s spiritual leader, performed the ceremony. On April 20, Dee Shamo, a justice of the peace for Providenciales, in Turks and Caicos, will lead a second ceremony that will also feature Jewish wedding traditions, at the Somerset Resort there.

headline: Alice Wylie and Alexander Schmemann
text: Alice Belle Wylie and Alexander Schmemann were to be married Sunday at St. Nicholas Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Valery Shemchuk, a Russian Orthodox priest, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Virginia Lam and Marc Abrams
text: Meeting Online (Don’t Tell Her Parents)

headline: Meryl Rosen, Roderick Bernstein
text: Meryl Gail Rosen and Roderick Samuel Bernstein were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Cantor Neil Benisvy officiated.

headline: Molly Moran and Mark Synnes
text: Molly June Moran and Mark Andrew Synnes were married Saturday evening at Old St. Patrick’s Church in Chicago. The Rev. Donald J. Fenske, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Anna Glanfield, Michael Hennessy
text: Anna Elizabeth Glanfield, the daughter of Sheila E. Glanfield and Thomas H. Glanfield of Delray Beach, Fla., was married Saturday to Michael Fitzgerald Hennessy, a son of Patricia F. Hennessy and Michael J. Hennessy, both of Vineland, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Amy Rublin, Justin Mayer
text: Amy Deborah Rublin, the daughter of Harriet K. Rublin and Burt M. Rublin of Wynnewood, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Justin David Mayer, a son of Debra Mayer of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Stephen Mayer. Rabbi Joshua Z. Gruenberg officiated at the Four Seasons hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: Talia Davis, Daniel Haykin
text: Small Garden, Big Yield: A Marriage

headline: Rachel Rovner, Adam Rozen
text: Rachel Hilary Rovner and Adam Mark Rozen were married Saturday in Chicago. Rabbi Sidney M. Helbraun officiated at the InterContinental Chicago Magnificent Mile Hotel, assisted by Justice Judith J. Gische of State Supreme Court in New York.

headline: Ann Ricks and Kevin Duffy
text: Dr. Ann Marie Ricks and Kevin John Duffy were married Saturday in Houston. The Rev. Edward Seton Fittin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michael Catholic Church.

headline: Christia Blomquist, Samuel Freedman
text: Christia Chana Blomquist and Samuel G. Freedman are to be married Sunday evening at Columbia University Faculty House in New York. Rabbi Jeremy Kalmanofsky is to officiate with Rabbi Morris Allen taking part.

headline: Toba Goldfein and Yossi Goldstein
text: Toba Gittel Goldfein, the daughter of Dr. Bea H. Goldfein and Rabbi Ephraim Goldfein of Philadelphia, is to be married Sunday to Yossi Goldstein, a son of Seema E. Goldstein and Jacob Z. Goldstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Edelman, the groom’s maternal grandfather, is to officiate at the Springfield Country Club in Springfield, Pa.

headline: Marguerite Daniels, Sean Anderson
text: Marguerite Danita Daniels and Sean Philip Anderson were married Saturday at the Zoellner Arts Center in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Wilson Kratz of the Journeys of the Heart ministries officiated.

headline: Wright’s Slam Gives U.S Life in World Baseball Classic
text: PHOENIX — For an understated star like David Wright, it was a telling display of emotion. Wright had crushed a ball toward the left-field seats at Chase Field, and he skipped — just for a moment — on his first steps out of the batter’s box. He had earned the right to let loose, in his own way.

headline: For Chinese, Maldives Boycott Goes Beyond Instant Noodles
text: BEIJING — Call it, perhaps, a storm in a kettle: A report that an upscale hotel in the Maldives removed kettles from the rooms of travelers from China to stop Chinese guests from cooking instant noodles in their rooms and not dining in hotel restaurant facilities has incited an online uproar here amid allegations of discrimination.

headline: Retirement Central
text: Lured by the affordable price, Susan Shapira, 58, recently moved into a condominium in the Century Village retirement complex in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: 2 Cabinet Agencies Are Cut in Restructuring by China
text: BEIJING — Chinese officials announced Sunday that the government would consolidate some cabinet-level ministries in an attempt to streamline the bureaucracy. The move is the seventh restructuring in three decades, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
text: On this morning. I think we’re talking about horsemeat, or something.

headline: The IMF on the Austerity Trap
text: The IMF has just released a new paper on austerity that is kind of heavy going (unnecessarily, I think), but ends up making a simple but important point.

headline: Attack, Said to Be Drone Strike by U.S., Kills 2 in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Two people suspected of being militants were killed Sunday morning in the volatile North Waziristan tribal region by what Pakistani and Taliban officials said was a drone strike.

headline: Intensive Care
text: Our son was born healthy, large and pink-skinned, with a newborn assessment score of a perfect 10, but an hour after his birth, a nurse told us that something was wrong. He was jaundiced. It was not a typical case of jaundice; his bilirubin levels kept increasing at an alarming rate. I’d only seen him for a few moments — he’d been delivered by C-section, then whisked away for the usual tests and procedures — but now, as I was moved to a recovery room, the doctors couldn’t tell me when I might see my baby again.

headline: With a Tour of the City, Quinn Declares Her Candidacy for Mayor
text: When the bus driver in the Bronx called out her name, Christine C. Quinn did not hesitate. The City Council speaker — and, as of Sunday, official candidate for mayor — bounded up the vehicle’s steps and gave him a warm handshake as passengers, unbothered by the delay, began to applaud.

headline: North Korea and the U.N. Sanctions
