text: Kim Jong-un and Uncle Sam face off.

headline: Inside the Conclave
text: The last few conclaves have been brief, selecting a pope in just a few days. In 2005, Pope Benedict XVI was elected a day after the conclave began.

headline: Myanmar Opposition Leader Vows Party Reform
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s main opposition party ended a congress over the weekend with the party’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, calling for a “good relationship” with the powerful military. She vowed to infuse new blood into the party, which is still recovering from more than two decades of persecution under military rule.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Last Waltz
text: SPECIAL POST — As if a whirlwind weekend of puzzling and late night socializing wasn’t enough, Daylight Savings Time has robbed the solvers of an hour’s sleep. There are more coffee cups on the tables of the ballroom than I remember in recent years.

headline: A Military Mom Goes Back to School
text: On my first day of school I cried, “Mommy, what if they’re all smarter than me?” I wasn’t a first grader. I was a 40-year-old Army wife, a mother of four and a new student.

headline: North Korea Faces Pressure From U.N. on Human Rights
text: GENEVA — Already angry over tougher sanctions imposed last week to punish its nuclear tests, North Korea faces renewed pressure over its human rights record as the United Nations Human Rights Council meets Monday to consider calls for an international inquiry into possible crimes against humanity.

headline: The (Very) Grand Tour
text: Culturati who’ve had enough of art-fair globe-trotting can now move on to music and dance. London’s Royal Opera House and the Ultimate Travel Company offer privileged access to some of the world’s best operas, ballets and symphonies. Each journey begins in London with a performance and private dinner at the Royal Opera House. Then maybe it’s off to St. Petersburg for a show at the Mariinsky Ballet followed by a backstage tour led by the company’s director. Past trips have included V.I.P. treatment at the Salzburg Easter Festival in Austria, a visit to ballet schools, lectures, private concerts and a chance to meet virtuosos like the South African tenor Johan Botha. From $4,640 per person; theultimatetravelcompany.co.uk/roh.

headline: Attack of the Trust Fund Zombie
text: So, I’ve Stephanopoulized, along with Senator Ron Johnson, who began by declaring that we need to agree about the facts — then promptly rolled out the old trust fund zombie. I’ve explained this one over and over again, for example here. And I have to say, it’s extremely telling that conservative Republicans don’t seem able to make their case without resorting, right from the beginning, to obviously dumb fallacies.

headline: Police Kill 16-Year-Old They Say Pointed a Handgun
text: Two plainclothes police officers shot and killed a teenage boy late Saturday night on a Brooklyn street, after he pointed a handgun at the officers, the police said.

headline: At a Neighborhood Church in Rome, Dolan Delivers a Star Turn
text: ROME — There was no mistaking the fact that a dignitary was coming to Mass in Monte Mario on Sunday.

headline: Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette
text: Some people are so rude. Really, who sends an e-mail or text message that just says “Thank you”? Who leaves a voice mail message when you don’t answer, rather than texting you? Who asks for a fact easily found on Google?

headline: Icon of Harlem’s Gay Night Life Gives Way to Wreckers
text: A block in Harlem that once resonated to the sounds of some of America’s top musicians has, in recent weeks, heard nothing more than the mournful rasp of hydraulic shears and a hydraulic excavator clawing away the remains of a century-old entertainment complex.

headline: Afghan Leader Says U.S. Abets Taliban’s Goal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai leveled particularly harsh accusations against the United States on Sunday, suggesting that the Americans and the Taliban had a common goal in destabilizing his country. The comments cast a shadow on the first visit by Chuck Hagel as defense secretary.

headline: ‘Oz the Great and Powerful’ Has Big Opening
text: LOS ANGELES — It was gridlock on the yellow brick road over the weekend as “Oz the Great and Powerful,” backed by a megawatt marketing campaign, took in about $80.3 million in North America and $69.9 million overseas.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) ARMY WIVES Brooke Shields, playing Air Force Col. Katherine Young; Torrey DeVitto as Maggie Hall, a former airborne soldier with three deployments in Iraq turned housewife; and Ashanti (above right, with Catherine Bell, left, and Sally Pressman), portraying Latasha Montclair, a mother of three with a deployed husband, are among those joining the cast in this Season 7 opener, which finds Fort Marshall mourning the loss of one of its own. In the Season 2 premiere of “The Client List,” at 10, trust becomes an issue for Riley (Jennifer Love Hewitt), who finds that even those she believes she can count on harbor their own secrets.

headline: How Grindr Is Changing the Way We Connect
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — It is easy to write off Grindr — a location-based dating application for gay men — as a hookup application because, well, that is what it is.

headline: For One Night, Sequester Becomes a Punch Line
text: President Obama has indeed brought change to Washington: in exchange for his white-tied presence on Saturday night, he successfully pressured the journalistic elite at the 128-year-old Gridiron Club to shorten its often interminably long annual dinner roast.

headline: Overrun by Crime, Oakland Looks to Make Allies in Community
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Over the next several months, this city just across the bay from San Francisco will be partitioned into five police districts from its current two. The smaller districts, according to a new plan, will each be led by a powerful captain who will be held accountable for crime reduction in regular meetings with the police chief.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Finals
text: SPECIAL POST — The final round of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is actually made up of three rounds: The C Division competitors, the B Division, and, of course, the elite A Division. The puzzle the finalists solve is the same, but the clues that each division receives are different, and if you are lucky enough — and good enough — to make it to the A Division, the clues are not for the faint of heart.

headline: After Cashing In on Job Cuts, Wall St. Looks to Worker Upturn
text: Wall Street is hopeful that American companies, after years of gaining ground at the expense of their employees, will start to succeed because of the rising fortune of those workers.

headline: In Wake of Cyberattacks, China Seeks New Rules
text: SHANGHAI — China has issued a new call for international “rules and cooperation” on Internet espionage issues, while insisting that accusations of Chinese government involvement in recent hacking attacks were part of an international smear campaign.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Found and Jailed in Fraud
text: FRANKFURT — Florian Homm, a flamboyant former hedge fund manager who spent the last five years in hiding, was arrested in Italy and faces extradition to the United States on securities fraud charges which could expose him to a lengthy prison sentence, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

headline: No Sets? No Costumes? No Music? No Problem
text: Contemporary Israeli Dance Week returned on Thursday to the La MaMa Ellen Stewart Theater in the East Village, and the opening-night program of three short dances by Noa Zuk exemplified what New York audiences have come to associate with the words “contemporary Israeli dance.”

headline: Batting Slumber Over, Japan Moves to Semifinals
text: TOKYO — As the jubilant Tokyo Dome crowd roared, Japan’s manager, Koji Yamamoto, stood on the field and raised his arms in triumph amid camera flashes.

headline: Click for Career Enhancement
text: SEATTLE — Anyone who wants to learn calculus, statistics or ancient Greek history can take free online courses in those subjects at a variety of sites from instructors with distinguished academic pedigrees. For more mundane pursuits, like learning how to paddleboard or build a planter box for the garden, there is an inexhaustible supply of free how-to videos on YouTube, eHow and other sites.

headline: Boyle Ends Scoring Drought as Rangers Solve Ovechkin and Capitals
text: WASHINGTON — Brian Boyle shot the puck as he glided backward to the top of the face-off circle, and when it went in at 10 minutes 53 seconds of the second period, he dropped to one knee and joyously windmilled one arm.

headline: Crude
text: Mark Thoma on Jeff Sachs. Also Ryan Cooper. And here’s what happens if you actually read the links from Scarborough-Sachs: you find that what I actually said bears no resemblance to their, ahem, crude caricature of my views.

headline: Progress for Francisco as He Throws Off Mound
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The right-hander Frank Francisco threw off a mound Sunday morning for the first time this spring training.

headline: Vulgarity’s Abrasive Master, but Not at Home
text: When Gilbert Gottfried finds something really funny — like one of his self-deprecating and willfully tasteless jokes — his narrow eyes grow even narrower, he lets out a gruff cackle and buries his face in the palm of his hand.

headline: Voices of a Deadly Blizzard, and Then Some Lullabies
text: On Tuesday evening the Oratorio Society of New York presented a concert of American choral music at Carnegie Hall, built around a new work by Paul Moravec, “The Blizzard Voices.” This oratorio about the “Children’s Blizzard” of 1888 had originally been scheduled to receive its New York premiere last November, but in a case of nature dislodging art imitating nature, that concert was canceled because of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: In Search of Debt Deal, Obama Walks a Narrow Path
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will go to Capitol Hill this week to try to salvage a big deficit-reduction deal, battling not only Republican resistance but also complaints from Democrats that he mishandled his last attempt.

headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Bad Jokes and Puns
text: You’ll roll your eyes constantly during “Clown Bar” — at its groan-worthy puns, its lewd double-entendres and its intentionally bad jokes. But you’ll also laugh quite often. This is a show made for those who enjoy a few winces along with their grins.

headline: Prankish Activity
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — You can practically smell the testosterone in this puzzle, can’t you? This is a manly puzzle for manly men, although anyone can solve it. You just have to know the names of your male animals.

headline: Conversations With Sondheim and His Melodies
text: The pianist Christopher O’Riley’s fascination with the contrapuntal textures of Radiohead songs inspired him to arrange many for keyboard. Art Tatum and Earl Wild were among the pianists to transcribe the works of George Gershwin.

headline: Q. and A. With Ken Griffey Jr.: Star Turn Over, Slugger Is Still Beloved
text: PHOENIX — Ken Griffey Jr. batted .524 with 3 home runs in the first World Baseball Classic in 2006. On Sunday, he and Ferguson Jenkins threw out ceremonial first pitches before the United States played Canada.

headline: From Head to Toe, Quiet Drama Unfolds
text: In “hurry,” the solo that Jean Butler performed at Danspace Project over the weekend, this dancer turned choreographer takes her time. Her feet bare, her long red hair tied up in a ponytail, she bends one knee, then the other. She rotates her shoulders, her hips, her ankles. Many of her precise movements retain the look of a warm-up, of someone working things out.

headline: In Talk Show Tour, Jeb Bush Promotes Book on Immigration and Replies to Critics
text: WASHINGTON — Stoking speculation about his presidential ambitions, Jeb Bush, the Republican former governor of Florida, performed a rare Washington feat on Sunday, appearing on all the morning talk shows as part of a blitz that has become equal parts book promotion and damage control.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Draws On an Original
text: In the five seasons that “Mad Men” has been on television that celebrated series set in the art-directed world of 1960s advertising has never marketed itself the way a ’60s ad man most certainly would have: by calling in a hotshot illustrator to do the job.

headline: Surprise Hit Was a Shock for Artists Heard on It
text: Hector Delgado gave up being a reggaetón artist five years ago to become an evangelical preacher in Puerto Rico. So it was something of a surprise when his former manager, Javier Gómez, called him three weeks ago and said his voice could be clearly heard on “Harlem Shake,” a song that had gone viral on the Internet and then climbed to the top of the pop chart.

headline: An Everywoman? In So Many Ways, No
text: The Nobel Prize-winning Austrian writer Elfriede Jelinek, in an interview in the Yale School of Drama journal Theater with her translator Gitta Honegger, describes how her male colleagues are allowed “to have this subjectivity, this precise, absolutely unmistakable gaze.”

headline: Speaking Rap’s Universal Language in the Ferment of the Arab Spring
text: The international language of hip-hop definitely includes “What’s up, Brooklyn!,” the recurring salutation from the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music during “Mic Check: Hip-Hop From North Africa and the Middle East” on Saturday night. A lineup of Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers, including activists from the Arab Spring, brought songs of protest and self-determination. The concert, which including the United States debuts of El Général from Tunisia and Deeb from Egypt, celebrated a courageous new forthrightness from Middle Eastern rappers. It also showed the pervasiveness of hip-hop, and how it works differently as a catalyst wherever it arrives.

headline: ‘Mic Check’
text: Photos from a concert featuring Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Words That Hurt and Kill: Lessons for Society From Bullying and Its Psychic Toll
text: When Emily Bazelon was in eighth grade, her friends “fired” her. She had loved them; now they rejected her — an act, she recalls, that left her “crawling with insecurity and self-doubt.”

headline: Drilling Earth Seems to Get It Annoyed
text: The cast of “Ring of Fire,” a two-part disaster movie served up by Reelz on Monday and Tuesday, deserves credit for putting some effort into the film rather than sleepwalking through it, as actors often do in these collect-a-paycheck jobs. The script is decent enough too, for the first half. But the closer the world gets to ending, the more wearyingly formulaic “Ring of Fire” becomes.

headline: Dissecting the Dance Even Before It Begins
text: It’s not unusual to see small-scale modern-dance performances in which the choreographer and dancers return to the stage for a question-and-answer session. But the Stripped/Dressed series of this year’s Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y has the choreographer and dancers explain things first.

headline: 2 Awards Given to Promote Multicultural Children’s Books
text: A month ago a nonprofit called First Book, which promotes literacy among children in low-income communities, announced the Stories for All project, a program intended to prod publishers to print more multicultural books. Kyle Zimmer, First Book’s chief executive, says that part of the motivation was the “chasm” between the number of people who want such books and what is available.

headline: Night of the Stars at the Richmond Bridge Club
text: After the Night of the Stars charity pro-am event at the Richmond Bridge Club in London on Feb. 28 the players received a booklet. This contained copies of the deals with bidding and play predictions by various experts from around the world. And to give Jason Hackett from England credit, he did mention the unusual contract reached when Shivam Shah sat South, partnering Azad Mahomed.

headline: Cory Booker, Twitter Visionary
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Cory Booker — the mayor of Newark and a virtual Twitter superhero for his chronicle of the city — made the trip to the annual South by Southwest conference here on Sunday to impart his tips and perspective on why Twitter is a valuable tool for governing and civic engagement.

headline: Looking Divine at South by Southwest
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Playing on screens throughout the South by Southwest festival this weekend were a variety of documentaries focusing on key figures in gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender communities. “Continental” shines its eye on Steve Ostrow, the owner of the Continental Baths, a bathhouse that became a cultural beacon. “Big Joy” focuses on the gay poet and filmmaker James Broughton, whose work in the 1960s and ’70s made him a voice of the sexual revolution. “Mr. Angel” spends time with the porn star and activist Buck Angel, whose work has changed perspectives on transgender performers in adult film.

headline: John Doyle to Direct a London Revival of ‘The Color Purple’
text: John Doyle, who received a Tony Award for best direction in the 2005 Broadway production of “Sweeney Todd,” will bring his talents to London for his next project, a revival of the musical version of “The Color Purple.” The Menier Chocolate Factory, a 150-seat performance space in a former factory, will host the engagement from July 5 to Sept. 14.

headline: Pearl Theater Company Delays McNally Play
text: The Pearl Theater Company has pushed back the spring premiere of Terrence McNally’s “And Away We Go” to the fall season. The play was previously scheduled to run from April 19 to May 19. “This Side of Neverland,” which features a pair of one-acts by J. M. Barrie, will now fill that period and close the Pearl’s 2012-13 season. The delay follows a February letter to subscribers stating that the company was experiencing a cash-flow shortfall and needed to raise an additional $250,000 to continue the current season as scheduled.

headline: Footnote
text: Kelly Osbourne  said on her Twitter account on Friday that a seizure caused her collapse on the set of E!’s “Fashion Police” last week. Ms. Osbourne was rushed to the hospital on Thursday and, according to her post on Twitter, which was accompanied by a photo of an I.V. line in her left arm, doctors are still trying to determine why the seizure occurred.

headline: For Wheeler, Demotion Is Probably Temporary
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On Sunday, for perhaps the last time before what is expected to be a promising major league career, Zack Wheeler was cut from a baseball team.

headline: Top Contenders to Lead the Roman Catholic Church
text: Cardinals selecting the next pope are looking for someone with the charisma of Pope John Paul II and the grit to tackle the church’s scandals.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes retail sales for February, import prices for February and business inventories for January (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for February and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: New ‘Arrested Development’ Episodes Aren’t Enough for Some Fans
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — For years after the cult series “Arrested Development” went off the air, the question was whether a movie about the demented Bluth family would follow. Now that the show, which ended in 2006, is getting new life with 14 more episodes on Netflix this spring, that was still the question of the hour at a South by Southwest festival Q&A session with Mitch Hurwitz, the show’s creator, and two of its stars, Will Arnett and Jeffrey Tambor.

headline: For Marvel Comics, a Renewed Digital Mission
text: LOS ANGELES — Like the rest of the publishing industry, comic books went digital long ago. You can catch up on Batman via mobile app and unfurl Wolverine’s claws from your laptop. But Marvel Comics upped the ante significantly on Sunday, unveiling a superhero-size slate of new and expanded mobile and online initiatives.

headline: Saudis Consider Firing Squads for Executions
text: CAIRO — After centuries of public beheadings, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia is considering firing squads as an alternative means of execution.

headline: G.O.P. in Arizona Is Pushed to Expand Medicaid
text: PHOENIX — In the battle to get the Medicaid expansion being championed by Gov. Jan Brewer approved by the state’s legislators, her closest advisers are hanging their hopes on the number eight. That is how many of the 17 Republicans in the State Senate they believe they can get on their side.

headline: Two Sides to a Deodorant Campaign
text: THE deodorant aisle was once more like the toothpaste aisle, with products mostly unisex rather than marketed strictly to men or women. But today, unisex deodorants account for only 12 percent of the market, according to the research firm Mintel, down from about 35 percent in 1990.

headline: Arthur Storch, Stage Director, Dies at 87
text: Arthur Storch, an exacting and successful director on Broadway and in regional theater, who once asked Eugène Ionesco to rewrite a play and goaded a young Aaron Sorkin to work harder, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Police Scatter Demonstrators in Capital of Azerbaijan
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — The police in the capital of Azerbaijan on Sunday used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons to disperse protesters demanding an end to the hazing and abuse of military conscripts, which activists say the government has concealed.

headline: Islamists Kill 7 Captives in Nigeria
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Radical Islamists in northern Nigeria have killed seven foreign construction workers who were kidnapped in February, a significant escalation of extremist violence in Nigeria’s continuing jihadist insurgency.

headline: From YouTube to the Cineplex
text: LOS ANGELES — How fast is YouTube building new media companies? Consider the case of AwesomenessTV, a YouTube-based channel for teenagers.

headline: Quinn Tour Opens Mayoral Campaign
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, officially began her campaign to become mayor of New York. Even before Sunday’s formal announcement, she was the perceived Democratic front-runner.

headline: Real Madrid on a Rampage; United Wilts
text: Real Madrid put an exclamation mark on an impressive run that began with a Copa del Rey win over arch rival Barcelona on Feb. 26 and continued to Sunday (at least) with a 2-1 win at Celta Vigo, the team’s ninth game without a loss in Spain’s La Liga. Those wins sandwiched a second triumph over Barcelona, in the league, and then last Tuesday’s classic demolition of Manchester United to advance to the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League.

headline: United States Avoids Elimination With Victory Over Canada
text: PHOENIX — Humiliation was just five outs away. Trailing by a run late in Sunday’s game at the World Baseball Classic, the United States faced the prospect of first-round elimination — and that was not the worst of it.

headline: B-Plus for City’s Parks, but Problems Remain
text: The conditions of more than 40 large parks in New York City have improved in the last two years, though problems — including a lack of resources and consistency — remain, according to a survey by an independent advocacy group.

headline: British Proposal to Rein In Banks Is Faulted
text: 8:07 a.m. | Updated

headline: Martha’s Brand Struggling for Right Fit
text: Media companies are often closely associated with their founders — Rupert Murdoch at News Corporation and Sumner Redstone at Viacom come to mind — but none are linked with their products in quite the way Martha Stewart is.

headline: Uprooted by Tsunami, Church’s Flock Regroups
text: IWAKI, Japan — After the rumbling and the devastating waves had ceased, the members of a little church a stone’s throw away from the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant discovered that a new set of troubles was just beginning.

headline: Indiana Player Knows How to Wow a Crowd
text: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. — Victor Oladipo believes there is a song for every occasion, and to the resignation of his Indiana teammates, those occasions include blinking, breathing and walking.

headline: South Korea Flirts With Nuclear Ideas as North Blusters
text: SEOUL, South Korea — As their country prospered, South Koreans have largely shrugged off the constant threat of a North Korean attack. But breakthroughs in the North’s missile and nuclear programs and fiery threats of war have heightened fears in the South that even small miscalculations by the new and untested leaders of each country could have disastrous consequences.

headline: Mildred Manning, ‘Angel’ of Corregidor, Dies at 98
text: Mildred Dalton Manning grew up poor on a Georgia farm. Her mother made all the family clothes on an old sewing machine. Hoping to escape a life of poverty, she attended nursing school during the Depression and became a nurse at a hospital in Atlanta.

headline: CT Scans Find Vascular Disease in Ancient Mummies
text: Atherosclerosis — the buildup of fats and cholesterol on the artery walls that can lead to stroke and heart disease — is generally considered a problem of modern times, a result of fatty diets and inactive lifestyles. But a new examination of mummies from ancient cultures suggests that the disease appeared long before the arrival of junk food and flat-screen televisions.

headline: Afghan Says Force Backed by the C.I.A. Beat Him
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The 29-year-old engineering student was standing outside his classroom here on Saturday morning when he said two pickup trucks full of armed men pulled up. The men, said to be members of a C.I.A.-backed Afghan strike force, grabbed him, tied his hands behind his back, draped a black hood over his head and drove him to an undisclosed location where, the student says, he was beaten and whipped.

headline: The Caretaker of Boston University Athletics
text: BOSTON — In Section 111, Row Q, Seat 1, above a corner of the Agganis Arena ice, a gray-haired man observed the action. Wearing a scarlet team jacket and a white Friends of Boston University Hockey cap pulled over enormous eyeglasses with brown frames, he was easy to miss. A trumpeter’s brief toot from the opposite end of the rink projected greater sound than the man’s enthusiastic clapping after each Terriers goal in a victory against Merrimack.

headline: Preparation and Vows of Defiance as Big Sugary Drink Ban Is Set to Start
text: With one day to go before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s ban on large sugary drinks goes into effect across the city, some big-drink lovers, and the places that serve them, vowed defiance. Others accepted it with a shrug. Then there were people like Leonardo Scarpone, the owner of Sanpanino, an Italian sandwich shop in Greenwich Village, who wondered if the small amount of sugar he added to his fresh-squeezed lemonade would push it into forbidden territory.

headline: To at Least One Earthling, Siberia Meteor Proved That Science Is Vital
text: Twice on a recent Friday, the cosmos intruded rudely on us earthlings. A meteor exploded over western Siberia, shattering windows, injuring hundreds and scaring pretty much everyone else. That same day, an asteroid passed within 18,000 miles of us, close enough to arch many an eyebrow among astronomers.

headline: No Stumping for Papacy, but Babies Do Get Kisses
text: ROME — The American contender kissed babies and joked about bad food inside the papal conclave. The Brazilian blessed a couple on their 70th anniversary. The Italian blessed a pack of journalists, and a baby, too. The reserved Hungarian did not kiss anybody.

headline: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering Web
text: Trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes: computer algorithms are doing all this work and more.

headline: Chávez Heir Faces Challenge in Ties With Armed Forces
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The multitudes in red shirts, clenched fists thrusting in the air — a dominant image of the political movement that President Hugo Chávez left behind — convey a sense of followers united and loyal to the father of their revolution and his designated heir, Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
text: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
text: VATICAN CITY — The cardinals who enter the papal conclave on Tuesday will walk into the Sistine Chapel in a single file, but beneath the orderly display, they are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine which man among them emerges as pope.

headline: No Catching or Doubting a Healthy, Happy Woods
text: DORAL, Fla. — On the second hole Sunday at the Blue Monster, Tiger Woods drained a 19-foot putt for birdie. When at last the applause died down, Graeme McDowell stood over a 7-footer for birdie that suddenly looked twice as long. He rolled it in to remain three strokes behind Woods, and as he walked off the green, he made eye contact with a friend and said, “We’re not playing for second place here.”

headline: Dwindling Deficit Disorder
text: For three years and more, policy debate in Washington has been dominated by warnings about the dangers of budget deficits. A few lonely economists have tried from the beginning to point out that this fixation is all wrong, that deficit spending is actually appropriate in a depressed economy. But even though the deficit scolds have been wrong about everything so far — where are the soaring interest rates we were promised? — protests that we are having the wrong conversation have consistently fallen on deaf ears.

headline: Hold Generic Drug Makers Accountable
text: A New Hampshire woman who was severely injured by a generic drug in 2004 is still struggling to hold the manufacturer liable. Her case will be argued this month before the Supreme Court, which has already severely limited the ability of consumers to sue generic manufacturers and may well limit it further. If so, some way must be found to compensate this plaintiff, Karen Bartlett, and others who have been hurt by generic drugs, which account for 80 percent of all prescriptions in this country.

headline: How to Shop for College
text: Colleges often make themselves appear less expensive — and more attractive to cash-poor families — through promotional materials and financial aid letters that hide the true costs. Last month the federal government unveiled an online college scorecard that can help families cut through some of the confusion. It gives students a reasonable idea of what they could owe once they graduate and allows clear cost comparisons among schools.

headline: Critics Wait for City to Rein In Bus Lines
text: Last summer, after a federal crackdown on discount bus lines running through Chinatown in Manhattan, city and state officials celebrated as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a law aimed at bringing some order to the curbside bus business in New York.

headline: Confirmation Questions for Mary Jo White
text: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s nominee for chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is expected to win Senate approval after her confirmation hearing on Tuesday. But unless Ms. White is aggressively questioned, neither the senators nor the public will have a clear idea of the kind of chairwoman she will be.

headline: When to Say No
text: The State Department’s latest environmental assessment of the controversial Keystone XL oil pipeline makes no recommendation about whether President Obama should approve it. Here is ours. He should say no, and for one overriding reason: A president who has repeatedly identified climate change as one of humanity’s most pressing dangers cannot in good conscience approve a project that — even by the State Department’s most cautious calculations — can only add to the problem.

headline: Private Manning’s Confidant
text: In early 2010, Pfc. Bradley Manning methodically uploaded a digital mother lode of classified United States military and diplomatic documents to the Internet insurgents of WikiLeaks. As everyone knows, WikiLeaks made these secret archives available to a few major news outlets, including this one. Many illuminating and troubling stories were published, and Washington has been gnashing its teeth ever since.

headline: Megadeals: Something to Cheer, or Fear?
text: Are recent mergers and acquisitions a sign of economic resurgence or could they actually sap the recovery?

headline: Downside of Drug Courts
text: To the Editor:

headline: JOBS Act Successes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Working at Home: Pros and Cons
Shopping While Black: Racism in Everyday Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Criticism, Police Change Policy and Begin Investigating More Traffic Crashes
text: In a marked shift of protocol, the New York Police Department has begun conducting robust investigations of traffic crashes that result in critical injuries but not certain or likely death.

headline: ‘The Man Who Sells the Moon’
text: The notion that one man can lay claim to all the extraterrestrial bodies in our little corner of the galaxy sounds preposterous. Yet Dennis M. Hope, 65, of Gardnerville, Nev., the subject of this Op-Doc video, believes just that. For three decades, he has built a thriving business by “selling” land plots in space, on places like the moon, Mars and Venus. Of course, he has no legal authority to do so. How does he get away with this? He told me that, back when he was a ventriloquist in the days before he “owned” the moon, his dummy taught him a valuable lesson: you can say anything you want to anybody as long as you smile.

headline: The Man Who Sells the Moon
text: This short documentary looks at Dennis Hope, a Nevada man who has made a living “selling” plots of land on the moon.

headline: After Rough Patch, ‘The Bachelor’ Wins Back Viewers
text: No matter which contestant Sean Lowe, the chiseled, strawberry blond, chooses as his fantasy fiancée on the three-hour season finale of ABC’s “The Bachelor” on Monday — will it be Catherine Giudici, 26, a quirky graphic designer from Seattle, or Lindsay Yenter, 25, a petite substitute teacher from Fort Bragg, N.C.? — the network has rekindled the romance between the reality series and its viewers.

headline: The Small-State Advantage in the United States Senate
text: The Constitution has always given states with small populations a lift, but the scale of the gap has grown in recent decades.

headline: Stoudemire’s Woes Make Deal Look Worse All the Time
text: When the tangled history of the Amar’e Stoudemire-Carmelo Anthony era is eventually written, it should be framed as a study in high-stakes gambling, in the fickle nature of the risk-reward scale and the consequences of unchecked desperation.

headline: Opposition Leader Will Seek Venezuelan Presidency
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The opposition leader Henrique Capriles Radonski said Sunday that he would run for president in a special election to replace Hugo Chávez, who died last week after 14 years in office.

headline: Yankees Are Said to Pursue Derrek Lee as Replacement for Mark Teixeira
text: DUNEDIN, Fla. — With few obvious options available to replace the injured Mark Teixeira at first base, the Yankees are becoming creative in their search. They have asked the retired first baseman Derrek Lee whether he would come out of retirement, according to a person with knowledge of the talks who asked to remain anonymous.

headline: Cuts Give Obama Path to Create Leaner Military
text: WASHINGTON — At a time when $46 billion in mandatory budget cuts are causing anxiety at the Pentagon, administration officials see one potential benefit: there may be an opening to argue for deep reductions in programs long in President Obama’s sights, and long resisted by Congress.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 10, 2013

headline: Harvard Search of E-Mail Stuns Its Faculty Members
text: Bewildered, and at times angry, faculty members at Harvard criticized the university on Sunday after revelations that administrators secretly searched the e-mail accounts of 16 resident deans in an effort to learn who leaked information about a student cheating scandal to the news media. Some predicted a confrontation between the faculty and the administration.

headline: Landlord Kills a Tenant in Brooklyn
text: An argument between a landlord and a tenant in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon ended with a gunshot that left the tenant dead, according to the police.

headline: Third Attempt at Trial in Killing of a Therapist
text: The two brothers stood for hours on end at the back of the courtroom last week, vigilantly watching for any sign that their sister’s killer might crumble yet again — robbing them once more of resolution in a criminal case that has dragged on for five years.

headline: Debates Renewed on Visors and Staged Fights
text: Visors and fighting in hockey are in the headlines again after two prominent injuries.

headline: Time on Mound Can’t Compare With Experiences Watching From Seat
text: DUNEDIN, Fla. — Mike Harkey, the Yankees’ bullpen coach for the past five seasons, had his best off-season since the Yankees won the World Series in 2009. The highlight came Nov. 18.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Admires Mariano Rivera’s Send-Off
text: TAMPA — While watching Mariano Rivera announce Saturday that this would be his final season, C. C. Sabathia wondered whether he, too, would one day have that privilege.

headline: Success in the Classic Could Help Revive Baseball in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Puerto Rico fielded a team for the World Baseball Classic that included players from the likes of the Savannah Sand Gnats, the Akron Aeros and the Brevard County Manatees. Such is the state of baseball in Puerto Rico, where the supply of major league talent has sharply declined.

headline: Bringing Back Detroit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fish Returns With Win and Guarded Optimism
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Six months after Mardy Fish pulled himself off one of the biggest stages in tennis, he was finally able to push himself back on Sunday.

headline: India Rape Suspect Found Dead in Jail
text: NEW DELHI — One of the men accused in a Delhi gang rape case was found dead in his jail cell on Monday morning, a jail official said.

headline: Suspect in India Gang Rape Found Dead in Jail
text: NEW DELHI — One of the men accused in the Delhi gang rape case was found dead in his jail cell on Monday morning, a jail official said.

headline: Myths About the Flu Vaccine
text: On Dec. 20, 1968, I got the flu. I remember it still: Christmas was a washout — I couldn’t leave the bed unassisted or keep anything down, not even a taste of the goose that someone else had to cook.

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Word of the Day | quail
text: quail •\ˈkwal\• noun and verb

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 11
text: “From highway bills to homeland security, small states make out like bandits.”

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8 P.M. (Encore) HINDENBURG: THE LAST FLIGHT Maximilian Simonischek portrays an engineer leading the design of the LZ 129 Hindenburg; Stacy Keach is an unscrupulous American industrialist; Greta Scacchi is his wife; and Lauren Lee Smith (above with Mr. Simonischek) is their daughter in this two-part fictionalized account of the May 1937 aviation disaster in which 35 people on board and 1 on the ground were killed when the German airship burst into flames and crashed as it tried to dock at Lakehurst Naval Air Station in Manchester, N.J. Part 2 will be shown on Tuesday at 8.

headline: Photo Replay: March 10
text: A view of the day in sports, from college basketball to speedskating.

headline: Roy Miller and the Red Bulls’ Late Show
text: A week after a thrilling season-opening tie against the Timbers in Portland, the Red Bulls returned to the West Coast on Sunday night and produced something decidedly less memorable.

headline: Love in the Time of Durjoy Datta
text: A lot of young women you have never met are crazy about Durjoy Datta.

headline: News Quiz | March 11, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Push to Investigate North Korea’s Human Rights Abuses
text: BEIJING — Could North Korea be headed toward an international inquiry into possible crimes against humanity?

headline: Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate
text: RUTLAND, Vt. — In the four years after the financial crisis struck, a great wave of federal stimulus money washed over Rutland County. It helped pay for bridges, roads, preschool programs, a community health center, buses and fire trucks, water mains and tanks, even a project to make sure fish could still swim down the river while a bridge was being rebuilt.

headline: The Geneva Auto Show’s Green Lining
text: With growing consumer interest in green vehicles and a pledge to build a European Union-wide network of electric charging stations, many Europeans are looking forward to the next generation of cars.

headline: Cabdriver’s Book Club
text: Dear Diary:

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 11
text: NEWS President Hamid Karzai leveled particularly harsh accusations against the United States on Sunday, suggesting that the Americans and the Taliban had a common goal in destabilizing his country. The comments cast a shadow on the first visit by Chuck Hagel as defense secretary. Alissa J. Rubin and Thom Shanker report from Kabul.

headline: Apps for Philips’s Hue Light Bulbs
text: How many apps does it take to screw in a light bulb? For Philips, apparently, there can never be too many.

headline: CVC-Led Group to Sell $1.4 Billion Stake in Indonesian Retailer
text: HONG KONG – A group led by the private equity firm CVC Capital Partners began marketing the sale of a 40 percent stake in Indonesia’s largest department store operator on Monday, a move that could raise up to 13.13 trillion rupiah ($1.36 billion).

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 11, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Think New York Is Costly? In New Delhi, Seedy Goes for 8 Figures.”

headline: Benches-Clearing Brawl at the World Baseball Classic
text: In “At Global Showcase, a Blowout and a Brawl,” Tyler Kepner writes about the events that transpired at a World Baseball Classic game on Saturday.

headline: How Many Text Messages Are Too Many?
text: Consider a text message–or voice mail or email–just to say “thank you” to the recipient for something he or she has done.

headline: Gujarat Is Yours, Modi Tells Indian Americans
text: EDISON, New Jersey —Gujarat’s controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi, unfurled his definition of secularism, addressing hundreds of Indian-Americans in New Jersey and Chicago through a live telecast from Ahmedabad on Sunday.

headline: From the Safety of Switzerland
text: MOSCOW — The novelist Mikhail Shishkin has won every major Russian literary award and several Western ones, but it is a letter that he wrote to a Russian ministry that has really made him a household name in Russia.

headline: Early Warnings About Ram Singh’s Safety; Suicide ‘Not Possible,’ Family Says
text: NEW DELHI — The family of Ram Singh, one of the accused in the Delhi gang rape case who was found hanged in his jail cell on Monday morning, was warned on Friday that his life might be in danger, one of his brothers said on Monday.

headline: Framing — and Reflecting — Beauty
text: Inside a beauty parlor in a small Florida town, Carrie is having her hair done. She is oblivious to the commotion around her. Peering intently into a mirror, she is at that quintessential moment of beautification when she must decide if the image she sees pleases her and she is ready to face the world.

headline: The Early Word: Silver Linings
text: In Today’s Times

headline: Thousands of Dead Pigs Found in River Flowing Into Shanghai
text: BEIJING — More than 3,300 dead pigs have been found in a major river that flows through Shanghai, igniting fears among city residents of contaminated tap water, according to official reports on Tuesday.

headline: This Week in Small Business: The Next Big Battle
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Chavismo and Human Development in Venezuela
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.”

headline: Daily Report: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering the Web
text: Computer algorithms are trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes.

headline: NELL Is a Computer That Reads the Web – With a Little Human Help
text: The clever code of computing – the algorithmic empire – is on the march across business and society, but human help still has a role to play. And that role is increasingly apparent as algorithms try to do more work that was once the realm of human intelligence.

headline: Decision Looms on Trade Status of 5 Shark Species
text: HONG KONG — Delegates at a major international meeting on wildlife trade voted on Monday to add several shark species to a list of plants and animals whose international trade is regulated. The vote was welcomed by conservationists, though it is still subject to final approval by the conference later this week.

headline: Indictee for President!
text: NAIROBI — When the International Criminal Court was established in 2002 it had many lofty ambitions. Ending impunity for crimes against humanity, genocide and war crimes. Delivering justice to those abandoned by their national courts.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 11, 2013
text: Update: March 12, 2013

headline: India Rape Suspect’s Family Says His Death Wasn’t Suicide
text: NEW DELHI — The case of a fatal gang rape aboard a bus here in December, which set off an uproar across India, took a surprising turn on Monday when the body of a suspect in the attack was found hanging from a bedsheet noose in his jail cell. Officials called the death a suicide, but the suspect’s family insisted that he had been killed.

headline: Competing Interests in an I.P.O.
text: When it comes to hot initial public offerings, there is a long-running debate over the obligations of the underwriter. In one classic case, the 1999 I.P.O. of eToys, a cache of documents newly unearthed by Joe Nocera of The New York Times offers insight into the way one Wall Street firm, Goldman Sachs, has approached these deals. In a lawsuit that is still going on, lawyers for an eToys creditors’ committee claimed that Goldman purposely set a low price to create a first-day pop in the stock for institutional investors, at the expense of the company itself.

headline: Monday Reading: Avoiding ‘Single’ Surcharge While Traveling
text: Avoiding “single supplements” while traveling, myths about the flu vaccine, Wi-Fi in every room and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Opinion Report: No to Keystone
text: From the editorial page

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Melanie Thernstrom on Untangling the Mystery of Food Allergies
text: Melanie Thernstrom wrote this week’s cover article about a doctor who is trying to cure children of their dangerous food allergies. Thernstrom is the author, most recently, of “The Pain Chronicles.” She last wrote for the magazine about twiblings.

headline: Divining What’s Next for Video Games
text: Since helping to invent the modern video-game industry in 1981 with his design of Donkey Kong, Nintendo’s Shigeru Miyamoto has repeatedly reinvented it, most notably with the Nintendo Entertainment System in the 1980s — it introduced Super Mario Bros. and the Legend of Zelda to American households — and in the 2000s with the Wii, whose arm-waving motion controls started yet another widely imitated video-game craze.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
text: Faced with a recent spate of high-profile incidents of violence, Nelson Mandela’s wife, Graça Machel last week broke the usual silence of the former first couple and said that South Africa was “an angry nation.”

headline: Q&A: Importing Camera Photos to an iPad Mini
text: Q.

headline: A More Opaque British Government
text: LONDON — British governments sometimes seem inclined to offer unrequested advice to countries in the so-called developing world about their commitment to Western democracy. But in recent weeks, the question could be inverted: how open is British society itself?

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 Soldiers in Pakistan Tribal District
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan – A roadside bomb attack killed three soldiers and wounded at least three others in Pakistan’s tribal belt on Monday, Pakistani security officials said.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘The Bachelor’ Draws Viewers, and Martha Stewart’s Need for Privacy
text: ABC’s romance reality show “The Bachelor” has experienced a rare resurgence after a downswing that lasted several seasons , Amy Chozick and Bill Carter report. The show, which pairs a hunky man with dozens of heavily made-up women until he picks one as his fiancée, has become the unlikely exception in a television season when almost every other show on ABC and its competitors has declined. The audience has increased to 8.8 million viewers, 3.3 million of whom are 18 to 49 years old, the most attractive group for advertisers. The show is especially popular among women, particularly those in households that make more than $100,000 a year.

headline: The Gun Report: March 11, 2013
text: On February 27, we included in our gun report the murder of two officers in Santa Cruz, Calif., who were shot while following up on a sexual assault claim. The gunman, Jeremy Goulet, who was killed by police, was an Army veteran who had been accused of raping two military officers in 2006. Instead of jail time, a plea bargain allowed him to walk away with a less than honorable discharge. Former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who once represented Santa Cruz in Congress, spoke at the slain officers’ memorial service and suggested that this slap on the wrist paved the way for Goulet’s final, horrific crime.

headline: Dell Agrees to Open Its Books to Icahn
text: Dell Inc. has agreed to open its books to the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, signaling a possible truce on one front in the battle over the computer maker’s proposed $24.4 billion buyout.

headline: Breitbarted
text: OK, I’m an evil person — and my scheming has paid off.

headline: Leave Iran to Its Own Devices
text: Iran should be left alone with its nuclear ambitions. Sanctions do nothing more than hurt those who have nothing to say about anything in their own country. Just tell the Iranians this: If you detonate one of the weapons outside of your country, your country will cease to exist.

headline: Massive March for Yamuna River Nears Delhi
text: NEW DELHI —Tens of thousands of villagers are marching toward Delhi to pressure the central government to save the Yamuna River, in one of the biggest protests against river pollution in India.

headline: After Lehman, Callan Speaks Out on a Proper Work-Life Balance
text: Erin Callan, former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, has kept mostly to herself after leaving Wall Street during the financial crisis.

headline: At 64 Percent, Cuomo’s Favorability Rating Hits a New Low
text: Heading into this year’s budget negotiations, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo remains popular with New York voters, but he is no longer drawing the sky-high ratings that he enjoyed for most of his first two years in office, according to a poll released Monday by Siena College.

headline: Online Betting Site Intrade Is Shut After Audit Queries
text: The online betting site Intrade announced late on Sunday that it had halted trading and frozen customer accounts after the company said it had discovered potential financial irregularities.

headline: Author of ‘Michael Haneke’ Twitter Account Reveals Himself
text: While there is still plenty of time for the real Michael Haneke, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker of “Amour,” to become a master of social media, the creator of a satirical Twitter account that (sort of) imitated him will not be carrying on the comedic impersonation well into his autumn years.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: National Geographic Traveler: Costas Christ on spending each spring farming blueberries in Maine. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Insider Attack Kills Several in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan police officer fired on American Special Operations troops and Afghan forces Monday morning, killing two coalition soldiers in the second insider attack in three days, Afghan officials said.

headline: With a New Web Site, Betting on Brooklyn
text: Bklynr, the creation of three Columbia Spectator alumni, is a subscription-only Web site that says it will publish three new in-depth articles every two weeks, beginning April 4.

headline: Schapiro Is Nominated to G.E. Board
text: Mary L. Schapiro is starting to get a taste of opportunities in the private sector after stepping down as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in December.

headline: Ukraine Gets Its Own Vogue
text: PARIS — Masha Tsukanova is the new face on the front lines of fashion. As the editor in chief of Vogue Ukraine, which made its debut this month as Vogue’s 21st international edition, she attended shows in Milan and made a brief appearance in Paris. She seemed to be fitting right in.

headline: Market Milestones Can Lead to False Assumptions
text: Any time the stock market hits a new milestone, whether it’s going up or down, we start to hear a lot of noise. And the chatter seems to be focused on this idea of what it all means.

headline: For the Tech Crowd, a Taste of Newspaper Talk
text: Here in Austin, Tex., where I’m attending the digital media extravaganza known as South by Southwest, or SXSW, the arrival of the local newspaper at the hotel room door each morning seems almost otherworldly. Amid this gathering of techie (not to say geeky, because that would be a bit unfair), mostly young, mostly male participants, where plaid flannel is the de rigueur fashion note and Google glasses are the accessory of choice, The Austin American-Statesman feels like an unfamiliar visitor from the distant past. (It’s a good paper, by the way, with Pulitzer Prizes in its history and a lively local report each day.) To put it mildly, this is not a print newspaper kind of crowd.

headline: Reasonable Representation
text: The Times's Adam Liptak on the growing advantage less populated states enjoy in the Senate.

headline: Talking Talent | Serena Williams
text: At 31 years old, Serena Williams is ranked the No. 1 female tennis player in the world, for the sixth time. Williams is arguably one of the most exciting athletes to ever grace tennis — with her lightning speed serve, her festive fashion and her fierce determination, Williams defines power. Although her life is virtually a hamster wheel of 24/7 tennis, Williams joined the Nike president and C.E.O., Mark Parker, and the first lady, Michelle Obama, on Feb. 28 in Chicago to announce Nike’s investment of $50 million in the United States to increase the physical activity of children in schools and communities, a portion of which will benefit the Let’s Move! Active Schools program. En route to the airport following the event, Williams discussed the first lady, the Miami Dolphins and her Chris Evert fantasy.

headline: A Poker Puzzle From the Logic Olympics
text: Congratulations to everyone who competed in the 36th annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament this past weekend! Check out Deb Amlen’s last few posts, including A.C.P.T. 2013: The Finals, for the ultimate winners and complete adventure.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kenseth’s Vegas Gamble Pays Off
text: Matt Kenseth celebrated his 41st birthday on Sunday by winning the Las Vegas stop on the Nascar Sprint Cup circuit.

headline: North Korea Declares 1953 War Truce Nullified
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea declared the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified on Monday, following through on a longstanding threat that it renewed last week amid rising tensions with South Korea.

headline: Former Mayor of Detroit Guilty in Corruption Case
text: DETROIT — Kwame M. Kilpatrick, a former mayor of Detroit, was found guilty on Monday of a raft of charges, including racketeering, fraud and extortion, capping a five-month public corruption trial against him and two co-defendants.

headline: The Heights of Hype
text: Now that we are well into March, it’s time to brace for the coming onslaught. No, we’re not talking about college basketball tournament madness. That is actually the enjoyable part, so fun we manage to block out reality and overlook the whole N.C.A.A. morass for a few minutes. No, the onslaught comes courtesy of CBS, which broadcasts both the N.C.A.A. tournament and the Masters golf tournament, a fact drilled into our heads so often by Jim Nantz every year that mental health counselors should consider setting up a hot line. Mute buttons everywhere quiver in anticipation of angry thumbs.

headline: Your Guide to New York’s Soda Ban
text: Update, 3:30 p.m. | A state Supreme Court judge in Manhattan invalidated the city’s sugary-drink ban on Monday afternoon. Read the article.

headline: Abraham Lincoln, War President
text: Throughout the Civil War, the federal courts made little attempt to curb the wide executive war powers claimed by President Abraham Lincoln. Judges issued few pronouncements on the legality of the president’s most controversial measures, one way or the other. This included the Supreme Court – with one critical exception: the ruling in the so-called Prize Cases in early 1863, involving the blockade of Southern ports. The justices, along narrow lines, validated Lincoln’s broad claim, under the war powers, to confiscate goods found aboard blockade runners, in perhaps the court’s most important decision during the entire war.

headline: S.B.A. Proposes Rule Changes to Lure Borrowers
text: Concerned, apparently, that not enough businesses are taking advantage of government-guaranteed loans, the Small Business Administration recently proposed changing some of its lending rules. If adopted, the new rules could make the agency’s loan programs accessible and popular enough that they could reach their legal limits on lending — something the programs have seldom ever done. Oddly enough, this is happening at the same time the prospective “sequester” budget cuts may force the agency to make fewer loans.

headline: The Race Is On
text: The Times's Michael M. Grynbaum on Christine C. Quinn's bid to be New York City's first female and openly gay mayor.

headline: Cutting the World’s Most Expensive Military
text: Mandatory budget cuts are forcing the United States military to trim down after a decade in which its budget has nearly doubled.

headline: 'Downton': The Original
text: The hit series is popular all over the world.

headline: Tenants Worried by Plans to Build Near City Projects
text: When Hassan Adam was growing up in public housing on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, his playground was a nearby recreational yard in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, where residents have long played basketball and neighbors hold an annual “family day.” Mr. Adam still lives in the project, and he taught his daughter to ride a bike in the play area.

headline: The Legitimizing of Rand Paul
text: My Sunday column argues that the great Rand Paul filibuster represented an important step in the Kentucky Senator’s quest to widen the Republican conversation on national security beyond the “strength good, appeasement bad” rhetoric that the party had fallen back on (though not as completely as some Republicans would like) in the aftermath of the Bush presidency. The most persuasive counterpoint to my interpretation is that the right’s rally around Paul’s drones-on-American-soil stand is sui generis, with no wider implications for the G.O.P. foreign policy debates: Many of the Republican Party’s hawks have always been skeptical of drone warfare (preferring boots on the ground, more prisoner-taking, etc.), and the fact that Paul was making a reductio ad hellfirum argument about drones taking down latter-day Jane Fondas made it that much easier for them to leap on the partisan bandwagon and #standwithRand.

headline: Cutting Down on the Meat, but Not the Taste
text: There are many ways to cut down your meat intake and increase your vegetable consumption without becoming a vegetarian. Culinary traditions around the world are filled with dishes in which meat is used sparingly, for flavor and substance, but is not at the center of the plate. Think stir-fries, and some of your favorite pastas that have a little bit of pancetta but are really all about the tomatoes.

headline: A Headset for Professional Gamers (and Amateurs, Too)
text: Turtle Beach wants to be the go-to brand of gaming headsets.

headline: Harvard Explains Why Staff E-Mails Were Searched
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Harvard and its president on Monday made their first public comments on the university’s searching of staff members’ e-mail accounts, and offered a qualified apology for keeping the searches secret from most of the employees involved.

headline: Who Studies Abroad, Who Stays Put and Why
text: American students are twice as likely as their British counterparts to consider foreign study, according to a new report.

headline: Senate Offers Immigration Blueprint
text: A group of senators has drafted a set of principles that includes a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants that hinges on increased border security and enforcement measures.

headline: The New Acropolis Museum
text: The new home for some of Athens most famous antiquities, one of the highest-profile cultural projects undertaken in Europe in this decade, opened on June 20.

headline: A Right to Unlock Cellphones Fades Away
text: In October the Library of Congress decided to invalidate a copyright exemption that allowed users to unlock their cellphones. This exemption expired Saturday.

headline: Mushroom, Bulgur, Spinach and Turkey Fritters With Yogurt Sauce
text: These are smaller than burgers and are served without buns, with a pungent garlic sauce. The recipe is inspired by a turkey and zucchini burger in “Jerusalem, a Cookbook,” by Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi.

headline: Walters Says There Are ‘No Plans’ for Hasselbeck to Leave ‘The View’
text: In a bid to tamp down talk about changes at “The View,” Barbara Walters said on Monday that “we have no plans” for Elisabeth Hasselbeck to leave the long-running ABC talk show.

headline: Vegetable Soup With Any Root
text: What’s for dinner?

headline: Yankees Tell Reporters to Reach Out to Jones
text: TAMPA, Fla. – With his sagging ship of a team listing in uncertain waters, General Manager Brian Cashman sent an S O S to an iconic Atlanta Braves player Monday.

headline: In Performance: Elrod & Harris
text: Carson Elrod and Jenn Harris in “The Universal Language,” part of “All in the Timing,” David Ives’s collection of offbeat sketches. The show is being revived by Primary Stages at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Electronic Arts Addresses Anger Over SimCity
text: The creators of the new SimCity computer game stopped short of giving the troubled game an all-clear on Sunday night, but the period of near-inoperability appeared close to an end.

headline: A Barclays Banker Bets on a ‘Fat Cat’
text: President Obama irked Wall Street bankers a few years ago by calling them “fat cats.” But one banker has embraced the name.

headline: Painterly Fashion
text: For his second women’s collection at Saint Laurent in Paris last week, Hedi Slimane sent out invitations in the form of an artist book called “49 Paintings” by Theodora Allen. Fashion houses teaming up with contemporary artists is nothing particularly new — there were actual Yayoi Kusama mannequins in Louis Vuitton’s windows when those two paired off — but to tap someone still in graduate school feels the riskier proposition. Allen is currently in her second year at U.C.L.A.’s M.F.A. program and has no gallery representation. “I’m looking at various 19th- and 20th-century bohemian countercultures — from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, to the early California Arts and Crafts movement, to singer-songwriters living in Laurel Canyon in the late 1960s,” she said of her inspiration.

headline: London Theater Journal: Well-Seated Performers
text: LONDON — Rupert Everett and Rowan Atkinson are very good at sitting. This is more challenging and less boring than it sounds. I, for example, sat for nearly five hours watching these actors sitting in different West End revivals one day recently. But I seriously doubt that anyone focusing on me, or on any of my fellow audience members, during those hours would have been held in thrall.

headline: Really? Acupuncture Can Reduce Symptoms of Hay Fever
text: THE FACTS

headline: Image of the Day: March 11
text: Schools reopen in the Kashmir valley after a long winter break.

headline: Conclave Smoke’s Recipe Is a Mystery
text: During the papal conclave in the Sistine Chapel, progress will be measured in black and white — the colors of the smoke that will emerge after the voting, coming from a copper flue jutting from the chapel roof. But just how those colors are created remains a bit of a mystery.

headline: Nieuwenhuis on Schedule to Return to Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Outfielder Kirk Nieuwenhuis and the Mets are still targeting Wednesday for his return to outdoor baseball activities.

headline: Ritual and Secrecy Surround Conclave
text: VATICAN CITY — It begins with prayers chanted in an ancient language and ends with a tiny figure on the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica unveiled as the supreme pontiff of more than a billion Catholics. The conclave to elect a pope, which starts Tuesday, unfolds with elaborate ritual, deep secrecy and politicking that would warm the heart of a machine politician.

headline: An Elaborate Ritual to Elect a Pope
text: The Times’s Daniel J. Wakin reports on planning behind the conclave beginning on Tuesday. It’s a process that goes back centuries.

headline: Bieber and Rihanna Cancel Shows
text: It may be that the promoters of Justin Bieber’s two scheduled concerts in Portugal this week were overly ambitious: the Web page for the Pavilhao Atlantico in Lisbon, where Mr. Bieber was scheduled to perform tonight and Tuesday, limits ticket purchases to six a customer.

headline: Airport Screening Concerns Civil Liberties Groups
text: Aviation security leaders are moving forward with plans to shift toward a risk-based system of passenger screening — an idea supported by the travel industry and government officials who want screeners to focus on travelers who may present a security threat.

headline: Family Ties
text: More photos from the Broadway play "August: Osage County."

headline: Estelle Parsons on Stage
text: A look at some of the actress’s theatrical performances.

headline: Tournament Watch: Which Teams Need a Strong Showing
text: As every regular season ends and conference tournaments begin, a batch of college basketball teams can breathe easily, knowing that they will soon be one of 68 teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament. This has become a steady truth for usual juggernauts like Duke, Michigan State and Kansas, which will soon seal its 24th consecutive appearance in the tourney, the third-longest streak in tournament history behind North Carolina’s 27 straight from 1975-2001 and Arizona’s 25 from 1985-2009.

headline: Obama to Address Gathering of Donors and Activists
text: President Obama will speak Wednesday night at a dinner for donors and activists at the first gathering of Organizing for Action, the nonprofit group created by former campaign officials to help advance the president’s agenda, according to officials with the new organization.

headline: Chronic Insomnia Affects Heart
text: Insomnia may be linked to an increased risk of heart failure, according to a large new study, and the more insomnia symptoms, the greater the risk.

headline: Q. and A. With Thea Goodman, Author of ‘The Sunshine When She’s Gone’
text: It’s unusual for me to interview the author of a novel, rather than a nonfiction book on parenting. But then, “The Sunshine When She’s Gone,” by Thea Goodman, is an unusual book. Ms. Goodman’s main characters, the new parents Veronica and John, find themselves in that strange, sleep-deprived dream state of new parenthood, and then act on escape fantasies that will seem familiar to anyone who has been there.

headline: Van Jumps Curb in Queens, Killing Boy
text: A 16-year-old boy was killed and four other pedestrians were injured on Monday morning when a van jumped a curb outside LaGuardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Koch Willed Secretary $100,000 From $10 Million Estate
text: She was his fiercely loyal and unwaveringly discreet personal secretary for nearly 40 years, and he credited her for helping him achieve professional acclaim. And so former Mayor Edward I. Koch rewarded his secretary, Mary Garrigan, with a $100,000 bequest, according to his will.

headline: Edward I. Koch’s Will
text: Read the full will of Former Mayor Edward M. Koch.

headline: The Curse of EconoSisyphus
text: Jeff Frankel participates in a discussion of Chinese currency policy — and finds many of the participants subscribing to the doctrine of immaculate transfer. As he says, I thought I had definitively disposed of that doctrine 25 years ago. But it keeps coming back.

headline: ’Ino Helped Usher In Simpler, Freer Fare
text: In a Facebook post on Sunday, ’ino announced that it had closed. When the shoebox-shaped and nearly shoebox-size panini shop opened on Bedford Street 15 years ago, there was nothing quite like it in New York, a restaurant that kept things simple and kept prices low, serving flavorful food in a room that was just adorable enough that you could decide, midmeal, that maybe the two of you squeezed into the counter were there on a date, and not just grabbing a bite.

headline: The Junk-Food Pile
text: What emerged from the 1,300-plus comments posted by readers in response to Michael Moss’s article, “The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food,” was not only a debate over the tactics of food-industry giants (sentiments expressed on this past weekend’s letters page) but also a series of confessions about the processed foods that readers find most tempting.

headline: Illinois Is Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.
text: For the second time in history, federal regulators have accused an American state of securities fraud, finding that Illinois misled investors about the condition of its public pension system from 2005 to 2009.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Director Contends Acid Attack’s Mastermind Yet to Be Found
text: The web of intrigue around Russia’s Bolshoi Theater continued to grow over the weekend after Anatoly Iksanov, the theater’s general director, told Russian television that he doesn’t believe that the mastermind behind the January acid attack on Sergei Filin, the ballet company’s artistic director, has been found.

headline: Left Behind, UConn Ponders Starting Over Again
text: Connecticut is not eligible to play in the Big East men’s basketball tournament, which begins Tuesday, nor can it qualify for next week’s bigger national show. It would still be fitting for the Huskies to be at Madison Square Garden for the conference finale Saturday night, if only for the purpose of turning out the lights.

headline: Street Style: Plaid
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of March 4.

headline: Fill-In | For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article “For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required” by Nicole LaPorte.

headline: Recording Williamsburg’s Latest Transformation, and Raging Against It
text: “Gut Renovation” is a documentary that tells a familiar tale. It chronicles buildings torn down, communities elbowed out, and new residents ushered in as a tidal wave of gentrification swept through Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Free Festival to Offer Plays With New York Themes
text: Plays with New York themes written by John Patrick Shanley, Amiri Baraka, Edward Albee, Lorraine Hansberry and more than a dozen others will be featured in a free festival of readings and panel discussions led by members of the Labyrinth Theater Company starting next Monday and running through March 24, the organization has announced.

headline: Hedge Fund Donates $30 Million to Imperial College
text: LONDON – Brevan Howard, the London-based hedge fund, agreed Monday to donate £20.1 million, or $30 million, to the Imperial College to set up a finance research center in its name.

headline: High Cotton
text: Q. Why are clouds white?

headline: Feng Shui Fries
text: A fast-food joint designed for good luck.

headline: The Netherlands Eliminates Cuba at World Baseball Classic
text: TOKYO — Kalian Sams hit a ninth-inning sacrifice fly to cap a come-from-behind, 7-6 win over Cuba on Monday night at Tokyo Dome that sends the Netherlands to the World Baseball Classic semifinals in San Francisco next week.

headline: The Shelf Life of Donor Blood
text: How long should blood be stored?

headline: British Politician and Ex-Wife Sentenced to Prison
text: LONDON — A sensational trial that featured a leading politician, his extramarital affair, a speeding ticket, his now-divorced wife and her decision to wreak her revenge ended on Monday with a judge sending both of them to prison.

headline: Giants Shore Up Defensive Line, Sign Jenkins
text: 4:49 p.m. | Updated With the N.F.L. free agency signing period starting Tuesday, the Giants have already made their first move to bolster their defensive line, signing former Eagles defensive tackle Cullen Jenkins, the team confirmed on Monday.

headline: In Search of Energy Miracles
text: At a legendary but secretive laboratory in California, Lockheed Martin is working on a plan that some employees hope might transform the world’s energy system: a practicable type of nuclear fusion.

headline: From Medea to Winnie
text: A look at the stage work of actress Fiona Shaw.

headline: Cheers and Fears: Audience Reactions at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Watching genre films and comedies with a South by Southwest audience makes a strong case for the power of the theatrical experience and the value of its preservation. The crowds in Austin dive into festival films with enthusiasm and vigor, which makes them ideal for filmmakers eager to see how their films play to genre-loving fans, giving some indication of how the films might be met by audiences around the country.

headline: Photo Replay: March 11
text: A look at the day in sports, including U.S. women’s soccer, a dramatic Netherlands baseball victory and skaters preparing for the world championships.

headline: In First Overseas Trip, Hagel Offers a Terse Review: ‘It’s Complicated’
text: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel left Afghanistan at dawn on Monday, his anonymous Air Force cargo plane making a grand sweep of the ice-covered peaks that encircle the capital, ending a three-day visit punctuated by attacks.

headline: Seeing, and Thinking, Like Sherlock
text: Arthur Conan Doyle’s novels and short stories about the incomparable detective Sherlock Holmes have never been out of print since their first publication in 1887. Holmes collections abound, as do movies, TV series, video games, hats, pipes, T-shirts and calendars, not to mention nonfiction books dissecting the Holmesian method.

headline: Celebrities Help Unicef Turn On ‘Taps’ for Clean Water
text: This year the Unicef Tap Project is harnessing social media in a big way to raise funds for clean water for children worldwide.

headline: U.S. Demands China Block Cyberattacks and Agree to Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The White House demanded Monday that the Chinese government stop the widespread theft of data from American computer networks and agree to “acceptable norms of behavior in cyberspace.”

headline: For Vince Carter, Happiness as a Sixth Man
text: “Back in the day, I didn’t really care,” said Dallas’s Vince Carter, in the visitors’ locker room after a game at Minnesota. “I’m suffering now.”

headline: Lumière | They Eat Horses, Don’t They?
text: Last October, the super-starred French chef Alain Ducasse invited Dan Barber, of the Blue Hill restaurants in New York, to the Plaza Athenée to cook for some special guests. American Ambassador Charles H. Rivkin and his wife, Susan Tolson, showed up, as did dozens of Paris luminaries. The Americans were wowed by Barber’s inventiveness, including his use of charcoal made from pig bones to roast a whole pig. The French, by contrast, were horrified.

headline: Even Without Intrade, Billions Will Be Bet on 2016 Race
text: The popular prediction market Intrade, which in November shut down its markets to United States residents after a complaint from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, announced on Sunday that it was closing down entirely.

headline: New Optimism on Resveratrol
text: A cloud has long hung over the intriguing thesis that resveratrol, a minor ingredient of red wine, activates cellular proteins known as sirtuins that promote longer life in laboratory worms, flies and mice.

headline: Nominee for S.E.C. Chief Pledges to Keep Focus on Enforcement
text: WASHINGTON — Mary Jo White plans to strike a hard line against Wall Street wrongdoing at a Senate confirmation hearing on Tuesday, as she deflects concerns over her ability to regulate the same banks she recently defended.

headline: With Few Details, Lucasfilm Signals ‘Star Wars’ Plans for TV
text: LOS ANGELES – Now that Lucasfilm is moving full steam ahead on a new “Star Wars” trilogy, the company — now owned by Disney — is starting to get its TV universe in order. On Monday came word that Lucasfilm has “decided to pursue a new direction in animated programming.”

headline: Ai Weiwei Is Making a Rock Album
text: When Chinese authorities jailed the dissident sculptor Ai Weiwei for 81 days in 2011, they may have created a monster, of sorts: now Mr. Ai has announced that he is recording a heavy metal album, and he has traced the roots of his interest in music to his incarceration, when his guards asked him to sing, and he realized that he knew only Chinese revolutionary songs.

headline: Mixing Scripture Into the Batter
text: CAMBRIDGE, N.Y. — At first, the prep work for 200 four-pound cheesecakes in the sunny, commercial kitchen seemed familiar, unremarkable.
