text: The Dolphins Get a New Fan

headline: Virginia VanZanten, Matthew Perlman
text: Virginia Kyle VanZanten and Matthew Blake Perlman were married Saturday at the Dumbo Loft, an event space in Brooklyn. Megan R. Brown, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Christina Poulsen, Maxwell Brunner
text: Christina Lee Poulsen, a daughter of Joyce Lee Poulsen and Poul Skoedt Poulsen of San Rafael, Calif., was married Saturday to Maxwell Roy Brunner, a son of Sally Taylor Brunner and Timothy Allan Brunner of Ridgefield, Conn. Canon Mark Stanger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco.

headline: Nancy Quay and Sherry Marcy
text: A Partner and the Key to Her Survival

headline: Italian Lawmakers Elect Speakers, but Stable Government Remains Elusive
text: ROME — The Italian Parliament elected speakers for the two houses of Parliament on Saturday, but failed to find broad agreement among lawmakers in what is shaping up to be an uphill effort to form a stable government after inconclusive elections last month.

headline: Dominicans Show Culture in Emotional Style of Play
text: MIAMI — The Dominican Republic has celebrated every hit as if it were its last, every putout as if it had decided the game. Its players have clenched their fists, pounded their chests and screamed — sometimes in the fourth inning. And if the Dominicans took a late lead, the whole dugout would explode, players bursting onto the field, like confetti out of a party popper.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 16, 2013

headline: Red Bulls Do Everything but Win, Again
text: HARRISON, N.J. — When they last met, the Red Bulls and D.C. United sat through a one-day postponement of their playoff game because of a snowstorm. The next day, D.C. ended the Red Bulls’ 2012 season.

headline: Dieng Powers Cardinals’ Defense, and Their Big Comeback
text: Standing in the center circle for the opening tipoff of the last tournament of the old Big East, Louisville’s Gorgui Dieng knew the moment was weighty, but he may not have recognized just how much so.

headline: U.S. Soccer: Klinsmann’s Choices, Summer Friendlies, Women’s Injuries
text: Jurgen Klinsmann will name his roster Monday for the United States’ next two World Cup qualifiers. The games — against Costa Rica on Friday in Commerce City, Colo., and against Mexico next Tuesday in Mexico City — won’t decide whether the Americans play in the 2014 World Cup, but they could make getting there a lot easier, or infinitely more difficult.

headline: New Prime Minister Seeks to Reassure World on China’s Rise
text: BEIJING — Does China have a growing image problem in the world?

headline: The U.S. and Afghanistan
text: The long troubled U.S. - Afghan relationship winds down.

headline: A Crowded Venue for Justin Timberlake
text: If you want to know how far the South by Southwest Music Festival has strayed from its anti-corporate, indie rock roots, you need only consider this: One of the most popular shows on the final night of the festival was Justin Timberlake, playing a concert sponsored by Chevrolet to promote the newly revamped Myspace Web site.

headline:
Turmoil in Cyprus
Over a Bailout
Rattles Europe
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Europe’s surprising decision early Saturday to force bank depositors in Cyprus to share in the cost of the latest euro zone bailout set off increasing outrage and turmoil in Cyprus on Sunday and fueled fears that the trouble will spread to countries like Spain and Italy.

headline: In China, New Premier Says He Seeks a Just Society
text: BEIJING — Li Keqiang, in his first comments as China’s prime minister, laid out a vision on Sunday of a more equitable society in which environmental protection trumps unbridled growth and government officials put the people’s welfare before their own financial interests.

headline: The Psychologist as (Wary) Parent
text: Nine years ago, I was eight and a half months pregnant with my first child and sitting with Debby, a treasured senior colleague and gifted psychotherapist. She departed from our regular business to venture:

headline: Kenyans Win in City’s First Major Race Since Marathon Cancellation
text: Freezing temperatures and a dusting of snow Sunday did little to slow Wilson Kipsang, who ran away from a pack of elite runners to win the 13.1-mile New York City Half, the first major road race in the city since Hurricane Sandy led to the cancellation of the marathon in November.

headline: U.N. Revives Effort on Pact to Regulate Arms Trade
text: In the shadow of the re-energized gun-control debate in the United States, negotiators at the United Nations will reconvene this week to try to reach a final agreement on a treaty to regulate the global trade in conventional weapons, a lucrative business that rights groups call the main source of illicit arms fueling deadly conflicts around the world.

headline: Ohio Teenagers Guilty in Rape That Social Media Brought to Light
text: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — Two high school football stars were found guilty on Sunday of raping a 16-year-old girl last summer in a case that drew national attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage.

headline: Wright Returns to Mets And Says Pain Is Easing
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Boldface names swept through the Mets’ spring training complex Sunday, including Regis Philbin, whose ceremonial first pitch sent cellphone cameras aloft around Tradition Field, and third baseman David Wright, whose presence in the clubhouse after his return from the World Baseball Classic also caused a stir.

headline: Disruptions: Stuck With a Provider Over the Long Haul
text: If dating were like the cellphone industry, you would have to sign a contract when you entered a relationship stating that you would remain monogamous for two years, even if you wanted to break up. That’s what cellular carriers have pulled off by successfully lobbying for a recent government ruling that you cannot take the phone you paid for and switch to another provider.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (E!) PLAYING WITH FIRE The former “Top Chef” competitor Candice Kumai; the night-life impresarios turned food entrepreneurs Derek and Daniel Koch; the brand ambassador Anna Boiardi; the pastry chef Julie Elkind; the restaurateur Todd English; and the actress and bakery owner Jennifer Esposito turn their lives into open cookbooks as they storm the New York culinary scene in this new reality series. In this premiere episode, the Koch twins prepare for the grand opening of Toy, a restaurant inside the Gansevoort Hotel. Ms. Boiardi, meanwhile, finds that her mother disapproves of her Bolognese-cooking technique. And Mr. English celebrates his birthday and the 10th anniversary of his restaurant Olives. Above, a scene from the show.

headline: Disney’s ‘Oz’ Keeps Lead at Box Office
text: “Oz the Great and Powerful” continued to cast a spell on moviegoers over the weekend, while another magician — “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone” — essentially arrived to a chorus of boos. “Oz” (Disney) took in an estimated $42.2 million at theaters in the United States and Canada, for a strong two-week total of $145 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Mound Builders'
text: A scene from the Signature Theater’s revival of Lanford Wilson’s 1975 play.

headline: Original Review: ‘The Mound Builders’
text: Mel Gussow’s 1975 review of the Lanford Wilson play.

headline: Turkish Authorities Detain Man in Death of Tourist From Staten Island
text: ISTANBUL — A 46-year-old homeless man suspected in the killing of a Staten Island woman was taken into custody on Sunday, the Turkish authorities said.

headline: A Low-Carb, Low-Budget Cooking Show, Fiercely Seasoned
text: Television cooking shows, with their globe-trotting superstar chefs, are no longer humble small-studio affairs. But there is one program, glamorous in its own way, that gleefully bucks the trend. It is taped in a cramped apartment kitchen in Jackson Heights, Queens, and appears on public access. Its star is a trim, sassy drag queen named Soraya Sobreidad who preaches the gospel of healthful Puerto Rican cuisine.

headline: Funny or Die Makes a Steve Jobs Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — Techies have been keeping a hot eye on dueling Steve Jobs biopics, one an indie starring Ashton Kutcher and the other, written by Aaron Sorkin, in the works at Sony, which made “The Social Network.”

headline: A Senate Plan Alters Waiting Periods for Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s 11 million illegal immigrants would have to wait a full decade for a green card but could earn citizenship just three years after that, under a provision being finalized by a bipartisan group of eight senators working to devise an overhaul of immigration law, several people with knowledge of the negotiations said.

headline: The Cypriot Haircut
text: OK, I didn’t see that one coming. With all the problems in Greece, Italy, Spain, and Portugal I wasn’t watching Cyprus. But that’s where the big euro news is this weekend; in return for a bailout, Cyprus is supposed to impose a large haircut — that is, loss — on all depositors in its banks.

headline: Appealing to Hearts and Gullets, Francis Delights Crowd on First Sunday as Pope
text: VATICAN CITY — In his first Sunday appearance from the papal apartment overlooking St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis charmed a huge crowd by infusing the message of the Gospel with personal recollections and a smattering of humor.

headline: Architectural Iconoclast Wins the Pritzker Prize
text: Toyo Ito, a Japanese architect who broke from Modernism and designed a library that survived his country’s catastrophic 2011 earthquake, was awarded his profession’s top honor, the Pritzker Architecture Prize, on Sunday.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Unswayed by Obama’s ‘Charm Offensive’
text: President Obama appeared on Sunday to still be enjoying a bit of good karma from his extended outreach to Congress last week, but Republican leaders who hold the most sway over fiscal negotiations were holding firm in opposition to the president.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Selection Sunday
text: Empty brackets become a thing of the past today as the field of 68 is chosen for the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Mike Huguenin is providing live updates and analysis.

headline: You Really Can’t Eat Just One, and Here’s the Reason
text: Americans eat 33 pounds of cheese and cheese products per year, per person, which is triple the consumption rate of the 1970s. Fans of Humboldt Fog and Cabot Clothbound Cheddar may hope this signals the return of the artisan producer, but Michael Moss gives all credit to mighty Kraft and the other food giants.

headline: Onstage Patter, Before the Feet Move
text: At the Ailey Citigroup Theater last April, Troy Powell talked about having to fill a small woman’s big shoes. He was referring to his succeeding Sylvia Waters, who was stepping down after 38 years as the artistic director of Ailey II, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s junior company. On Wednesday, when Ailey II opened its first New York season under Mr. Powell’s direction, he said that for himself and seven new dancers “everything is new, including my shoes.”

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: As Kuroda Enters What Could Be His Final Season, Wells Is an Unlikely Guide
text: TAMPA, Fla. — An unlikely friendship was forged in front of Hiroki Kuroda’s locker Thursday morning when the quiet and clean-cut Kuroda invited the gregarious and tattooed David Wells to pull up a chair.

headline: Teixeira Expected to Be Out Longer With Partly Torn Tendon Sheath
text: TAMPA, Fla. — First baseman Mark Teixeira returned to the Yankees’ spring training complex Sunday morning, wearing a brace on his right wrist and delivering grim news. His injury was originally thought to be a sprain, but is a partly torn tendon sheath. He will most likely be out until June, and maybe longer, if he and the Yankees do not employ an abundance of caution.

headline: Drones: A Booming Business?
text: Unmanned aerial vehicles, also known as drones, may soon become commercialized. In Grand Forks, N.D., people are preparing for a coming boom in drones-related business.

headline: Domestic Drones Stir Imaginations, and Concerns
text: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — On the pilot’s computer screen, planted at ground level a few yards from the airport runway here, the data streaming across the display tracked an airplane at 1,300 feet above a small city on the coast, making perfect circles at 150 miles per hour.

headline: Republicans Act With Air, if Not a Vote, of Confidence
text: WASHINGTON — A year ago this month, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin stood on the floor of the House and declared that the ideals of small government, privatized health care and rigorous spending discipline captured in the budget plan about to pass the House would and should be central to the 2012 election campaign.

headline: Painting’s Removal Stirs Outcry
text: For more than 100 years it hung in the Seward family home in Auburn, in central New York State: a large oil painting by Thomas Cole, the founder of the Hudson River School, that was given to Gov. William H. Seward to thank him for his work expanding the Erie Canal.

headline: Summoning Jazz Spirits to the Temple
text: On a small stage facing the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art the WNYC radio host Terrance McKnight put on his most serious voice and requested a divine secret of the saxophonist Charles Lloyd. “Who does one talk to,” he asked, “to have one’s 75th birthday fall on a Friday night?”

headline: Mother, as She Lives and Breathes
text: A series called “Bates Motel” can’t open with a shower scene. But since this new drama, starting Monday on A&E, is, after all, a prequel of sorts to the movie “Psycho,” homage had to be paid to Alfred Hitchcock upfront. The creators went with that director’s sly sense of humor.

headline: Pregnant Girl Vanishes, and Story Lines Fork
text: There are times during “Top of the Lake” when you can convince yourself that you’re watching a mystery story about a girl who goes missing. But that sensation never lasts.

headline: Start With Adolescent Spirit, Then Grow Into a Role
text: A singer trying out a role for the first time anywhere at the barnlike, high-exposure Metropolitan Opera is like a runner taking a chance on a new distance at the Olympics. And that race is the marathon when the role is a touchstone like Violetta in Verdi’s “Traviata,” which returned to the Met on Thursday starring Diana Damrau, Plácido Domingo and Saimir Pirgu and conducted by Yannick Nézet-Séguin.

headline: I’ll Be There for You
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a smooth solve until I got to the payoff. I solved this puzzle by Daniel Landman (who appears to be making a debut) from the outside in, noting the theme entries of two-word phrases that started with S and I. It’s an enjoyable solve, perfectly pleasant for a Monday, with a payoff that seems a bit Wednesdayish to me.

headline: A Death in Paraguay Leads a Niece to Brutal Truths
text: The style is simple but the emotions highly sophisticated in “108 (Cuchillo de Palo),” Renate Costa’s insistently prodding documentary about the secret life of her gay uncle, Rodolfo Costa, under the oppressive government of the Paraguayan dictator Alfredo Stroessner.

headline: Lebhar IMP Pairs in St. Louis
text: ST. LOUIS — The winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs on Saturday evening here were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York. They finished 5.36 international match points ahead of Lewis Gamerman of Westwood, Mass., and Robert McCaw of Sudbury, Mass. Third were Robert Cappelli of Bloomfield, Mich., and Robert Katz of Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Selling Stars, Brands and Baby Bands
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Two images linger from this year’s South by Southwest Music festival, which ended Sunday after five nights and days with hundreds of performances. One has been the major part of SXSW for all of its 27 years: sharing the crowded sidewalks with sleep-deprived but bright-eyed musicians toting their own equipment to the next gig. The other is more recent: a 62-foot-high outdoor stage built to resemble a snack-chip vending machine that turned into a six-story video billboard when it wasn’t showing live performances.

headline: Footnote
text: The New York theater company Clubbed Thumb has announced its lineup for the 18th annual Summerworks festival, which is set for May 24 to June 29 at the Wild Project in the East Village. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, is to feature the three new plays; “Phoebe in Winter,” by Jen Silverman (“Crane Story”), “La Brea,” by Gregory S. Moss (“Billy Witch”) and Clare Barron’s “Baby Screams Miracle.”

headline: Waiting for the Run on the Banks
text: The economics Nobel laureate Paul Krugman could not have been clearer about the dangers of forcing depositors in Cypriot banks to take a loss on their accounts.

headline: To Reassure Investors, Fed Stresses It Will Not End Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — Each time in recent years that the Federal Reserve has paused in its efforts to stimulate the economy, it has come to regret the decision as premature. Its leading officials say the recovery has been slower as a consequence of those pauses. It is a mistake they do not want to repeat.

headline: South by Southwest Music Festival
text: Scenes from this year’s festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: Zimbabwe Arrests Opposition Officials and a Human Rights Lawyer
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Security officials arrested three senior officials of the Movement for Democratic Change, Zimbabwe’s main opposition political party, and a renowned human rights lawyer on Sunday, one day after a largely peaceful referendum on a draft constitution.

headline: A Conference With Dual Constituencies Vows to Improve
text: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual Transformation conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A’s, held last week in New Orleans.

headline: Pick Your N.C.A.A. Tournament Sleepers
text: Now that we know who will be playing, it’s time to think about which lower-seeded teams will pull off upsets in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Spreading Disruption, Shaking Up Cable TV
text: The table in the conference room on the sixth floor of the IAC headquarters in Manhattan was a portrait of organization. In front of each of the 10 chairs was a leather case holding a fresh tablet of paper, with a sharpened pencil placed above it, just so. Everything in “the Helm,” as they call the room, was precise, orderly, logical. Just the way Barry Diller likes it.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Clippers Overpower Knicks, Whose Skid Reaches 4 Games
text: LOS ANGELES — The easiest way to get embarrassed in the N.B.A. is to be dunked on, to challenge the opposing player as he rises up and tries to put you on his highlight reel. The Los Angeles Clippers are the best team in the league at making opponents look silly, to the point that their video clips go viral seemingly within minutes.

headline: Obama’s Visit to Israel Renews Effort to Free Spy
text: JERUSALEM — When President Obama lands here on Wednesday, he may encounter some Israelis staging a hunger strike in support of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel.

headline: Free Downloads of ‘Da Vinci Code’ to Promote ‘Inferno’
text: How about this for a promotional thriller: Beginning Monday, on the 10th anniversary of the release of the mega-bestseller “The Da Vinci Code,” its publisher, Doubleday, will allow anyone to download the entire book free for a week.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include housing starts for February (Tuesday) and weekly jobless claims, existing home sales for February, the Philadelphia Fed index for March and leading economic indicators for February (Thursday).

headline: HLN’s Jodi Arias Coverage Helps Bolster Ratings
text: The cable news channel HLN, which had some of its highest ratings during the trial of Casey Anthony two years ago, has become fixated on another: the trial of Jodi Arias, a woman accused of killing her ex-boyfriend, Travis Alexander, in Arizona in 2008.

text: View and print our N.C.A.A. Tournament bracket. The tournament begins Tuesday.

headline: White House Urged to Fire a Housing Regulator
text: WASHINGTON — Prominent state attorneys general are calling on President Obama to fire the acting director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency and name a new permanent director, arguing that current policies are impeding the economic recovery.

headline: Time’s Health Care Opus Is a Hit
text: Publishing a 36-page cover article called “Bitter Pill: Why Medical Bills Are Killing Us” certainly didn’t seem like a shameless attempt to bolster newsstand sales for Time magazine.

headline: Richard D. Lyons, Versatile Times Reporter, Dies at 84
text: Richard D. Lyons, who covered science, Congress and the United Nations during almost 30 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 84.

headline: Tax Breaks: Mostly Tilted Toward the Wealthy
text: Tax expenditures cost the federal government more than $1 trillion a year in lost revenue.

headline: Dispute on Transgender Rights Unfolds at a Colorado School
text: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — Coy Mathis was born a boy. But after just a few years, biology succumbed to a more powerful force.

headline: Divided Views of SAC Capital Settlement
text: Not many Wall Street executives, let alone hedge funds, could write a $616 million check and remain solvent.

headline: San Francisco Symphony’s East Coast Tour Is Canceled as Labor Talks Break Down
text: The San Francisco Symphony has announced that negotiations over a new contract with its musicians have broken down with the players’ rejection of a federal mediator’s proposal for a cooling-off period. As a result, the orchestra’s East Coast tour, which was to have included concerts at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Thursday as well as concerts in Newark on Friday and Washington on Saturday, has been canceled.

headline: Tax Credits or Spending? Labels, but in Congress, Fighting Words
text: WASHINGTON — In a low-income neighborhood in Bozeman, Mont., taxpayers helped pay for the construction of a grocery store, Town and Country Foods. They are doing the same in New Orleans, with federal dollars helping to build new groceries, including a Whole Foods, in an area still suffering after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Louisville’s Pressure Defense Creates Victories
text: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino has his assistants chart deflections whenever his team takes the court, whether for practice or for games. The totals are collected and posted, and Pitino reinforces the message every day, every hour, practically every minute through the season: stay active on defense, keep your hands busy, knock the ball away. At Louisville, deflections form the foundation for the team’s swarming defense.

headline: Terror Haven in Mali Feared After French Leave
text: NEMA, Mauritania — With France planning to start withdrawing its troops from Mali next month, Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the African soldiers who will be relied on to continue the campaign against militants linked to Al Qaeda there do not have the training or equipment for the job.

headline: Criticizing Bloomberg, Liu Enters Race to Succeed Him
text: Brushing off his legal troubles as the price of taking on powerful interests, an exuberant John C. Liu, the city comptroller, officially began his campaign for mayor on Sunday with a vow to represent the “100 percent,” not “the 1 percent.”

text: This is the second part of a six-part series.

headline: Gideon’s Muted Trumpet
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Why Iran May Be Ready to Deal
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Drones, Ethics and the Armchair Soldier
text: Ten years ago, I watched the Iraq invasion unfold on TV. It was for me, like most Americans, a remote-control event, the type that you tuned into occasionally to see how it was going before changing the channel, like the Olympics. And, as often happens in the Olympics, we crushed the opposition. But we Americans at home were not the only ones with remote controls. Many of our soldiers also had them, and used them to direct one of the most devastating military assaults in the history of modern warfare. The technological superiority of the United States — its ability to strike with precision from a distance — produced something like the “shock and awe” the media had relentlessly advertised. And it inspired a similar reaction in moral and legal theorists who were concerned about the relationship between advanced military technologies and the legitimation of warfare.

headline: Riffs by Cab Riders, Secretly Recorded for the Sake of Art
text: His career as a New York City taxi driver began with a graveyard shift, a creative itch, and a brazen interpretation of privacy laws.

headline: Cruelty to Women Overseas
text: Each year some 47,000 women around the world die as a result of unsafe abortions. Efforts to reduce that toll are severely hampered by the Helms amendment, which was originally enacted in 1973 and restricts the use of United States foreign aid money to finance abortions overseas, even in places where abortion is legal.

headline: A Worsening Haitian Tragedy
text: The aid group Doctors Without Borders said last Tuesday that the cholera crisis in Haiti was getting worse, for the most unnecessary and appalling of reasons: a lack of money and basic medical supplies.

headline: No Nukes on the Korean Peninsula
text: It’s little wonder that South Koreans are thinking about ways to defend themselves, given North Korea’s bizarre and dangerous behavior. The North has recently launched a long-range rocket and conducted its third nuclear test. It has also unleashed a barrage of apocalyptic threats, including potentially launching “pre-emptive nuclear strikes” on Seoul and the United States and declaring the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified.

headline: Marches of Folly
text: Ten years ago, America invaded Iraq; somehow, our political class decided that we should respond to a terrorist attack by making war on a regime that, however vile, had nothing to do with that attack.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 17, 2013

headline: U.S. Looked at Wall Street Journal Over Claims of Bribery
text: The United States government’s inquiry into News Corporation broadened last year when the Justice Department investigated claims that employees in the China news bureau of The Wall Street Journal bribed local officials with gifts in exchange for information.

headline: Drugs for Early-Stage Alzheimer’s
text: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed lowering the bar for approving drugs to treat people at the earliest stages of Alzheimer’s disease, before they have developed any serious impairment or overt dementia. The goal is commendable — to find ways to prevent or slow the progression of this terrible disease before it can rob people of their mental capacities. But the proposal raises troubling questions as to whether the agency would end up approving drugs that provide little or no clinical benefit yet cause harmful side effects in people who take the medications for extended periods.

headline: Saving Schools and Libraries by Giving Up the Land They Sit On
text: The Brooklyn Heights library is neither the oldest nor the most dilapidated branch of the Brooklyn Public Library system. But the 52-year-old limestone building is nonetheless ripe for demolition.

headline: What Does It Mean to Live With Less?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fire in Bronx Apartment Building Kills 7-Year-Old Girl
text: A fire started in a Bronx apartment building just after 3 a.m. on Sunday, announcing itself with thick clouds of black smoke billowing through the hallways. It burned through a fourth-floor apartment, killing a 7-year-old girl and critically injuring a 3-year-old girl, the authorities said.

headline: Hacker Case Leads to Calls for Better Law
text: Matthew Keys, the 26-year-old deputy social media editor at Reuters charged with assisting computer hackers, has emerged as the latest lightning rod in the continuing battle between proponents of Internet freedom and the Justice Department.

headline: Clippers Whip Knicks, but Martin Remains Unimpressed
text: LOS ANGELES — In a three-minute postgame interview Sunday, Knicks forward Kenyon Martin indicated his bitterness toward the Los Angeles Clippers, his former team. And he did not give the Clippers much credit for their 93-80 win over the Knicks at the Staples Center.

headline: In Florida, a Political Marriage Soured Before a Top Official Stepped Down
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — As the annual press corps political roast unfolded here on Tuesday evening, Gov. Rick Scott stared stone-faced, holding a secret, while he watched a reporter spoof his strained relationship with his lieutenant governor, Jennifer Carroll.

headline: Bubbling Up: The Downside of Being No. 1
text: Of all the numbers in college basketball, No. 1 may be the most ubiquitous. You can find it on jerseys and foam hands and after victories when index fingers are shot skyward. You can hear it — “We’re No. 1” — chanted on most nights.

headline: Trial to Start in Class Suit on Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
text: In one of the most significant courtroom tests of a key Bloomberg administration policy, a federal judge will begin hearing testimony on Monday in a trial to determine whether the New York Police Department has been unconstitutionally stopping black and Hispanic males in the street over the last decade.

headline: José Alfredo Martínez de Hoz, Argentine Official During Dictatorship, Dies at 87
text: BUENOS AIRES — José Alfredo Martínez de Hoz, who was the economics minister during Argentina’s dictatorship, died on Friday at his home here, where he was under arrest, accused of human rights abuses. He was 87.

headline: Starting a Papacy, Amid Echoes of a ‘Dirty War’
text: BUENOS AIRES — One Argentine priest is on trial in Tucumán Province on charges of working closely with torturers in a secret jail during the so-called Dirty War, urging prisoners to hand over information. Another priest was accused of taking a newborn from his mother, one of the many baby thefts from female prisoners who were “disappeared” into a system of clandestine prisons.

headline: Trading Hearings Put Focus Back on JPMorgan’s Chief
text: Jamie Dimon, the influential chief of JPMorgan Chase, watched from New York on Friday while in Washington his top lieutenants were questioned by a Senate panel over a multibillion-dollar trading loss.

text: Can celebrity 'ambassadors' who get involved in diplomacy or antipoverty efforts do more harm than good?

headline: Excavating Lost Artifacts of the 1970s
text: “The Mound Builders,” a 1975 play by Lanford Wilson, offers a sort of archaeological dig through the atmosphere and the attitudes that pervaded the decade in which it was written. Watching the new Signature Theater Company production, which opened on Sunday night, is like cracking open a time capsule that’s been buried for years. Unfortunately, in the director Jo Bonney’s slackly acted production, the contents don’t prove as fascinating to us today as we had reason to hope.

headline: City’s Sheltering of Out-of-Town Homeless, and Mayor’s Remark, Stir Debate
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has a penchant for hyperbole, was at it again this month when he fumed that New York State’s guarantee to shelter the homeless means “you can arrive in your private jet at Kennedy Airport, take a private limousine and go straight to the shelter system, and walk in the door and we’ve got to give you shelter.”

headline: A Field With Everything Except an Obvious Favorite
text: A season of extraordinary upheaval in college basketball yielded an N.C.A.A. tournament field with few favorites, several more surprises and a landscape wide open for potential upsets.

headline: Protection Orders and Gun Crimes
text: The New York Times examined gun-related crimes committed by people subject to domestic violence protection orders. These documents highlight three such cases across the country.

headline: In Clutch Situations, Michigan Turns to Burke
text: In a lineup loaded with talent, point guard Trey Burke stands out as the unquestioned choice when Michigan needs a basket. Everyone knows it, too.

headline: Trade Revis? Worth Considering if It Improves Jets, Johnson Says
text: PHOENIX — Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, said for the first time Sunday night that if making his team better meant trading any player — including cornerback Darrelle Revis — he would listen to an offer.

headline: Tisch Uneasy About Prospect of Losing Cruz
text: PHOENIX — Steve Tisch, who owns the Giants with John Mara, said Sunday that he was anxious about the idea that receiver Victor Cruz might draw an offer sheet from another team, which would force the Giants to decide whether to match the offer to retain Cruz or lose him and receive a first-round draft pick as compensation.

text: Gonzaga has a long men’s basketball tradition, more than a decade of consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, but this season the Bulldogs became one of the most unlikely teams to reach No. 1. And that was in large part because of their unlikely star.

headline: Guard Is Steady Force for Miami
text: There are more charismatic stars in the N.C.A.A. tournament, more compelling characters, louder and flashier. There are players who jump on scorers’ tables, and players who preen after dunks. Shane Larkin of Miami does none of that. He treats basketball like a chemistry exam, and he gets consistently high grades.

headline: In Some States, Gun Rights Trump Orders of Protection
text: Early last year, after a series of frightening encounters with her former husband, Stephanie Holten went to court in Spokane, Wash., to obtain a temporary order for protection.

headline: Obama Nominates Justice Aide for Labor Post
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that he would nominate Thomas E. Perez, who heads the Civil Rights Division at the Justice Department, to be the next secretary of labor, a choice that promised to provoke a debate with Republicans about voting rights, immigration and discrimination.

headline: Soft Landing for Nadal in Triumphant Return
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Rafael Nadal’s collapses on a court after winning championship points should not be surprising, given all his successes in past years and recent months. But after injuries had kept him off hardcourts for more than 11 months, his fall to the hardcourt surface at the BNP Paribas Open as a champion on Sunday did seem remarkable.

headline: He Hasn’t Had It All Either
text: I have not had it all.

headline: With Chance to Firm Up Standing, Nets Stumble Against the Hawks
text: It will be April when the Nets next play on the sleek herringbone court of Barclays Center, and by then their game Sunday night against the Atlanta Hawks will linger as either a distant memory or a haunting omen. The Nets are good enough to have secured a solid footing in the Eastern Conference playoff race but too inconsistent to emerge as a credible threat.

headline: Lewis Rallies for Title and No. 1 Ranking

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (TMC) MY LEFT FOOT (1989) Daniel Day-Lewis, in his first Oscar-winning role, portrays Christy Brown (1932-81), who was born in Dublin with cerebral palsy and learned to write and paint using the only limb he could control, his left foot. Brenda Fricker, who also won an Oscar, and Ray McAnally play Christy’s parents; Ruth McCabe (above, with Mr. Day-Lewis) is the young woman he falls in love with and eventually marries; and Fiona Shaw is the doctor who largely facilitates his education in what Vincent Canby, writing in The New York Times, called “an intelligent, beautifully acted adaptation” of Mr. Brown’s first book, directed by Jim Sheridan. But “though ‘My Left Foot’ is blunt and tough in its presentation of Christy’s handicaps, it avoids any direct criticism of the handicapped world into which he is born, one in which his mother spends most of her time being pregnant, in which poverty is as likely to make the spirit ugly as beautiful, and in which the church always has the last word.”

headline: While Sliding Rangers Look Up in Standings, the Surging Penguins Look Down
text: After a trip that ended with three straight losses, the Rangers occupy 10th place in the Eastern Conference with only 21 games to play. They face two games in the next two nights from a perspective they have not seen in more than five years.

headline: Kingdom of the Netherlands, the Epitome of the Classic
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The goal of the World Baseball Classic has never been to prove which nation is best at baseball. This is not that kind of sport. Small samples can yield misleading conclusions. The validity of World Series results comes largely from the six-month grind just to get there.

headline: N.F.L. Is Pressured on Issues of Gay Rights
text: PHOENIX — The N.F.L.’s investigation into why a team employee asked a college player if he liked girls during last month’s scouting combine has found that the comment was part of casual banter — “chatter that was inappropriate” — but not part of a formal interview process, said Robert Gulliver, the league’s top human resources executive.

headline: Boston University’s Coach Closes In on Retirement
text: BOSTON — The man at the wake for the father of the future Boston University hockey coach Jack Parker quietly approached Parker’s mother to offer his condolences. He also offered something more: cash.

headline: The Nets’ Long and Winding Road Trip
text: When the N.B.A. completed the Nets’ schedule in August, forward Reggie Evans scanned the dates, and one doozy of a trip immediately caught his eye. The block of road games in late March, the one that involves 17 days, 8 cities, 10 chartered plane rides. Plans had to be made early.

headline: Greek Soccer Player Banned for Nazi Salute
text: Last Updated, 11:12 a.m. Giorgos Katidis, a 20-year-old Greek soccer player who celebrated a game-winning goal on Saturday by giving a Nazi salute to fans in Athens, has been banned for life from representing his country in international tournaments.

headline: News Quiz | March 18, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck.

headline: Puerto Rico Ousts Champion and Nears a Title of Its Own
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Alex Rios had not played here since the 2007 All-Star Game, when the American League manager, Jim Leyland, inserted him in right field in the bottom of the ninth inning. With the bases loaded in a one-run game, a fly ball settled into Rios’s glove for the final out.

headline: A Conversation With: Pakistani Author Mohsin Hamid
text: One of the most anticipated book releases this year is “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia” by the Lahore-born writer Mohsin Hamid. The tome, which debuted March 5, is written in a cheeky self-help format and tells the rags-to-riches story of a man in modern Asia.

headline: The Vatican and the Other China
text: BEIJING — There are approximately as many Catholics in the world as Chinese — over 1 billion each, with 1.3 billion Chinese just surpassing the world’s 1.2 billion Catholics.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March  18
text: NEWS Europe’s surprising decision early Saturday to force bank depositors in Cyprus to share in the cost of the latest euro zone bailout set off increasing outrage and turmoil in Cyprus on Sunday and fueled fears that the trouble will spread to countries like Spain and Italy. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus, and Landon Thomas Jr. from London.

headline: Lawmaker Says Britons Agree to New Press Rules After Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — After months of wrangling and dispute, and centuries of rambunctious freedom, lawmakers agreed to ground rules on Monday for a new press code, the most significant step toward stricter curbs on this country’s scoop-driven newspapers since the phone hacking scandal convulsed Rupert Murdoch’s media empire and much of British public life.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 18, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Keeping an Eye on Online Test-Takers.”

headline: How Much Do You Know About Your Family’s History?
text: Many families have stories–of triumph, of struggle, of events almost too funny or too unlikely to be real, but somehow are. Does your family have stories like these? What family narratives did you grow up hearing? How do you think they’ve helped define who you are and how you see yourself?

headline: In the Bronx, Nine High Schools Share One Building
text: In “Nine High Schools, One Roof,” Liz Robbins and Theodoric Meyer write about the Stevenson Campus in the Bronx.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are
text: Charles Fréger was fascinated by what the human race lost over the millenniums when it evolved from hunter-gather to farmer and, eventually, urban dweller. After learning that there were Europeans who continued ancient pagan rites of celebrating the winter solstice and the beginning of spring, he set out to examine what traditions faded as people became more civilized.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Extends Restrictions on Italian Ambassador
text: NEW DELHI— ­ A diplomatic tiff between India and Italy showed no signs of easing Monday after India’s Supreme Court extended its travel restrictions against the Italian ambassador for another week.

headline: After Frosty Past, Pope Meets Argentine Leader
text: VATICAN CITY — A day before his formal installation, Pope Francis met privately on Monday with Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the president of his native Argentina, with whom he had clashed over social issues like Argentina’s legalization of same-sex marriage.

headline: Russia’s New Normal
text: MOSCOW — It’s the sort of thing one hates hearing from one’s child. “You know, mom,” my 11-year-old daughter said, “It makes me particularly nervous when people make fun of gays.”

headline: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
text: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: Sexual Offenses Bill to Be Altered to Pass Parliament
text: NEW DELHI— A bill aimed at toughening India’s laws on rape and sexual violence will be altered, India’s law minister said Monday, a move expected to garner wider political support in a divided Parliament.

headline: The Unregulated Work of Mechanical Turk
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“
