headline: Daily Report: Domestic Drones on Patrol
text: On the pilot’s computer screen, planted at ground level a few yards from the airport runway in Grand Forks, N.D., the data streaming across the display tracked an airplane at 1,300 feet above a small city on the coast, making perfect circles at 150 miles per hour.

headline: Zimbabwe Police Defy Order to Free Lawyer, Group Says
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The Zimbabwean police defied a high court ruling issued at midnight on Sunday ordering the release of a renowned human rights lawyer, Beatrice Mtetwa, and continued to hold her on charges of obstructing justice, a rights group said Monday.

headline: Indonesian Carrier Orders $24 Billion in Jets From Airbus
text: PARIS — Airbus said Monday that it had received a record order for $24 billion worth of new single-aisle jets from the Indonesian low-cost airline Lion Air, marking a significant inroad for the European plane maker into one of the fastest-growing air travel markets in Asia that until now has been dominated by its American rival, Boeing.

headline: Pakistani Militants Kill 4 in Attack on Court Complex
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  —  Militants stormed a court complex in northwestern Pakistan on Monday, killing 4 people and wounding at least 30 people, including a judge, in the latest assault on government authority in the region.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 18, 2013
text: Updated: March 19

headline: This Week In Small Business: Surviving Shark Tank
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Up Here on This Island
text: The boy banged his thigh into the corner of the table, stopped mid-stride, grimaced, and the way you’d say godDAMmit, he said: johnHANcock! Then, because he knew that in the special school there was an expectation of a show of normality, he said: You’re probably wondering why I said that, but you wouldn’t understand.

headline: How the Other Half Thinks
text: NAIROBI — For a ringside seat on the spectacle of Kenyan democracy’s turbulent workings, I’d recommend Dormans on Mama Ngina Street. I had just ordered an espresso at the café, around the corner from the Supreme Court, on Saturday when the mood on this normally bustling street suddenly turned.

headline: Blunt Report Says G.O.P. Needs to Regroup for ’16
text: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders on Monday offered a sweeping self-critique of a party they said was in an “ideological cul-de-sac” and needed better outreach and a new brand of conservatism to appeal to younger voters, ethnic minorities and women.

headline: SAC Looks on the Bright Side
text: SAC LOOKS ON THE BRIGHT SIDE  |  The $616 million fine against SAC Capital Advisors that was announced on Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission would be enough to cripple some hedge funds. But SAC saw the positive in the penalty, which settles two insider trading lawsuits brought by the government, DealBook’s Peter Lattman writes. The $15 billion hedge fund said in a statement that the settlements were “a substantial step toward resolving all outstanding regulatory matters.”

headline: Opinion Report: Treating Alzheimer’s
text: From the editorial page

headline: Environmental Woes Could Reverse Global Development
text: Climate change and other environmental disasters could put 3.1 billion people into extreme poverty by 2050, if no significant steps are taken, says an annual United Nations report on the state of global development.

headline: March Madness for Book Geeks Rolls On
text: College basketball fans may have to wait until Tuesday for their yearly N.C.A.A. tournament fix, but March Madness for lit geeks is already well under way thanks to The Morning News’s Tournament of Books.

headline: Monday Reading: Frugal Travel Along the Yangtze River
text: Frugal travel along the Yangtze River, a dad can’t have it all either, answers to questions about paying for college and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Gender Bias Seen in Visas for Skilled Workers
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee heard testimony Monday afternoon arguing that the H-1B visa program, which covers highly skilled temporary foreign workers, often in high-tech fields, discriminates against women.

headline: Tournament Bracket and Forecast
text: Need help with your N.C.A.A. bracket? Nate Silver is estimating each team’s chance of advancing to any given stage of the N.C.A.A. bracket. View his estimates as a table and read his pre-tournament analysis.

headline: Advertising Research Foundation Gets Its First Female Leader
text: The Advertising Research Foundation is naming a longtime research executive at General Mills as its next president and chief executive, making her the first woman to lead the organization.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ben Ehrenreich on Witnessing the Friday Protests in a West Bank Village
text: Ben Ehrenreich is the author of this week’s cover article about the weekly Friday protests against Israeli occupation of Nabi Saleh in the West Bank. Ehrenreich has published two novels, “Ether” and “The Suitors,” and contributed to Harper’s Magazine, Los Angeles Magazine and other publications.

headline: The View of New York Under an Umbrella
text: Dear Diary:

headline: An Oracle Veteran’s Comeback Plan
text: This has the makings of a decent revenge story, or at least a tech giant face-off.

headline: Thai Modern
text: Rather than rooms, the Naka hotel is made up of 94 minimalist glass-and-stone pods, elevated and scattered pell-mell among tropical almond trees in this secluded new beach resort on the western coast of Phuket, Thailand. Each unit comes with a private pool and a cantilevered bedroom that juts out 20 feet toward the Andaman Sea. Rates from about $1,000; designhotels.com.

headline: A New Focus on Poverty Raises a Question About Times Coverage
text: Poverty was in the news last week, with the coverage of Pope Francis’ attention to poor people worldwide, particularly those in his home country of Argentina.

headline: Cyprus Bailout Puts New Pressure on Europe’s Banks
text: 12:14 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ericsson and ST Microelectronics to Dissolve Venture
text: BERLIN — Ericsson and STMicroelectronics announced plans on Monday to dissolve their unprofitable four-year-old Swiss venture, ST-Ericsson, a move that may eliminate 1,600 jobs worldwide.

headline: Senate Report on JPMorgan Loss May Provide Fresh Evidence
text: The Senate report and hearing on JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar trading loss provides a portrait of a bank that went right to the edge of acceptable practices, and may have even stepped over the line. The questions now are what type of enforcement action the bank could face, and whether any individuals will be ensnared by the case.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bribery Inquiry at The Journal, and Taking Aim at Cable TV
text: A United States government inquiry into News Corporation broadened last year after the Justice Department investigated claims that Wall Street Journal employees in China bribed local officials with gifts in exchange for information, Christine Haughney writes. The Journal broke the news of the investigation on Sunday. Paula Keve, a spokeswoman for The Journal, said that the company was conducting its own investigation and had found no evidence of impropriety. The bribery accusations came out of a broader investigation into News Corporation’s practices, and Ms. Keve suggested that the claims had been made to discredit The Journal’s reporting.

headline: Island Nightmares
text: What is it about islands around Europe’s periphery? Is there some peculiar psychological thing about proximity plus the illusion of isolation that makes them turn themselves into havens for runaway banks? Inquiring minds want to know.

headline: Leading Off: Selection Science or a Dartboard?
text: Normally, one of the best things about N.C.A.A. tournament week is its  democracy. No, not every one of the tournament’s 68 teams has an equal chance to win the title, but every single person in your circle of acquaintances has a roughly equal chance to win your N.C.A.A. pool. Because no matter how much the rabid basketball fans think they know about R.P.I. and strength of schedule and just how well Coach A does against Coach K, once the tournament starts, all that knowledge has as much to do with picking winners as it does forecasting an election in Burma. The bloke who picks against Notre Dame because it wore those horrific lime green jerseys in the Big East tournament? Our money’s on him.

headline: Resistance to HPV Vaccines Needs New Solutions
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend three vaccinations for preteens and teenagers: a booster for tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) given at 11-12 years; quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MCV4), with a first dose at 11-12 and a follow-up at 16-18; and human papillomavirus vaccine (HPV), given in three doses over a six-month period to boys and girls 11-12.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Hires Co-Heads of U.S. Technology Banking
text: The Royal Bank of Canada said on Monday that it had hired Michal Katz and Michael Carter as co-heads of its United States technology investment banking group. The bank also hired Erik-Jaap Molenaar as a managing director in technology mergers and acquisitions. All three come from Barclays, and had previously worked at Lehman Brothers.

headline: Queens Central Library Opens Wider
text: It’s a mystery at first. The youngsters on the computers in the children’s center adjoining the Queens Central Library appear to be squatting on floor cushions, but their legs are nowhere to be seen. In a moment, it grows clear. They’re seated at shallow wells scooped into the floor so there’s no danger of falling off their chairs.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York: As a chilly March drags on at the greenmarket, even a ramp would look good right now. Or how about a batch of rutabaga fries? — Patrick Farrell

headline: A Blankfein Wedding
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, has gained a daughter-in-law.

headline: Ectopic Pregnancy Treatments Preserve Fertility
text: Each of the three main treatments for ectopic pregnancy — a condition in which a fetus develops outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tube — appears to be equally effective in preserving a women’s ability to become pregnant in the future, a new study found.

headline: Parity in N.C.A.A. Means No Commanding Favorite
text: Even before the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket was announced on Sunday, there was plenty of discussion about how much parity there was in this year’s field. The chatter only increased after Louisville, the No. 1 overall seed, was placed in a brutally tough Midwest region that also includes Duke and Michigan State.

headline: The Unobstructed Home
text: The houses photographed for Deborah Pierce’s book, “The Accessible Home: Designing for All Ages & Abilities,” look so inviting that I want to move in.

headline: Beans and Greens: A Power Couple
text: If you’ve been a longtime follower of Recipes for Health, you know how much I like combining beans and greens. They make a good, nourishing couple and every peasant cuisine in the world seems to know this. It’s so easy to put together a hearty, high-protein one-dish meal rich in vitamins and minerals with these two foods as the focus.

headline: A Small-Business Office Is Accused of Advocating for Big Business
text: For decades, the Office of Advocacy, a bureau within the Small Business Administration, has worked behind the scenes to soften the impact of federal regulations on small companies. It is charged with, among other responsibilities, representing “the views and interests of small businesses before other federal agencies.” To learn how regulatory policies might affect small businesses, the office regularly convenes round-table discussions with its constituents.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Karen Elson and Buzz Aldrin
text: A dual review of what’s new, by model mom and smoky-voiced chanteuse Karen Elson and legendary moonwalker Buzz Aldrin.

headline: Maria Shriver Appears on ‘Today’ for Papal Coverage
text: Maria Shriver, a former NBC correspondent, took a first step toward resuming that role on Monday when she contributed a report to NBC's “Today” show.

headline: Singapore’s Lessons for an Unequal America
text: SINGAPORE

headline: Mali Exit Strategy
text: Back from North Africa, The Times’s Eric Schmitt reports on mounting concerns surrounding French plans to draw down troops.

headline: Chrysler Warns Dodge Challenger Owners of Fire Risk
text: Concerned about a fire hazard, Chrysler is telling owners of about 2,500 of its 2013 Dodge Challengers with the 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6 to stop driving the cars and not park them near any structure.

headline: With New Chinese Leaders in Place, Waiting for an Agenda to Emerge
text: China’s leadership succession that began last autumn is now complete. Xi Jinping holds the three top positions as general secretary of the Communist Party, chairman of the Central Military Commission and president. Li Keqiang is the new premier.

headline: Colleges Hope 8 Seconds on TV Provide Lasting Image
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The prime-time national television spotlight landed on the Florida Gulf Coast men’s basketball team at 6:14 p.m. Sunday and lasted for about eight seconds, as the Eagles whooped and danced and waved towels in delirium.

headline: The Яussians Are Coming! The Яussians Are Coming!
text: How big a deal is the Russian factor in Cyprus’s crisis? Pretty big, it seems. Over at FT Alphaville, Izabella Kaminska reports on estimates of 19 billion euros in Russian nationals’ deposits in Cyprus banks, which is more than the country’s GDP. Without being an expert here, I wonder whether this is an understatement; given what we think we know about the nature of much of this Russian money, is all of it really being declared as Russian?

headline: A Triumphant Show by the Artist Yadier Molina
text: San Francisco

headline: Discovery Wins Bid to Televise Canyon Crossing
text: Nik Wallenda, the daredevil who crossed Niagara Falls on a tightrope last year, will try a similar stunt at the Grand Canyon in June, he announced on Monday.

headline: Image of the Day: March 18
text: Farmers protest outside the Parliament in New Delhi.

headline: Grand Bargaining
text: Like others, Greg Sargent has been pleading with “centrist” pundits to acknowledge an obvious truth: Barack Obama has actually proposed the mix of spending cuts and revenue increases they want, while Republicans are unwilling to make so much as a dime of compromise. Greg looks at yesterday’s talk shows and finds this confirmed openly by GOP leaders: there is no ratio of spending cuts to revenues that will reconcile them to any tax hike whatsoever.

headline: Hillary Clinton Endorses Same-Sex Marriage
text: Saying that “gay rights are human rights,’’ Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former secretary of state and potential 2016 presidential candidate, has endorsed same-sex marriage.

headline: China Cites Risk of New Tension as U.S. Bolsters Missile Defenses
text: HONG KONG — China said Monday that the United States’ decision to strengthen antimissile defenses in response to threats from North Korea risked deepening regional tensions, underscoring Beijing’s caution on further pressuring the North despite its third nuclear test.

headline: The Coupon Collector Puzzle
text: Your favorite breakfast cereal has decided to run a tasty promotion. Each box of cereal will contain one of six different coupons. Collect all six coupons and win a prize! How many boxes of cereal can you expect to buy before you have at least one of each coupon?

headline: A Contentious Bailout for Cyprus
text: The Times’s Peter Eavis explains why markets are on edge over the plan to save Cypriot banks.

headline: Race and Republican Politics
text: The Republican Party released a report today that attempts to explain why the G.O.P. keeps alienating large chunks of the American electorate. We’ll have lots to say about the report on our editorial page, but I wanted to separately address the issue of race.

headline: Really? Diabetics Should Avoid Eating Fruit
text: THE FACTS

headline: House of Cards: Episode Seven and Father Figures
text: Do reporters care about the tiny trophies of governance? Ashley Parker and David Carr review episode seven of the Netflix series “House of Cards,” and discuss whether the people who wield pens care about getting one with presidential pixie dust on it.

headline: Annie Baker Wins Blackburn Prize and Horton Foote Honor
text: Annie Baker has been awarded the prestigious Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, an international award given annually since 1978 to women who have written works of outstanding quality. The prize, which Ms. Baker won for “The Flick,” her three-hour incisively nuanced exploration of love and friendship, includes a cash award of $25,000 and a signed, numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

headline: Bloomberg’s Plan Would Make Stores Conceal Cigarettes
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, fresh off a defeat in his campaign to limit large servings of sugary drinks, is returning to a front where he has enjoyed far more success: making it more difficult to smoke, by proposing legislation on Monday requiring stores to put cigarettes out of sight.

headline: Man Group Imposes Limits on Cash Bonuses for Executives
text: LONDON — The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund firm in the world, is imposing its own bonus cap for top executives.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: ‘Step One’
text: Part 8: The actor Stark Sands performs “Step One” from the musical “Kinky Boots.”

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Billy and Stark
text: Part 13: Lauper and Fierstein discuss what the actors Billy Porter and Stark Sands brought to their characters.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein, composer and writer of the musical “Kinky Boots.”

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Working Together
text: Part 2: Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein talk about the origins of their creative partnership.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Doing the Show
text: Part 4: Lauper and Fierstein talk about how they each became involved with “Kinky Boots,” and discuss the individual expertise they each brought to the production.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Cyndi’s Influences
text: Part 6: Cyndi Lauper describes her songwriting process and musical influences on “Kinky Boots,” and explains how she taught herself to write for musical theater.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Finding Broadway
text: Part 3: Lauper and Fierstein recall their earliest memories of Broadway, and explain what led them to become writers and performers.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Writing Partners
text: Part 5: Lauper and Fierstein explain the most difficult part of creating a musical adaptation, and reflect on their working relationship.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Less Rigid
text: Part 9: Lauper and Fierstein discuss the differences between writing musical theater and pop songs, and explain the purpose of out-of-town tryouts.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: ‘History of Wrong Guys’
text: Part 10: Lauper and Fierstein reflect on the changes they made to the character Lauren in adapting the show from the film, and discuss her song “The History of Wrong Guys.”

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: The Audience
text: Part 14: Lauper and Fierstein talk about the audience’s role in refining the show, and Billy Porter and Stark Sands reflect on their relationship with their “Kinky Boots” characters.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: ‘Not My Father’s Son’
text: Part 11: The actors Billy Porter and Stark Sands perform “Not My Father’s Son” from the musical “Kinky Boots.”

headline: TimesTalks | ‘Kinky Boots’: Preview
text: Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein talk with The Times’s Patrick Healy about their collaboration on the musical “Kinky Boots,” and discuss the challenges of composing music for the stage.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Adjustments
text: Part 7: Lauper and Fierstein talk about the process of refining the show and what they learned from its trial run in Chicago.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’: Harvey’s Father
text: Part 12: Lauper and Fierstein discuss the writing process behind “Not My Father’s Son.”

headline: Viewing the Glass as Half Full, but Not Too Full
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Street Style: Chunky Knits
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of March 11.

headline: The Gun Report: March 18, 2013
text: We have an unusually long list of violent incidents in which guns were involved this weekend. It couldn’t be because Sunday was St. Patrick’s Day, could it? Here is our weekend report.

headline: China Arrests Man After Wife’s Self-Immolation Protest
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese police arrested the husband of a Tibetan woman who died last week after setting herself alight in protest, an overseas group said on Monday, following a separate fatal self-immolation at a Tibetan Buddhist monastery over the weekend.

headline: Heart Puts Some Led in Its Summer Tour
text: It is hardly unheard of for rock stars to pay tribute to their colleagues and forbears, but Heart is taking professional hat-tipping to a new level.

headline: A Risk for Films That Move at a Zombie’s Pace
text: LOS ANGELES — It was the middle of 2006, and hardly anyone was particularly worried about the zombie apocalypse.

headline: What Comes Next for SAC
text: The two settlements reached between SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund controlled by Steven A. Cohen, and the Securities and Exchange Commission raise the question of what comes next for the firm.

headline: White or Pink Beans With Beet Greens and Parmesan
text: If you use white beans for this savory dish, the beet greens will infuse them with a lovely pink hue. Even more standout is the savory/umami flavor that the Parmesan rinds impart. Parmesan rinds will keep for months. Wrap them in foil and keep in the freezer. They add great depth of flavor to vegetarian soups and stews.

headline: New Jersey to Allow Casinos to Offer Daily Fantasy Sports
text: With its plan to legalize sports gambling held up in the courts, New Jersey is allowing casinos to offer daily fantasy sports games as an alternative.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Lent

headline: Stealing the Technology Show
text: The Times’s Jenna Wortham on expectations versus reality at South by Southwest Interactive.

headline: Big Brown’s Big Victory
text: Big Brown became the first horse since 1915 to win the Kentucky Derby with three or fewer starts coming into the race.

headline: Allon Exits Race for New York Mayor
text: Tom F. Allon, a newspaper publisher who switched party affiliations to run as a Republican for mayor of New York but failed to gain early traction among voters, said on Monday that he would abandon his candidacy.

headline: Function Over Form
text: Robert Stern may encourage risk and experimentation at Yale, but he is a staunch defender of his more traditional buildings.

headline: Dee Dee Bridgewater to Play Billie Holiday Off Broadway
text: “Lady Day,” Stephen Stahl’s musical about the jazz singer Billie Holiday, will have its New York premiere at the Little Shubert Theater in September. The production will star the vocalist and actress Dee Dee Bridgewater, who performed the role in Paris and London to acclaim in the 1980s.

headline: Fire Commissioner’s Son Resigns as Offensive Twitter Posts Surface
text: The son of the Fire Department commissioner, Salvatore J. Cassano, resigned on Monday from his job with the department after a series of offensive Twitter posts, many of them racially inflammatory, surfaced.

headline: From Lehman to Cyprus
text: The European decision not to honor deposit insurance in Cyprus, by making all depositors contribute to the cost of a bailout, reminds me of the decision to let Lehman Brothers go under. Moral hazard is being avoided. The question is what that will cost.

headline: Injuries Affect U.S. Roster for Costa Rica and Mexico Games
text: Injuries and illness have left United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann with a patchwork roster heading into two important World Cup qualifiers in the next nine days.

headline: Slaves’ Forgotten Burial Sites, Marked Online
text: They have been bulldozed over by shopping centers, crept over by weeds and forgotten by time. Across the country, from Lower Manhattan to the Deep South, are unmarked slave burial sites, often discovered only by chance or by ignominious circumstance as when construction crews accidentally exhume bodies when building a shopping mall.

headline: Philip Crangi for JewelMint
text: For its inaugural Studio Series, JewelMint tapped the CFDA designer Philip Crangi to create a limited-edition collection, which makes its debut online today. Though Crangi says that all of the pieces are original and exclusive to JewelMint, G&B x JM looks like it was plucked right from his classic collection of Giles & Brother. “I work from this group of references that I think keeps the continuum going with Giles & Brother,” he says about the tribal and equestrian influences on his etched brass and rose gold designs.

headline: Tamil Nadu Students Protest Alleged Human Rights Abuses in Sri Lanka
text: CHENNAI, Tamil Nadu—The police sought to arrest more than 200 university students in Tamil Nadu’s capital, Chennai as protests raged on college campuses over allegations of the Sri Lankan army’s brutal treatment of Tamil rebels.

headline: Marriott Ties in With ‘42’ to Promote Loyalty Program
text: Marriott International is using the release of the new film “42,” about Jackie Robinson breaking Major League Baseball’s color line, to promote its loyalty program to African-Americans.

headline: Locker Room Lies
text: Photos from the Off Broadway play “Good Boys and True.”

headline: Surveying Emancipation
text: President Lincoln’s issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation on Jan. 1, 1863 lent new urgency to the question of “what shall we do with the Negroes.” What had been only a possibility a few months before — the freeing of more than 3 million slaves still behind Confederate lines — had now become a likelihood dependent only on the success of Union armies.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Raikkonen’s Lotus Wins Formula One Opener
text: Kimi Raikkonen seemed to outsmart the competition in the season-opening Formula One race on Sunday, scoring a victory for Lotus in the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne.

headline: The Hurdles to a Higher Offer for Dell
text: More than a month has passed since Dell announced its planned $24.4 billion sale to its founder, Michael S. Dell. Since then, a number of shareholders have loudly complained that the price Mr. Dell has offered for the computer company is far too low.

headline: Fill-In | Boom Over, St. Patrick’s Isle Is Slithering Again
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article “Boom Over, St. Patrick’s Isle Is Slithering Again” by Amy Chozick.

headline: A Warning to Clean Bagpipes
text: A prominent Scottish bagpiping school has warned pipers around to world to clean their instruments regularly after one of its longtime members nearly died of a lung infection caused by fungi growing inside his bag.

headline: Sodas of The Times: Root Beer
text: The tasting panel found that the best root beers, which can be made with all sorts of ingredients, in varying proportions, were the ones whose flavors integrated seamlessly.

headline: Solar Storm Season, a Cancer Cluster in Detail and Twitter Science
text: Massive solar storms and the threat to the power grid and global communications; the story of cancer in Toms River; the science behind being social online.

headline: Power and Politics
text: Photos of the Broadway revival of “A Man for All Seasons.”

headline: New Concussion Guidelines Stress Individual Treatment
text: The American Academy of Neurology said Monday that it had revised its guidelines for handling concussions to emphasize treating athletes case by case rather than according to a predetermined scale.

headline: A House in the Barclays Center’s Shadow Doesn’t Linger on the Market
text: On a noisy street in Brooklyn is a little clapboard house that looks as if it dropped out of a charming suburban sky. It has friendly yellow siding and a pitched roof, a chimney and a backyard. It all looks quaint and adorable. Except for the view from its front door: 12,000 panels of arched, rusted steel.

headline: Classical Recordings
text: Britten: ‘The Rape of Lucretia’

headline: Woods and Vonn Join Ranks of Top Sports Couples
text: Tiger Woods announced Monday afternoon that he is dating the world and Olympic champion skier Lindsey Vonn. On his Facebook page, Woods posted some pictures of the couple, along with this statement:

headline: Genetic Art, Whale Hearts and Morality
text: BOOK

headline: With Your Goat’s Eye Martini, a Taste of Muskrat
text: James Cameron, the filmmaker (“Avatar” and “Titanic”) and explorer who last year dived to the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in his submersible, was about to enter a cocktail party given by the Explorers Club on Saturday evening at the Waldorf Astoria in Midtown, where the menu included a martini with a goat’s eye, pickled bull penises and strawberries dipped in white chocolate with black sprinkles of maggots. Later that night, Mr. Cameron would be awarded the club’s Explorers Medal. But first, a reporter asked him to name the strangest thing he had ever eaten.

headline: Solar Storms and Sunspots
text: The Sun can release sprays of electrons and protons called coronal mass ejections.

headline: Sun Storm Forecast: Tiny Chance of Havoc
text: In 1859 the sun erupted, and on Earth wires shot off sparks that shocked telegraph operators and set their paper on fire.

headline: A Burst of Solar Power
text: A NASA physicist explains why scientists are increasingly concerned about the effect of solar flares on our wired world.

headline: Boys’ Club: Spring’s New Haircut
text: While “the Chop,” a pretty safe, layered bob plus some bang action, is making its rounds across beauty salons, I’ve noticed a more daring look on the red carpet in recent months that has a fresh, springlike appeal. At the Oscars, it was Charlize Theron’s blond Caesar cut that turned heads as much as her Dior gown. And Anne Hathaway’s grown-out “Les Misérables” pixie also stirred the pot with its poufy volume. A few weeks before that, at New York Fashion Week, it was Miley Cyrus’s transformative short crop in a shocking blond that seemed to announce: “I no goodie-goodie Disney star.”

headline: No Time to Lament as Nets Face 8-Game Trip
text: There is no shame in dropping a game to the Atlanta Hawks, even at home, but the Nets projected disappointment in the way they competed Sunday night in a puzzling 105-93 loss that bore a number of implications for playoff seeding.

headline: How Recent Popes Differ on Key Issues
text: Try to figure out which pope said what in seven critical areas.

headline:
Syrian Rebels Pick
U.S. Citizen to Lead
Interim Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s main exile opposition coalition elected a naturalized Syrian-born American citizen early Tuesday to be the first prime minister of an interim Syrian government, charged with funneling aid to rebels inside Syria and offering an alternative to the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Firing Carmody, Northwestern Aims Higher
text: EVANSTON, Ill. – It made sense that on a gloomy, gray morning, Northwestern announced the firing of men’s basketball coach Bill Carmody. Despite leading the program to unprecedented levels of success — including four National Invitation Tournament bids — Carmody never brought the Wildcats to an N.C.A.A tournament.

headline: Madonna, Dressed for Camping, Weighs In on Boy Scouts’ Gay Ban
text: Wearing a Cub Scout summer uniform, a Scoutmaster’s brimmed hat and hiking boots, Madonna took the occasion of an appearance at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s 24th annual Media Awards ceremony to advise the Boy Scouts of America that the organization should “change their stupid rules,” specifically its ban on gay members.

headline: Walkabout – 3/18: Second Life for Hong Kong Airport; Street View at 22,000 Feet
text: Air to Sea A one-time airport in Hong Kong has taken on a new life as a cruise terminal. Though it will not fully open until later this year, The Kai Tak Cruise Terminal welcomed its first 2,000 passengers during a trial run this weekend. (CNN)

headline: The Spirit of Adventure
text: Sometimes all it takes to feel transported is a new accessory in an exotic material. See the interactive slide show

headline: How One Soldier Learned the Iraq War Was On
text: This week, The Times will feature reflections on the 10th anniversary of the invasion. We invite anyone who was directly affected by the invasion to submit their essays via atwar@nytimes.com. Please keep pieces to 500 words.

headline: I Want More Children; He Doesn’t
text: When we were first married, my husband and I talked about “the big stuff.” We discussed religion and politics; we respected the differences in our opinions. We both wanted to raise children in New York City and remain united against the suburbs. With no red flags in sight, we began our union with confidence.

headline: A New Approach to Hip Surgery
text: Larry Kufel had always been an active man, tall and rangy, who worked out regularly and picked up basketball games at the gym. But age was taking a toll on his joints, and it had become clear that he needed a hip replacement.

headline: ‘The Bible’ Producers Deny Suggested Obama Link
text: The producers of the hit mini-series “The Bible” on the History Channel scoffed Monday at online suggestions that an actor who plays Satan on the series was intentionally made up to resemble President Obama.

headline: Landmark Status Sought for Public Library’s Rose Reading Room
text: Community Board 5, which represents Manhattan’s central business district, has requested that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designate as an interior landmark the main Rose Reading Room at the New York Public Library’s flagship branch.

headline: Vitamin D May Lower Blood Pressure in Blacks
text: African-Americans have significantly higher rates of hypertension, and lower blood levels of vitamin D, than the rest of the population. Now a randomized trial suggests that vitamin D supplements may help lower blood pressure.

headline: The Risks of Transferring a Car Loan to a Credit Card
text: The credit card site CardHub.com recently reviewed current zero-balance credit card transfer offers and found that many cards let consumers transfer all sorts of debt — not just credit card debt — onto the new cards.

headline: Bancroft Prize Awarded to Two Historians
text: The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious annual honors for historians, has been awarded to two scholars for books published last year.

headline: The Lesson From Cyprus
text: The Cyprus fiasco sets a high bar for the euro zone’s new banking union. The new superregulator might not have been able to stop the blowup, or to avoid losses for insured depositors. The clear lesson from the mess is the need for a procedure to wind down failing banks.

headline: What to Make of New Mexico
text: We know what you are thinking. You do not know what to make of New Mexico. Overrated? Underrated? Final Four sleeper? Disappointing early exiter?

headline: A New Effort in Boston to Catch 1990 Art Thieves
text: It was one of the most brazen art thefts in history. Two thieves, posing as police officers, prevailed on the night watchman at Boston’s Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum to let them in. After tying him up, and a leisurely 81 minutes, they walked out with 13 works of art and into the annals of one of the world’s most infamous unsolved crimes.

headline: For Civilian Drones, the Sky is the Limit
text: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — As I wrote in Monday’s paper, crossing the hobbyist’s remote-controlled airplane with cheap electronics from the cellphone industry seems likely to yield highly capable, very inexpensive drones.

headline: Ina Drew Takes Risk, Goes on the Defensive
text: Writing a profile about someone who is not cooperating with your story starts to feel a little bit like an exercise in stalking. I did not actually stalk Ina Drew, the chief investment officer who resigned from JPMorgan Chase following the bank’s $6 billion loss, as I reported on her for the magazine last October. But I did think about her for many of my waking moments throughout the summer of 2012, as I reported the story. I also showed up at her home once. I rang the doorbell, and met her husband, a tall, genial-looking man who told me that she was not available and would not talk to me, not that day and not anytime soon.

headline: In Performance: Judy Kuhn
text: Judy Kuhn, accompanied by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf on cello, sings “Loving You” from Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical “Passion,” now in revival at the Classic Stage Company.

headline: With a Big If, Science Panel Finds Deep Cuts Possible in Auto Emissions and Oil Use
text: A panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that deep cuts in oil use and emissions of greenhouse gases from cars and light trucks are possible in the United States by 2050, but only with a mix of diverse and intensified research and policies far stronger than those pursued so far by the Obama administration.

headline: The Labor Agenda
text: Unemployment is persistently high. Wages are low. Inequality is rising. Employee bargaining power is decreasing. The lack of good jobs and the dearth of opportunities cast doubt on any and all indications of economic recovery.

headline: The Small Picture: When the Dogs Come Running In
text: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: A Shining Moment Comes Early
text: The Florida Gulf Coast men’s basketball team grabbed a piece of the national spotlight before their first appearance in the N.C.A.A. tournament, if only for eight seconds.

headline: Second Thoughts in Europe as Anxiety Rises in Cyprus
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The lights were dimmed and the doors were locked. But inside a branch of Laiki Bank, one of Cyprus’s two dominant banks, a few silhouettes glided about Monday, filling cash machines to calm a wave of anxiety that has washed over this tiny island since European leaders took the unprecedented step Saturday of trying to force depositors to pay for part of an international bailout.

headline: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
text: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: People’s Theater
text: A look at some of the shows produced at the Public Theater under its artistic director, Oskar Eustis.

headline: For 10th Anniversary of Iraq War, a Low-Key Approach From The Times
text: Anniversary journalism, as I’ve noted before, is a tricky proposition. At its best, it’s an opportunity to look back on an important event and provide the rich perspective that can only come with time. At its worst, it’s empty – a mere regurgitation of what happened with little that is new or fresh added.

headline: Photo Replay: March 18
text: A view of the day in sports, including the dusty beginning to mountain-bike racing in South Africa.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: The Business of Fashion explains how the SXSW festival explored technological innovations like 3-D printing that will affect the fashion industry.

headline: Detecting Heat Stress in Cows
text: Heat stress among dairy cows is a growing problem in the United States as the climate warms and farmers look to increase production from their herds. Now, researchers say farmers can predict which cows are in danger of overheating: the ones that stand for long periods without lying down.

headline: A Challenge to Dollo’s Law
text: Dollo’s law, named for the 19th-century paleontologist Louis Dollo, states that evolution always moves forward — that an organism cannot redevelop an organ or attribute discarded by its ancestors. But new research on humble dust mites, the tiny arachnids that live in cushions and carpets everywhere, is challenging the law.

headline: Columbia Picks New Journalism Dean
text: Steve Coll, a veteran of The Washington Post and The New Yorker whose investigations won him two Pulitzer Prizes, will be the next dean of the Columbia Journalism School, the president of Columbia University announced on Monday.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Outfield Preview
text: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Julie Hochfelder, Aaron Webman
text: Julie Anne Hochfelder and Aaron Louis Webman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Steven Bayar at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: On the Trail of Cancer
text: IT’S HIGH TIME a book did for epidemiology what Jon Krakauer’s best-selling “Into Thin Air” did for mountain climbing: transform a long sequence of painfully plodding steps and missteps into a narrative of such irresistible momentum that the reader not only understands what propels enthusiasts forward, but begins to strain forward as well, racing through the pages to get to the heady views at the end.

headline: A Parisian Passover
text: Putting on a Seder every year can be a bit of a challenge in Paris.

headline: Solving the Passover Puzzle
text: PARIS — A Seder in Paris should never be boring. So when Roger Yvon, an upscale butcher, proposed his signature deboned duck decorated with pitted green olives for the Passover dinner, I ordered two.

headline: For Timberwolves Forward, a New Decisiveness
text: Although Minnesota Timberwolves forward Derrick Williams had a career-high 28 points Sunday night in a 97-95 win over the New Orleans Hornets, his reaction was typically low-key. “Feels good,” he said, brushing aside his individual achievement to talk about the team. “We got a close win. That’s even better.”

headline: Former Romanian Premier Ordered Released From Prison
text: The Romanian former prime minister Adrian Nastase will be released early from prison after serving nine months of a two-year term for corruption, a Bucharest court ruled on Monday.

headline: A Newborn, but No Wobbly Legs
text: DISSING JULIA ROBERTS’S streetwalker on Rodeo Drive in “Pretty Woman”; sneering at Elaine Benes’s tussles with “skinny mirrors” at Barneys on “Seinfeld”: the intimidating salesclerk used to be the ultimate signifier of upscale retail. Of late, though, she (for it is often a young, beautiful she) has taken a curious turn toward overweening niceness.

headline: Good News Beats Bad on Social Networks
text: BAD NEWS SELLS. If it bleeds, it leads. No news is good news, and good news is no news.

headline: Q&A: Playing DVD Movies in Windows 8
text: Q.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on Arizona Voting Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared divided along familiar lines on Monday as it heard arguments  over whether Arizona can require proof of citizenship from people seeking to register to vote in federal elections.

headline: Lifting the Shadow of Scandal
text: There has been so much enthusiasm around the public style of Pope Francis — who has been populist, self-effacing and unscripted in his first few days as pontiff — and so much eagerness from so many quarters to see him as the reformer that the Catholic Church needs, that I felt like a bit of a downer accentuating the negative in my Sunday column, and emphasizing all the moral credibility that still needs to be rebuilt. But if personal holiness and seriousness of faith were sufficient qualities in a Roman pontiff, the last ten years would not have been a period of crisis in Catholicism, and the shadow of the sex abuse crisis would be fully lifted from the church. And it’s especially important, at the outset of a new pontificate, to understand the precise nature of that shadow, because at this point it’s no longer really about priestly sex abuse itself. Rather, it’s about a church that has cleaned house effectively and set up impressive structures of accountability everywhere except at the most prominent levels of the hierarchy.

headline: A Gray Jobs Market for All Ages
text: INSIDE the lower-level studio of the McBurney Y in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, Abba’s 1970s hit “Dancing Queen” is thumping out: “See that girl, watch that scene, diggin’ the dancing queen.” Right in step to the bouncing beat is a senior squad of 40 slightly sweaty women and men, ages 60 to 85.

headline: The Great Aid Gap
text: IT was an unusually enthusiastic shout-out for the job certificate programs offered by many community colleges. A report found that men with nondegree certificates in computer/information services earned $72,498 a year on average — more money than 72 percent of men with associate’s degrees and more than 54 percent of men with bachelor’s degrees.

headline: Aquatic Academy Isn’t Kid Stuff
text: “ATTENTION,” reads a sign at the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, Calif., “Sharks Ahead.”

headline: In Tourism, Classes Can Open Doors
text: JOHN LINDER had a career as a senior human resources manager, but he wanted something more. “It was a good job, but I didn’t want to be in an office anymore or in a corporate environment,” he said. He also did not want extensive schooling, since he already had a master’s degree.  He loved to travel, and knew his strong people skills would translate well. His answer: a two-week immersion course at the International Tour Management Institute.

headline: Back on Campus to Experience Road Not Taken
text: ADITI ROY wasn’t looking to become an entrepreneur or head to Wall Street or move up the corporate totem pole like most of her compatriots in the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School executive M.B.A. program. She was the morning news anchor for WCAU-TV, the NBC affiliate in Philadelphia, and already had a stint as West Coast correspondent for the network.

headline: Online Certificate Programs at Colleges and Universities Gain Popularity
text: AS employers demand skills and more skills, many people are turning to online certificate programs to acquire a specific expertise that can lead them to a job or a promotion — or, sometimes, simply to ensure that they hang on to their current position.

headline: Those Returning to School Can Find Help in the Tax Code
text: ROCCO ABBATEMARCO, 42, a middle school teacher from New York City, recently moved to Portland, Me., where he landed a teaching spot at a youth correctional facility. His new job required that he become certified in special education. To do so, Mr. Abbatemarco is taking accredited online courses, studying in the evening and on weekends.

headline: Colleges Assess Cost of Free Online-Only Courses
text: VIRGINIA M. ROMETTY, the chief executive of I.B.M., recently urged her employees to take 40 hours of continuing education this year. The company would not reimburse tuition, but would pay for expenses, like textbooks.

headline: Budding Entrepreneurs Can Choose an M.B.A. Lite
text: THEY’RE called entrepreneurship or small-business certificates, and they don’t carry the cachet or the credit of an M.B.A. But they take far less time to obtain, and they cost less, too. More colleges are offering them as a way to help people get their businesses off the ground.

headline: A Low Seed, but L.I.U. Will Take It
text: The Long Island University Blackbirds aren’t New York City’s best-known basketball team — they might not even crack the Top 10 of that list — but they might be its most successful.

headline: Acupuncture for Allergies (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Welcome Foot Support (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anthony Speaks About Wednesday Return to Knicks
text: SALT LAKE CITY – Carmelo Anthony ran up and down the court, took jumpers and showed improvement in his lateral movement during the Knicks’ shootaround Monday at EnergySolutions Arena. Then, for the first time in nearly a week, he spoke to reporters and explained how he felt after having fluid drained from his sore right knee Friday.

headline: A Crucial Number (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Weathering the Storm
text: Q. What determined which trees and other plants survived after inundation by Hurricane Sandy?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Somalia, Pakistan, Cyprus and West Bank.

headline: Washington Post Says Pay Model Will Start This Summer
text: The Washington Post will soon begin charging readers for access to its Web site, adopting a model that has taken hold at hundreds of newspapers as they attempt to make money from their online traffic.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein
text: 9:01 p.m. | Updated  Tonight ArtsBeat live streamed a conversation with two members of the creative team behind the new Broadway musical “Kinky Boots”: Harvey Fierstein, who wrote the book, and Cyndi Lauper, who wrote the songs. Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by Patrick Healy.

headline: Former Pentagon Lawyer Offers Pros and Cons of Drone Court
text: WASHINGTON – The former top lawyer at the Pentagon during President Obama’s first term warned on Monday that the secrecy surrounding the government’s use of “targeted killings” by drone strikes and other means is breeding mistrust, but he voiced skepticism about proposals for court review of decisions about which terrorism suspects the executive branch decides to assassinate.

headline: Bringing a Virtual Brain to Life
text: For months, Henry Markram and his team had been feeding data into a supercomputer, four vending-machine-size black boxes whirring quietly in the basement of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne.

headline: Scene City: Madonna in Cub Scout Drag
text: Madonna joins Anderson Cooper, members of the “Jersey Shore” cast and others at GLAAD Media Awards.

headline: Elegant Headphones, Crammed With Features
text: The French technology company Parrot is known primarily for its hands-free systems for cars, but it has added to its lineup a pair of wireless headphones that blend design and comfort with some very clever features.

headline: An Emperor in Drag and Other Decadencies
text: A maniacal, lecherous, cross-dressing emperor hosts a blindfolded groping party and packs a corrupt senate with prostitutes. Is this a newly discovered sequel to “Fellini Satyricon”? A gross-out John Waters film? Or “The Real Housewives of Ancient Rome?”

headline: A Work Trip, an Animal Rescue and a New Puppy
text: I STARTED flying quite a bit for business around 2002. I used to work for a public policy group and I had to go to a ton of meetings. It wasn’t really hands-on, and I really wanted to do more with my career.

headline: Speedy Check-In Lets Hotel Guests Bypass Front Desk
text: Hotels are changing the way guests check in to their rooms, eliminating the traditional stop at the front desk to speed up, simplify and, in some cases, personalize the process.

headline: Medieval Remains, Dwindling Butterflies and Chatterboxes
text: This week’s opening category is “interesting stuff buried in the British Isles.”

headline: Evangelical Groups Call for Path to Citizenship in Immigration Overhaul
text: A coalition including some of the nation’s largest evangelical Christian organizations said on Monday that Congress should include “clear steps to citizenship” for illegal immigrants in any bill to overhaul the immigration system.

headline: Reggie Miller Twitter Q. & A.
text: Reggie Miller, former star shooting guard for U.C.L.A. and the Indiana Pacers and member of the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, answered questions via Twitter about the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Miller will be part of the broadcast team covering the tournament for Turner Sports.

headline: A Soft-Focus Look at Fox’s Tough-Talking Tough Guy
text: He’s been called “one of the few visionaries in the television business” and the “most successful executive” in TV; a Republican kingmaker who would become “the sharpest thorn in the side of Barack Obama” and a pit-bull political strategist with only “two speeds: attack and destroy.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Kickstarting ‘Veronica Mars,’  and Microsoft Connections
text: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include a Kickstarter project for a ‘Veronica Mars’ movie that has already surpassed its goal, a video of a penguin showing great enthusiasm, or agitation, over an iPad and musicians accused of buying virtual fans.

headline: Congolese Warlord Wanted for War Crimes Surrenders to U.S. Diplomats in Rwanda
text: Last Updated, 10:06 a.m. A Congolese warlord whose troops were routed over the weekend walked into the United States Embassy in Rwanda on Monday and asked to be sent to The Hague to stand trial for war crimes.

headline: Lost Sleep Can Lead to Weight Gain
text: The best path to a healthy weight may be a good night’s sleep.

headline: Moments of Lyricism in a Purely Russian Story
text: In Shostakovich’s career, pockmarked with forced commissions, attempts to placate Soviet officials and humiliating bouts of censorship, his string quartets occupy a special place. Many critics have likened them to a confessional into which the composer confided the fears and hopes he had to suppress in public. But most of all, the 15 quartets represent the music Shostakovich wanted to write at a given moment.

headline: ‘Giselle’ Meets Kabuki in a Tale of Love, Madness and Toxic Breath
text: A Rudyard Kipling ballad starts with the refrain “Oh, East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet.” In the choreographer Yasuko Yokoshi’s “Bell,” which had its world premiere on Saturday at New York Live Arts, East and West indeed don’t meet. But they share the stage; they overlap; they coincide. The result, unlike any production I have seen, runs a gamut: It’s peculiar, admirable, a bit long-winded and sometimes perplexing.

headline: ‘Bodyguard’ and Its Diva, Now Onstage
text: LONDON — Playing a pop goddess in “The Bodyguard,” the new musical based on the 1992 movie that starred Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner, Heather Headley gives great diva. Ms. Headley, who won (and deserved) a Tony as the title character in Disney’s “Aida,” scores another personal triumph and once again transcends her material as the celebrity in jeopardy in Alexander Dinelaris’s lumpy adaptation of Lawrence Kasdan’s original screenplay.

headline: Off the Streets, Out of the Mines
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The South African dance company Via Katlehong began in 1992 as an effort to siphon young men off the tough streets of Katlehong, a township near Johannesburg. About 10 years later French presenters took an interest in the troupe’s blend of dances from the street and the mines, and it began to tour internationally — a chain that often ends with local idioms being transformed into slick global products.

headline: Freedom Is Brief for Canadians Who Fled Prison by Helicopter
text: OTTAWA — In a bold prison break, two Canadian convicts shinnied up a rope at a provincial detention center north of Montreal to a hijacked helicopter hovering overhead and, briefly, experienced freedom.

headline: Museums Go Shopping at Maastricht
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — Every March museum directors and curators from around the world flock to the European Fine Art Fair, held in a soulless convention center here. They come to look at the art, gauge the market and network with colleagues, collectors and trustees. But this year, barely 24 hours after the preview on Thursday, there were reports that more museums than usual were among the serious shoppers.

headline: How Fast We Slow Down Running Longer Distances
text: How fast do we slow down?

headline: On the Origins of Gadgets
text: Once, maybe, everyone more or less understood everything and how it worked. But society pushed past that point long ago, into a realm where we are dependent on devices and structures we couldn’t possibly make ourselves and whose origins we don’t even know. As you realize if you’re reading this on a cellphone.

headline: Love Goddess? Never Saw That Coming
text: One of the more notable things about the season finale of “Girls” on Sunday is that Hannah, the heroine played by Lena Dunham, kept her clothes on.

headline: As Crop Prices Surge, Investment Firms and Farmers Vie for Land
text: From the potato fields of Michigan to the high prairies of Kansas, farmers are receiving record prices for their land — but economists and banking regulators warn that this boom, like so many before it, could end badly.

headline: Albums by Low and Phosphorescent
text: LOW“The Invisible Way”(Sub Pop)

headline: Bloomberg Doubles Its Tech Television
text: 5:53 p.m. | Updated In a world of shrinking newsrooms, real expansion is an increasingly rare story. But next Monday, Bloomberg West, Bloomberg Television’s show on technology, will double its daily programming to two hours. Along with the existing afternoon program, Bloomberg West will present another hour of tech news at 10 a.m. Pacific time.

headline: Jordan’s King Finds Fault With Everyone Concerned
text: CAIRO — King Abdullah II of Jordan leads one of the smallest, poorest and most vulnerable Arab nations. But that does not stop him from looking down on many of those around him, including the leaders of Egypt, Turkey and Syria, as well as members of his own royal family, his secret police, his traditional tribal political base, his Islamist opponents and even United States diplomats.

headline: St. Louis Watches Selection Show in Electronics Store
text: St. Louis navigated Virginia Commonwealth’s full-court press well enough to win the Atlantic 10 Conference tournament title game Sunday afternoon at Barclays Center. It was after the game when the Billikens were slowed by what some might consider a more stressful situation — fighting New York City traffic on the way to the airport.

headline: What the Cyprus Bailout Could Mean for Europe’s Debt
text: The Cyprus bailout is perhaps an even bigger deal than it first seemed, and not for bad reasons.

headline: U.N. Rights Council to Vote on Resolution on Sri Lanka
text: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council is preparing to vote this week on a resolution that urges Sri Lanka to deliver on its promises to investigate allegations of mass civilian slaughter in the army campaign that crushed a rebel group in May 2009, and expresses growing international concern over a lengthy catalog of continuing atrocities.

headline: Stolen Works
text: Two men disguised as police officers stole 13 works of art in 1990, including rare paintings by Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer, all of which have been valued at approximately $500 million.

headline: 10 Years Later, an Anniversary Many Iraqis Would Prefer to Ignore
text: BAGHDAD — The war that arrived a decade ago is still too painful and too controversial to be taught to schoolchildren or subjected to serious academic study at universities, and the local news media are too busy reporting on the latest bombings, protests and political disagreements to care much about an anniversary.

headline: Small Knives, Small Risk? Not Everyone Thinks So
text: HOW do flight attendants feel about allowing passengers to carry little knives on board? Well, I can always depend on Rene Foss, a flight attendant for over 25 years, to get right to the point.

headline: Wanted Congolese Rebel Leader Turns Himself In to U.S. Embassy
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Bosco Ntaganda, a Congolese rebel general accused of massacring civilians and building an army of child soldiers — considered one of Africa’s most wanted men — surprisingly turned himself in to the American Embassy in Rwanda on Monday, saying he wanted to be sent to the International Criminal Court.

headline: Mets’ Harvey Delivers Another Strong Outing
text: JUPITER, Fla. — The Mets’ future hinges on the performances on a group of young arms in which the club has invested its resources and rested its hopes.

headline: Style at SXSW
text: There was no shortage of perfectly worn in Converse, cut-off shorts and sundresses at SXSW this year.

headline: Local Russian Hijab Ban Puts Muslims in a Squeeze
text: LEVOPADINSKY, Russia — The girls of the Salikhov family live in frontier country. Their road is dirt, punctuated by puddles and sheep, and their house does not have plumbing or running water. They had been hoping this would be the year the local authorities got around to hooking up natural gas.

headline: American Honda Divides Its Biggest Ad Assignments
text: One of the largest recent reviews for an advertising account has ended with the incumbent agency keeping a significant part of the assignment, but relinquishing two large pieces to two other agencies.

headline: Pennsylvania: Appoint Judges, Ex-Governors Say
text: Four former Pennsylvania governors called for eliminating elections for senior judges in favor of appointing them. Judges seeking campaign donations are open to corruption, the governors argued. “The influence of money on judicial elections is pernicious,” said Edward G. Rendell, a former Democratic governor, who joined with a fellow Democrat, George Leader, and two Republicans, Tom Ridge and Dick Thornburgh, in the unusual bipartisan appeal. Last month, a Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice, Joan Orie Melvin, was convicted on campaign corruption charges. Only six states select all judges in partisan elections, according to Pennsylvanians for Modern Courts, which wants the governor to fill the state’s three appellate benches. The change requires a constitutional amendment. Critics say it would introduce secretive back-room deals.

headline: Man Says He Killed Tourist in Turkey After She Rebuffed Kiss
text: ANKARA, Turkey — The fatal encounter between a Staten Island woman and a homeless man in Istanbul earlier this year began when she resisted his attempt to kiss her, according to a two-page statement he gave to prosecutors.

headline: Oh, California
text: Of all the things I’ve been called in my time, the one that surprises me the most is “California Writer.” When I hear that, I look over my shoulder, certain that the phrase must apply to the writer behind me or to my left. It’s the way I feel when I am addressed by my husband’s last name. It takes me a moment to realize his mother is not in the room.

headline: U.S. Drug Costs Dropped in 2012, but Rises Loom
text: Spending on prescription drugs nationwide has been slowing for years because of the increasingly widespread use of low-cost generics. But in 2012, something unheard-of happened: money spent on prescription drugs actually dropped.

headline: Hughes Is Hit by Grounder in Return, but Says He’s Fine
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Tucked away in the corner of the Yankees’ minor league facility, on a day off for the team, three players who are key to the Yankees’ hopes this season toiled in relative obscurity Monday.

headline: A New First Couple in Sports: Woods and Vonn
text: With eerily similar announcements to a combined Facebook and Twitter audience of nearly 6.5 million, Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn confirmed Monday that they are dating, then asked for privacy because they want to live, in Woods’s words, “as an ordinary couple.”

headline: Negotiators for Arms Trade Treaty Discuss Regulation of Ammunition
text: Negotiators at the United Nations began a final round of talks on Monday aimed at completing a treaty to regulate the international trade in conventional weapons. Objections by the United States and other major weapons exporters prevented an agreement. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, lamented what he called the lack of regulatory controls for the import and export of conventional weapons, asking why “there are common standards for the global trade in armchairs but not the global trade in arms.” One of the most contentious issues was whether ammunition should be included in the scope of the treaty. Anna McDonald, a representative of Oxfam, which is pushing for strong treaty, said her group wanted strict and specific language that would regulate ammunition. Thomas Mason, a representative of the World Forum on Shooting Activities, a group that represents firearms makers and users, said the sheer volume of ammunition produced made such monitoring impractical.

headline: China: More Pigs Found in River
text: The number of dead pigs found in a river near Shanghai rose to more than 13,000 over the weekend. Last Friday, the figure stood at about 7,500. The authorities, who are in the middle of a weeklong effort to collect the carcasses, are still trying to determine how the pigs died and why they ended up in the Huangpu River, which winds through Shanghai. The government has insisted that there is no evidence of an epidemic and that the food supply is safe. City officials also say the river meets national water quality standards. The authorities say they believe that many of the pigs came from the nearby city of Jiaxing, in Zhejiang Province, where there are major pig farms.

headline: Former Calpers Chief Indicted Over Fraud
text: As head of the country’s largest pension fund, Federico R. Buenrostro wielded vast influence in the money management world.

headline: Seeking Profit for Taxpayers in Potential of New Drug
text: WASHINGTON — With automatic spending cuts cascading through the government, lawmakers are calling for a review of federal policies they say have allowed businesses to profit on government research with limited return for taxpayers or consumers.

headline: Bombs Strike Bus Station in Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — Suicide bombers crashed an explosives-laden Volkswagen into a crowded bus on Monday as it was parked at a depot in Kano, northern Nigeria’s largest city, and officials said at least 20 people were killed, possibly many more, as the conflagration spread to four nearby buses.

headline: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps.

headline: New Jersey Lawyer Guilty of Murder
text: NEWARK — For years Paul W. Bergrin eluded charges from his former colleagues in the United States attorney’s office that he had become “house counsel” for gangs, using his criminal defense practice here as an elaborate front for prostitution, drug running and even the killing of witnesses.

headline: ABC Works on an App for Live Streaming Shows to Mobile Devices
text: THE WALT DISNEY Company, while sorting out the future of the online video Web site Hulu, has an app in the works that may render Hulu passé for some people.

headline: A Bank Levy in Cyprus, and Why Not to Worry
text: Never mind.

headline: It’s Move It or Lose It in Path of a Nor’easter
text: PLUM ISLAND, Mass. — Barbara Murray walked her dog past a ribbon of the police tape that wound its way around sections of this scenic barrier island, about an hour north of Boston, where she has lived for 50 years.

headline: Strategy in Scandal Makes Spanish Duke’s Ex-Partner a Prisoner in Home
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Diego Torres, a onetime marketing guru, built a $2 million dream home outside Barcelona, but it has become a luxury bunker since he challenged the Spanish royal family by revealing its private e-mails as part of his legal defense in a corruption investigation.

headline: A Young Man With Down Syndrome, a Fatal Encounter and a Cry for Understanding
text: You may not have heard of Robert Ethan Saylor, but his death in January should inspire something more lasting than a small-town police investigation.

headline: A Cure, in Essence, for H.I.V. in Some Adults
text: Two weeks ago, American doctors reported that they had “functionally” cured a baby infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with an aggressive treatment of drugs starting some 30 hours after the baby was born. Experts hailed the feat but cautioned that the findings might have little relevance to adults.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 3
text: This is the third part of a six-part series.

headline: Should Depositors Save Cyprus's Banks?
text: Is penalizing depositors to prop up Cypriot banks just? Or will it undermine confidence in banks elsewhere in Europe, causing an economic meltdown?

headline: Taxing Savers in Cyprus
text: A European plan could force Cyprus to tax bank depositors as a condition of a bailout in a way that would unfairly punish savers and could do lasting damage to confidence in banks in other euro-zone countries in financial crisis. The country’s leaders have a chance to change the agreement and should do so.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Tihar Inmate Niranjan Kumar Mandal
text: NEW DELHI — The death of Ram Singh, one of the six defendants in the Delhi gang rape case who was found hanged in his cell, has raised speculation about its cause and questions about the management of Tihar Jail. While the post-mortem report suggested suicide, Mr. Singh’s parents contend that the police murdered him, in part because both his arms were damaged from previous accidents.

headline: The Andes Chronicles: A Ban on Hydraulic Fracturing
text: Once or twice a year I bring news from the small Catskills town of Andes, and usually the news concerns the ongoing battle to preserve the town’s rural character in the face of incursions from entrepreneurial energy companies. A few years back Andes passed an ordinance banning wind turbines. Late last month the town board passed a law prohibiting heavy industry. The intended target of the law was hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, the technique by which natural gas is extracted from underground rock formations that have been subjected to the high velocity impact of chemically laced water.

headline: Ranked No. 1, Lewis Keeps Expectations in Check
text: PHOENIX — As a teenager, Stacy Lewis spent 18 hours a day wearing a back brace to cope with scoliosis. That was hard.

headline: A Pattern of Problems at a Hospital for Veterans
text: WASHINGTON — In an unusually strong letter sent to the White House on Monday, the office that handles complaints from federal whistle-blowers says it has found a pattern of problems at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., that raises serious questions about the hospital’s management practices.

headline: Vatican’s Bureaucracy Tests Even the Infallible
text: VATICAN CITY — An Italian industrialist tried to curry favor by donating $100,000 worth of truffles. A Mercedes-Benz executive hoped for an audience to suggest improvements to the Popemobile. But in the final years of the papacy of Benedict XVI, others sent very different messages, too, desperate for the pope’s ear.

headline: Arizona’s Barrier to the Right to Vote
text: Arizona’s Proposition 200, passed in 2004, prohibits local officials from registering any would-be voter who does not provide “satisfactory evidence of United States citizenship.” That requirement conflicts with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, also known as the Motor Voter Act, which set up a national registration system for federal elections.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Ax Isn’t Sharp Enough
text: Washington

headline: The Progressive Shift
text: There is a statue outside the Federal Trade Commission of a powerful, rambunctious horse being reined in by an extremely muscular man. This used to be a metaphor for liberalism. The horse was capitalism. The man was government, which was needed sometimes to restrain capitalism’s excesses.

headline: Does China Have a Foreign Policy?
text: Shanghai

headline: Falling Out of Love With China
text: Washington

headline: Pre-K Provider Stole Millions, State Audit Says
text: One of New York City’s largest providers of special education services to preschoolers with disabilities illegally diverted millions in taxpayer financing to a girls’ religious school, summer camps and a kosher supermarket owned by the group’s officers and board members, state auditors said on Monday.

headline: Cyprus Bailout Incites Turmoil as Blame Flies
text: BRUSSELS — A plan to rescue the tiny European country of Cyprus, assembled overnight in Brussels, has left financial regulators, German politicians, panicked Cypriot leaders and a disgruntled Kremlin with a bailout package that has outraged virtually all the parties.

headline: For Colorado Governor, a Long Path to Gun Limits
text: DENVER — The wounds and rage from a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater were still raw one morning last July when Gov. John W. Hickenlooper went on national television to discuss grief and guns. Shaken and groping for answers, he nevertheless cast doubt on one idea: that tighter gun laws could have prevented the carnage.

headline: More Charges Against Brooklyn Legislator
text: A New York lawmaker already facing bribery charges is now facing additional charges of falsely securing tens of thousands of dollars in travel reimbursements from the Assembly by submitting travel vouchers when he was not working on legislative business.

headline: A Goal for Obama in Israel: Finding Some Overlap on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — If President Obama’s most obvious goal on his trip to Israel this week is to forge a connection with the Israeli people, his challenge behind closed doors is to persuade Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he can rely on the United States to take care of Iran.

headline: State Leaders Reach Deal to Raise Minimum Wage
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement on Monday to increase the state’s minimum wage to $9 over the next three years.

headline: In Women’s Bracket, Top Seeds Are the Same but Baylor Leads the Way
text: If the only remarkable element of the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament bracket was its parity, the opposite is true for the women’s bracket, revealed Monday, with all roads leading again to Baylor, the Goliath out of the Big 12 that has lost once in two seasons.

headline: Just You Wait
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to another episode of True Stories, in which I regale you with a long-buried and potentially embarrassing story from my life that is unceremoniously dislodged from my brain by an entry in the puzzle.

headline: Tennis Association Seeks Parkland, and Gets a Fight
text: It was two years ago that a match at the United States Open was interrupted because an 18-inch hairline crack developed along the service line in the middle of a game. “Of course, it was all captured on TV,” recalled Daniel Zausner, the chief operating officer of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens. “It was an embarrassment.”

headline: How Blogger Helped the Steubenville Rape Case Unfold Online
text: On the day after two high school football players from Steubenville, Ohio, were found guilty of rape, Alexandria Goddard, a crime blogger whose early and dogged research helped bring national attention to the case, is still fending off criticism that she helped create “an Internet lynch mob.”

headline: A Glut of Electronic Waste
text: As recently as a few years ago, broken monitors and televisions were being recycled profitably. But flat-screen technology has lowered demand, creating stockpiles of useless material across the country.

headline: Nets Still Trying to Find Themselves
text: There is no shame in dropping a game to the Atlanta Hawks, even at home, but the Nets projected disappointment in the way they competed Sunday night in a puzzling 105-93 loss that bore a number of implications for playoff seeding.
