text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Murder Conviction Tossed Out in Queens
text: A judge has thrown out the murder conviction of a man who already served more than 13 years in prison and granted him a new trial, saying that the Queens district attorney’s office had failed to give the defense information that would have shown a crucial witness lied on the stand.

headline: Unwanted Electronic Gear Rising in Toxic Piles
text: Last year, two inspectors from California’s hazardous waste agency were visiting an electronics recycling company near Fresno for a routine review of paperwork when they came across a warehouse the size of a football field, packed with tens of thousands of old computer monitors and televisions.

headline: A Focus on 3 Encounters in a Stop-and-Frisk Trial
text: The first time the police stopped and then frisked him on his block in the Bronx, David Floyd remembered wanting only “to get home” and “be in my own space.” The second time it happened, Mr. Floyd testified, he was left with the impression that “I needed to stay in my place, and my place was in my home.”

headline: The Senate’s Muckraker
text: I’ll miss Carl Levin when he leaves the Senate after the next election — and you will, too.

headline: Traffic Fatalities in City Increased in 2012, but Officials Point to Larger Picture
text: More than 270 people died in New York City traffic in 2012, the most traffic-related fatalities since 2008, officials said on Monday.

headline: Court Is Asked to Drop Charges Against Kenya’s President-Elect
text: PARIS — Lawyers for Kenya’s president-elect, Uhuru Kenyatta, said Monday that the charges of crimes against humanity that he faces should be dropped because they were based on hearsay and were fundamentally flawed.

headline: For Some, Spending Less on Drugs
text: As lower-cost generic drugs have become more widely prescribed, the dollar amount spent on drugs fell last year for the first time.

headline: Abortion Doctor’s Murder Trial Opens
text: PHILADELPHIA — In opening statements in court on Monday, prosecutors charged that a doctor who operated a women’s health clinic here killed seven viable fetuses by plunging scissors into their necks and “snipping” their spinal cords and was also responsible for the death of a pregnant woman in his care.

headline: Injuries Leave Knicks With Odd Lineup
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Through 64 games this season, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson never had to construct his starting lineup out of pure desperation. Woodson did for Monday’s nationally televised game against the Utah Jazz.

headline: Erwin Harris, Ad Executive Who Seized Cuban Assets, Dies at 91
text: Erwin Harris left behind a respectable record of achievement as an advertising executive, an estimable collection of Chinese antiquities (his lifelong hobby), a loving family and a remarkable if little-remembered role in the tortured history of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba in the early 1960s.

headline: Nets Look Impressive in First Stop of Their Trip
text: AUBURN HILLS, MICH. — The Nets began their longest trip of the season — 13 days away from home, which will most likely fall between a fascinating footnote and a season-defining stretch — by doing something they have routinely done all season: win against a mediocre team.

headline: Olen Burrage Dies at 82; Linked to Killings in 1964
text: Olen Burrage, a Ku Klux Klan member who owned the Mississippi farm where the bodies of three slain civil rights workers were found in 1964, died on Friday in Meridian, Miss. He was 82.

headline: A Justice Dept. Official Is Named to Lead Labor
text: WASHINGTON — With a few confirmation victories in his pocket, President Obama decided Monday to press ahead with another cabinet nominee in defiance of Republican opposition as he tapped an assertive civil rights regulator to be his next labor secretary.

headline: Booth Gardner Dies at 76; Ex-Washington Governor
text: Booth Gardner, a two-term governor of Washington whose diagnosis with Parkinson’s disease after he left office helped motivate him to lead a successful voter initiative to allow physician-assisted suicide, died on Friday at his home in Tacoma. He was 76.

headline: A Guide to Watching Syria’s War
text: Amateur video has been pivotal to the way the conflict in Syria is understood.

headline: Ban on Gay Marriage Led Lawyers to Shift Role
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Nine years ago, city officials here sued to strike down a state ban on same-sex marriage. It was the first government challenge to such a law, and it set in motion a legal chain reaction that gave rise to a momentous Supreme Court case to be argued next Tuesday.

headline: In Rare Move, Patriots’ Owner Gives Details of Welker Talks
text: PHOENIX — In a news conference that offered an unusual amount of detail from one of the N.F.L.’s most tight-lipped organizations, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft said Monday that everyone in the organization wanted receiver Wes Welker to return. Welker signed a two-year contract with the Broncos last week for $6 million per year, and the Patriots signed Danny Amendola to replace him for about the same amount.

headline: One Person One Vote (or Was That One Voter One Vote?)
text: WASHINGTON — With the exception of the Senate, where voters from states with small populations have vastly more power than those from, say, California or Texas, the rest of the American political system is committed to the bedrock principle of “one person one vote.”

headline: In the Song of Egypt,  a Chord for Both Secular and Religious Jews
text: Hanina, the 5-year-old I baby-sit, loves to play “pretend.” When we come up with a story he enjoys, we play it over and over. Small children love repetition — if it’s fun the first time, it’ll be fun the second! (And the 22nd!) Hanina’s favorite books inspire many of our games. I can’t count the number of times we’ve ridden the Magic School Bus as it made its interminable, fact-filled way through the local water works or blasted into outer space. Other games, like a recent one featuring a marauding army of killer cannibal princesses, Hanina dreams up on his own.

headline: Q&A: Logging Out of Gmail From Another Computer
text: Q.

headline: Celtics Give Heat All They Can Handle, but They Handle It
text: BOSTON — They trailed by 17 in the first half. They trailed by 13 with eight-plus minutes to play. They were hit by an offensive explosion like none they had seen all season, not from Kevin Durant, Kobe Bryant or Carmelo Anthony.

headline: So You’re Extinct? Scientists Have Gleam in Eye
text: Until recently, the arrow of natural selection seemed to go only one way. A species could form, then it could flourish, then it could go extinct. And once it was extinct, it could not come back.

text: guileless •\ˈgi(-ə)l-ləs\• adjective

headline: Bryant’s Roles Evolve From Peacemaker to Assistant Coach
text: LOS ANGELES — Having been many things to many people and everything to the Lakers over the last 17 years, Kobe Bryant emerged last week in a role no one expected: assistant coach.

headline: L.I.R.R. Train Derails in Queens
text: A Long Island Rail Road train derailed Monday night west of Jamaica Station in the vicinity of Forest Hills, Queens, causing potential delays for the morning commute, but no injuries, the authorities said.

headline: Fukushima Blackout Hints at Plant’s Vulnerability
text: TOKYO — The stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant this week experienced its worst power failure since the disaster there in 2011, and though the plant’s operator said all electricity was restored by early Wednesday, the problem underlined its continuing vulnerability.

headline: Rangers Manage to Break Losing Streak, if Not Their Scoring Struggles
text: Marc Staal watched from a Madison Square Garden luxury box, attending his first game since taking a puck near the right eye in a frightening accident March 5. Staal did not speak to reporters, but obviously liked what he saw — a 2-1 shootout victory for the Rangers over the Carolina Hurricanes and his brothers Eric and Jordan on Monday night.

headline: United States Facing Two Qualifying Games With Thin Roster
text: When United States national team Coach Jurgen Klinsmann called in attacking threats like Jozy Altidore, Herculez Gomez and Clint Dempsey for his latest roster, it was surely done with the hope that the United States would be able to score often in its two coming World Cup qualifying matches. Given the injuries and illness that have racked Klinsmann’s group of defenders, he could hardly be blamed for thinking he will need as many goals as possible.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) SPLASH The Olympic gold medalist Greg Louganis, above, will tutor 10 celebrities — among them, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Louie Anderson, Drake Bell, Keshia Knight Pulliam and Kendra Wilkinson — in the art of diving before they try to flip, twist and spin off a regulation platform and springboard in this new competition series. The diver David Boudia and the director of the United States team, Steve Foley, will critique each dive. Chuy Bravo, Rory Bushfield, Nicole Eggert, Ndamukong Suh and Katherine Webb round out the roster of competitors; Joey Lawrence and Charissa Thompson host.

headline: Dominican Republic Reaches World Classic Final
text: SAN FRANCISCO — No team has gone undefeated in a World Baseball Classic. The Japanese won it in 2006 and 2009 while losing three games the first time and two the second. Now, the Dominican Republic will take an unblemished record into the final game on Tuesday at AT&T Park.

headline: News Quiz | March 19, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The Rebels’ Loose Cannon
text: Steve Green had seen it all before. The hand gestures. The histrionics. The nonstop conversation Marshall Henderson was having with himself.

headline: Thomas Helps Short-Handed Knicks Hold Off Jazz
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Kurt Thomas sat at his locker, his right foot in a bucket of ice, in the visitors’ locker room at EnergySolutions Arena. He had a smile on his face, appearing content to quietly reflect on his night.

headline: Jets Sign a Pass Rusher
text: The Jets bolstered their pass rush Monday by signing outside linebacker Antwan Barnes to a three-year contract.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 19
text: NEWS President Nicos Anastasiades delayed a vote on a $13 billion deal that set off outrage for calling on Cypriot bank depositors to bear part of the cost, while stock markets faltered on concerns over the plan. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus, and Landon Thomas Jr. from London.

headline: Francis Vows to Serve ‘Poorest, Weakest’ and Urges Leaders to Offer Hope
text: VATICAN CITY — Striking a tone of radical humility that has already become his trademark, Pope Francis offered a passionate pledge in his installation Mass on Tuesday to serve “the poorest, the weakest, the least important,” urging world leaders to protect human life and the environment and use tenderness to inspire hope.

headline: British Newspapers Challenge New Press Rules
text: LONDON — A day after British lawmakers agreed to ground rules for a new press code, an array of newspapers protested on Tuesday against the attempt to impose stricter curbs on this country’s scoop-driven dailies following the phone hacking scandal that convulsed Rupert Murdoch’s media empire and much of British public life.

headline: A Verdict in the Steubenville High School Rape Case
text: In “Ohio Teenagers Guilty in Rape That Social Media Brought to Light,” Richard A. Oppel Jr. writes about a case that drew wide attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage over the episode.

headline: False Historical Consciousness
text: BEIJING — My courtyard home in the heart of old Beijing has a view of the Drum Tower, which for centuries helped citizens keep track of the time.

headline: Should Computer Games Be Used for Classroom Instruction?
text: Some say the future of classroom learning should be digitized and “gamified,” so that students barely notice they are learning. Do students learn important skills and concepts playing computer games? What do you think?

headline: Who Lives Longest?
text: A Swedish baby born in 1800 had a life expectancy of just 32 years. We know this because Sweden was one of the first countries to keep extensive records of births and deaths and, by 1800, had a reliable national system that allowed this morbid statistic to be calculated. That baby’s life may sound nasty, brutish and short, especially for a nation advanced enough to keep such detailed records, but before you imagine 19th-century Swedish teenagers suffering the regret and ennui of midlife crises, consider this: that same year, a 20-year-old Swede could reasonably expect to live another 37 years.

headline: Where Home Is an Elusive Fantasy
text: A young man stands in a swimming pool, eyes covered, shoulders hunched, his head slightly bowed. A child bounces from bed to bed. A dainty green cupcake with confetti sprinkles occupies a place of honor on a paper plate.

headline: Rejection of Deposit Tax Scuttles Deal on Bailout for Cyprus
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Lawmakers rejected a 10 billion euro bailout package on Tuesday, sending the president back to the drawing board to devise a new plan that might still enable the country to receive a financial lifeline while avoiding a default that could reignite the euro crisis.

headline: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
text: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

text: The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Buyer for BBC’s Book Unit on Travel
text: SERRAVAL, France — In 2007, when the British Broadcasting Corporation bought the Lonely Planet travel guidebooks, it drew criticism from rival media organizations in the private sector, which argued that a public television company had no business expanding into areas like book publishing.

headline: Questioning the TOMS Shoes Model for Social Enterprise
text: After visiting Argentina and seeing the impact of poverty on some of its children, Blake Mycoskie was inspired to create a philanthropic “for-profit business that was sustainable and not reliant on donations.” The result was Toms Shoes, which promised that for every pair of shoes it sold, it would give away another pair to a child in need.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Militant Suspected in Daniel Pearl Killing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials have arrested a senior militant accused of involvement in the murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002.

headline: Creating Canada’s ‘Quantum Valley’
text: Showing how quickly an esoteric technology can become mainstream, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, who together founded BlackBerry, are establishing a $100 million venture fund for technologies that employ practical applications of quantum physics.

headline: Many Israelis Unsure of Obama, but Are Ready to Listen During Visit
text: JERUSALEM — Obama administration officials have made it clear that the top agenda item for the president’s visit here this week is to win the hearts of the Israeli people. He has a lot of work to do.

headline: The Politics of the 14th Amendment and the Debt Limit
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Finance Bill, Nearing Senate Passage, Would Protect Some Favored Programs
text: WASHINGTON — The worst of the federal cuts to a major infant nutrition program would be reversed. Embassy security and construction could be spared in the wake of the consulate attack in Benghazi, Libya. And child care subsidies, once seen as critical to the success of welfare reform, would take a haircut, not the hammer blow that President Obama once loudly warned was coming.

headline: Assessing the Cyprus Bailout
text: The European plan to take money from bank depositors to help pay for a bailout of Cyprus has set off alarm bells among some analysts and politicians. But the move, far from setting a precedent for other countries, has a lot to do with the particulars of Cyprus, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: Allegations of War Crimes in Sri Lanka Shake Indian Government
text: NEW DELHI– The Congress Party faced a new crisis on Tuesday after a southern political party threatened to withdraw from the governing coalition if India did not join an international push to investigate alleged war crimes in Sri Lanka.

headline: In Performance: Judy Kuhn of ‘Passion’
text: Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical “Passion,” set in 19th-century Italy, tells an unlikely love story: Giorgio, a young army captain with a beautiful mistress, is changed by the obsessive love that Fosca, an invalid he meets while serving at a mountain outpost, has for him. In this number from the Classic Stage Company revival, Fosca, played by Judy Kuhn, sings “Loving You,” in which she tells Giorgio that her love for him “is not a choice, and not much reason to rejoice.” Ms. Kuhn is accompanied on cello by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf; the arrangement is by Rob Berman, the show’s musical director. “Passion” continues through April 19.

headline: Subjunctivitis
text: The subjunctive mood is a bit more arcane than other entries on our list of favorite grammar gaffes, like subject-verb agreement. Still, it’s a sign of polish and precision to get this right. The subjunctive is most often used in contrary-to-fact conditions and for wishes and other hypothetical expressions.

headline: The Dunning-Kruger-Madoff Effect
text: Via Mark Thoma, Hale Stewart is bemused by John Hinderaker of PowerLine. As Stewart notes, Hinderaker begins by asserting that everyone knows that an economic crisis is coming — which apparently means everyone he talks to — then rolls out just about every one of the myths that have been proved wrong again and again by events, from the looming debt crisis to the imminent takeoff of inflation.

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Music and Dance
text: The grand cities of Mumbai and New York differ from each other in a million ways, but are brought together by a few common strands – their entrepreneurial spirit, their dynamic “always on-the-go” nature, their lively sidewalks, their gorgeous coastlines, the diversity of their residents who bring unique culture and religion and their vibrant music scene.

headline: Boeing and Ryanair Agree to a Deal for 175 New Jets

text: Lost sleep can lead to weight gain, a new approach to hip surgery, hotel guests check in without a front desk and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Cogan, Taylor, and the Confidence Fairy
text: Ugh. And I say that advisedly. John Cogan and John Taylor have a piece in the WSJ (where else) arguing that the latest Ryan budget would actually be expansionary, because confidence! It’s as if all the experience of recent years, in which the confidence fairy has yet to make an appearance, hasn’t happened.

headline: Expat Fury at Cyprus ‘Bank Raid’
text: LONDON – Thousands of expatriates living in Cyprus may be having second thoughts about picking the Mediterranean island as their retirement home.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ABC Works on a Streaming App and British Newspapers Protest Regulations
text: The Walt Disney Company is working on an app that would stream ABC programming to the tablets and phones of cable and satellite subscribers, Brian Stelter reports. ABC would be the first of the American broadcaster to provide such an app, and it is likely to result in a mixture of awe and fear from other networks. Disney already has streaming apps for content from ESPN and the Disney Channel, but special complexities exist for networks like ABC because of older contracts with companies that produce its shows and local stations, which might feel threatened by the app. It is not yet clear what the app would mean for online streaming services like Hulu, which does not require viewers to subscribe and has grown increasingly marginalized as its parent companies (including Disney) seek more lucrative revenue streams.

text: BANGKOK — The American ambassador to Laos said on Tuesday that the Laotian authorities had blocked a United States investigation into the disappearance of two citizens and a resident of the United States.

headline: Southwest Broadens Approach in New Campaign
text: Southwest Airlines, for the first time in many years, is making major changes in how it presents itself to current and potential customers.

Lew, the American Treasury secretary, met with President Xi Jinping of China on Tuesday in the first high-level encounter between American and Chinese officials since Mr. Xi assumed the presidency, and one that recognized sticking points in a relationship that has drifted in the last few months.

headline: Condoleezza Rice to Write Book for Henry Holt
text: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is writing a book that will examine the creation of democracy at home and abroad, drawing upon stories from her career and personal life, the publisher Henry Holt & Company said Tuesday.

headline: A San Francisco Classic: Vesuvio’s Bohemian Coffee
text: I had to tell people to stop. After I put out an informal call for San Francisco bar recommendations for this month’s Drink column, I simply couldn’t visit the dozens of bars that people suggested. I’m sure I had to omit some of your favorites — chime in and let me know what those are — but 20 bars in four days was all I could manage. This time.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and Political Savvy
text: Anyone wondering why Republicans such as Jon Huntsman and Rob Portman are suddenly announcing their support for gay marriage (and why the anti-gay marriage forum at the Conservative Political Action Convention last week was empty while the pro-marriage forum was packed) should take a look at this poll from ABC News and the Washington Post.

headline: 7 Marines Killed in Nevada Training Exercise
text: WASHINGTON — Seven Marines were killed and several others were injured when a mortar round unexpectedly exploded during a live-fire training exercise at a weapons depot in western Nevada, the military said Tuesday.

headline: A 1930s Beauty Contest With Shapely Horns and Fine Beards
text: You probably knew this already, but there was a time when there were regular goat beauty pageants in Central Park.

headline: You Don’t Dance With Your Face, or Do You?
text: In contemporary dance, the face is largely unexplored territory. A neutral expression is the default, so as not to distract from what’s happening elsewhere.

headline: Civil Disobedience
text: San Francisco’s city attorney discusses why he challenged his state’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Q&A: Keeping Adobe Flash Player Secure
text: Q.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Jewish Daily Forward: What is kosher salt, exactly? And why do chefs like it so much? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Hitchcock’s Earliest Films to Tour U.S.
text: With a film and TV movie about Alfred Hitchcock and even a new TV series based on his work, fans of the director have had a lot to check out recently. Now add nine more films, black-and-white silents that constitute his earliest-surviving work, which will be shown together on an American tour later this year.

headline: Away From the Bronx, Cano Takes On a More Vocal Role
text: San Francisco

headline: Another New Album Coming From Justin Timberlake
text: Justin Timberlake says he plans to release new music in the near future: a second volume to his just-released album, “The 20/20 Experience.”

headline: A Gay Man at Midlife Ponders Being Lonely and ‘Invisible’
text: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Around the World in 60 Days
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Since the beginning of February, I’ve played in four states in the United States, three countries (soon to be four), and have reshuffled my suitcases almost as often as a casino worker shuffles cards. The sport might be called something different each place I travel, but the last two months of excitement have come together as fitting parts of my ascension to become a more complete player.

headline: Dismissing Concerns, Panel Backs White’s S.E.C. Nomination
text: Mary Jo White cleared an important hurdle on her path to becoming a top Wall Street regulator when a panel of lawmakers overwhelmingly backed her nomination on Tuesday.

headline: The Gun Report: March 19, 2013
text: Many readers have wondered when the gun violence death toll, post-Newtown, would surpass the death toll from the Sept. 11 attacks. It didn’t take long. According to Slate’s gun-death tracker, which we link to each day, an estimated 2,793 people have died as a result of gun violence since December 14, 2012. The recorded death toll of the Sept. 11 attacks stands at 2,752.

headline: Wanderlust in Repose
text: Part of the beauty of travel, stylistically speaking, is letting go of the restraints of the everyday for a more carefree look.

headline: Posters for Chefs, the New Rock Stars
text: Whether we’re talking about San Francisco in the 1960s, during the early years of the Grateful Dead and Jefferson Airplane, or the alternative-rock scene that produced bands like Superchunk, Soundgarden and Pavement in the 1980s and ’90s, rock music has long been a fertile breeding ground for visual art.

headline: A Streak That Doesn’t Take the Spotlight
text: About the only thing you can fault the Miami Heat on these days is their lousy timing. Yes, the Heat’s 23-game winning streak is one to behold, no matter the time of year and yes, it certainly is a reason to tune in to games when the regular season usually turns to unwatchable mush. But there is so much out there clamoring for fans’ attention these days, the Heat are struggling to get the hype machine pointed squarely in their direction.

headline: Bringing Back the Dead
text: A Stanford professor discusses the science and ethics of resurrecting extinct species.

headline: The States With the Highest Car Insurance Rates
text: If you want cheap car insurance rates, it’s best not to live in Louisiana. Or Michigan.

headline: Queens Museum of Art to Be Renamed Amid Expansion
text: The 9,335-square-foot Panorama of New York City will still be there, but the familiar logo for the Queens Museum of Art will not. The cultural institution in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is changing its name to the Queens Museum. The renaming accompanies a planned $65-million, 50,000-square-foot expansion that is scheduled to be finished in October.

headline: Shorter Cyprus
text: So, a quick summary: The Germans don’t want a Cyprus collapse / exit from the euro, but they also don’t want the spectacle of German taxpayers bailing out Russian money-launderers. So what they did instead was blackmail Cyprus into having Cypriot depositors bail out Russian money-launderers. That way Germany’s hands are clean.

headline: In Charter, Malone Returns to His Roots
text: John C. Malone is returning to his roots.

headline: Image of the Day: March 19
text: More than 35 people were killed in a bus accident in Maharashtra.

headline: M.L.S. Plays On, Minus 38
text: Squeezed on all sides by scheduling conflicts and an unforgiving worldwide soccer calendar, Major League Soccer will play on with  eight games this weekend as leagues around the world take a break on two official FIFA dates for international matches.

headline: A Witness to 4 Iraqi Wars, but No More
text: Mohammed Hussein is a former head of the newsroom in The New York Times’s Baghdad bureau. He fled to Syria in 2007 at the height of the sectarian fighting, returned in 2008 when the situation improved, then moved to the United States with his family in 2010 under a program in which Iraqi interpreters working with Americans could receive special immigrant visas. His previous blog posts can be read here.

headline: Judge Approves Sale of Rights to Hostess Brands, Including Twinkies
text: A federal bankruptcy judge on Tuesday approved the sales of several major Hostess Brands product lines, including Twinkies, fetching about $800 million for the various pieces of the bankrupt baking company and clearing the way for it to be eventually wound down.

headline: It’s Mr. Hell on the Line
text: The two men who founded the seminal proto-punk band Television in 1973 had almost everything young rockers need: ambition, attitude, brooding good looks and a modicum of talent. Here’s what they lacked: names that evoked their malcontented essences.

headline: Doctors Urge F.D.A. to Restrict Caffeine in Energy Drinks
text: A group of 18 doctors, researchers and public health experts jointly urged the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to take action on energy drinks to protect adolescents and children from the possible risks of consuming high amounts of caffeine.

headline: Hal Steinbrenner Plots New Course for Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — On Oct. 17, in the hours before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series was scheduled to begin, a steady, gloomy rain fell on Detroit. Sitting in his hotel room, Hal Steinbrenner watched the downpour and frowned. And then his phone rang.

headline: Garbled Texting as a Sign of Stroke
text: Slurred and incoherent speech is one of the classic signs of a stroke. But new research finds that another symptom may be garbled and disjointed text messages, which could provide early clues to the onset of a stroke.

headline: Marie Ponsot Wins Lucrative Poetry Prize
text: Marie Ponsot, a poet known for her bold reimaginings of traditional forms, has been awarded the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, one of the most prestigious (and richest) in poetry, which comes with a $100,000 award.

headline: Demystifying Taylor’s Confidence Fairy (Wonkish)
text: I was wondering, but Noah Smith does the work.

headline: Iraqis’ Pain Never Abates as Attacks Kill Dozens
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq closed a painful decade just as it began: with explosions reverberating around the capital.

headline: Debevoise & Plimpton’s Trusts and Estates Group Finds a New Home
text: In December, the trusts and estates lawyers at Debevoise & Plimpton received shocking news. The law firm’s leadership said it had decided to eliminate its trusts and estates practice, and instructed the group’s lawyers to look for a new home.

headline: Settlement of Class Action Against Audi Gets Preliminary Approval
text: A federal judge has given preliminary approval to settling a class-action suit over transmission problems on about 64,000 of Audi’s most popular models.

headline: Rand Paul to Speak at Iowa Republican Dinner
text: Senator Rand Paul will speak at the Iowa Republicans’ Lincoln Day Dinner in Cedar Rapids on May 10. The fund-raiser for the state party offers Mr. Paul an early chance to introduce himself to potential caucusgoers as he considers a bid in 2016.

headline: Port Authority, With Eye on Income, Will Pick Firm for Trade Center Observatory
text: New York’s newest and tallest observation deck will offer an interactive immersion in all things New York as it shuttles visitors 102 floors into the sky and provides panoramic views of the city and beyond, from the harbor to Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

headline: The Right Wine for Halibut
text: Halibut is the chardonnay of the fish family, essentially neutral in flavor but brilliant in transmitting external influences. In David Tanis’s recipe for halibut skewers with yogurt sauce, the dominant flavors will be the Turkish spices, along with the lemon, onion and cooling herbs.

headline: Samsung Speaks Up First About a Smart Watch
text: Samsung Electronics has made it clear that it is making a wristwatch, even as Apple is rumored to be working on a smart watch itself. It is rare for a big tech company to voluntarily reveal a future product.

headline: ‘Anna Nicole,’ as in Smith, Is Part of City Opera’s Coming Season
text: New York City Opera announced on Tuesday that its 2013-2014 season would feature the American premiere of two operas, “Anna Nicole,” by Mark-Anthony Turnage, based on the paparazzi-filled life and death of Anna Nicole Smith, and  “Endimione,” a little-known and rarely staged work composed by Johann Christian Bach in 1772.

headline: Swirls of Stain, the Art of N.C.A.A. Branding
text: LAS VEGAS — The basketball court at the Mountain West Conference tournament was like no other, impossible to ignore, which is exactly the point. Stained in at least four hues of brown, it featured deep contrasts of arcs and boxes and jags, including a range of snow-capped peaks stretching the length of the floor.

headline: Judge Proposes a National Lawyers Corps to Help Immigrants
text: As Congress takes up immigration reform, Robert A. Katzmann, a federal appellate judge in New York, has been looking beyond the debates and envisioning a crisis.

headline: Transocean Chief Admits Crew Shortcomings in Oil Spill
text: NEW ORLEANS — The chief executive of the company that owned the Deepwater Horizon oil rig acknowledged in court on Tuesday that his crew should have done more to avert the 2010 oil well blowout that left 11 dead and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches along the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Rand Paul on Immigration
text: The Times’s Michael D. Shear talks about Senator Rand Paul’s proposals on immigration.

headline: It’s a Bag, It’s a Desk, It’s Got Geek Appeal
text: Considering its purpose – a bag that coverts to a standing desk for the iPad – shouldn’t the Strotter Platforma look much, much nerdier?

headline: Lesson Learned After Financial Crisis: Nothing Much Has Changed
text: People have learned their lesson.

headline: The Truth About Working From Home
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about the pros and cons of allowing workers to do their jobs from home.

headline: What If You Hate Mountains?
text: In a recent report from the World Economic Forum analyzing 140 countries’ competitiveness in travel and tourism, Switzerland (above) ranked first, and the United States was sixth. The factors that determined a country’s ranking include its tourism infrastructure, appeal to business travelers and friendliness (in that last category, Iceland scored high marks and Bolivia finished last).

headline: Creamy Banana Pudding With Pistachio Crumble
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: New ‘Guy,’ New ‘Girl’ Joining ‘Once’
text: The Tony Award-winning Broadway musical “Once” is having a cast makeover. Sunday will mark the last scheduled appearance of the show’s Tony-winning star, Steve Kazee, and his colleagues Cristin Milioti, Elizabeth A. Davis and Will Connolly.

headline: These Chicks Are Not of the Easter Basket Variety
text: After about 70 days of carefully controlled incubation beneath deep river sand, heated electrically from below, three rare maleo chicks have hatched at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Jeter, His Ankle Still Stiff, Is Scratched From Lineup
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Derek Jeter described his mood as more frustrated than concerned, although the Yankees may feel otherwise. He complained Tuesday about more than the normal stiffness in his surgically repaired left ankle and was scratched from the starting lineup against the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Broadway ‘Cat’ Revival Cools at Box Office
text: This is the season of star vehicles on Broadway – Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson, Tom Hanks, Alec Baldwin, Bette Midler – but not all of them are burning rubber at the box office.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Psychiatric Diagnoses
text: To the Editor:

headline: What the Stats Say About This Year’s Tournament
text: Last season, The Quad published a study that showed field goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin are the three statistics most correlated to college basketball success.  Using that information, we identified Duke, Missouri and Michigan as vulnerable teams entering the 2012 N.C.A.A. tournament.  All three lost their first game.

headline: Misunderstanding IS-LM (Wonkish and Unimportant)
text: Some readers have asked me to reply to this Steve Keen piece claiming that I don’t understand the IS-LM model. Sigh. I really don’t want to spend time fighting against people with whom I don’t really have a current policy disagreement — and this is so silly, besides. But to satisfy those who are for some reason nervous, here’s a brief explanation of why somebody doesn’t understand IS-LM.

headline: To Many Yogurt Fans, It’s All Greek
text: You know Greek yogurt is having its moment when an artisan in Brooklyn is making it from an old family recipe, downtown mixologists are using it in a cocktail and chefs are pairing it with fried brussels sprouts and green cauliflower.

headline: Blair Says Iraq Would Be ‘Worse Than Syria’ Now, if Antiwar Critics Had Prevailed
text: Defending Britain’s participation in the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair told the BBC that Iraq “would look a lot more like Syria, and probably a lot worse than Syria,” today if the war had not taken place.

headline: Spam Texts Vex Me and Make Me Feel Old
text: I haven’t lived in Atlanta for several years. But my cellphone, which still has an Atlanta phone number, apparently maintains a very active social life there. Every weekend it gets invitations to wild parties throughout the city, including a hip place called “The Mansion Elan.”

headline: Raising Children Who Will Speak Up to Prevent Rape, Not Defend It
text: I spent Sunday morning at a birthday party for one of my son’s classmates. As the kids gathered around a paper-covered table to begin an art project, I stood off to the side, furiously typing away on my phone as I scoured my Twitter feed for news of the verdict in the Steubenville rape case.

headline: Mariinsky Theater Plans Star-Studded Opening of New Opera House
text: The Mariinsky Theater in Russia announced on Tuesday plans for a three-day celebration to mark the opening of the new Mariinsky II opera house in St. Petersburg in May.  An opening-night gala conducted by the theater’s artistic and general director, Valery Gergiev, on May 2 will feature performances by an array of stars that include Plácido Domingo, Olga Borodina, Ekaterina Gubanova, Anna Netrebko, René Pape and Yekaterina Kondaurova.

headline: For the G.O.P., It’s Not Just the Message
text: The battering that Republican candidates suffered in 2012 — particularly among women and minorities — seems finally to have worked its way into the party’s cerebral cortex. For weeks, party leaders like Eric Cantor have talked about broadening the party’s appeal, and on Monday, Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, unveiled a lengthy report that took the party to task for alienating large segments of the public.

headline: House Ethics Panel Finds Cause to Investigate 2 Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee has found credible evidence that two lawmakers — a Republican from Alaska and a Democrat from New Jersey — improperly used campaign money for personal expenses, among other abuses.

headline: Solid as a Rock
text: In the rarefied world of haute couture jewelry, Taffin’s designer James de Givenchy offers a unique combination of elegance and edginess. It’s a mix he loves, and lives by.

headline: The Revolt of the (Republican) Elites
text: The Republican National Committee’s extended autopsy on the G.O.P.’s 2012 defeat, which officially abjures policy recommendations but then goes on to nudge the party toward supporting comprehensive immigration reform and gay marriage, is the highest-profile distillation of what I described last week as the “donorist” view of how the Republican Party needs to change. As Ramesh Ponnuru suggests, this the party elite’s vision of domestic policy reform, reflecting the views of people who are already “more likely to favor same-sex marriage and comprehensive immigration reform on principle,” and who don’t “tend to have any major problems with the Republican economic agenda and do not believe it needs to be rethought in any serious way.” Or to put it another way: If you believe that Mitt Romney’s economic platform and “you built that” rhetoric would be the basis for a durable majority if they weren’t associated with the religious right and anti-immigration sentiment, then this is the vision of Republican reform for you.

headline: MSNBC Announces Replacement for Chris Hayes
text: MSNBC on Tuesday named Steve Kornacki the new host of “Up,” a weekend morning panel discussion program that is about to be vacated by its original host, Chris Hayes.

headline: A Closer Look at Obama’s Plan to Pay for Energy Research With Drilling Fees
text: As was discussed here last Friday, President Obama has proposed using a tiny portion of federal revenues from offshore oil and gas production to build an “Energy Security Trust” to pay for the kinds of tough or longer-term energy research projects that the private sector tends to neglect. (A White House explanatory graphic is here.)

headline: Former Governor Advances in South Carolina Race
text: The first chapter in a wild race to fill a Congressional seat in South Carolina was written Tuesday when former Gov. Mark Sanford staged something of a comeback in a Republican field crowded with 16 candidates, and Democrats overwhelmingly picked Elizabeth Colbert Busch, a businesswoman on leave from Clemson University.

headline: Little Resistance on the Heat’s Path
text: BOSTON — LeBron James could not be slowed by the personal demons that once haunted him in the most hostile of N.B.A. arenas, or by the ghosts of famous Celtics past, or by a 43-point scorer suitably named Green.

headline: College Groups Connect to Fight Sexual Assault
text: Frustrated and angry over the handling of sexual assault cases at Occidental College in Los Angeles, a group of students and faculty members recently decided to take the matter to the federal government as a civil rights case. Few people had explored this legal terrain, so the Occidental group reached out to women at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who had filed a similar complaint — which this month prompted a federal investigation — for insights on how to press their case.

headline: European Art Fair May Join With Sotheby’s for Chinese Sales
text: In what might seem like a pairing of competitive bedfellows, the organizers of the European Fine Art Fair – that 10-day event going on through Sunday in Maastricht, the Netherlands – announced on Tuesday that they were in talks with Sotheby’s about holding a high-end art and antiques fair in China. The new event, which would be called Tefaf Beijing 2014, would be “planned as a collaboration between Maastricht, the Netherlands-based event, and Sotheby’s recently forged joined venture with China’s state-owned Beijing Ge-Hua Cultural Development Group,’’ the European Fine Art Fair said in an e-mail.

headline: Charges Upgraded in Hit-Run Crash That Killed Couple
text: A grand jury has indicted the driver accused in a fatal hit-and-run crash this month on new charges of second-degree manslaughter, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Tuesday.

headline: A SWAT Team for Waterlogged Artwork
text: THE patient was in rough shape.

headline: Inviting Tropical Fruits to Stick Around
text: The exotic tastes of tropical fruit evoke an endless summer of ocean breezes, sandy beaches and drinks with umbrellas. But just like their colder-climate cousins (say, blueberries and peaches), these fruits have their season.

headline: Justices Permit Resale of Copyrighted Imports
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of decisions issued on Tuesday, the Supreme Court made it easier to import textbooks and other copyrighted products from abroad and made it harder for plaintiffs in class-action suits to stay out of federal court.

headline: An Interior Design Showroom Featuring Lalique Maison
text: Lalique has unveiled an interior design showroom in New York featuring Lalique Maison, a collection of furniture and accessories by Tina Green and Pietro Mingarelli. Lady Green is the wife of the British billionaire Sir Philip Green and the creative director of Argent, an interior design firm with offices in London and Monaco. She took on Lalique Maison after Silvio Denz, the chairman of Lalique, toured a yacht she had outfitted with a generous number of his products.

headline: Living in the Columbia Street Waterfront District
text: The lively Brooklyn neighborhood lies west of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway, bound by it and a working harbor.

headline: Between the Drink and the B.Q.E.
text: A cynic might call this Mosesville. Ever since the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel were built in the 1940s, courtesy of the powerful city planner Robert Moses, the semi-industrial strip of South Brooklyn now called the Columbia Street Waterfront District has been a skinny, scruffy island of a neighborhood cut off from adjacent areas.

headline: Ducks Re-Sign Perry
text: Scratch Corey Perry’s name off the list of trade rumors as the N.H.L.’s April 3 deadline approaches. Anaheim signed Perry to an eight-year, $69 million contract extension late Monday night.

headline: No Silver Bullet for Reaching Fuel and Emissions Goals, Study Says
text: The United States could possibly achieve the goal of an 80 percent reduction in oil use and greenhouse gas emissions from cars and small trucks by 2050, but it will not be easy, a National Research Council report said.

headline: Say Goodbye to the Assault Weapons Ban
text: Fans of military-style assault weapons can stop worrying — their gun lobby has done its work, and all but assured that Congress will not pass a ban on their dangerous toys.

headline: Decision Point: Understanding the U.S.’s Dilemma Over North Korea
text: In this lesson, students will play the role of White House advisers, exploring policy options and recommending the best strategy for preventing war in East Asia.

headline: In Mayor’s Race, Sources of Contributions Shift
text: #nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1{position:relative;width:480px;height:495px;}.nytg-aiAbs{position:absolute;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 p{font-family:arial,helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:13px;line-height:18px;margin:0;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle0 {font-size:12px;line-height:16px;padding-bottom:3px;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle1 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle2 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:center;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle3 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:right;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle4 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle5 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle6 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle7 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;text-align:right;color:#020200;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle8 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;color:#020200;}

headline: Malone’s Minority Report
text: John C. Malone has slipped through the door again. The American cable magnate is buying 27 percent of Charter Communications from three buyout firms for $2.6 billion. He’s no garden-variety minority owner, though. Even heavyweights like Rupert Murdoch and Barry Diller can attest to Mr. Malone’s cunning use of smaller stakes. Charter investors should keep their guards up.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: More Injuries for Knicks, but the News Isn’t All Bad
text: The Knicks issued two more injury updates Tuesday, involving a bulging disk, a stress reaction and a stress fracture. In the context of this freakishly painful Knicks season, it practically qualified as a good-news report.

headline: Off Broadway Theater To Be Named After Lynn Redgrave
text: The Culture Project’s main stage theater at 45 Bleecker Street is being renamed the Lynn Redgrave Theater to honor the British actress, who died in 2010.

headline: Senator Is Angry Over Bill’s Exclusion of Assault Gun Ban
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who 35 years ago discovered the bullet-riddled body of the gay activist Harvey Milk, reacted with anger on Tuesday that gun control legislation the Senate is to consider next month will not include the reinstatement of an assault weapons ban, a measure she had fought desperately to keep.

headline: By The Numbers
text: We chart the success of the architect Peter Marino, who has been riding high since his work for Barneys New York twenty years ago.

headline: Lizard Olympics
text: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
text: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.

headline: U.S. Said to Look Into Microsoft Bribery Allegations
text: SEATTLE — Federal authorities are examining Microsoft’s involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Michelle Shocked Draws Fire for Anti-Gay Remarks
text: Michelle Shocked, the punk folk-singer, liberal activist and born-again Christian, has drawn fire for an anti-gay tirade in San Francisco over the weekend, during which she said God hates homosexuals.

headline: Turning Down a Deposit Tax
text: The Times’s Liz Alderman discusses next steps after Cyprus rejects a proposed bailout for its troubled banks.

headline: This Week’s Links
text: This is a weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Photo Replay: March 19
text: A view of the day in sports, including wrestling in Tbilisi, Georgia, and curling in Riga, Latvia.

headline: Baked Beans With Pomegranate Molasses, Walnuts and Chard
text: This Iranian-inspired rendition of baked beans is sweetened with pomegranate molasses, which you can find in Middle Eastern markets.

headline: Leader of the Pack
text: Twenty years ago, the architect Peter Marino vaulted onto the style world’s A-list with his limestone-clad design for the Barneys New York flagship, helping ignite a mania for luxurious retail environments that endures to this day. Hundreds of boutiques later, for clients like Louis Vuitton and Dior, Marino has nearly doubled his business in the last two years and is riding higher than ever — more often than not on a Harley-Davidson.

headline: Black-Eyed Pea Soup or Stew With Pomegranate and Chard
text: This is another dish inspired by a recipe in Louisa Shafia’s book “The New Persian Kitchen.” You can use more or less water, depending on whether you want the dish to have the consistency of a soup or a thick stew. It’s hearty, and the most beautiful pink hue.

headline: Statue of Liberty to Reopen by July 4
text: Updated, 4:52 p.m. | The Statue of Liberty, which has been closed to visitors since Hurricane Sandy struck and open for only one day since the fall of 2011, will reopen by the Fourth of July holiday, federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: Snedeker Plans a Return at the Arnold Palmer
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The fastest starter out of the gate in 2013 returns to action at the Arnold Palmer Invitational this week after spending the past five weeks on his couch in Nashville.

headline: Rebutting the Contention That Small Is Better for Banks
text: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm Paul Hastings and is writing “The Crisis Not Wasted – The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.’s First Five Hundred Days,” a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term of office.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
text: FiveThirtyEight’s Nate Silver spoke with Megan Liberman on Tuesday about our forecast for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, strategies to win your tournament pool and the end of the overwhelming favorite in college hoops.

headline: Record Ticket Sales for Bowie Exhibition in London
text: LONDON — “David Bowie Is,” a major retrospective of the British singer’s career and cultural influence, which opens at the Victoria and Albert Museum on Saturday, has sold over 42,000 advance tickets, more than double the amount generated by any previous exhibition at the museum.

headline: Large White Bean, Tuna and Spinach Salad
text: You could use canned cannellini beans for this, but I love the size and texture of large white limas. I don’t soak limas because the skins tend to detach and the beans fall apart when you cook them. You want them intact for this, but you also need to make sure to cook them all the way through.

headline: The Retro-Lean-Back Snow Day
text: It’s a snow day here.

headline: Judge Sets Court Date in ‘Spider-Man’ Trial
text: A federal judge has set a May 28 trial date for the director Julie Taymor, Bono and the Edge of U2, and the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” to battle in court over a lawsuit stemming from the spectacular implosion of their years-long collaboration on the show.

headline: Wheelies: The Make-Some-Noise Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Actress’s Suit Against IMDb for Publishing Her Actual Age Can Go to Trial
text: LOS ANGELES — Junie Hoang, the actress who sued Amazon and its Internet Movie Database unit for posting her age, can take her complaint — or at least some of it — to a jury.

headline: The House That Generosity Built: Staten Island Little League Plans Opener
text: Opening Day arrives two weeks late for Staten Island Little League this season, but after Hurricane Sandy’s knockdown pitch, having any season is cause for celebration.

headline: Guggenheim Gets Grant to Commission Chinese Art
text: For years now the Guggenheim Museum has been broadening its scope far beyond the Western world to places like South and Southeast Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and North Africa. Now it is extending its reach even further, embracing the art of China.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Shop: Chocolate for You, Coffee for Me

headline: If Those Dusty Common Rooms Could Talk ...
text: Alison, in her 40s now, is having straight vodka with a former beau in a room that looks like the Harvard Club. “They say if you marry money, you earn every cent of it,” she observes.

headline: Hit Men and Hurt Lovers Meet Minnesota Nice
text: A pair of sweet Scandinavian hit men in Minnesota grill a young woman under bright lights while serving her elderberry wine. In flashback, the woman talks to a new friend at a bar — about the weather, horses and the men who recently did them wrong.

headline: Chez Sardine
text: Inside the restaurant where stoner Asian food meets fat-on-fat cuisine.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Vatican, Argentina, Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Journalism Professor Sues Columbia, Claiming Misuse of Endowment Funds
text: A tenured professor at Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism and co-director of that school’s business program filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing the university of misdirecting $4.5 million in funds over the last decade.

headline: 2 Cuisines, Both Full of Themselves
text: ONE MAJOR THEME of modern restaurants is what we might call Asian stoner food. This is the cuisines of Japan, Korea and other places as seen through bloodshot eyes, the cravings of a hipster whose late-night munchies send him out in search of tacos stuffed with bulgogi, pigs’ tails cooked in root beer and the like.

headline: Panic in Cyprus
text: It comes as no surprise that the Parliament of Cyprus on Tuesday voted down a terrible plan to tax insured bank deposits as part of a deal to rescue its failing financial system. The country’s leaders and policy makers in Europe will now have to go back to the drawing board.

headline: Mars Rover Is Repaired, NASA Says
text: A NASA official said Tuesday that engineers had resolved the latest problem with the Curiosity rover on Mars and that the laboratory-on-wheels should resume science operations this week after a three-week delay.

headline: Revealing a Lot, Aromatic and Otherwise
text: “The scent, my God: it is so indecent," said the author and perfume blogger Denyse Beaulieu from Paris. She was speaking of Shocking, the 1937 Elsa Schiaparelli perfume dressed in hot pink: the original version, not a later reformulation.

headline: Wistful Reflections but Very Few Regrets
text: “It was fantastic! It was fantastic! Beyond belief!”

headline: Pop-Up Hotels: Rooms With a Fleeting View
text: POP-UP STORES. Pop-up restaurants. Pop-up lounges. Shouldn’t this fascination with pop-ups — which are by definition ephemeral — have disappeared already?

headline: Hotel Review: Pousada de Cascais in Cascais, Portugal
text: Rates

headline: The Doctor Is In (Well, Logged In)
text: Surfing the Web in his all-white Dumbo loft, Dr. Jay Parkinson, 37, looks like any other young tech visionary. He has a trim beard and thick-framed glasses. He wears slim-fitting black outfits and jaunty scarves. He speaks with a measured, “This American Life”-like cadence. And he’s a firm believer in the utopian promise of the Internet.

headline: City Approves 700-Unit Rental Complex on Gowanus Canal
text: Gritty and offbeat as its reputation is, the Gowanus Canal may, in a few years, start becoming more bourgeois.

headline: The Sound of Tango, the Story of Mary
text: There was no piano in Astor Piazzolla’s vacation home in Parque del Plata, Uruguay, where he spent the summer of 1968 working with the poet Horacio Ferrer on an operita, a “little opera,” so he composed on the bandoneón. The resulting work, “María de Buenos Aires,” is an intense cocktail of poetry, tango music and dance that is performed by a folk contralto, an operatic baritone and one male actor. But it’s the fourth voice — the bandoneón, the soulful South American accordion — that calls the shots and, to borrow Ferrer’s words, “burns in the back of your throat.”

headline: Tongue-in-Cheek Commentary, With Arms and Legs
text: Paul Taylor made his dance “Scudorama” 50 years ago. After 10 years it fell out of his troupe’s repertory, not to be revived until 2007. Leading the matinee program on Saturday during the company’s three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater, the work retained its odd fascination.

headline: Building a Narrative That’s Explosive
text: In 2010 Tom Bissell — author of seven books, contributor to publications like The New Yorker and Harper’s Magazine, darling of book reviewers who compare him to writers like Wells Tower and John Jeremiah Sullivan — announced that he was going to “go game,” in the way that prominent writers “go Hollywood,” in search of bigger paychecks and the challenges of a new form.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Strike Darkens Halls
text: Carnegie Hall will remain dark on this Wednesday and Thursday evenings. Ditto the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark on Friday and the Kennedy Center Concert Hall in Washington on Saturday.

headline: Crustacean Elation
text: The Red Hook Lobster Pound finally opened its doors in March after sustaining massive damage from flooding during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: As ARM Chief Steps Down, Successor Talks About ‘Body Computing’
text: ARM Holdings, the specialist in low-power semiconductors, is looking to put computers everywhere around us, and even inside us.

headline: Before Obama Trip, Polls Find Sympathy With Israel, and Doubts on Peace
text: New polls released just ahead of President Obama’s trip to Israel this week find that Americans continue to sympathize more with Israel than with the Palestinians. But few want the United States to take a leading role in resolving the conflict there, and most do not anticipate that the trip will do much to ease regional tensions.

headline: Businesses Return to the Neighborhood, and the People Follow
text: Crocuses are peeping out of tree pits in Red Hook, Brooklyn, once drowned by a briny soup of seawater and diesel fuel. At the newly reopened Fairway supermarket, bright piles of lemons, tomatoes and oranges pop almost luridly. Kevin’s, a beloved seafood restaurant, has a shiny new wood floor and a new bar built out of donated marble, and across the way in the back of the Red Hook Lobster Pound, gutted by Hurricane Sandy and since rebuilt, sits a shiny new deep fryer, a veritable symbol of marital compromise and rebirth.

headline: The Best Easter Hams
text: The Dining section tasting panel tried a variety of hams that were wet cured, smoked over wood and minimally processed. Here are the results.

headline: How to Pick an Easter Ham
text: I do not come from ham-eating people.

headline: Playing at New Directors/New Films
text: Images of select films screening in the festival.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
text: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.

headline: More From The Times, and Elsewhere, on the 10th Anniversary of the Iraq War
text: I wrote Monday about The Times’s relatively low-key approach to covering the Iraq war’s 10th anniversary, contrasting it to more robust efforts in The Guardian and to its own efforts on the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Eisenhower Memorial in Criticism Barrage
text: WASHINGTON — Simmering conflict over a $142 million memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower designed by the architect Frank Gehry for the National Mall here erupted into the open on Tuesday at a Congressional hearing on the future of the project.

headline: West 22nd Street, 4:51 P.M.
text: Photo: tableau with woman, firefighter and small dog.

headline: True Story Inspires Tale of Sex Trade; in a Twist, a U.S. Marshal Is the Bad Guy
text: Enough films about human trafficking have been made in recent years that the outlines of “Eden” should be painfully familiar. But that familiarity doesn’t cushion this movie’s excruciating vision of under-age women conscripted into sexual slavery by a criminal enterprise from which there is seemingly no escape.

headline: Early Favorites in a Showcase for New Filmmakers
text: Killers and clowns, the quick and the dead roam through New Directors/New Films, the annual showcase of promising and confirmed cinematic talent that begins on Wednesday. Now in its 42nd year, the series was established to present work from emerging filmmakers from across the globe back when such festivals were rare. A joint venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, where all the screenings will be held, it remains a laudatory New York event.

headline: A Model for Reducing Emissions
text: Who would have thought the United States would one day be a leader in cutting greenhouse gas emissions?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smart Shoes and the Top Social Network Among Teens
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Brazilian Billionaire Confirms Talks to Sell Stake in Energy Firm
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista confirmed on Tuesday that he was negotiating to sell part of his stake in MPX, his natural gas and electricity generation company that has over $3 billion in debt and several generation projects running behind schedule.

headline: Israel’s Animated Diplomacy
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 8:02 p.m. On the eve of President Obama’s visit to the Middle East, Israel’s embassy in Washington rolled out the cartoon red carpet, in the form of an animated YouTube clip apparently designed to make light of reported tension between the two countries’ leaders.

headline: Real Fur, Masquerading as Faux
text: The Stuart Weitzman ballet flats from Neiman Marcus sported sweet faux fur pom-poms. The Alice and Olivia coat was trimmed with a dark faux fur collar.

headline: Online Comments in Ohio Rape Case Lead to Charges Against Two
text: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — The rape trial that concluded here on Sunday with the conviction of two high school football stars has spurred calls in many quarters for expanding — or more aggressively enforcing — the legal obligations of those who know about a sexual assault, or who could be in a position to prevent one.

headline: France: Court Says Head Scarf Is No Grounds for Firing
text: France’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a French Muslim woman was unjustly fired in 2008 for wearing a head scarf at work in a private child-care center in a Paris suburb. The court ruled that the dismissal violated the woman’s religious freedom. Religious symbols of all kinds are banned from public schools and institutions under French law, but the child-care center is private. The ruling overturned an appeals court decision, which had said the center had the right to set its own rules about religious neutrality. Interior Minister Manuel Valls told Parliament that the court’s ruling was regrettable because it “calls into question the principle of secular education.”

headline: Michigan State’s Toughness Starts With Its Nonconference Schedule
text: CHICAGO — Mark Montgomery never noticed this about Tom Izzo. Not that he could. Between playing for Michigan State when Izzo was an assistant, then serving as an Izzo assistant for 10 seasons until 2011, Montgomery had too much else going on to scrutinize Izzo’s sideline mannerisms.

headline: Massachusetts: M.I.T. Will Release Documents in Hacking Case
text: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Tuesday announced that it would release documents related to the case against Aaron Swartz, the Internet activist who committed suicide in January, about a month before he was to go to trial on charges that he illegally downloaded academic articles from the university’s computer network. In a letter to the M.I.T. community, the university president, L. Rafael Reif, said lawyers for Mr. Swartz had requested in federal court that the institution make evidence related to the case public. Mr. Reif said M.I.T. planned to release those documents, with some information redacted, when it completed an investigation led by a computer science professor, Hal Abelson, into the university’s role in the case. Professor Abelson said in late January that he hoped to complete the investigation within a few weeks.

headline: Ohio: Teenage Killer Gets Life
text: A defiant 18-year-old was sentenced Tuesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for a 2012 shooting at a high school cafeteria in Chardon, where he killed three students and wounded three others. Wearing a T-shirt with the word “killer” printed on it, T. J. Lane directed an obscene statement and gesture toward family members of the shooting victims when asked for a statement. He pleaded guilty last month to three counts of aggravated murder, two counts of attempted aggravated murder and one count of assault.

headline: Britain: Girl Shot by Taliban Returns to the Classroom
text: Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old Pakistani campaigner for girls’ education who was gravely wounded by the Taliban in October, is back in school for the first time since the attack, according to a statement by her family. Ms. Yousafzai, shown with her father, is now enrolled full time at Edgbaston, a private girls’ high school in Birmingham, England, where her family now lives and where she underwent extensive medical treatment in recent months. “I miss my classmates from Pakistan very much, but I am looking forward to meeting my teachers and making new friends here in Birmingham,” she was quoted as saying in the statement.

headline: Court Announces Early Release of Same-Sex Marriage Arguments
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Tuesday that it would release same-day audio recordings of oral arguments in two same-sex marriage cases scheduled to be heard next week.

headline: Ian McKellen to Lead Wedding for Patrick Stewart
text: Sir Ian McKellen has announced that he will be officiating at the wedding ceremony of Sir Patrick Stewart, 72, and Sunny Ozell, 35, a singer and songwriter whom Mr. Stewart met in 2008 when he was performing in a production of “Macbeth” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Jane Goodall Admits Borrowing Passages for New Book
text: A forthcoming book by Jane Goodall, the primatologist known for her research on chimpanzees, contains passages taken from Web sites without attribution, according to a published report.

headline: Put Cigarettes Out of View? It’s Been Tried
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg this week announced his latest salvo against smoking, his press office put out a news flash: “City Would Be First in Nation to Keep Tobacco Products Out of Sight.”

headline: For Some Palestinians, Wariness on Eve of Obama Visit
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — There are no American flags lining the streets here, no banners bearing the official “Unbreakable Alliance” logo of President Obama’s visit, as there are seven miles away in Jerusalem. Instead, dozens of posters warn the president not to bring his smartphone when he arrives in the West Bank because there is no 3G service, one of an untold number of complaints Palestinians have about their life under Israeli occupation.

headline: N.R.C. Votes for Upgrades to Some Reactor Vents
text: WASHINGTON — The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3 to 2 on Tuesday to require improvements to the emergency vents at 31 American reactors that share design similarities with the Japanese reactors that melted down two years ago. The agency stopped short, however, of requiring filters to scrub out radioactive particles coming through those vents.

headline: Praising Griner Proves Far Easier Than Stopping Her
text: WACO, Tex. — Just in case anyone doubted Baylor’s confident intent to reach the women’s Final Four in New Orleans, Coach Kim Mulkey wore a fleur-de-lis on her T-shirt as she watched the tournament pairings, while some fans wore Mardi Gras beads and sang, “When the Saints Go Marching In.”

headline: Deal in Albany Would Extend Higher Taxes on Top Earners
text: ALBANY — Congress dodged the so-called fiscal cliff in part by raising taxes on high incomes. California voters addressed their state’s school budget troubles with a surcharge on big incomes. And now Albany has decided to raise revenue with a high income tax rate for people with seven-figure incomes.

headline: StubHub Barred Near Yankee Stadium, for Now
text: The Yankees won a court order Tuesday temporarily preventing StubHub from opening a store near Yankee Stadium that is designed to allow customers to pick up their tickets before games.

headline: Teenage Gunman in Ohio Mocks Victims’ Families
text: Thomas Lane wore a T-shirt with KILLER scrawled in black ink during his sentencing Tuesday in an Ohio courtroom for shooting and killing three students in a high school cafeteria and wounding two others last year.

headline: A Decade Later, Stability Eludes Iraq
text: The first American bombs and missiles to hit Baghdad were four 2,000-pound bunker-busters dropped by two F-117 Nighthawk fighter-bombers and 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles, a thunderous volley aimed at killing Saddam Hussein and his two sons in a secret underground redoubt beside the Tigris River known as Dora Farms. The impacts, some missing their targets, came soon after first light on March 19, 2003.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Is Reining In Payday Lenders
text: JPMorgan Chase will make changes to protect consumers who have borrowed money from a rising power on the Internet — payday lenders offering short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.

headline: Banning the Big Gulp Ban
text: Neither I nor anyone else I’ve read on last week’s judicial stay of New York City’s “Big Gulp Ban” is a lawyer. (We call it the Big Gulp Ban, though in fact it famously would not have banned 7-Eleven’s massive drinks.) But I doubt that our Board of Health was being “capricious” or “arbitrary” — those were the words of the ruling justice, Milton A. Tingling — when it decided last September, by a vote of 8 to 0 (you read that right), to forbid the sale, where it could, of super-size sugary drinks. (From this point on I’ll just call them “soda.”)

headline: 2nd Vote for Closing Long Island College Hospital
text: The board of the State University of New York voted on Tuesday, for the second time in several weeks, to close Long Island College Hospital, which was taken over by the university system two years ago, and which university officials say is losing $1 million a week.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 4
text: This is the fourth part of a six-part series.

headline: Iraq War’s 10th Anniversary Is Barely Noted in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — A decade after the night that American bombs first rained down on Baghdad, the president joked about wearing a green tie for a belated St. Patrick’s Day celebration. Congress noisily focused on whether spending cuts would force the cancellation of the White House Easter egg roll. Cable news debated whether a show about young women has too much sex in it.

headline: Ryan Tiptoes Around a Revis Question
text: PHOENIX — Jets Coach Rex Ryan, speaking at the A.F.C. coaches’ breakfast on Tuesday, perhaps played a game of semantics when he said that the Jets are not actively trying to trade cornerback Darrelle Revis, even as he acknowledged that the team would listen to offers.

headline: Renovation Pays Off for a Chelsea Nonprofit
text: When the New York Foundling, one of the city’s largest and oldest child welfare agencies, completes a $5.5 million renovation of its Chelsea headquarters this summer, it will squeeze more workers into less space and lease its top three floors, bringing in substantial revenue.

headline: Developers Are Making Bets on a Rising East Harlem
text: Sharon Kahen and his partner Haim Levi are making a multimillion-dollar bet on East Harlem. The developers recently closed on a vacant parcel at 119th Street and Third Avenue where they plan to build a 60-unit market-rate rental building.

headline: Joel Breitkopf
text: Mr. Breitkopf, 48, is a principal of Alchemy Properties, which specializes in boutique residential developments.

headline: Britain’s Press Crackdown
text: In an attempt to rein in its reckless tabloid newspapers, Britain’s three main political parties this week agreed to impose unwieldy regulations on the news media that would chill free speech and threaten the survival of small publishers and Internet sites.

headline: In Shift, Lobbyists Look for Bipartisan Support to Repeal a Tax
text: WASHINGTON — When executives from Cook Medical gathered last month to offer Representative Cheri Bustos a tour of their central Illinois medical equipment plant, they had good reason to expect a frosty reception from Ms. Bustos, a new Democratic congresswoman.

headline: Was It Worth It?
text: Is America better off now than it was when Saddam Hussein was in power?

headline: A Decade of Despair
text: Baghdad

headline: What America Learned in Iraq
text: Annapolis, Md.

headline: Iraq: Where Terrorists Go to School
text: IRAQ, President George W. Bush said in 2003, was a “central front” in the war on terrorism. He was wrong, but prescient. Iraq has become a front for militant extremism — a front the United States created.

headline: Sectarian Strains Pit Some Iraqis Against Their Own Leaders
text: RAMADI, Iraq — As Rafe al-Essawi, the embattled Sunni leader, sped south on a desert highway last week to attend the funeral of a political ally who was assassinated, his cellphone rang with a warning: Up ahead, Iraqi soldiers, backed by two helicopters hovering overhead, planned to arrest him.

headline: Francis Ruddle, Who Led Transgenic Research, Dies at 83
text: Francis Ruddle, a Yale University geneticist who plumbed the DNA of mice and men, and from whose laboratory sprang the first transgenic mammal — a mouse with added foreign DNA — died on March 10 in New Haven. He was 83.

headline: In a New Aisle, Energy Drinks Sidestep Some Rules
text: Fans of Monster Energy, the popular high-caffeine energy drink, may not notice the change: its ingredients will be the same and its familiar label bearing a green, clawlike monogram will change only slightly. But the drink’s maker has decided after a decade of selling it as a dietary supplement to market it as a beverage, a switch that will bring significant changes in how it is regulated.

headline: Democrats, Dragons or Drones?
text: On this 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq, three things are clear. First, whatever happens in Iraq, we overpaid for it in lives and treasure and focus. Second, you can overpay for something decent and you can overpay for total junk. What exactly we overpaid for in Iraq is not yet clear and will be decided by Iraqis. Third, as much as we’d prefer to forget about Iraq, what happens there matters more than ever for the Middle East.

headline: Ten Years After
text: Ten years after it began, the Iraq war still haunts the United States in the nearly 4,500 troops who died there; the more than 30,000 American wounded who have come home; the more than $2 trillion spent on combat operations and reconstruction, which inflated the deficit; and in the lessons learned about the limits of American leadership and power.

headline: Murrey Marder, Early McCarthy Skeptic, Dies at 93
text: By certain journalistic lights, the reporter Murrey Marder was an editor’s nightmare. He wrote slowly and squeezed against deadlines. He debated with editors. His articles were long, often complicated and never laid claim to stylish writing.

headline: Damage From Derailment to Slow L.I.R.R. Trains for Days
text: There will be minor delays and some cancellations of Long Island Rail Road trains until at least Friday, officials said, citing extensive damage that was caused by a train derailment.
