headline: Genetically Modified Fish
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clemency for Pollard, Jailed as a Spy for Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Affirmative Action: Looking at the Data
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tale of Two Newspapers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Mar. 20, 2013
text: “I came in here as a 30-something with kids, a mother who was alive. This case killed my whole life.”

headline: Justices Explore Fine Line on Generic Drug Injuries
text: WASHINGTON — In 2010, a New Hampshire jury awarded Karen Bartlett $21 million for the ordeal she endured from taking a generic pain pill for an aching shoulder. It caused two-thirds of her skin to slough off, damaged her lungs and esophagus and rendered her legally blind.

headline: On Gay Unions, a Pragmatist Before He Was a Pope
text: BUENOS AIRES — The very idea was anathema to many of the bishops in the room.

headline: G.O.P. Opposition to Immigration Law Is Falling Away
text: WASHINGTON — Republican opposition to legalizing the status of millions of illegal immigrants is crumbling in the nation’s capital as leading lawmakers in the party scramble to halt eroding support among Hispanic voters — a shift that is providing strong momentum for an overhaul of immigration laws.

headline: Used to Baghdad’s Battles, and Adjusting to New York’s Bustle
text: In his first 48 hours in the Bronx, Omar al-Mashhadani caught a few echoes of the life that he and his family had left behind in Baghdad. Thousands of people were swarming along 161st Street, toward the hulking stadium on the other side of the El on River Avenue.

headline: Protecting Their Own, Russians Offer an Alternative to the Cypriot Bank Tax
text: MOSCOW — When the European Union said it would bail out Cypriot banks by seizing a percentage of deposits, Cypriots erupted. Russian government officials also raged, on behalf of Cyprus’s many Russian depositors.

headline: For Steinbrenner and Yankees, a Commitment to a New Order
text: For Yankee fans hoping Brian Cashman will trade a prospect or two to get a player like Justin Morneau from the Minnesota Twins to play first base until Mark Teixeira returns — if he returns — this season from a wrist injury, it might be useful to hear some recent comments from Hal Steinbrenner.

headline: Corrections: March 20, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fun House Cries
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — And now, directly from the Heavy Lifting Department: today’s puzzle by Raymond C. Young, which is the first quadruple pangram SQUISHed inside a 15 x 15 grid.

headline: Back in Connecticut, DiPietro Is Trying to Remain Positive
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — As the final buzzer sounded Sunday, Rick DiPietro looked toward the rafters, raised his gloved right hand in triumph and hugged his teammates.

headline: Early Days of the Iraq War on The Times’s Front Pages
text: A look at how The New York Times covered the initial, often confusing accounts of the American-led invasion in Iraq.

headline: Father Describes Behavior of Son Accused of Murder
text: After enduring years of his son’s bizarre behavior, Leonard Tarloff had grown accustomed to the alarming phone calls that indicated that something was once again amiss.

headline: Using ‘Sponsored Content’ to Keep Viewers Watching
text: TELEVISION networks and channels are becoming increasingly involved in the creation of commercials that appear during their shows, hoping to counter the growing penchant among viewers for zapping or zipping through conventional commercials.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 19, 2013

headline: Melanoma Drug Succeeds in Late-Stage Trial
text: A cancer drug based on a tumor-killing virus has for the first time succeeded in a late-stage clinical trial, giving a lift to a technology that has long tantalized doctors and researchers.

headline: Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Iraq’s Fragile Future
text: When President Obama withdrew the last combat troops from Iraq in 2011, Iraqis became responsible for their own future. They continue to face political strife, sectarian violence and corruption and mismanagement. As a country in transition in the volatile Middle East, it still merits sustained American interest.

headline: Cyprus Bailout Promises Crucial Test for Germany
text: BERLIN — The divisive international bailout deal for Cyprus, with its heavy burden for individual savers, has emerged as a potentially decisive test for the German-led push for discipline and austerity in the currency union.

headline: Both Needing a Win, the Rangers Top the Devils
text: NEWARK — Last spring the Rangers and the Devils stood at the pinnacle of the East, battling in the conference finals for a chance at the Stanley Cup. On Tuesday night they stood at a far more modest place — along the playoff cut line — battling to salvage what has been a mediocre season for both teams.

headline: Bishops Challenge Cuomo on Stronger Abortion Rights
text: ALBANY — As Roman Catholics worldwide celebrated the inauguration of Pope Francis, New York bishops traveled to Albany on Tuesday to meet with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose looming effort to strengthen abortion rights in the state has met with strong protests from Catholic and evangelical clergy.

headline: Campaign Diets
text: On the campaign trail in New York, the path to City Hall leads past hundreds of social events, and thousands of restaurants. Candidates have their own ways of coping with the temptations of food.

headline: No Merger for Los Angeles Museum
text: After several weeks of exploring a merger to shore up its weak financial status, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles appears to have decided to try to go it alone, releasing a statement on Tuesday announcing its intention to stay independent.

headline: French Minister Steps Down in Swiss Bank Investigation
text: PARIS — Just hours after an announcement that he would be investigated on charges of tax fraud and money laundering, Budget Minister Jérôme Cahuzac resigned from the French government on Tuesday evening, though he insisted he had done nothing wrong.

headline: Next Campaign Stop: The Third Lunch Today
text: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, was greeting voters at an Upper West Side political club recently when, midschmooze, he picked up a chocolate-frosted doughnut and prepared to help himself to a sizable, sprinkled bite.

headline: Administration Official Defends Release of Detainees
text: Under fierce questioning from Republicans at a hearing in the House of Representatives, the top Obama administration official in charge of immigration enforcement insisted Tuesday that the release of more than 2,200 immigrants from detention in February was solely a budgetary savings measure, and he disputed accusations that they had included many dangerous criminals.

headline: Subway Worker Freed After Hours Stuck in Mud
text: A construction worker on the Second Avenue subway project who became stuck in mud up to his waist in a 75-foot-deep tunnel on Tuesday night was freed early Wednesday morning in a four-hour rescue involving more than 100 emergency workers, the authorities said.

headline: Minority Groups Remain Outnumbered at Teaching Programs, Study Reports
text: Despite major changes in the racial makeup of American public school students, the people training to be teachers are still predominantly white.

headline: Police Department Monitor Is Topic at a Mayoral Forum
text: Two central characters recurred in the Tuesday night mayoral debate over public safety and the future of the Police Department: one who is real and one who is, at least at this point, still notional.

headline: Quest for Illegal Gain at the Sea Bottom Divides Fishing Communities
text: DZILAM DE BRAVO, Mexico — Whispers of high-speed boat chases, harpoon battles on the open sea and divers who dived deep and never re-emerged come and go around here like an afternoon gale.

headline: Grocers Won’t Sell Altered Fish, Groups Say
text: Several supermarket chains have pledged not to sell what could become the first genetically modified animal to reach the nation’s dinner plates — a salmon engineered to grow about twice as fast as normal.

headline: New Worries About Heading the Soccer Ball
text: Heading a soccer ball can, on the plus side, score goals and impress fans. But it may also adversely affect a player’s ability to think, a new study of high school soccer players suggests.

headline: Word of the Day | nonentity
text: nonentity •\nän-ˈen-tə-te, -ˈe-nə-\• noun

headline: At the Final Four, a Routine Sight of Green and White
text: Since 1995, when Tom Izzo became head coach at Michigan State, every incoming class has made at least one trip to the Final Four before graduating.

headline: Zimbabwe: Constitution Passes by Wide Margin
text: Voters overwhelmingly approved Zimbabwe’s new Constitution, the Election Commission announced Tuesday, with more than three million people voting yes and fewer than 200,000 voting no. The new charter replaces the Constitution that has governed Zimbabwe since the end of white minority rule in 1980 and is a crucial step toward holding presidential elections this year to replace an uneasy power-sharing government installed after the violent 2008 election.

headline: World-Class Pitching Carries Undefeated Dominicans to Title
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Horns beeped through the chilly air Tuesday night, and flags flapped through the raindrops. At a ballpark with a statue of Juan Marichal out front, the Dominican Republic reached the pinnacle of international baseball competition.

headline: Cleaner Fuel Means Lower Emissions
text: Emissions of CO<sup>2</sup> into the atmosphere have dropped sharply. One of the main reasons has been the replacement of coal with natural gas for power generation.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (Science) THROUGH THE WORMHOLE WITH MORGAN FREEMAN In “Is There a God Particle?” Mr. Freeman, above, speaks with the scientists Joseph Incandela and Lyn Evans of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research near Geneva. They discuss recent progress in the search for the Higgs boson, an elementary particle believed to supply mass to other particles.

headline: News Quiz | March 20, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The View From Oshima
text: Locals say Oshima has a better view of Japan’s most famous peak than anywhere else in the country.

headline: David Ranta’s Statement to Court, 1991
text: Read David Ranta’s statement to the court when he was remanded on June 10, 1991.

headline: Jailed Unjustly in the Death of a Rabbi, Man Nears Freedom
text: In the wintry darkness 23 years ago on a back street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a jewelry thief fleeing a botched robbery panicked and shot a Hasidic rabbi in the head.

headline: India Moves Towards Stronger Law to Protect Women
text: India’s lower house of Parliament passed a bill Tuesday intended to better protect women from sex crimes, widely hailed as a step forward in India’s attempt to deter sexual offenders after the fatal gang rape of a young woman in Delhi in December sparked a nationwide movement to improve women’s security.

headline: China and Japan Spar Over War Trials, More Than 6 Decades On
text: BEIJING – What would international reaction be if Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, were to publicly cast doubt on the fairness of the Nuremberg Trials, which condemned top Nazis at the end of World War II?

headline: India’s Foodie Web Sites Bring Gourmet Treats to Delhi Doors
text: With late nights at work the norm and the kirana (corner) stores displaying only shelves of dusty cans and dried beans, urban Delhiites with sophisticated palates are increasingly looking to the Internet to bring the market to them. Many of these sites that feature fresh, organic produce and gourmet products were started by young entrepreneurs who didn’t want time constraints get in the way of a good home-cooked meal.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 20
text: NEWS Lawmakers rejected a 10 billion euro bailout package for Cyprus on Tuesday, sending the president back to the drawing board to devise a plan that might enable the country to receive a financial lifeline while avoiding a default that could reignite the euro crisis. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus.

headline: Computer Networks in South Korea Are Paralyzed in Cyberattacks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Computer networks running three major South Korean banks and the country’s two largest broadcasters were paralyzed Wednesday in attacks that some experts suspected originated in North Korea, which has consistently threatened to cripple its far richer neighbor.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 20, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the Economix blog post “Only Half of First-Time College Students Graduate in 6 Years.”

headline: Parading on the Edges
text: “I love surreal-ness,” said Nicole Bengiveno, staff photographer of The New York Times, who photographed the St. Patrick’s Day parade in New York on Saturday. “You have men in skirts, you have people with shamrocks on their faces — I kept snapping pictures of people with these funny hats and green hair. Because they’re just really in the spirit.” Followed by the freelance videographer Elaisha Stokes, Ms. Bengiveno demonstrates how, for the parade-going photographer, it is helpful to be drawn to strangeness. After all, if you have photographed as many parades as she has, an eye for the uncommon can be a gift. Likewise, a knack for sticking to the sidelines. “I like to stay around the edges,” Ms. Bengiveno said. “I like the idea of being invisible.”

headline: Do You Ever Feel Guilty About What, or How Much, You Throw Away?
text: Americans throw away hundreds of millions of tons of trash every year. We throw away spoiled food, old sneakers, unwanted pianos and bulky televisions. That’s a lot of garbage.

headline: The 10th Anniversary of the Iraq War
text: In this post we use several different Times pieces to help students understand this anniversary. Each question links to the piece in which an answer can be found.

headline: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
text: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: John Dillinger’s Terraplane Revisits His Childhood Home
text: An eight-cylinder 1933 Essex-Terraplane briefly used by the notorious bank robber and jail escapee John Dillinger is on display at the Indianapolis International Airport, where, according to airport representatives, it is attracting crowds of visitors.

headline: How to Live in Assisted Living
text: Sometimes Martin Bayne speaks in little more than a whisper, like many people with advanced Parkinson’s disease. But his voice has a way of carrying.

headline: Forgiveness Formulas
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Seeking Lessons From the Iraq War. But Which Ones?
text: WASHINGTON – Stephen J. Hadley, who played a central role in the decision a decade ago to go to war in Iraq, recently described the cascade of misjudgments and inaccurate assumptions inside the Bush White House leading up to the war as a “failure of imagination.” His explanation of what went wrong is rife with lessons for two crises – one in Syria, another in Iran – that President Obama confronts as he lands in Israel on Wednesday morning.

headline: Too Big Not to Fail
text: LISBON — Education policy isn’t the Portuguese government’s strong suit. There have been 28 education ministers since 1974. Only half of the country’s 25-to-34 year-olds have successfully completed high school; dropout rates are among the highest in Western Europe.

headline: With Set-Aside, Deutsche Bank Cuts 2012 Profit
text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: In Israel, Obama Seeks to Offer Reassurance of ‘Unbreakable Bonds’
text: JERUSALEM — It took four years and a second term, but President Obama traveled to Israel on Wednesday for a richly symbolic state visit, bearing a message of solidarity to a wary Israeli public, and a promise to defend Israel from threats near and far.

headline: Deal Makers Foresee a Feast of Activity, Survey Finds
text: As deal makers prepare to head down to New Orleans for one of the biggest merger conferences of the year, many will do so with a spring in their step.

headline: Business for Sale: A Long-Haul Trucking Company
text: Let’s take a look at another business for sale. And once again, we’ll consider the business from the point of view of a potential buyer, but we will also see what lessons this business might hold for owners of other businesses.

headline: Becoming the All-Terrain Human
text: Kilian Jornet Burgada is the most dominating endurance athlete of his generation. In just eight years, Jornet has won more than 80 races, claimed some 16 titles and set at least a dozen speed records, many of them in distances that would require the rest of us to purchase an airplane ticket. He has run across entire landmasses­ (Corsica) and mountain ranges (the Pyrenees), nearly without pause. He regularly runs all day eating only wild berries and drinking only from streams. On summer mornings he will set off from his apartment door at the foot of Mont Blanc and run nearly two and a half vertical miles up to Europe’s roof — over cracked glaciers, past Gore-Tex’d climbers, into the thin air at 15,781 feet — and back home again in less than seven hours, a trip that mountaineers can spend days to complete. A few years ago Jornet ran the 165-mile Tahoe Rim Trail and stopped just twice to sleep on the ground for a total of about 90 minutes. In the middle of the night he took a wrong turn, which added perhaps six miles to his run. He still finished in 38 hours 32 minutes, beating the record of Tim Twietmeyer, a legend in the world of ultrarunning, by more than seven hours. When he reached the finish line, he looked as if he’d just won the local turkey trot.

headline: Happy International Happiness Day
text: LONDON – If you want to avoid the risk of being accosted by total strangers urging you to “be happy,” you should probably stay home on Wednesday.

headline: American Realty Capital Offers to Buy Cole Credit for $5.7 Billion
text: American Realty Capital Properties said on Wednesday that it had offered to buy Cole Credit Property Trust III for $5.7 billion, in a deal that would create one of the biggest publicly traded real estate investment trusts.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Is Said to Scrutinize Microsoft Accusations
text: Federal authorities are examining Microsoft’s involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times.

headline: JPMorgan’s New Policy on Payday Lenders
text: JPMorgan Chase is moving to protect customers whose accounts are tapped by Internet-based payday lenders, planning to give those customers more power to stop withdrawals and close their accounts, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. Under the changes, to be announced on Wednesday, JPMorgan is also limiting the fees it charges customers when the withdrawals trigger penalties.

headline: Waiting for Catastrophes: Aleksandar Hemon Talks About ‘The Book of My Lives’
text: In 1992, Aleksandar Hemon was visiting Chicago when war broke out in his home country, Bosnia. Chicago became his adopted home, and he soon became a highly praised writer of fiction. In 2004, he received a MacArthur “genius” grant. Mr. Hemon’s new book, “The Book of My Lives,” collects nonfiction pieces about his upbringing in Sarajevo and his life in America. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hemon discussed displacement, visiting Sarajevo now, the purpose of art and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Opinion Report: Iraq, Ten Years Later
text: From the editorial page

headline: Suntech Unit Declares Bankruptcy
text: HONG KONG — Suntech Power, a Chinese manufacturer that became the world’s largest producer of solar panels by 2011 only to be battered by plummeting prices, announced on Wednesday evening that its main operating subsidiary had been pushed into bankruptcy by eight Chinese banks.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Networks Embrace Content Marketing and Retailers Admit to Faking Faux Fur
text: Television networks and channels are becoming increasingly involved in making commercials, hoping to prevent audiences from skipping ads, Stuart Elliott writes. New efforts at content marketing (also called content advertising and native advertising) have become the norm as networks try to convince marketers to pay more for airtime. Scripps Networks Interactive, the parent of cable channels like DIY, Food Network and Travel Channel, is one of the leaders in the field. Jonathan LaConti, vice president for ad sales at the company’s New York office, said that Scripps strives to make commercials that look “really natural,” particularly if they involve one of the network’s hosts.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Picking a Flavorful Easter Ham
text: Picking a flavorful Easter ham, when fake fur is actually real fur, new worries about heading the soccer ball and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Heating Oil Companies Face Inquiry on Purity of Fuel
text: State and federal authorities are investigating whether several New York heating oil businesses cheated tens of thousands of customers for years, selling fuel diluted with recycled or waste oil, according to law enforcement and city officials.

headline: As Bailout Deadline Approaches, Cyprus Scrambles to Find Funds
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Scrambling to placate international lenders, Cyprus late Wednesday proposed to nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and conduct an emergency bond sale to help raise the €5.8 billion the indebted country needs to secure a bailout.

headline: Voters, Deficits, and Jobs
text: Update: On the other hand, via Greg Sargent, a huge majority of Americans — three quarters! — supports federal spending programs to create jobs. But we know that this is out of the question, because, well, because.

headline: In One Simple Tool, Hope for H.I.V. Prevention
text: Two plastic rings, a rubber band, and a thread.

headline: Two for the Road
text: With a clever bag and shoe combination, dressing for any destination can be shockingly simple.

headline: The Tale of a Transgender 6-Year-Old Child Raises Reader Concerns
text: In Monday’s New York Times, an article by the national reporter Dan Frosch examined a Colorado case involving a 6-year-old child, who is biologically male but identifies as a female. The article used the child’s name, Coy Mathis, and two color photographs that showed her face clearly.

headline: Psychiatric Patient Arrested in Beating Death at a Brooklyn Hospital
text: A 47-year-old psychiatric patient was beaten to death in a locked shower room at Interfaith Medical Center in central Brooklyn late on Tuesday, officials said, and another patient, a 20-year-old, has been charged with second-degree murder in the killing.

headline: Joining the Toad Patrols of Britain
text: My latest Green column goes patrolling for toads in Britain. Toads are mostly terrestrial creatures but when they mature at the age of about three they return in early spring to the body of water in which they were born to spawn.

headline: Round Trips to Cyprus
text: Still trying to wrap my head around the Cyprus situation; what makes it so interesting (as in “may you live in interesting times”) is the role of the island as a tax, regulation, and law enforcement haven.

headline: Chinese Solar Panel Giant Is Tainted by Bankruptcy
text: HONG KONG — It was the Icarus of the solar power industry. And, on Wednesday, it fell to earth.

headline: Australia Prime Minister Fights Own Party to Stay in Office
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The embattled prime minister of Australia, Julia Gillard, was fighting for her political life on Thursday after she accepted a public demand for a leadership ballot put forward by a senior lawmaker from her ruling Labor Party, who said that the party’s only hope of prevailing in upcoming elections was to return to office the man Ms. Gillard deposed in a 2010 party coup.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making an iTunes Wish List
text: The iTunes Store has millions of songs, videos and other digital goods that make it easy to run up the credit-card bill. If you find items you want to buy — but need to pace your spending — you can use the Wish List feature to set them aside for purchasing later. To use the Wish List when you are logged in and browsing the iTunes Store, click the triangle next to the price listed for a song, album, video, book or other content for sale, and choose “Add to Wish List” from the menu that appears.

headline: With JPMorgan Settlement, MF Global Clients Move Closer to Payout
text: MF Global customers moved one step closer to recouping their missing money late on Tuesday when JPMorgan Chase released its claim to more than $500 million belonging to the bankrupt brokerage firm.

headline: Colorado Reels After Killing of Top Official Over Prisons
text: DENVER — As Colorado’s governor signed a hard-won package of gun control measures on Wednesday, officials across the state were reeling from the seemingly inexplicable shooting death of the state’s prisons chief, who was gunned down at the front door of his home.

headline: Study of Men’s Falling Income Cites Single Parents
text: WASHINGTON — The decline of two-parent households may be a significant reason for the divergent fortunes of male workers, whose earnings generally declined in recent decades, and female workers, whose earnings generally increased, a prominent labor economist argues in a new survey of existing research.

headline: India’s Weakened Government May Struggle For Reform
text: India’s government faced accusations Wednesday that it will be incapable of bringing about much-needed reforms after the withdrawal of its biggest ally Tuesday night, a southern political party that protested the government’s stance on Sri Lanka’s alleged war crimes.

headline: More Proof That Rules Alone Won’t Save Threatened Wildlife
text: HONG KONG – A major international conference on wildlife trade last week added 343 animal and plant species to the list of roughly 34,000 that are considered threatened. Trade in these creatures is either banned or strictly monitored, and the outcome was widely welcomed by conservationists as an important development.

headline: ‘Downton’ Season 3 Sets PBS Record
text: The third season of “Downton Abbey” was even more popular than previously believed. The season’s seven episodes averaged 11.5 million viewers a week, PBS said Tuesday after it received updated Nielsen numbers that included digital video recorder playbacks. Earlier numbers suggested that seven million to eight million viewers had tuned in for each episode. The total audience — up about 65 percent from the second season — makes the third season of “Downton” the most popular drama ever televised by PBS. The show’s online viewership was counted separately. But there, too, a record was set: The public broadcaster said there were 900,000 video streams on the “Masterpiece” Web site the day after the Season 3 finale, the most for the site.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Southern Foodways Alliance: It must be spring: Hansen’s Sno-Bliz in New Orleans has started serving sno-balls again. — Julia Moskin

headline: Afghans Compromise Over Ban on Elite U.S. Troops
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai’s government has agreed to compromise on his demand that American Special Operations forces immediately leave Wardak Province, according to statements from American and Afghan officials on Wednesday, breaking an increasingly acrimonious impasse.

headline: Google Hosts Narendra Modi at Tech Summit
text: MUMBAI– Gujarat’s controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi, will address a Google summit in New Delhi on Thursday to speak about how the Internet is changing politics in India.

headline: Hugo Chávez’s Unlikely Soccer Legacy
text: In death, Hugo Chávez may conjure more debate and split more opinions than he ever did in life. Whether the former Venezuelan leader is remembered as a man of the people who brought millions out of extreme poverty or castigated as a deranged autocrat who drove his country in to debt and hyperinflation, the true measure of his time as a president will lie in the legacy and future he has left for Venezuela.

headline: ‘The Rite of Spring’
text: It’s not surprising that Disney set a battle between a stegosaurus and a Tyrannosaurus rex to a soundtrack of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” in the 1940 film “Fantasia.” For most children, that’s what the music is about. But few are probably aware that when the ballet made its debut at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in 1913, a near riot broke out in the audience.

headline: The Gun Report: March 20, 2013
text: What if there were a technology that insured that only the person who owned a gun could shoot it? No child who stumbled across the gun could accidentally shoot his brother. No one could make use of a stolen gun. No one could buy a gun on someone else’s behalf because it wouldn’t work for anyone but the buyer. Such a technology would not eliminate gun violence, of course, but it certainly would decrease it. It would greatly diminish, and perhaps even eliminate, fatal accidents involving children finding guns in their homes, which I find the most wrenching stories to read in The Gun Report. Such a technology, it turns out, does exist. I plan to write about it soon.

headline: Van Cliburn, My Nemesis
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Robert Forster to Play Reagan in a New Play
text: The actor Robert Forster, a Rochester native (and Max Cherry in Quentin Tarantino’s “Jackie Brown”), will portray Ronald Reagan at Rochester’s Geva Theater Center in June, the theater announced.

headline: Once So Mighty, Now Gone: China’s Ministry of Railways
text: BEIJING — With nearly 100,000 kilometers of track, China’s railway system is the second-largest in the world, according to Sheng Guangzu, the last minister of railways. Its nearly 9,400 kilometers of high-speed rail — rising fast as China invests heavily in the sector — is the largest.

headline: The Power Breakfast: Andrew Jenks
text: The filmmaker Andrew Jenks sits down with The Times’s Tanzina Vega at Delicatessen in New York City to discuss the latest season of his MTV show, “World of Jenks,” and the evolution of reality TV.

headline: A New Purpose for an Old Telephone Building, but Its Dull Face Remains
text: When City Room last visited the bulky old telephone switching station at 375 Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, it was poised to emerge — like a chrysalis — from its limestone shell and turn into a sleek glass-skinned office tower, putting at risk its standing as one of the uglier skyscrapers in New York.

headline: Wisdom From Flyers With Nut Allergies
text: When Roxanne Palin of Manhattan travels by plane with her family, some of whom are allergic to tree nuts or peanuts, she has a standing battle plan. She books flights in advance so that the three with allergies can sit together, and makes sure they bring their own food and beverages. She swabs their seats and table trays with alcohol pads or baby wipes. She packs eight doses of self-injectable epinephrine, including back-ups, in case any of them has an allergic reaction.

headline: Autonomy Questions for Hewlett-Packard
text: You didn’t really think Mike Lynch would stay away from Hewlett-Packard, did you?

headline: U.K. Takes Steps to Spur Stuttering Economy
text: LONDON — The British government was forced on Wednesday to seek new ways to revive the sputtering economy after acknowledging for the second time in three months that it would take longer than expected to meet its debt-reduction target.

headline: Just 5 Banks Prohibit Use of Social Security Numbers
text: Despite the risk of fraud associated with the theft of Social Security numbers, just five of the nation’s largest 25 banks have stopped using the numbers to verify a customer’s identity after the initial account setup, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

headline: The Master Fish Butcher of Tokyo’s Union Square
text: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: A Sophisticated Instagram Alternative
text: Maybe Instagram’s privacy blunder took the bloom off the rose, but that’s no reason to stop sharing photos through social media as Instagram alternatives continue to emerge.

headline: Last Splash
text: A promenade outside of Mumbai adorned with a mural by Rouble Nagi. The prime season for tourism there is ending as temperatures rise ahead of monsoons.

headline: Back in the Tournament, Butler Has a Challenge in Bucknell
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The Butler men’s basketball team is a No. 6 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s East Regional after a 67-56 loss in the semifinal round of the Atlantic 10 tournament to eventual champion St. Louis. The Bulldogs enter the N.C.A.A. tournament with a 26-8 record.

headline: ‘The Revisionist’ Eyes Broadway as It Extends Run
text: One of the hottest Off Broadway tickets, the Vanessa Redgrave-Jesse Eisenberg play, “The Revisionist,” is adding an extra week of performances before its new closing date of April 27, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater announced on Wednesday. The theater’s leaders have also begun exploring transferring the production to Broadway during the 2013-14 season.

headline: Rat Body Linked to Blackout at Atomic Site
text: TOKYO — The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant said Wednesday that it had found what it believed was the cause of an extended blackout that disabled vital cooling systems this week: the charred body of a rat.

headline: An Insider’s Tour of Chongqing Yields Frugal Gems
text: As we drove down the mountain from Lao Jun Dong, a Taoist temple perched above the smoggy mega-city of Chongqing, I tried to describe to YangYang, my host and a local magazine editor, the kind of restaurant where I wanted to eat that Sunday evening.

headline: Pope Francis, the Pragmatist
text: The Times’s Simon Romero explains how Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio navigated the politics of gay marriage.

headline: Symbolic Visit
text: The Times’s Isabel Kershner on what Israelis expect from a visit by President Obama.

headline: For Kentucky, There’s Always Last Year
text: North Carolina A&T won an N.C.A.A. tournament game for the first time on Tuesday, a 73-72 victory over 20-loss Liberty. (Make that 21-loss Liberty.) And in pro basketball, the Denver Nuggets won their 13th straight.

headline: 8 Filipinos Are Charged in Incursion on Borneo
text: MANILA — Eight Filipinos were charged on Wednesday in a Malaysian court with committing terrorism and waging war in connection with their recent incursion on the island of Borneo, according to the Malaysian state news agency Bernama.

headline: To Save a Man’s Life, a Muddy Tug of War With the Earth Itself
text: Deep below Second Avenue, where workers blast into Manhattan’s bedrock to build the first new subway line in New York City in decades, mud and muck are a fact of life.

headline: Longing for the Test of War as a Young Man
text: The war began for me while I was sitting on a couch in a living room. Like many people, I watched it all commence on television. At a friend’s house on campus, I sat with a few college friends and drank Bud Ice from bottles. We weren’t drinking beer because of the war; we were drinking simply because, being in college, it was something we often did. White smoke from an explosion would burst up from the cityscape of Baghdad as the sound echoed through the dark. Yellow tracers from antiaircraft fire sprayed randomly into the sky. The ticker on the bottom of the screen euphemistically summarized what was happening (while adding some alliteration and a subtle rhyme): “Large explosion rocks Iraq’s capital.”

headline: Safety Agency Upgrades Inquiry on Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedans
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it is upgrading an investigation into fuel leaks on about 250,000 Mercedes-Benz sedans, according to a report posted on the agency Web site. The investigation covers 2003-8 E-Class models.

headline: Image of the Day: March 20
text: Students in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, protest alleged war crimes committed against the Tamil community in Sri Lanka.

headline: Matches as Memories
text: Everyone swipes the matches. They were once ephemera — written on, burned up in the space of a weekend — but they’re now a keepsake. Maybe they bring you back to the Hemingway Bar at the Ritz or remind you of the pink-and-white striped pool towels at the Beverly Hills Hotel. In a way, they are the perfect hotel souvenirs, and also the most anachronistic — having been left essentially unchanged since the bygone days of steamer trunks, Baedeker guides, swizzle sticks and, let’s not forget, smoking.

headline: Where NASA’s Voyager Is a Musical Instrument
text: Instead of the usual warning to silence all electronic gadgets, the WNYC host John Schaefer asked the audience at Merkin Concert Hall, gathered on Thursday evening for Bang on a Can’s 2013 People’s Commissioning Fund Concert, to keep their phones on.

headline: Questions Abound in Learning to Adjust to Health Care Overhaul
text: Baked in the Sun is a wholesale baker and distributor of freshly baked pastries near San Diego.

headline: Mariam Farhat, Known as ‘Mother of Martyrs,’ Dies at 64
text: Mariam Farhat, a Palestinian lawmaker known as the “mother of martyrs” after three of her sons died in attacks against Israel, one of which was a suicide mission that she encouraged in a homemade video, died on Sunday in Gaza City. She was 64.

headline: PEN/Faulkner Fiction Award Goes to Benjamin Alire Sáenz
text: Joining a pantheon that includes Philip Roth, E.L. Doctorow and John Updike, Benjamin Alire Sáenz has won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his short story collection, “Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Should a Bakery With More Than 50 Employees Offer Health Insurance?
text: We just published a case study about Baked in the Sun, a wholesale bakery and distributor trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act, which requires businesses with 50 or more employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. The company, owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, who are married, started out making scones 16 years ago and expanded with the growth of coffeehouses. Baked in the Sun now produces nearly 20,000 items per day — almost 200 different products, including brownies, coffee cakes, muffins and cookies — and employs nearly 100 people in San Marcos, Calif.

headline: A Challenge Grant From Weills to Spur Carnegie Hall Renovation
text: Carnegie Hall has received a $10 million challenge grant from its chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and his wife, Joan, and their Weill Family Foundation toward the completion of its $230 million renovation. The project, known as the Studio Towers Renovation, will create new spaces for music education on the landmark building’s upper floors and upgrade the concert hall’s backstage areas. It is scheduled to be completed in 2014.

headline: From Morgan Stanley, Investing in Women on Corporate Boards
text: The lack of women on corporate boards has been a hot topic in financial circles recently, especially after a debate in Europe last year over imposing quotas.

headline: HBO Cancels ‘Enlightened’
text: Despite some critical acclaim, a second-season ratings spike and a Golden Globe award for best actress, HBO’s “Enlightened” will be no more. After two seasons, the series, created by Mike White and Laura Dern, who also starred, has been canceled, The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: All the Plan B’s for Cyprus Look Dreadful
text: The Cypriots have an expression, “eninboro allo.” It means: I cannot take any more of it.

headline: Minds at War
text: Any attempt to calculate the carnage of the Civil War, the number of sick, wounded, dismembered and dead, leaves one numb in the struggle to make sense of it all. The conditions and horrors faced by those who fought the war exacted a horrific toll.

headline: Outside the Citadel, Social Practice Art Is Intended to Nurture
text: In Detroit a contemporary-art museum is completing a monument to an influential artist that will not feature his work but will instead provide food, haircuts, education programs and other social services to the general public.

headline: Seder in Paris: Readers Want to Correct and Connect
text: PARIS — Mastering Passover hasn’t been easy. I’ve just written my Letter From Paris column on learning to do a proper Seder – as a Roman Catholic married to a Jew, and as an American living in Paris, where people tend to keep their religious beliefs and rituals to themselves.

headline: Trapped in the Muck
text: The Times’s Marc Santora on the successful effort to rescue a worker on the Second Avenue subway construction site.

headline: A Chef’s Guide to Eating in Jerusalem
text: When the London-based chef and restaurateur Yotam Ottolenghi, who grew up in the Jewish west side of Jerusalem, crisscrossed his hometown to research a cookbook he was writing with his company’s head chef, Sami Tamimi, from the Arab east, he became a specialist in the city’s subtle culinary distinctions. From the spices preferred by Jews from Libya to the technique Palestinians perfected for boiling chickpeas, “Jerusalem: A Cookbook” contains recipes inspired by the many flavors of the city’s shops and restaurants in tucked-away corners. Jerusalem should not be missed, Mr. Ottolenghi said. “Especially,” he added, “if you’re interested in those layers of the history, the people, the religions, the tensions.”

headline: Palmer Is Down on McIlroy’s Absence, Long Putters
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – Despite good-natured needling by the tournament host, Arnold Palmer, the world No. 1 Rory McIlroy chose love over a legend.

headline: How Viable Is Rand Paul for 2016?
text: Perhaps no Republican has had a better 2013 than Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator who drew attention and praise for his talking filibuster against the C.I.A. director nominee John Brennan, then last week won the straw poll at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington. Then, on Tuesday, as my colleague Ashley Parker reports, Mr. Paul gave a speech to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, outlining his plan for immigration reform.

headline: Havana, Art Deco Capital
text: Cuba is one of the world’s most significant but overlooked troves of Art Deco architecture, with many classic examples of the style in a state of disrepair.

headline: Indian Government Gets Support From Unlikely Corner
text: India’s beleaguered governing Indian National Congress received an unexpected boost Wednesday evening when a political party that had withdrawn its support in September offered its backing – on foreign policy, at least.

headline: And Snoring in 14E …
text: Finnair began a new check-in service this month that allows passengers to share their Facebook profiles with others on board and even see who’s seated next to them. It is the latest of a handful of carriers experimenting with social seating. The voluntary service is a boon for fliers looking to socialize, not for those hoping to take a nap.

headline: A ‘Sham Procedure’ Leads to Disappointing M.S. News
text: Today, the results of an early study on a controversial treatment for M.S. will be released.

headline: Who Has The Fastest LTE Service?
text: Which cellular carrier’s LTE data service is the fastest?

headline: Republicans Ask Themselves What Went Wrong
text: Gail Collins: David, I recall that during the presidential primaries, you worried that the Republicans would nominate Mitt Romney, that Romney would lose and then the Tea Party would beat its chest and say that the only road to victory was through the far right. Last weekend, Senator Ted Cruz told a convention of conservatives: “We’re winning!” It made me think about what a good predictor you are.

headline: The Missing Piece
text: Landon Donovan’s self-imposed exile from soccer has often been described as unprecedented or unusual, but this is hardly true. There is a rich and compelling history of surprising celebrity sabbaticals, with a wide variety of outcomes.

headline: Pope Meets Other Religious Leaders, Pledging Respect
text: ROME — Pope Francis promised friendship, respect and continued dialogue with other religious leaders on Wednesday, pledging cooperation with Orthodox churches, describing the spiritual bond between Catholics and Jews as “very special” and expressing gratitude to Muslim leaders.

headline: Baby Steps on Gun Control
text: As gun-control opponents often argue, no single law will prevent any single act of gun violence. But hardly a day goes by without a reminder of how out-of-control our gun culture is, how much violence is committed with guns—and how tragic it is that the gun lobbies want to prevent the government from even trying to rein things in.

headline: Keeping the World Safe for Art
text: The job of a museum guard demands long hours, constant vigilance and a reservoir of patience to put up with illicit picture takers, soda smugglers and pontificating amateur art critics, among other annoyances.

headline: The Era of Deep Archiving Begins
text: As a Dartmouth student in the early 1970s, William McDonough went, somewhat casually, to hear a lecture by a visiting celebrity. Mr. McDonough had little idea beforehand who Buckminster Fuller was, but listening to the designer and futurist had a long-term effect.

headline: Sudden Rise in Home Demand Takes Builders by Surprise
text: SACRAMENTO — After six years of waiting on the sidelines, newly eager home buyers across the country are discovering that there are not enough houses for sale to accommodate the recent flush of demand.

headline: Young Opponents of Gay Marriage Undaunted by Battle Ahead
text: WASHINGTON — They hear that their cause is lost, that demographics and the march of history have doomed their campaign to keep marriage only between a man and a woman. But the young conservatives who oppose same-sex marriage — unlike most of their generation — remain undaunted.

headline: Police Search I.M.F. Chief’s Home in French Financial Investigation
text: PARIS — The French police on Wednesday searched the Paris apartment of Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in connection with an investigation into her handling of a financial scandal when she was the French finance minister.

headline: A ‘Big Data’ Freeway for Scientists
text: The University of California, San Diego, this week plans to announce that it has installed an advanced optical computer network that is intended to serve as a “Big Data freeway system” for next-generation science projects in fields including genomic sequencing, climate science, electron microscopy, oceanography and physics.

headline: Excerpt: 'Breakfast at Tiffany's'
text: Emilia Clarke and Cory Michael Smith in a scene from the new Broadway play at the Cort Theater.

headline: Number of Hunger Strikers Surges at Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — A hunger strike by detainees who have been held for years without trial at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has grown to involve at least 25 prisoners, the Defense Department disclosed Wednesday.

headline: Moscow Court Rejects Punk Band’s Appeal
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow appellate court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by three members of the punk group Pussy Riot who were jailed for hooliganism after they called for the Virgin Mary to rid Russia of President Vladimir V. Putin in a protest in a church last year.

headline: Student Crossword | The Human Body
text: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about the human body. And you can find the answers here.

headline: Spring Training
text: Though men have been wearing their suits with running shoes and incorporating sweatshirts into work gear for a while now, the athletic look continues this spring. Miuccia Prada presented a collection of what seemed to be team uniforms for the future. Valentino, Bottega Veneta and Raf Simons showed the majority (if not all) of their looks with sneakers instead of proper oxfords. Some designers were even more specific with their sporty adaptions — as in the case of the young British designer Lou Dalton, who created this high-fashion take on a baseball shirt ($399; openingceremony.us).

headline: What Argentine Priests Knew About the ‘Dirty War’
text: In 1975, I watched churches in Buenos Aires fill with distraught mothers praying futilely for news of missing sons and daughters. Troubled police officers frequented the confessionals. Most Argentines suspected that President Isabel Perón and her Rasputin, José López Rega, were behind official death squads that made so many people disappear. Priests knew the details.

headline: Dreams of Saving Art Deco Havana
text: HAVANA — Kathleen Murphy Skolnik gasped one recent morning as she gazed up into the stairwell of a 1939 downtown apartment building here and pointed at the chevron pattern in the ironwork, at the unpolished rust-pink marble and a simple alcove on the stairway crowned by a stepped arch.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa: Longer, and Shaping Up for a Big Year
text: Pictures of Azzedine Alaïa’s latest collection don’t adequately capture the three-dimensional quality of the knitting. Polka dots on a baby-doll dress, shown with matched leggings, are actually raised, like embroidery, and a series of vertically striped dresses are in fact ribbons of lacework backed by a shimmery knit. Other sophisticated techniques include honeycomb pleating, and most of the garments have a minimum number of seams. It’s remarkable what Mr. Alaïa is able to express through one form.

headline: Chemicals Would Be ‘Game Changer’ in Syria, Obama Says
text: JERUSALEM — Showing solidarity with Israel’s growing concern about chemical weapons in neighboring Syria, President Obama stated bluntly on Wednesday that if an investigation he had ordered found proof that the Syrian military had used such weapons it would be a “game changer” in American involvement in the civil war there.

headline: Barclays Bankers Cash In on Past Bonuses
text: LONDON — It pays to be a Barclays banker.

headline: Knicks’ Anthony Says He Is Ready to Return
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks slept in their own beds Tuesday night after being on the road for 10 days, the longest such stretch of the season. A brutal five-game western road trip, during which they were 1-4 and lost Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler and Kurt Thomas to injury, is finally in the past.

headline: At Hanjan, It’s No Secret When the Chicken Died
text: For the most part, American restaurants are not keen on reminding their customers that the meat they’re about to eat comes from an animal that has, at some point along the way, been killed.

headline: CBS Renews ‘C.S.I.’
text: CBS announced Wednesday that it has renewed the biggest television hit of the past decade, “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” for a 14th season.

headline: Justices Back Loggers in Water Runoff Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that logging companies and forestry officials in Oregon were not required to obtain permits from the Environmental Protection Agency for storm-water runoff from logging roads.

headline: Cell Therapy Shows Promise for Acute Type of Leukemia
text: A treatment that genetically alters a patient’s own immune cells to fight cancer has, for the first time, produced remissions in adults with an acute leukemia that is usually lethal, researchers are reporting.

headline: Exhibitions on View
text: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer.

headline: With Freddie Mac Suit, Banks Face Billions More in Libor Claims
text: The fallout from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, has already cost banks $2.5 billion in penalties, not to mention loss of reputation.

headline: Team on the Way to Collect Congo War Crimes Suspect
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — American officials on Wednesday said that a team from the International Criminal Court was on its way to Rwanda to collect a war crimes suspect who had turned himself in to the American Embassy and that they were hoping Rwanda would cooperate.

headline: Fed to Maintain Stimulus Efforts Despite Jobs Growth
text: WASHINGTON — Employment has been increasing at a healthy clip for the last few months, but the Federal Reserve is not ready to relax just yet.

headline: Backup Cat Out of ‘Breakfast’
text: Even as “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” prepared to open on Broadway Wednesday night, one cat was out of the bag — or at least, out of a job. The main cat understudy, Montie, a black-and-white male, has been fired for being, well, difficult. He didn’t follow stage directions.

headline: Single Parents: Unsupported, and Feeling the Blame
text: Sometimes research results are politically incorrect, or even offensive for some of us, and still worth talking about.

headline: Ronald Dworkin’s ‘Religious Atheism’
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Many Strands Make Up One Woman
text: A modernizing democrat or a “kleptocrat in a Hermès scarf”? Pakistan’s “daughter of destiny” (the title of her autobiography) or puppet of the West? That Benazir Bhutto, a two-time prime minister of Pakistan educated at Harvard and Oxford, contained not merely multitudes but multitudes of contradictions, would seem to be the premise of the uneven one-woman show “Shaheed: The Dream and Death of Benazir Bhutto,” written and performed by Anna Khaja at the Culture Project.

headline: Yankees Say Jeter May Not Be Ready for Opener
text: TAMPA, Fla. — It’s Derek Jeter, so people automatically assume he will exceed normal standards. But it is possible that not even Jeter will be able to make the Yankees’ opening day lineup less than sixth months after fracturing his left ankle and needing surgery to repair it.

headline: Chip Kelly Could Have Been a Giant
text: PHOENIX — Keep this in mind when the Giants and Eagles play: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin tried to hire new Eagles Coach Chip Kelly as a quality control coach not that long ago and was turned down. Kelly was the offensive coordinator at the University of New Hampshire, early in his meteoric rise, when the Giants came calling in 2006.

headline: NIMBY Deficit Hawks
text: Jerry Moran often repeated the Republican party’s magical incantation when he was running for senator from Kansas in 2010: “We don’t have a revenue problem – we have a spending problem.” After he was elected, he continued the drumbeat, and supported using the debt ceiling as a threat to enact more budget cuts. He opposed the 2011 budget deal that led to the sequester, not because he was against the sequester but because it didn’t cut spending enough.

headline: Iran’s Support Emboldens Assad, Envoy Says
text: WASHINGTON — Iran is stepping up its military assistance to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, and the supplies have strengthened his belief that he can prevail in his struggle with the opposition, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

headline: Bon Jovi Bests Bowie on Album Chart
text: With the top of the Billboard album chart this week looking like a bit of a flashback to 1986, Bon Jovi is No. 1 and David Bowie has landed at No. 2 with his first new album in a decade.

headline: Hands, Disfigured in Fire, Are Now Essential to Livelihood
text: On a recent Saturday, Sandy Yu, protected by a red parka, was one of the few sidewalk vendors who showed up along a normally jammed Fifth Avenue commercial strip in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Stimulus Derangement Syndrome
text: Miles Kimball goes after John Taylor’s latest, and in the process reminds us of an earlier Taylor episode, in which JT argued that low interest rates are actually contractionary — a conclusion he reached by confusing the Fed’s setting of an interest rate target, which is achieved by buying bonds, with a rent-control-type price ceiling enforced by simply banning above-target transactions. It was an amazing thing for a highly credentialed macroeconomist to say. But it wasn’t unique; just offhand I can think of multiple comparable flubs ever since we began monetary and fiscal stimulus to fight the Great Recession.

headline: Test Run: Rdio vs. Spotify for Streaming Music
text: Talking about Spotify versus Rdio, two competing music streaming services, can be like arguing with someone in a bar over two baseball teams: People passionately love one or the other and will happily share their disdain for the rival. But Spotify often wins with its might and size, touting millions more users than Rdio.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Amazon-C.I.A. Deal, and Googling for GIFs
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Diverging Fortunes for Men and Women
text: In recent decades, men have lost ground to women in educational attainment, cutting into the real income of most males as prospects for those without a college education have worsened.

headline: ‘Tonight,’ With New Host, Set to Reclaim Its New York Roots
text: NBC has settled on two new stars for “The Tonight Show”: Jimmy Fallon and New York City.

headline: Iraq: 10 Years and Counting
text: Americans try to understand the war as Iraqis live with its consequences.

headline: A Simpler Way to Complain About Student Loan Collections
text: Borrowers who run into trouble with their federal student loans should have an easier time filing complaints about private collection agencies that work under contract to the government, a new report says.

headline: The Nuggets Have a Streak of Their Own
text: With all eyes cast squarely upon the Miami Heat’s 23-game win streak, the Denver Nuggets have quietly put together a timely blitz of their own.

headline: Blending Art and Technology
text: Though other museums have experimented with interactive technology, the extent of a program at the Cleveland Museum of Art is unprecedented.

headline: Key Democrat Chides President and Senators on Pace of Immigration Bill
text: 6:46 p.m. | Updated As the Senate Judiciary Committee held its second hearing this week on overhauling the nation’s immigration laws, the committee’s chairman issued a frustrated plea for speeding up the overall pace of producing actual legislation.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Rationalizing Iraq
text: Via Conor Friedersdorf at The Atlantic

headline: Appeal Denied, Ex-Consultant Is Off to Jail
text: For 17 months, John F. Haggerty Jr., a former Republican political consultant, fought his conviction on charges of stealing campaign money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Michelle Shocked Says Comments on Gay Marriage Were Misunderstood
text: At least ten clubs and music halls have canceled concerts by Michelle Shocked since she went on an anti-gay tirade during a show in San Francisco on Sunday night.

headline: Cyprus Shows How Not to Do a Bailout
text: Cyprus can’t really be about Cyprus, can it? After all, the banking sector in that country pales in comparison to things like the London Whale trade and the amount of capital the big banks have to raise to meet Basel III.

headline: Best-Selling Russian Writer Turns From Crime to History
text: MOSCOW — Grigory Chkhartishvili, the best-selling Russian writer known for his detective novels set in imperial Russia (written under the name Boris Akunin), and for his foray into opposition politics directed against Vladimir V. Putin announced that from now on he would devote himself to writing a multivolume history of Russia.

headline: Hawk Cam Returns for Third Season
text: Updated, 4:58 p.m.,Thursday | The Hawk Cam, which has chronicled the lives of red-tailed hawks in Washington Square Park since 2011, has returned for a third season. The stars of the reality raptor drama, believed to be last year’s couple, Rosie and Bobby, are currently warming three eggs on a nest situated on the 12th-floor window ledge of New York University’s president, John Sexton.

headline: A Litany of Betrayals, Petty Yet Terrifying
text: The feminist Russian punk band Pussy Riot, some of its members recently imprisoned, stands for many things, notably opposition to the policies of Vladimir Putin. One of its best-known songs contains the line “Virgin birth-giver of God, drive away Putin!” Another is titled, depending on the translation, “Putin Is Wetting Himself.”

headline: Devils Enjoying Surge in Attendance
text: The Devils have won only three of their last 10 games, but they are on a more successful run at the box office. Including Wednesday night’s game against the Rangers at the Prudential Center in Newark, the Devils have sold out 14 of their last 16 home games this season and 25 of the last 27 games stretching back to last season’s playoffs.

headline: She Can’t Be Caged
text: Talk about revolving-door justice. On Monday, Lindsay Lohan struck a deal to spend 90 days in rehab instead of jail, after pleading no contest to reckless driving in a car crash last year along the Pacific Coast Highway. Twitter users were quick to judge.

headline: Indian Motorcycles Revs Up a New App
text: Can you sell a nostalgic brand using a high-tech phone?

headline: New Reasons to Change Light Bulbs
text: People sometimes have trouble making small sacrifices now that will reward them handsomely later. How often do we ignore the advice to make a few diet and exercise changes to live a longer, healthier life? Or to put some money aside to grow into a nest egg? Intellectually, we get it — but instant gratification is a powerful force.

headline: If You Like Billie Holiday, Try Madeleine Peyroux
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Intertrust Sues Apple, Charging Patent Violations
text: Intertrust, a company that nabbed a huge settlement over patents in a lawsuit with Microsoft nearly a decade ago, has turned its focus to Apple, suing the technology giant on Wednesday and charging infringements of its security and content protection patents.

headline: Site Where Man Was Pulled From the Mud
text: A diagram of the site in New York City where a worker was trapped in mud for four hours.

headline: Monetary Policy Statement From the Federal Reserve
text: Following is the text of the Federal Reserve’s statement on Wednesday announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent:

headline: 71 Years in New York City Is Enough for Elaine Stritch
text: Elaine Stritch is leaving the building.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu Meet in Israel
text: President Barack Obama held a joint press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday in Israel.

headline: The Prolific Willy Rizzo
text: FASHION WAS A CHALLENGING SUBJECT for a photojournalist like Willy Rizzo. He was already well established and living in Paris in the 1950s, his subjects having included politicians, playboys and a pontiff, when Alexander Liberman, then the art director of Vogue, asked him to shoot for the magazine.

headline: Peru, Chile and the War of the Pacific
text: In many parts of the world, soccer equals history. Not a fan? Simply listening to the 40,000 fans at Estadio Nacional in Lima amplify the Peruvian national anthem blaring through the speakers before Friday night’s South American World Cup qualifier with Chile might change things.

headline: The Salary Bracket: This Is One Harvard Wins
text: Breaking down the N.C.A.A. tournament by alumni salaries, Harvard is the top seed.

headline: Profit Down 31%, FedEx Cuts Outlook
text: Express shipping seems much less urgent these days.

headline: Emphasizing Safety, N.F.L. Passes Rule on Helmet Hits
text: PHOENIX — Tom Coughlin has pulled players aside during games to remind them not to lower their heads when they strike a blow.

headline: Scouting Report
text: Collaboration

headline: Flexibility and Moxie Can Save West Side
text: New York is at a crossroads. After half a century a fleeting opportunity has finally arrived to address the disaster of Penn Station, the nation’s busiest and most appalling transit hub, and to reimagine a new West Side for Midtown Manhattan that could be a center for development and innovation.

headline: Photo Replay: March 20
text: A view of the day in sports, including the women’s European wrestling championships.

headline: Mad for Museums in China
text: In China, museums — big, small, government-backed, privately bankrolled — are opening like mad. In 2011 alone, some 390 new ones appeared. And the numbers are holding.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Finance Government and Soften Spending Cuts
text: Read an updated version of this post.

headline: Travel Essentials | Brussels
text: The short list on where to eat, sleep and view art in Belgium’s capital.

headline: Art Market | Big in Belgium
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Kreider Gets Another Chance at Sticking with Rangers
text: Chris Kreider, the Rangers’ rookie forward, will get a third try at sticking with the team this season after being recalled from the American Hockey League Wednesday. Kreider scored six goals in eight games for Connecticut, the Rangers’ A.H.L. affiliate, since his latest demotion on Feb. 28.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: March 21
text: Fashion trend: transparent bags; Frame Denim’s skinny jeans; a wardrobe staple acquires some fresh looks; and Candela Turco’s Pasionae Murano glass rings.

headline: In City Hall, a One-Man Show That Ran for Three Terms
text: The man hated lawyers. He wiped out political corruption (Tammany Hall, anyway). He was a Republican who bonded with Franklin D. Roosevelt. On his first day at City Hall he cut his own salary in half. During a newspaper strike he read the comics on WNYC Radio.

headline: Better Asteroid Detection Is Needed, Experts Say
text: Making a case for the need to detect asteroids before they hit Earth, a former astronaut said Wednesday that the number of casualties would have been enormous had the space rock that exploded in Russia last month blown apart directly over New York City instead.

headline: Where’s Voyager 1? That Depends.
text: For about three hours on Wednesday, Voyager 1 had left the solar system — before a rewritten news release headline pulled it back in.

headline: Stepping Back Into a Jazzy Tap-Dance Cabaret
text: This week the American Tap Dance Foundation is presenting two productions, one recreating tap’s past, one exhibiting tap’s present. “Rhythm Is Our Business,” the backward-looking show, opened at the Theater at the 14th Street Y on Tuesday with a video montage of great moments in tap from the 1930s through the 1950s that was oddly silent and so dimly projected you could barely see it. The live performances that followed were much more vivid, though a little faint too.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Syria, North Korea and Greece.

headline: Camouflage on the Fall 2013 Runways
text: How camo can you go?

headline: Canyons, Inspiring to the Eye, Capture the Ear, Too
text: The visionary French composer Olivier Messiaen and the citizens of Utah had a mutual appreciation. Messiaen, inspired to write his glittering “Des Canyons aux Étoiles” (“From the Canyons to the Stars”) after visiting the state’s parks in 1972, declared southern Utah the most mystical landscape he had ever seen. In gratitude, a mountain was renamed in his honor.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: LED Light Bulbs
text: LED bulbs are a gigantic improvement over incandescent bulbs and compact fluorescents. David Pogue tries out LED bulbs and kits from six manufacturers.

headline: A Disguise for When You Want to Be Seen
text: No one saw it coming. The men’s fashion collection that Dries Van Noten showed for spring was a cavalcade of camouflage.

headline: Palestinian Protesters Set Up Camp in West Bank
text: AL-AZARIYA, West Bank — It was hardly the most visible place to stage an anti-Obama protest, on a stony hillside on the edge of this West Bank town just east of Jerusalem. But for the Palestinians, it was highly symbolic.

headline: Sensuously Rippling Bodies, All There to Serve the Rhythm
text: The performers of DanceBrazil, as seen this week at the Joyce Theater, exist in a ravishing, hard-working paradise. They’re barefoot; their attire (T-shirts, loose trousers, light dresses or skirts) has no hint of luxury. What matters here above all is the gorgeously full physicality of movement, allied to music. While spines continually plunge beneath the level of the waist, legs kick explosively above it or maintain powerful extensions like searchlights.

headline: The Man of the Hour, or Four
text: After an enervating evening that was about to hit the four-hour mark and was driving some members of the audience to the exits, Madonna came on stage Saturday at the 24th Glaad Media Awards and reminded people exactly why she’s a superstar.

headline: Republican Council Members Endorse Lhota
text: All four Republican members of the City Council made an endorsement in the New York mayoral race on Wednesday, pledging their support to Joseph J. Lhota, a former deputy in the Giuliani administration and Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman.

headline: Celebrating Philip Roth at 80
text: Mr. Roth’s native Newark celebrated his birthday with a daylong academic conference, a new photo exhibition, a bus tour and a party at the Newark Museum.

headline: Country’s Straight-Talk Feminists
text: Country music fearmongers in the mid-2000s had their choice of invading bêtes noires. From one direction Taylor Swift arrived, a pop-friendly ingénue with sparkling songs and a killer instinct. From another, Miranda Lambert was stomping in, full of vitriol and skepticism, an alpha answering to no beta.

headline: Goodbye, Newark, the Place Roth Never Left
text: NEWARK — Since he announced his retirement from writing, Philip Roth has been in an unusually good mood. On Tuesday he celebrated his 80th birthday here — a city where he no longer lives but never entirely left — by juking into a reception space at the Newark Museum behind marching-band drummers from Weequahic High School, his alma mater. There Mr. Roth, normally the most private of authors, was greeted with applause from 250 friends, relatives and invited guests, including members of the Philip Roth Society, scholars who specialize in his work.

headline: Spring North American Championships
text: ST. LOUIS — At the Spring North American Championships here the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by Martin Fleisher of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J. They finished just over one board ahead of JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif., and Jeff Meckstroth of Clearwater Beach, Fla. Third were John Kranyak of Las Vegas and Vincent Demuy of Laval, Quebec.

headline: Thorny Questions for Justices in Raisin Case
text: WASHINGTON — The current Supreme Court sometimes seems to relish a procedural puzzle.

headline: A Feminist Illustrator Gets Her Due
text: Barbara Nessim is honored with a London retrospective.

headline: At the Table, a Touch of Couture
text: In 2009, the fashion label Christian Lacroix suspended its couture and women’s ready-to-wear activities and lost 90 percent of its staff, including Mr. Lacroix. But under Sacha Walckhoff, Lacroix’s longtime creative director, the company continues to design vibrant, pattern-clashing items. Next month in the United States, it will introduce a 50-piece collection of china in four motifs. The tableware, made by Vista Alegre in Portugal, features polychromatic butterflies, roughly painted black stripes, a floral mosaic and a 19th-century engraving of the ancient Roman arena in Arles. The bold consumer is encouraged to combine any or all of these patterns.

headline: Photography’s New Prominence
text: Large numbers of exhibitions are being organized by museum photography departments across the country at a time when a new crop of photography curators have taken the helm at major museums.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of Scandinavian Design
text: Antik, which sold Scandinavian antiques in TriBeCa until May, has re-emerged in Greenwich Village as Hostler Burrows. When the shop opened in the late ’90s, “people knew Hans Wegner, Georg Jensen, Jens Risom — three Danish designers,” said Kim Hostler, an owner with Juliet Burrows. The women have since introduced other 20th-century Scandinavians. Shown at top, the work of five Swedish designers: 1940s blue-gray chairs by Otto Schulz ($14,000 a pair), 1950s ivory chairs by Kerstin Horlin-Holmqvist ($12,500 a pair) and a table by Axel Einar Hjorth ($16,000). Above, 1950s porcelain vases by Berndt Friberg (from $2,200 each) and a 1939 rug by Sigvard Bernadotte ($28,000): (212) 343-0471, hostlerburrows.com.

headline: Sculpture From the Storm
text: Most of the thousands of tree limbs and stumps left by Hurricane Sandy were sent to composting facilities and trash heaps. But some homeowners have embraced the wreckage by turning their downed trees into sculpture. Gregg Klewicki, a 45-year-old woodcarver in Huntington, N.Y., began his craft when he was 20. His first project, he said, was a giant nose that he placed on his front lawn. Within a few weeks, someone knocked on his door willing to pay $300 for it, so he started carving on the weekends. A few years later, Mr. Klewicki had enough commissions to quit his day job driving a beer truck. Last week, he laid down his chain saw long enough to talk to a reporter.

headline: Sales at Ann Gish, Tom Dixon and Others
text: Bed and tabletop linens are up to 80 percent off at Ann Gish Thursday to Sunday (a queen-size Jack Stripe silk duvet cover by Ann Gish, shown, originally $1,165, is $350); 4 West 20th Street, (212) 727-2122, anngish.com.

headline: Some Plants Deserve a Toast
text: Amy Stewart has a way of making gardening seem exciting, even a little dangerous, as she did with “Wicked Plants,” her best-selling book about poisonous and invasive vegetation. In “The Drunken Botanist” (Algonquin, $19.95), her latest, Ms. Stewart is once again out to show the sexier side of the garden, this time linking plants to alcoholic spirits.

headline: Bavarian Castle, Moat Included
text: A 12th-century castle in Kipfenberg, Germany, is on the market for $7.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
text: A 12th-CENTURY BAVARIAN CASTLE SURROUNDED BY A MOAT AND 27 ACRES

headline: Cubes and Spheres at Work
text: The British designer Faye Toogood makes one-of-a kind, expressively minimal furniture. But Ms. Toogood, a former editor at The World of Interiors magazine, wanted to reach a broader audience and turned to batch production, making 10 to 100 pieces of a design at a time. Her Batch line was introduced in London last year and is now available in the United States at Matter, in SoHo. The collection includes the Element table, right, which has a tinted glass top that rests on a cube, sphere and cylinder, all made of solid ash. “I have fabricated the table in many different materials before,” she said. “By simply changing the materials and the volume and void of the piece, it has seen many incarnations.” This one is 39 inches square, 8 inches tall and $5,360. Information: (212) 343-2600 or mattermatters.com.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
text: WASHINGTON, D.C.

headline: Properties for $800,000
text: A four-bedroom co-op in Washington, D.C., a Gothic revival in Omaha, Neb., and a parlor floor condo in an 1894 townhouse in Savannah, Ga.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I want my home to stand out from the crowd. Which paint colors will make it look unique, but still clean and crisp?

headline: Shopping for Paperweights
text: Andrew Zobler, the founder and chief executive of the Sydell Group, has amassed 100 or so paperweights since he was a boy.

headline: Paperweights
text: SOME 8-YEAR-OLD BOYS collect Legos or baseball cards, but when Andrew Zobler was that age, he collected paperweights. It wasn’t exactly his decision.

headline: The Particular Puzzles of Being a Small Museum
text: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, 13 people gathered outside the Merchant’s House Museum on East Fourth Street in Manhattan. Each had paid $15 for a guided tour of the surrounding NoHo neighborhood, once a tony section of the city. Their guide: an expert from the museum.

headline: Technology That Serves to Enhance, Not Distract
text: CLEVELAND

headline: Progress Stalls in California on Earthquake Warnings
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Scientists at the Caltech Seismology Laboratory were at their computers last week when a warning popped up on the screen: “Earthquake, earthquake!” The initial magnitude of the quake, 100 miles away, was 5.2, the alert said, and a countdown clock warned that mild shaking would reach here in 40 seconds.

headline: Leader Unafraid to Venture Outside of the Lines
text: THINK of the Society of Illustrators and the image likely to spring to mind is that of a quaint, august institution whose heyday coincided with that of The Saturday Evening Post. But this wasn’t the picture the society presented one recent winter evening, when every floor of its building on East 63rd Street fairly blazed with activity.

headline: Enshrining Art With a Permanent, and Personal, Home
text: RIVALING earlier American moguls who built elaborate edifices to house their art collections, magnates of the 21st century are pouring their fortunes into founding their own ambitious museums.

headline: Examining Sargent’s Shift From Oil to Watercolors
text: BY the time John Singer Sargent reached his mid-40s at the beginning of the 20th century, he had long been saluted as the best society portrait painter of the Gilded Age. But he was having a midlife career crisis.

headline: Renovation, Italian Style
text: Elisabetta Bruscolini and Giancarlo Astrologo are passionate collectors of friends, objects and, yes, homes.

headline: Rothko’s Journey to His Fields of Color, in Full View
text: FOR many art lovers, Mark Rothko’s layered bands of misty color represent the apex of 20th-century abstraction. Here was an artist who painstakingly distilled the achievements of the painters who came before him and forever changed how we see the horizon line.

headline: A Tribute for Turning Light Into Art
