text: TAMPA, Fla. — One day after the Yankees said they were shutting down shortstop Derek Jeter from playing in any more major league spring training games, he announced Friday that nobody should rule out anything.

headline: What Are You Doing for World Water Day?
text: When you open your tap today and, as if by miracle (and thanks to a good deal of engineering), a stream of clean and drinkable water starts flowing, think of the millions of people for whom such basic access is not so simple.

headline: Gibraltar Seeks to Woo Brazilian Hedge Funds and Private Equity
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Tiny Gibraltar is trying to cash in on Brazil’s rising wealth.

headline: “Bluebird Wine”
text: From “Old Yellow Moon”

headline: Among the Vines in Chile, Villas and Views
text: From my horse-top perch, I could view seemingly endless rows of green vines, stretching out across a wide valley floor. To the west, sharp mountains rose behind a glassy emerald lake reflecting slow-moving clouds; a family of herons roosted by the water. Other than the winemaker who rode next to me, a few workers, hundreds of cattle, those herons and millions of precious grapes, I was alone on this 11,000-acre Chilean estate.

headline: Winter Is Prime in Puglia
text: Disappointment swept across the table. Daniela, our waitress, with tight jeans and dyed pink hair, hovered over our table, shaking her head. “I trying to warn you,” she scolded. There were dozens of bowls of antipasto unfinished, many of them untouched. She just shook her head some more. “I leaving and you eating. Now.” With a nod that smacked of finality, she turned and sashayed back to the kitchen.

headline: Miami, My Way
text: We stood on the Everglades boardwalk, an hour south of Miami Beach, squinting in the sun, looking like fools. He was as white as milk and as gangly as Napoleon Dynamite, with a gaudy beach towel we’d bought at a Woolworth’s tied around his neck. I was dressed head-to-toe in discount specials: a bright orange cover-up and plastic sandals three sizes too big. As we stood in our absurd get-ups, marring the blue-skied Florida backdrop, he told me I looked like a Dreamsicle.

headline: Ready to Fight Gay Marriage at Court Door
text: WASHINGTON — As gay couples fight for the right to wed, a little-known but determined force is working to stop them: Brian S. Brown, a 39-year-old father of eight who has raised millions of dollars from religious conservatives — especially his fellow Roman Catholics — to become the nation’s leading opponent of same-sex marriage.

headline: Judges’ Spat Strikes a Chord Among Deal Makers
text: Deal makers delivered a verdict on snarky judges at the annual M.&A. jamboree in New Orleans this week. The spectacle of Delaware jurists bashing the clever bromides and superfluous legal rulings of colleagues elicited hoots of delight from the assembled lawyers and bankers. The criticism is on target. To avoid any confusion, courts should stick to the facts and the law.

headline: Hofstra Fires Basketball Coach
text: After a 7-25 season and a litany of player arrests, Hofstra fired its men’s basketball coach, Mo Cassara, on Friday morning after three seasons.

headline: In Defense of Palestinians
text: Back when Republicans senators and conservative commentators were consumed with trying to bury Chuck Hagel’s nomination as defense secretary, one of their patently false lines of attack was that he was anti-Israel.

headline: New Leader Taps Mexican Discontent to Press Agenda of Change
text: MEXICO CITY — Few topics get Mexicans more worked up than their country’s cellphone service, especially that provided by the dominant carrier, Telcel.

headline: A Mad Romance
text: For the shoe designer Christian Louboutin, the cinema of India has always been a magical, otherworldly, Technicolor fantasy. He heads to the Marrakesh film festival to meet his favorite stars of the screen.

headline: Well Before Summer, Hamptons Luxury Real Estate Is Scorching
text: The emerald hedgerows that are a natural euphemism for Hamptons exclusivity (out here, good hedges, not good fences, make for felicitous neighbors) are hanging tight.

headline: Immigration Talks Hit Snag Over Business and Labor Concerns
text: 9:01 p.m. | Updated On Friday evening, the group of eight senators who are working to produce bipartisan immigration legislation and racing to work out a final dispute between the business and labor communities before Congress left for a two-week recess hit yet another obstacle, when the four Republican senators in the group spurned what a major union described as a another attempt at compromise.

headline: Shalom, Mr. President: Obama Tries to Charm Israelis With Hebrew
text: JERUSALEM — As one Israeli columnist put it, he had them at “Shalom.”

headline: John Mayer to Tour This Summer
text: John Mayer announced on Friday he will mount a major concert tour this summer, his first in three years. The tour comes after a lengthy period of surgery and resting his voice to repair damage to his vocal cords.

headline: Wanted: Hot- and Cold-Running Quiet
text: It was the street noise that made Crystal Wei want to leave her shared apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where she paid a rent of around $1,100 a month. A bus stop was nearby, as was a rowdy bar. Ms. Wei made an uneasy truce with the racket, but her mother, when she visited, couldn’t sleep.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Strange and Thrilling Stories
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, J. Robert Lennon admires Jamie Quatro’s collection of stories, “I Want to Show You More,” calling it “an obsessive first collection that feels like a fifth or sixth.” Mr. Lennon writes:

headline: However Justices Rule, Issues Remain
text: If the Supreme Court strikes down the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman, same-sex couples across the country will undoubtedly gain access to a broad range of federal benefits.

headline: Another Day of Madness
text: The second day of the Round of 64 featured 16 more games on Friday, with many more upsets.

headline: Does a No. 1 Seed’s Margin of Victory Mean Anything for Its N.C.A.A. Title Hopes?
text: Southern almost pulled off the one upset that hasn’t happened at the N.C.A.A. tournament. And although No. 1-seeded Gonzaga escaped the first loss to a No. 16 when it pulled away from the Jaguars at the end of its 64-58 win on Thursday, it is easy to question whether its close call could have implications in the long term.

headline: Cruz, Patriots and Seahawks: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Digitally Aided Education, Using the Students’ Own Electronic Gear
text: Educators and policy makers continue to debate whether computers are a good teaching tool. But a growing number of schools are adopting a new, even more controversial approach: asking students to bring their own smartphones, tablets, laptops and even their video game players to class.

headline: Is Your Kitchen a Health Hazard?
text: OUR kitchens may be killing us — slowly. Not so much with radon or gas leaks, but with kindness and proximity.

headline: The Financial Effects of a Court Ruling Recognizing Gay Marriage
text: This week’s Your Money column tries to envision how life may change for same-sex couples if the federal law that bans gay marriage is struck down.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 22
text: Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

headline: PPR to Show Breton Roots With Rebranding as Kering
text: PARIS — PPR is on the way out. The Paris luxury group, whose stable of brands includes Gucci, Balenciaga and Puma, said on Friday that it was changing its name to Kering.

headline: Rebel Leader in Congo Is Flown to The Hague
text: NAIVASHA, Kenya — Bosco Ntaganda, a rebel commander accused of massacring civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was flown out of Rwanda on Friday bound for the International Criminal Court at The Hague, where he faces 10 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

headline: Paris Auction Goes Forward Despite Heritage Claims
text: Sotheby’s in Paris went forward today with a two-day sale of pre-Columbian artifacts despite claims by four Latin American nations that many of the 313 items had been illegally exported.

headline: Upscale, Downsized
text: With prices of roughly $30,000 to $50,000, a smaller class of luxury cars offers a less-is-more display of status.

headline: Taking It to the Limit
text: The new documentary “People’s Park“ surveys the range of human activity in a bustling urban park in Chengdu, China. People stroll, snack, socialize, practice calligraphy and engage in a wide variety of song and dance, from Chinese opera to pulsing disco. Some ignore the camera; others play to it. The filmmakers, Libbie Dina Cohn and J. P. Sniadecki, are never seen, but their presence is felt, not least because of how they chose to portray the park’s myriad denizens and activities: as a literal panorama of leisure and revelry, filmed in one long tracking shot.

headline: Nets Clinch, and Owner Wants You to Know
text: Upon seeing his team clinch its first playoff berth in six years, Mikhail D. Prokhorov celebrated with the verbal equivalent of a Champagne shower.

headline: Inside ‘The Place Beyond the Pines’
text: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the director Derek Cianfrance narrates his film’s opening sequence.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Brian K. Vaughan Talks About ‘The Private Eye’
text: New at No. 3 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is “Season One: Avengers,” a look back at the earliest days of Marvel’s premiere superhero team. The “Season One” books are conceived as a way of introducing new readers to Marvel’s biggest heroes without being weighed down by the decades of sometimes-convoluted history can sometimes be amassed.

headline: Myth Making on Motorcycles
text: “I never felt more like Janet Leigh in my life,” Ryan Gosling said with his best straight face.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures for March 22
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including the return of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to Brooklyn.

headline: A ‘Mary Tyler Moore Show’ Reunion, Via Cleveland
text: The cable channel TV Land lives on nostalgia for classic television and that will certainly reach a peak this summer in an episode of the sitcom, “Hot in Cleveland.” The show will reunite all of the major female stars from one of television’s most beloved comedies, “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”

headline: Waiting for War, and Working to Fit In
text: And here we had all been getting on so well.

headline: When ‘What Do You Do?’ Is Taboo
text: TALKING TO UNEMPLOYED friends and colleagues requires a certain delicacy. The question “How was your day?,” when leveled with what is perceived as an undue amount of concern, can cause steam to emerge from ears. Robert Reich, the secretary of labor under President Clinton, said, “I don’t ask ‘What are you doing with yourself these days?’ or ‘How’s the job search coming?’ unless it’s a good friend. I wait for him to bring it up. Being jobless is distressing enough without people asking about it.”

headline: How About a Little Luxury?
text: From tailfinned Cadillacs of the 1950s to three-ton S.U.V.’s at the turn of the century, luxury vehicles have always pushed the limits of size and mass.

headline: Buick Stakes a Claim in Munchkinland
text: WARREN, N.H. — Buick’s image is so ingrained in the national consciousness that the name has become shorthand for an American road barge with ample proportions. That moose, someone may say, “is as big as a Buick.”

headline: From the Andrews Sisters to Hip-Hop
text: AT 23 WILLY MOON is a throwback artist in the most contemporary mode, with an ear for melding early rock sounds with synthy production and hip-hop beats. Signed to a major label before he ever played a gig, Mr. Moon was noticed by Jack White, who released his single “Railroad Track” and took him on tour in England last year. His debut album, “Here’s Willy Moon,” 12 propulsive songs that total less than 29 minutes, will be out April 2 on Cherrytree/Island; thanks to its use in an iPod commercial his single “Yeah Yeah,” which borrowed a Wu-Tang Clan sample, has already made the charts.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: “The Tonight Show” is expected to move back to New York City, and surging demand for homes has left some areas of the country with a shortage of inventory.

headline: Short Season for a Rare Fish
text: Fishermen in Cagnes-Sur-Mer, in southeastern France, collect young fish in their nets on Thursday during the short poutine fishing season. Poutine, a type of baby sardines, are found between Antibes and Menton on the French Riviera for only about 45 days each year at the end of winter. Their price at market reflects their rarity: They will fetch about 30 euros, or $40, per kilogram.

headline: JPMorgan Board Confirms Dual Role for Dimon
text: JPMorgan Chase’s board said on Friday that it was standing behind Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chairman and chief executive, in the face of calls from some investors that the two jobs be split.

headline: A Voice That Leaps Between Genres
text: KINGSTON, N.Y. — Rebecca Martin and Larry Grenadier live in a house on a hill in this weathered Hudson Valley city, some 90 miles upriver from Manhattan. At a glance, their sturdy Victorian doesn’t seem like the obvious hub of a small-batch initiative to redraw contemporary jazz singing. During one recent visit, there was snow on the ground and soup on the stove, and their 7-year-old son, Charlie, was home from school.

headline: Shuffleboard? Oh, Maybe Let’s Get High Instead
text: For Cher Neufer, a 65-year-old retired teacher, socializing with friends (all in their 60s) means using marijuana. Once a week they get together to play Texas Hold ’Em poker “and pass around a doobie,” Ms. Neufer said.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 22, 2013
text: The New York Times critics on "Admission," "Olympus Has Fallen" and "Gimme the Loot."

headline: The Extreme (Existential) Makeover
text: AMONG the many unexpected downsides of increased longevity (running through one’s retirement money; more years in an assisted-living facility; entertaining the possibility that we ourselves may suffer the consequences of global warming, even though we thought we were just “passing the problem on to our children”), one can now include the prospect of more time to sit on a park bench brooding about how we could have done it differently — been better than ourselves.

headline: The Vehicular Side of the Vatican
text: As the newly installed pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis will often be seen greeting the world from the back of a rather peculiar vehicle. It’s taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one we’ve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

headline: At 102, Margaret Dunning Looks Ahead to Next Concours
text: At 102, Margaret Dunning could be living a genteel, quiet life. Instead, Ms. Dunning, who owns a 1930 Packard 740, has become a doyenne of the show-car circuit and is often away from home.

headline: Vatican City 1
text: It’s taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one we’ve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 22
text: More photographs.

headline: The Best Thing I Learned At SXSW Was From the Unabomber
text: Now that I’m back and mostly recovered from South by Southwest, my friends, editors and fellow reporters keep asking me about the most interesting thing I saw in Austin.

headline: Kyle Dake Is Going for Four
text: The Cornell senior Kyle Dake is looking to make wrestling history this weekend. If he wins the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A tournament in Des Moines, Iowa, he will be the only collegiate wrestler to have won four titles in four different weight classes.

headline: Big Ticket | Baronial Show House Sold for $22.85 Million
text: A magisterial limestone town house on one of the Upper East Side’s most moneyed blocks sold for $22.85 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Finding Their Next Facebook
text: As you sit across from Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, it is easy to lose track of whom exactly you’re talking to. Tall, blue-eyed and each built as broad-shouldered as a fridge, the twins are identical right down to their entrees: a pair of lobster rolls, with potato chips. Each has an espresso; neither eats the biscotti it comes with. And while the restaurant around them is spinning with chatter on this February night, the twins are each laser focused on getting their message across.

headline: Obama Withdraws Judicial Nomination After Second G.O.P. Filibuster
text: President Obama has withdrawn the nomination of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to serve on an important federal appeals court in Washington, blaming Republicans for blocking her confirmation twice.

headline: Scheduling Conflict Forces Ravens to Open on Road
text: The Baltimore Ravens, the defending Super Bowl champions, will open the season on the road because the N.F.L. and Major League Baseball could not work out a scheduling conflict with the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Heartbreaking News, Heavenly Exhortations and Lonely Sentiments
text: Chvrches

headline: A Sitcom That Some Find, Well, Alien
text: In her 30-year acting career Jami Gertz has never heard a negative peep from her parents about her projects. “It could go straight to video,” she said, “and my father will be like, ‘You were the best thing in it.’ ”

headline: Movie Review | 'Admission'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Admission."

headline: A Family’s Secrets Bared, on Camera
text: It took a powerful, disturbing dream from which she awoke sobbing to convince Robin Charboneau, an Oglala Sioux and member of North Dakota’s Spirit Lake tribe, that “I needed to open my mouth, and I needed to speak.” So she let the documentary filmmaker David Sutherland follow her for more than three years as she struggled to raise her family as a single mother while confronting her alcoholism and the scars of being sexually abused as a child.

headline: Another Look at Natural Gas
text: After my column on Wednesday about how the nation’s natural gas boom is helping reduce emissions of heat-trapping carbon, I received a bunch of e-mail arguing that gas obtained by hydraulic fracturing could, on the contrary, worsen climate change.

headline: Visors Should Be Mandatory, Says Player Who Lost an Eye
text: For a true advocate for mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

headline: Movie Review | 'Olympus Has Fallen'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Olympus Has Fallen.”

headline: BlackBerry Z10 Goes on Sale in U.S.
text: An after-midnight sale at a 24-hour Best Buy store in New York’s Union Square was the site of the American debut of the BlackBerry Z10 smartphone on Friday.

headline: Big as a Buick? Not This One
text: The Encore is a bold move from a brand once known for cautious conservatism.

headline: Suddenly, They’re All Gone
text: Caring for the old is just like parenting an infant, only on really bad acid. It’s all there: the head-spinning exhaustion, the fractured brain, the demands and smells. Only this time with the knowledge that it won’t get better.

headline: Dressing Up for a Special Occasion
text: THESE DAYS WE ARE constantly surrounded by sweet baked goods, but once upon a time they were really considered quite special. Daily bread was usually brown and meant for sustenance; only for holidays, Easter in particular, was it rich and extravagant, made with fancy white flour, milk, butter and eggs, and studded with candied fruit.

headline: At The New Republic, Even Firings Enter the Digital Age
text: Just one year after the Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes bought The New Republic, the magazine confirmed it had fired one of its top editors.

headline: Gay Conversion Therapy
text: New Jersey’s Governor Chris Christie is apparently agonizing over whether he should sign a bill that would outlaw so-called “reparative therapy.”

headline: A Forger’s Impressions of Impressionism
text: On a sunny weekday morning in a cafe in Brooklyn the French director Gilles Bourdos is flipping through his laptop’s gallery of international art. There’s a charcoal study of Cézanne card players; Picasso’s inkblot Don Quixote, tilting his lance at the Spanish sun; and a blue-hued, Old World fantasy, bearing the kaleidoscopic hallmarks of Marc Chagall.

headline: A Secret-Agent Premiere for a New Range Rover
text: A conventional news conference would hardly suffice for the debut of the 2014 Range Rover Sport, Land Rover executives thought, so on March 26, the night before the New York auto show opens for two days of press previews, the new S.U.V. is to be revealed in a Hollywood-caliber video.

headline: Plug and Play for Internet Connections
text: Far too often, drivers of older vehicles try to add the services available in new Internet-connected cars by balancing smartphones in their laps. But smartphones — aside from the obvious distraction they present — cannot do things like monitor the car’s location when someone else is using it or send a maintenance reminder based on miles traveled.

headline: Arab Student Explains Why He Heckled Obama in Jerusalem
text: The 24-year-old student from Israel’s Arab minority who interrupted President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he made them in an interview with The Lede on Friday.

headline: Little Support for Idea of Medicare Payments That Vary
text: Medicare should not adjust payments on a broad regional basis to reward hospitals and doctors that spend less to achieve high-quality care, an interim report issued Friday by the Institute of Medicine concluded.

headline: Cuban Dissident Calls to End Embargo
text: Blogger and activist Yoani Sánchez regularly condemns the Cuban regime from her home in Havana. On her first trip abroad in nearly a decade, she also called for an end to the American embargo.

headline: Cultural Capital
text: This issue starts off in America, or at least an idea of America. Brooklyn, N.Y., has, as we all know, become a bastion of handcrafted, locally sourced, small-scale-production everything, from bikes to beer. The irony is that this passion for authenticity, diversity and a longing for realness have now turned what was once just a borough into a global brand, one that is vigorously being exported around the world: France, Russia, the United Arab Emirates. The local has gone global, or in other words, anti-homogenization is itself now being homogenized: In Paris you find food trucks, in Gorky Park a snack kiosk called Williamsburg, there is a Brooklyn Diner in Dubai, and even the native beer, Brooklyn Brewery, is planning an outpost in Stockholm — how local is that? When a value system based on unscalability starts to scale, it may be time to turn to other locales for a sense of uniqueness and locally grown culture.

headline: Ribaldry Before the Code
text: BERT WHEELER and Robert Woolsey made 21 feature films together (and a couple separately) between 1929 and 1937. They were one of the most popular comedy teams of a decade that knew several great ones, and yet today they are almost unknown, except to cinephiles who make a habit of exploring the uncharted overnight territory of the Turner Classic Movies channel.

headline: Bausch & Lomb Plans I.P.O.
text: Bausch & Lomb, the eye-care company primarily owned by Warburg Pincus, filed documents on Friday to go public again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Israel, Myanmar and Cyprus.

headline: This Week’s Movies: March 22
text: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “Admission,” “Olympus Has Fallen” and “Gimme the Loot.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Nigerians React to News of Achebe’s Death
text: LAGOS, Nigeria— The news of the death of Chinua Achebe, the influential Nigerian author renowned for his novel “Things Fall Apart,” reverberated across the country’s cultural and political circles on Friday. “I must say it’s a most painful death for me,” said Odia Ofeimun, a poet and the former president of Association of Nigerian Authors. “Just when we were learning to argue with him, he died.”

headline: Ch-Ch-Ch Changes of David Bowie
text: LONDON — A photograph hangs inconspicuously near the entrance of “David Bowie Is,” a Victoria and Albert Museum exhibition opening on Saturday that has already sold a record number of tickets. It shows the young man who began life as David Jones, seated, in a dark suit and tie, with a leg propped up on his chair, beneath which sits a drum bearing the name of his band, the Kon-rads. One hand grips a saxophone, the other rests delicately against his face, and he looks out at the world with a mesmerizing blend of reserve and come-hither allure.

headline: Israeli Students Reflect on Obama’s Speech
text: President Obama gave a fervent address to students from universities in Israel on Thursday during his first presidential trip to the country. Some of the students shared their views of the speech with The Times.

headline: Yoko Ono Details Why She Posted Lennon’s Bloodied Glasses on Twitter
text: On what would have been her 44th wedding anniversary Wednesday, Yoko Ono said, she walked through a park, remembering how much she and her husband, John Lennon, had laughed and smiled on their wedding day. “Then I felt the emptiness more acutely because of the beautiful memory,” she said.

headline: Bowie on Display
text: A look back at a David Bowie career retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London in 2013.

headline: The Hall, a Player as Important as the Strings
text: The Bach Variations festival, which the New York Philharmonic is presenting through April 6, is built on a question: Should large symphony orchestras still play Bach, now that there are so many ensembles specializing in the historically informed performance of Baroque music? With four conductors from different backgrounds — Alan Gilbert, Andras Schiff, Masaaki Suzuki and Bernard Labadie — the Philharmonic also looks at the question of how. What they failed to address is the where.

headline: Obama in the Mideast: Sampling the Reviews
text: To the Editor:

headline: Comeuppance of a Reprobate, With Hints of Gluck’s Glory to Come
text: Among the 50-odd operas written by Gluck, to say nothing of myriad variants and other hybrid entertainments, only a handful tend to show up on the modern stage. Almost invariably these are the so-called “reform” works of Gluck’s later years, like “Orfeo ed Euridice,” “Alceste” and the two Iphigénie operas, all composed between 1762 and 1779.

headline: Low-Income Students and Elite Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fastidious Percussion With Plenty of Electronics
text: Five pedestals stood in the atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Thursday night: perforated, metallic-looking bases, lighted from within, supporting oval platforms, each large enough to hold one musician surrounded by equipment. It was the architect Uffe Surland Van Tams’s setup for Tyondai Braxton’s “Hive,” billed as “part installation/part band” by the Guggenheim’s Works & Process series and Wordless Music, which presented it.

headline: Coyote Hunting in Utah
text: A $50 bounty to control the coyote population in Utah has hunters excited, environmentalists crying foul and state wildlife administrators stuck somewhere in the middle.

headline: Amid ‘Kill’ Chants, Croatia and Serbia Set Peaceful Example
text: ZAGREB, Croatia — For all the talk of conciliation, for all the pleas for tolerance before the game and for all the statements from players and coaches that the war should take a back seat to the soccer, the crowd at the Maksimir Stadium in Zagreb found it harder to forget and forgive on Friday.

headline: Interview With Cuban Blogger Yoani Sánchez
text: Last Updated, Saturday, 9:10 p.m. Yoani Sánchez stepped out of a coffee shop in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York and quickly pulled a winter hat over her head, covering about three inches of her waist-length brown hair. “This is my disguise,” she said, “It’s not working.”

headline: A Plan to Demolish Libraries to Save Them
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Sameness of Their Differences
text: In the darkness the sound might be crying or laughter. Brightening lights reveal a woman sitting in a pile of feathers. She laughs hysterically. She hyperventilates. One fit subsides, only to be followed by another. Pain seems to rack her body, as if she were giving birth. She screams.

headline: The Sly Coyote Becomes a Bounty Hunters’ Target in Utah
text: OGDEN, Utah — Spencer Glauser, who started hunting as a boy perched on his father’s shoulders, is an unabashed coyote hater. “One’s too many” to have roaming the mountains and encroaching on towns, he said.

headline: No Disciplinary Hearing for Nash; Rangers Waive Halpern
text: Rick Nash, the Rangers’ top scorer, will not face suspension for the leaping elbow he delivered to the back of Tomas Kopecky’s head in a 3-1 loss to the Florida Panthers on Thursday night.

headline: Movie Review | 'Gimme The Loot'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gimme The Loot."

headline: T Spring Travel 2013
text: “America and Beyond” is the theme of the spring travel issue of T. Start off locally with “Modernism Is the Message,” a look at fashion’s new minimalism, as seen through the eyes of the photographer Mario Sorrenti. Then read Simon Romero’s piece on how São Paulo, Brazil’s largest city, is being redefined. There’s also a report on Seoul, the South Korean capital that is becoming the fashionable intrigue of the Far East, and an essay on the exportation of Brooklyn, which has transformed the borough from landmass into global phenomenon. As you hopscotch around the globe, don’t forget to read Alexandra Marshall’s dispatch on the young chefs revolutionizing Paris, Christian Louboutin’s travel diary of his visit to the Marrakesh film festival or “Matches as Memories,” which rounds up the perfect hotel souvenirs that may also be the most anachronistic: matchbooks.See more from the issue >>

headline: Creating ‘Cosmos’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Breaking It Down: Nieminen vs. Nalbandian
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–The match was over.

headline: Tower at O’Hare May Be a Victim of Federal Cuts
text: CHICAGO — Up 14 stories by elevator and two more by stairs, Adonna Prior, an air traffic controller, watched for airplanes emerging as specks in the sky from her perch at the top of O’Hare International Airport’s sleek $40 million north tower.

headline: There’s a Word for a Movie Like This
text: Sometimes a movie is so awful that the word awful is not up to the task of conveying its awfulness. The awful “InAPPropriate Comedy” is such a movie. It is memorably awful. It is stunningly awful. It is so awful that we are fortunate that “awful” has an adverbial use that means “very” or “extremely.” This movie is awfully awful.

headline: Cholera in Haiti
text: To the Editor:

headline: Goes Well With Swagger
text: DURING THIS BRIEF LULL between New York’s two dueling monster art fairs, the recent Armory Show and the forthcoming Frieze, one wonders about the accuracy of the genteel, old-fashioned term, “the art world.”

headline: Major League Baseball v. Biogenesis of America
text: Major League Baseball ton Friday of filed a lawsuit in Florida state court that accuses six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport when they provided various players with performance-enhancing substances.

headline: Obsessed? You’re Not Alone
text: Sharing an Amtrak car recently with four chatty debutantes on their way to a cotillion in Boston, powerless not to eavesdrop, I started cataloging all the vernacular expressions they emphatically overused, transcribing the choicest dialogue to Facebook. (“They’re just jealous of her.” “They’re jealous.” “Because she’s pretty. And has a nice personality.” “She’s pretty.” “So jealous.”) But the short phrase that so got my attention was “I’m obsessed.”

headline: Week in Pictures for March 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

headline: A Weekend in the Country: Britain’s Power Elite at Play
text: Chipping Norton, England — The power centers of British politics and media may reside in London, but their tentacles extend to a tiny working-class market town with rows of glistening stone buildings, 17th-century pubs and a medieval church.

headline: Wealthy Russians Ensnared as Cyprus Crisis Deepens
text: MOSCOW — Two decades ago, Dmitry E. Rybolovlev was a small-town hustler hoping to strike it rich amid the collapse of the Soviet Union. Today, he is one of the wealthiest men in the world, with a penthouse in Monaco, a yacht named “My Anna” worth more than $100 million, and two of the most expensive private residences in the United States.

headline: Words and War: Toni Morrison at West Point
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — As thousands of hungry West Point cadets streamed into the mess hall for their 20-minute lunch break here on Friday, they paused from the rush to the tables to give a rousing group cheer to a guest who has received hundreds of accolades, but perhaps none this thunderous.

headline: Some Sour Music for Horwitz
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jay Horwitz, the Mets’ public relations director got into some hot water with fans this week because of something he posted on his new Twitter account.

headline: Sheepsquatch, Pulling the Wool Over Your Eyes
text: Television’s baser purveyors can’t get enough of the endlessly futile search for bigfoots, extraterrestrials and ghosts, but credit the newest show in the genre, “Monsters and Mysteries in America,” with at least recognizing that those Big Three have received a disproportionate amount of attention. It seems to realize that we haven’t heard nearly enough about the sheepsquatch infestation.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Netflix TV, and Bitcoins for Drugs
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Doctors and a Prescription for Trouble
text: Will the last woman in Atlanta who is not being followed by a camera crew please raise her hand?

headline: Relics of the Bygone (and the Illegal)
text: Someone knocked on the door of the basement apartment on East 115th Street on March 13. A man let him in. A detective watched, and arrested the man who had opened the door.

headline: After Withdrawing, Harvard Star Roots From Afar
text: Plenty of college basketball fans across the country were rooting for Harvard on Thursday night when it upset third-seeded New Mexico, 68-62, in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 64. There was no bigger supporter than Brandyn Curry, who was watching the game with his family in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Quarterfinals
text: ST. LOUIS — The Rockwell Mixed Pairs here on Wednesday evening were won by a married couple, Paul and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas. They finished one-third of a board ahead of Barbara Lehman of Glenview, Ill., and Craig Jacobson of Skokie, Ill. Third were Jenni Carmichael of Kennesaw, Ga., and Greg Humphreys of Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
text: I was going to post something substantive, but first I had tech problems (an hour on the phone with NY Times support), then internet access problems, so enough for today. Here’s some cheerful stuff from a group people have been telling me to give a listen.

headline: Where Citizenship Went to Die
text: Harare, Zimbabwe

headline: Orders Cut, as Publisher and Retailer Quarrel
text: A standoff over financial terms has prompted the bookstore chain Barnes & Noble to cut back substantially on the number of titles it orders from the publishing house Simon & Schuster, raising fears among other publishers, agents and authors that the conflict may harm the publishing industry as a whole.

headline: Pennsylvania: Environment Secretary Resigns
text: Michael Krancer, the state environment secretary, will step down next month to return to private law practice, Gov. Tom Corbett said Friday. Since taking office in January 2011, Mr. Krancer, 55, has been accused by environmentalists of lax regulation of Pennsylvania’s booming oil and gas industry, and of reporting incomplete results of water tests from private wells near gas sites. Mr. Corbett, a Republican, praised Mr. Krancer’s efforts to stop gas companies from sending wastewater to treatment plants that were not equipped to process it, as well as his role in keeping open three refineries that were in danger of being closed.

headline: Ex-President of Pakistan to End Exile in Bid to Regain Influence
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani military lore is obsessed with the romance of the daredevil commando, parachuting into hostile territory and taking the fight to the enemy despite daunting odds.

headline: Pope Cancels Newspaper Delivery Back Home in Argentina
text: Pope Francis, apparently working down his to-do list since taking his new position, made a call to his local newspaper kiosk in Buenos Aires this week to cancel his daily delivery and send his greetings, according to a report from the Catholic News Agency.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wild Ones
text: At the Paris fashion shows earlier this month, the biker’s jacket was prominent on many in the audience.

headline: Boeheim Still Defiant, Whether or Not End Is Near
text: San Jose, Calif.

headline: Italy’s President Asks Center-Left Party to Form Government
text: ROME — A month after national elections failed to yield a clear result, President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy on Friday asked the leader of the Democratic Party to try to form a government, but only if he meets the challenge of mustering a strong enough majority to govern.

headline: Girls Excel in the Classroom but Lag in Entry to 8 Elite Schools in the City
text: In the United States, girls have outshined boys in high school for years, amassing more A’s, earning more diplomas and gliding more readily into college, where they rack up more degrees — whether at the bachelor’s, master’s or doctoral levels.

headline: Waking Up to the Enduring Memory of Rape
text: Memphis

headline: A Look at Pablo Berger’s ‘Blancanieves’
text: The black-and-white silent film “Blancanieves” sets the story of Snow White amid a bullfighting milieu in Seville, Spain, in the 1920s.

headline: For Musicians, the Most Prized Violins Are for Borrowing, Not Buying
text: The din inside the Metropolitan Pavilion in Chelsea recently was that of any crowded trade fair, except for the snippets of music that wove in and out of the roar of voices.

headline: ‘Tonight Show’ to New York? Local Comics Applaud
text: Even though the influence, buzz and relevance of network talk shows has waned, make no mistake, “The Tonight Show” still matters, particularly to comedy.

headline: The Bullpen Bloomberg Built: Candidates Debate Its Future
text: It is the ultimate symbol of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s management style, borrowed from Wall Street, plunked incongruously into the middle of City Hall and studied by everyone from M.B.A. students to visiting heads of state.

headline: Bud Palmer, Jump Shot Pioneer, Dies at 91
text: Bud Palmer gained fame as a sports telecaster, covering everything from the Olympics to dog shows. He was Mayor John V. Lindsay’s official greeter, welcoming dignitaries to the city. He was the first writer of Glamour magazine’s “Ask Jake” column, offering women advice from a man’s viewpoint. (“Don’t show up drunk for a dinner date.”) And he was the first captain of the New York Knicks.

headline: The Rat Pack, Fondly Recalled
text: She was a just toddler when her father, Pat Boone, was a Las Vegas headliner who hobnobbed with the Rat Pack. But the singer Debby Boone had her eyes and ears wide open, and she remembers things like the look of Sammy Davis Jr.’s house and Dean Martin’s jokes about her father’s teetotaling. And on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle Ms. Boone, glamorized to the max, was the very picture of a tastefully attired Las Vegas babe as she devoted an entire program to songs of the Rat Pack era in a show titled “Swing This.” The swing was provided by an excellent nine-member band under the direction of John Oddo, the longtime musical director of Ms. Boone’s mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney.

headline: Tight Deadlines and Lagging Funds Bedevil Obama Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — It was another turbulent week for President Obama’s health care law. Congress rejected a White House request for nearly $1 billion to carry out the law, even as federal responsibilities increased to include the supervision of insurance markets in more than half the states. Then, on Friday, Republican attacks on the law continued in the Senate, where Democrats beat back Republican proposals to repeal the law and many of its tax increases.

headline: Artistic Touches in Mexican Food
text: The last great Mexican meal I ate was in 2004, at La Super-Rica Taqueria in Santa Barbara, Calif., whose most famous patron was Julia Child. The lines were endless.

headline: Police Storm Squatters at Rio Stadium Site
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian police on Friday stormed the work site of Maracanã, the venerable soccer stadium under renovation ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, in an attempt to end a standoff with more than 20 indigenous protesters who had squatted for years in an adjacent building that once housed Brazil’s first Indian Museum.

headline: Opening With a Clang, a Rebel Recovers
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The 3-point attempt clanged high off the rim, again, and the standout Mississippi shooting guard Marshall Henderson ran downcourt shaking his head. Great, he thought. I’m finally playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and now I stink.

headline: Egypt: Dozens Injured in Protests
text: Dozens of people were injured Friday when thousands of supporters and opponents of the ruling Muslim Brotherhood clashed outside the group’s Cairo headquarters, many of them armed with weapons like meat cleavers, cattle prods and pistols. The police fired tear gas as protesters tried to approach the headquarters. Anti-Brotherhood protesters also attacked the offices of the Freedom and Justice Party, the Brotherhood’s political wing, in Alexandria and Mahalla, according to local reports. The confrontations in Cairo were among the most violent between Brotherhood supporters and opponents since deadly clashes outside the presidential palace in December. For months, opposition groups and protesters have called on President Mohamed Morsi, above, a former Brotherhood leader, to make political concessions, including replacing his cabinet with a national unity government. Mr. Morsi has resisted those calls, deepening Egypt’s political stalemate.

headline: Bearing Witness, With Words
text: “If you don’t like someone’s story,” Chinua Achebe told The Paris Review in 1994, “write your own.”

headline: Sectarian Violence Spreads in Myanmar
text: Clashes between Buddhists and Muslims spread to villages outside a city in central Myanmar on Friday.

headline: Williams’s Star Shined in Knicks Guard Tandem
text: Ray Williams and Micheal Ray Richardson parted ways years ago, not by choice, and in Richardson’s mind, much too soon.

headline: Left Behind: Johan Santana
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla — Johan Santana will continue conditioning his arm at the Mets’ spring training facility here when the rest of his teammates depart for New York at the end of the month, Manager Terry Collins said Friday.

headline: At Virginia Commonwealth, a Defense That Is Called Havoc
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — To end practice Wednesday, Shaka Smart stood at midcourt and had his Virginia Commonwealth team — players, assistant coaches, trainers, everyone else — line up in the paint.

headline: Man Killed in Brooklyn Shooting; Three Are Wounded
text: Four people were shot — one fatally — in an apartment at a Coney Island housing project on Friday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Eager Rebounder From Iran Powers Oregon With Double-Doubles
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Arsalan Kazemi’s father owns a candy factory, churning out gaz, a nougat-and-pistachio concoction that visitors to Esfahan, Iran, buy as a souvenir. When Kazemi comes home in the summer, for just a week or so, his father gives him some to bring back to the United States.

headline: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. vs. Costa Rica
text: It was wild, and it was wintry, but it was a win. The United States national team righted its teetering World Cup qualifying campaign with a 1-0 win over Costa Rica on Friday night in Commerce City, Colo., in a game that nearly descended into farce as inch after inch of snow piled up.

headline: Los Angeles Mayor Is Leaving Without Car, Job or Regrets
text: LOS ANGELES — Antonio R. Villaraigosa has been a mayor whom this city loves to love and loves to hate. The red carpets. The late-night parties. The lofty promises, many met and some not. The disintegration of a marriage and a relationship with a television reporter while in office, all covered with the flashbulb ferocity befitting a Hollywood personality.

headline: Lebanese Premier Resigns as Syrian War Fuels Sectarian Split
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s prime minister resigned on Friday and called for a national unity government to rescue the country from deepening sectarian divisions over the war in neighboring Syria, which threatens to spill over the border. Lebanon’s most powerful political factions back opposite sides in the Syrian conflict.

headline: A Menu in Harmony With the Cocktails
text: Since it opened in 2007, 116 Crown, a hip, urban place in Ninth Square in New Haven, has been known for its striking onyx bar and inventive cocktails. Now, with the help of a new chef, it is quietly reinventing itself as a first-class restaurant. John Ginnetti, who owns 116 Crown with his wife, Danielle, said he knew it would be a challenge: “When you walk in, there’s this giant glowing bar. We knew that would work against us as a dinner place.”

headline: Prestigious High Schools, Testing and Gender
text: New York City high schools that rely entirely on the eighth-grade Specialized High School Admissions Test tend to have fewer female students.

headline: A Rare Dive Into His Own Songbook
text: The pianist George Cables ended his first set at the Iridium on Wednesday night with “My Muse,” a compact tune with the kind of crisp, sunny melody that might have made it a staple in the age of jukeboxes and roller rinks. Over a percolating rock beat, he played the theme jauntily, saving all his flash for a cascading solo that started fast and never flagged. If the song carried a burden of sentiment, he wasn’t about to let it show.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 22, 2013

headline: Senate Democrats Offer a Budget, Then the Amendments Fly
text: An updated version of this article can be found here.

headline: Darlings of Yore Hear the Cheers, but Not for Them
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The N.C.A.A. tournament unfolded here as if in some sort of parallel universe: the conversation dominated by Gonzaga, the spotlight stolen by Harvard.

headline: Beyond the Cheese, a Quirky World of Flavors
text: Mint Premium Foods began life as a gourmet food shop, and when entering the Tarrytown restaurant one is met by a display case containing huge chunks of delicious cheese, bowls of salty, fragrant olives and shelves of imported sauces, pastas and crackers. If you’re lucky, the elegant proprietor, Hassan Jarane, will offer you a slice of Pickwick Cheddar with caramelized onion, a pesto basil Gouda or a subtle truffle cheese from Tuscany.

headline: Walking While Black in New York
text: The New York City Police Department has a long history of violating constitutional rights by stopping, questioning or frisking people on the streets without legal justification. The city has steadfastly denied that the detentions — made under its increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program — have been based on race.

headline: Watchman at the Water’s Edge
text: Two bird-watchers moved camera-ready through the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge last week, grateful that the first ospreys had arrived at their familiar nests after flying 2,600 miles from winter roosts in South America. The fish hawks hungrily plied the bay’s resources as jetliners traversed the horizon across the way at Kennedy Airport. But the birders were more intent on investigating worrisome breaches in the refuge’s earthen walls caused by Hurricane Sandy. Would that affect the comings and goings this year of the multitudes of aquatic and meadow birds that favor the 13,000-acre preserve?

headline: Keep Guns Out of Criminal Hands
text: The Senate, at long last, will take up a package of gun-control measures when it returns from recess next month. On Thursday, the majority leader, Harry Reid, announced that one of those measures will require almost all gun buyers to undergo a background check. This is a vital step that would help keep guns out of the wrong hands, and it deserves far more bipartisan support than it has received.

headline: Overdue Reconciliation
text: President Obama concluded a successful visit to Israel on Friday by helping broker an end to the self-defeating standoff between two American allies, Israel and Turkey. The breakthrough is a credit to both prime ministers, Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, but it is also a sign that Mr. Obama, criticized as “leading from behind” on foreign policy, is prepared to engage more directly in international affairs.

headline: A Favorite Is One of the First to Go
text: PHILADELPHIA — The final two and a half minutes were, in Andy Enfield’s estimation, the longest two and a half minutes of his life. The game could not end soon enough, not with the way Georgetown was making 3-pointers and chipping away at Florida Gulf Coast’s lead.

headline: Among 200 Wines, Local Reds Shine
text: LONG ISLAND REDS shone when eight of the Island’s producers joined 32 vintners from other wine regions on Monday in New York Drinks New York, a public tasting of more than 200 wines.

headline: Corrections: March 23, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Spiral-Horned Antelope
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was a brain-breaker for me, but it was ultimately doable.

headline: Mary and the Zombies: Consciousness Revisited
text: Thanks to the nearly 800 readers who submitted comments on last week’s column, “Mary and the Zombies: Can Science Explain Consciousness?”  Together they produced over 100,000 words (a good sized book).  The column summarized two widely discussed arguments against understanding consciousness as entirely physical: the Mary Argument and the Zombie Argument.

headline: North Dakota to Put End to Abortions on the Ballot
text: North Dakota lawmakers passed a resolution on Friday to allow the public to decide whether the State Constitution should assert that life begins at conception, a move that would essentially ban all abortions in the state.

headline: Iceland: Prosecutor Issues Charges Over Collapse of 2 Banks in 2008
text: A special prosecutor in Iceland issued indictments this week against the chief executives and 14 other employees of two banks whose spectacular collapse during the financial crisis of 2008 sent the Icelandic economy into a tailspin. In one of the world’s most ambitious prosecutions stemming from the crisis, the 16 people are being charged with manipulating the financial markets and with putting their institutions in jeopardy by flouting internal rules. Among other things, the indictment says they issued loans to friendly companies that in turn used the loans to buy shares in the banks, elevating their stock prices. The people charged could face up to six years in prison if convicted.

headline: A Lifelong Colorado State Fan, From Horns to Tail
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — At the Stank family home in Greeley, Colo., there is a picture of a 6-month-old Justin lodged in the mouth of a bulldog.

headline: Saving Children From Guns
text: For nearly two months, my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I have been publishing a daily blog in which we aggregate articles about shootings from the previous day. Of all the stories we link to, the ones I find hardest to read are those about young children who accidentally shoot themselves or another child. They just break my heart. Yet Jennifer and I find new examples almost every day.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Bachmann Problem
text: The current intramural squabbling on the right is just too delicious for words. At least for nice words.

headline: Database Is Shut Down by NASA for a Review
text: WASHINGTON — NASA has shut down a large public database and is limiting access to agency facilities by foreign citizens as part of a broader investigation into efforts by China and other countries to get information about important technology.

headline: Teeing Off at Edge of the Arctic? A Chinese Plan Baffles Iceland
text: GRIMSSTADIR, Iceland — Struggling to stand upright against a howling wind, Bragi Benediktsson looked out over his family’s land — a barren expanse of snow and ice that a Chinese billionaire wants to turn into a golf course — and laughed. “Golf here is difficult,” said Mr. Benediktsson, a 75-year-old sheep farmer.

headline: Looking Beyond a Restaurant’s Charm
text: A breakfast and lunch spot called Two Blondes and a Stove, which opened in August in Huntington Village, N.Y., changed its name and its ambitions within six months or so of its opening. Now called BlonDee’s Bistro and Bar, it is also serving dinner.

headline: New Jersey Wins Fight Against a Tiny Invader
text: LINDEN, N.J. — The enemy forces were numerous, numbering in the thousands. They were particularly adept at hidden warfare. The fight, which endured for more than a decade, was complicated by the difficulty of detection, with the invader measuring an inch and a half, tops.

headline: Kansas Survives Against 16th Seed; La Salle Upsets Kansas State
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The 7-footer Jeff Withey’s shot-blocking and inside scoring in the second half Friday enabled Kansas to hold off Western Kentucky, 64-57, and avoid the upset of upsets as the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: State Defends Immigrant License Limits
text: PHOENIX — At a hearing on Friday on a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of an order that would keep some young immigrants from getting driver’s licenses, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona again found herself trying to prove that her policies are not discriminatory.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in Theft at Masa
text: A former bookkeeper for Masa, one of the most expensive and well-reviewed restaurants in New York, pleaded guilty on Friday to stealing almost $100,000 from the business over the course of a year.

headline: Mets’ Latest Weapon, So They Hope
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The mysterious apparatus sits high above the home plate seats at Tradition Field, the spring training home of the Mets. Dark, glossy and rectangular, it resembles an expensive flat-screen television.

headline: Comic Book Fundamentals
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — “Back to basics” could be the theme of the third installment of Asbury Park Comic Con, to be held at Convention Hall on the Boardwalk here on March 30.

headline: Rivals Fault Quinn’s Block of a Vote on Sick Time
text: Two Democratic candidates for mayor challenged Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on her home turf on Friday, for blocking a vote over paid sick-leave legislation.

headline: Horace Mann Reaches Settlement With Former Students
text: The Horace Mann School has reached a settlement worth hundreds of thousands of dollars with most of the former students who have said they were sexually abused by staff members there, a person familiar with negotiations said Friday.

headline: To Wealthy Plain Jane With Poor Boyfriend: Be Careful
text: THE APARTMENT, WITH its marble floors, gratuitously high ceilings and unaffordable modern art, is what you would expect as the Manhattan home of a wealthy author and television financial expert. The expert’s daughter is less glamorous. But that seemingly plain, dull and easily pushed-around daughter finally lashes out.

headline: With New Pope, Spotlight Returns to a Mild but Rebellious Priest
text: VIENNA

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Anthony’s 37 Points Help Knicks Secure a Playoff Berth
text: TORONTO — It was little more than a week ago that a doctor stuck a needle in the back of Carmelo Anthony’s stiff right knee and drained the fluid that had dampened his game. It was only days ago that Anthony returned, gingerly, to the Knicks’ lineup, his knee still a source of curiosity and concern.

headline: A Broader Field of Abstract Expressionists
text: ART HISTORY HAS OFTEN been accused of being overly concerned with the canon, the significant artists and masterpieces within the field, and that concern becomes even more complicated where living artists and recent history are involved.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Suspect in Knifing
text: Police officers shot and killed a man Friday night who they said had stabbed his roommate in Brooklyn and then threatened the officers with a knife, a spokesman for the New York Police Department said.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: An Artist’s Eye at Work
text: GREENWICH, CONN. — In the photograph “Crystal Fantasy,” in the Bruce Museum’s “Avant-Garde Persuasion: The Photographs of Harold Haliday Costain,” drinking glasses and decanters of all shapes and sizes rise from a fishbowl filled with water. Shimmering with points of light, they float diagonally against a rippling background as if lured by a mysterious force.

headline: Stars of a Violent Rap Video Are Found Guilty of Violent Crimes in Real Life
text: The slick rap video had all the trappings of a hit: guns, gritty urban setting, armed robbery and a flashy getaway car. But, as it turned out, the video found its true potential not on YouTube, but in federal court.

headline: First Visor Wearer Remains Advocate
text: For a true advocate of mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

headline: A Different School Bus
text: Earlier this month, a beat-up school bus from Wassaic, N.Y., rolled into Queens Village, and a team of public school students, parents and members of advocacy groups descended upon it. They covered its sun-washed green paint with sky blue, ripped out its seats and any traces of its former life — which at one point included transporting a 30-piece marching band and dance ensemble to play at demonstrations and other social- justice activities.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. Along Madison and Fifth Avenues at 44th and 45th Streets, the lampposts have basketlike structures encircling the posts above head height, with some kind of soft-looking material inside. What are they used for? Nests?

headline: This Mayor’s Decree: Smile
text: EVERY NEIGHBORHOOD in New York City has its unofficial mayor, and Morningside Heights has Bobby Fibel.

headline: Song of the Sanitation Worker
text: GARBAGE IN, GARBAGE OUT, the saying goes. Robin Nagle defies that maxim in “Picking Up: On the Streets and Behind the Trucks With the Sanitation Workers of New York City” (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $28), an entertaining tribute to the unheralded municipal employees who remove your trash.

headline: Peace Prevails on the Pitch
text: Croatia defeated Serbia to enhance its prospects of qualifying for the World Cup, but Friday’s match was about much more than soccer.

headline: In Search of the Perfect Espresso Bean
text: Curt Ellis, 33, is executive director and a founder of FoodCorps, a nonprofit organization started in 2010 to improve schoolchildren’s diets by placing volunteers in their communities for a year of service. He also was a maker of the documentary “King Corn,” which won a Peabody Award. Mr. Ellis lives with his wife, Caitlin Boyle, 31, the founder and president of film.sprout, a distributor of documentaries; and their 8-week-old son, Oliver, in a 390-square-foot fifth-floor walk-up in the East Village. Mr. Ellis, an Oregon native, likes to run on Sundays, visit a farmers’ market and cook.

headline: Building High Anxiety
Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 23, 2013
text: “Nobody knows what the devil they are up to.”

headline: Local Stop: Elmhurst, Queens
text: The rows of identical single-family homes belie the broader cultural and architectural mix of the neighborhood.

headline: Gauchos, Kung Fu and a Paraboloid
text: A bright yellow banner advertising a “Kung Fu Training School” hangs in front of Elmhurst’s oldest church, a simple clapboard structure built in 1734, when the Queens neighborhood was still the independent town of Newtown. Despite rows of seemingly uniform single-family houses, signs of the area’s diversity are everywhere, particularly in the streets crowded with Asian and Latin American shops.

headline: Creighton Aces the Drill, Defeating Cincinnati
text: PHILADELPHIA — Coach Greg McDermott has punctuated nearly every one of his team’s practices this season with a free-throw drill. His players must make 10 in row, sometimes more, before they can head home. If it looks as if he might have to turn out the lights on them, he puts a couple of minutes on the clock. Once time runs out, the loners who are left behind line up and run.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Costa Rica (0)
text: No frills. Lots of snow. Three points. Is there anything else we need to know?

headline: Wintry Weather and U.S. Team Throw Blanket Over Costa Rica
text: COMMERCE CITY, Colo. — The temperatures were freezing. The winds were battering. The snow was coming down sideways.

headline: The Mayor’s Geek Squad
text: It was a case for a digital Sherlock Holmes. Last fall, the city’s Department of Environmental Protection wanted, finally, to crack down on restaurants that were illegally dumping cooking oil into sewers in their neighborhoods — congealed yellow grease is responsible, the department says, for more than half of New York’s clogged drains. The question, of course, was how to find the culprits?

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) SPARKLE (2012) Whitney Houston, above, who died before this film was released, portrays Emma, a performer turned prim church lady in late-1960s Detroit in this remake of the 1976 movie starring Irene Cara and Lonette McKee, with a score by Curtis Mayfield. The “American Idol” winner Jordin Sparks plays Sparkle, Emma’s youngest daughter, who breaks free from the ranks of the girl group she has formed with her sisters (Carmen Ejogo and Tika Sumpter) and ascends to stardom against her mother’s wishes. “Houston dominates the new ‘Sparkle’ and gives its most compelling vocal performance in her rendition of ‘His Eye Is on the Sparrow,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Her vocal stamina was considerably diminished by the time she filmed the movie, but her disciplined, slightly hoarse rendition of that gospel standard gives ‘Sparkle’ much of its heart.” He added: “If the new songs on the soundtrack are effective Motown pastiches, most of them pale beside their prototypes. But diluted Motown is better than none.”

headline: Marriage and the Supremes
text: I’M not sure I’ve ever seen advocates of gay rights — of equal rights, I should say — as revved up as they are right now, with the Supreme Court poised, on Tuesday and Wednesday, to consider same-sex marriage in two separate cases.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 23
text: NEWS Lawmakers in Cyprus took steps late Friday to revise a formula for obtaining a bailout of the country’s banks but faced strong signals that the plan would not pass muster with international lenders. The Parliament put off until later this weekend a vote on a crucial new proposal that would confiscate 22 to 25 percent of uninsured deposits above €100,000 through a new tax on account holders in one of the nation’s most troubled banks. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Assailants suspected of being terrorists killed an 18-year-old boy in the Sopore district on Tuesday night, IBNLive reported. Initial investigations have pointed to the involvement of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba. The attack came on the heels of a suicide attack on a Central Reserve Police Force camp in Bemina last week. The police have arrested four people, including a Lashkar-e-Taiba operative, in connection with that attack, according to NDTV.

headline: Senate Passes $3.7 Trillion Budget, Setting Up Contentious Negotiations
text: WASHINGTON — After an all-night debate that ended just before 5 a.m., the Senate on Saturday adopted its first budget in four years, a $3.7 trillion blueprint for 2014 that would provide a fast track for passage of tax increases, trim spending modestly and leave the government still deeply in the red a decade from now.

text: In Today’s Times

headline: Kidnapped Australian Is Freed in Southern Philippines
text: MANILA — An emaciated 54-year-old Australian man held for 15 months by a kidnap-for-ransom group in the southern Philippines was released Saturday, officials said.

headline: Poverty Blamed for Bulgaria’s Suicide Wave
text: LONDON – Bulgaria’s caretaker government will introduce a plan on Monday to try to tackle an epidemic of suicides that is afflicting the impoverished East European nation.

text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of real women, with professional makeup by Tina Turnbow. Here, the fashion and beauty blogger Kristin Booker in a look Turnbow created just for her.

headline: Obama Has Lost Advantage Over G.O.P. on Economy
text: During the debate over the so-called fiscal cliff in December, public opinion surveys showed more Americans trusted President Obama than trusted Republicans in Congress when it came to handling the nation’s economy. The New Year’s Day deal to avoid going over the cliff, which included higher marginal tax rates on high earners — something Mr. Obama had campaigned on and lobbied for — was largely seen as a victory for the president.

headline: Costa Rica Considering Protest to FIFA
text: Costa Rican soccer officials said they planned to file a protest with FIFA on Saturday after Friday night’s 1-0 loss to the United States in a World Cup qualifying match played in a blizzard.

headline: Updates and Analysis: N.C.A.A. Tournament, Round of 32, Day 1
text: Top seeded Gonzaga is out of the N.C.A.A. tournament thanks to No. 9 Wichita State and No. 3 Marquette ends the run of No. 6 Butler. Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters detail Saturday’s action from the N.C.A.A. Tournament.

headline: The Gun Report: March 23, 2013
text: Today, Joe is devoting his column to smart gun technology, which includes biometric gun locks that ensure only a gun’s owner can fire it. States including New Jersey and California would like to make “gun personalization” technology, as it is called, required for all legally owned firearms. Many Second Amendment absolutists believe that any refinement to current gun laws is an infringement on their rights. “Why should legal gun owners suffer background checks when such a small percentage of people use guns to kill?” they ask.

headline: Security Cameras on East Coast Capture Meteor
text: Security cameras on the East Coast captured a flash in the sky Friday night that appears to have been a small meteor.

headline: Behind Image of Seamless Transition, Vatican Navigates Uncharted Waters
text: VATICAN CITY — Sharing lunch is rarely historic, except perhaps when the two people eating are a pope and his predecessor.

headline: A Once-Vibrant City Struggles as Panama Races Ahead on a Wave of Prosperity
text: COLÓN, Panama — On one end of the Panama Canal, the nation’s capital gleams with new skyscrapers; a subway, the first in Central America, is under construction; and new malls and restaurants fill with patrons. The city fancies itself a mini-Dubai on the Pacific.

headline: France Confirms the Death of a Qaeda Leader in Mali
text: France on Saturday officially confirmed the death of the regional Qaeda leader Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, weeks after he was reported to have been killed in fighting in northern Mali at the end of February.

headline: Variety: A Collectible Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s quote comes from essayist ANNE FADIMAN, who writes of Vladimir NABOKOV’s tendency to “hoard” rare words that seem otherworldly to us now. And man, this was a hard one! I tend to solve Acrostics by “toggling” back and forth between guessing the clues and filling in the words as they take shape. But how do you do that when some of the words are IRIDULE or LEMNISCATE? It’s like Eugene Maleska came back to life and wrote an acrostic.

headline: As His Recovery Lags, Santana Stays Positive
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — There appears to remain a long road ahead for the left-hander Johan Santana, who has not pitched in a spring training game and will not join his teammates for the start of the regular season next month.

headline: Just Freed, Cleared Man Has a Heart Attack
text: On his second day of freedom after serving 23 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, David Ranta suffered a serious heart attack Friday night, his lawyer said.

headline: China’s Leader Argues for Cooperation With Russia
text: MOSCOW — President Xi Jinping of China made a case on Saturday for closer economic and foreign policy cooperation with Russia, using a speech at a university here to argue that the countries have converging goals, including an expansion of the oil and gas trade, as they pursue dreams of “national revival” and seek to offset the influence of the developed West.

headline: McIlroy and Wozniacki Striving, With Some Success, for Ordinary
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The day after Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn posted formal, studio-quality photographs on their Facebook and Twitter accounts to show that they were dating, the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki posted her own sports power-couple shot on Twitter.

headline: In Snowstorm, U.S. Finds Remedy for a Cold Spell
text: They continued the soccer match during a snowstorm Friday night near Denver for a very good reason.

headline: A Tireless Connoisseur of Texas Barbecue Gets Ready for the Main Course
text: DALLAS — Daniel Vaughn stood at the counter at Lockhart Smokehouse here, ordering dinner. Lockhart serves smoked meat the way butchers serve raw meat — wrapped in a large rectangle of butcher paper — and its customers are encouraged to eat it the way cowboys used to, or maybe Neanderthals, without sauce, forks or even plates.

headline: How Much Electricity Comes From Renewable Sources
text: Circles are sized according to the electricity use per capita for a selection of countries.

headline: Bands Go Beyond the Music
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — What you do not always see during the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament on television is this: a bass trombone player who hops around on stilts before the game, a band director who rips off his dress shirt and conducts in a tank top, and a tuba player who shimmies out of his pants at halftime, revealing American-flag boxers and tights.

headline: Mohsin Hamid
text: Mohsin Hamid, a Pakistani writer, is the author, most recently, of “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia.” The film adaptation of his best-selling book, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” will be in theaters April 26.

headline: The Ambiguous Island
text: For over 20 years, photographer Alex Webb has been documenting street life in Cuba.

headline: For Blacks in Cuba, the Revolution Hasn’t Begun
text: Havana

headline: The Obama Era, Brought to You by the Iraq War
text: WHEN prominent people in Washington spend an anniversary apologizing for being catastrophically, unforgivably wrong about a decade-old decision, you might expect that the decision in question had delivered their party to disaster or defeat. But last week’s many Iraq war mea culpas were rich in irony: one by one, prominent liberals lined up to apologize for supporting a war that’s responsible for liberalism’s current political and cultural ascendance.

headline: Where Battier Goes, Winning Streaks Follow
text: The question of whether it is better to be loved or hated may never be answered satisfactorily, but when it comes to Shane Battier, there is no need to choose. He is loved and hated with equal passion, based almost entirely on how one feels about Duke basketball.

headline: In India, Women’s Issues Are Finally Out Front
text: Having recently returned to the United States from a four-year assignment in India, I’m often asked about events in that country. And so it was with the brutal rape and murder of a 23-year-old student in New Delhi in December that set off big protests across India and was covered widely around the world. Why has this particular rape inspired so much outrage, people ask, when sexual violence is, sadly, so pervasive and commonplace there?

headline: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, the Sequel
text: LAST week, scientists sequenced the genome of cells taken without consent from a woman named Henrietta Lacks. She was a black tobacco farmer and mother of five, and though she died in 1951, her cells, code-named HeLa, live on. They were used to help develop our most important vaccines and cancer medications, in vitro fertilization, gene mapping, cloning. Now they may finally help create laws to protect her family’s privacy — and yours.

headline: Israel: Bits, Bytes and Bombs
text: READING the news from the wider Middle East and then watching President Obama visiting Israel triggered this thought: The president looked as if he were visiting an atoll in the Pacific, or maybe New Zealand — but definitely some kind of island state surrounded by roiling seas.

headline: Imprisoned by Innovation
text: PRISONS — those bastions of routine and tradition — are finally ripe for disruption. Such is the rosy conclusion of “Beyond the Bars,” a provocative report from management consultants at Deloitte published earlier this month.

headline: St. John’s Weathered a Season of Changes
text: St. John’s will host Dayton on Sunday at Carnesecca Arena in making its fourth consecutive appearance in the N.C.A.A. Division I women’s basketball tournament, an accomplishment that does not begin to suggest the turbulence the Red Storm encountered.

headline: The Times’s Work in Progress
text: SINCE I started as The Times’s fifth public editor last September, I’ve taken up topics from “false balance” in news articles to negative arts criticism to government secrecy. After six months, 16 Sunday columns and close to 100 blog posts to the Public Editor’s Journal, I thought it would be worthwhile to see where some of the issues I have written about stand now.

headline: Report Card on Health Care Reform
text: Republican leaders in Congress regularly denounce the 2010 Affordable Care Act and vow to block money to carry it out or even to repeal it. Those political attacks ignore the considerable benefits delivered to millions of people since the law’s enactment three years ago Saturday. The main elements of the law do not kick in until Jan. 1, 2014, when many millions of uninsured people will gain coverage. Yet it has already thrown a lifeline to people at high risk of losing insurance or being uninsured, including young adults and people with chronic health problems, and it has made a start toward reforming the costly, dysfunctional American health care system.

headline: Shrinking Prisons, Saving Billions
text: The mandatory sentencing craze that gripped the country four decades ago drove up the state prison population sevenfold — from under 200,000 in the early 1970s to about 1.4 million today — and pushed costs beyond $50 billion a year. Until recently, it seemed that the numbers would keep growing. But thanks to reforms in more than half the states, the prison census has edged down slightly — by just under 2 percent — since 2009. A new analysis by the Pew Charitable Trusts shows that the decline would have been considerably larger had the other states not been pulling in the opposite direction.

headline: Heightened Scrutiny
text: One of the central questions in the two gay marriage cases to be argued before the Supreme Court this week is whether gays and lesbians are a protected class under the Constitution. Under longstanding principles, government actions that fall heavily on “discrete and insular minorities” historically subject to prejudice and stigma are to be given particular scrutiny.

headline: Unhappy? Clean House
text: London

headline: Your Phone vs. Your Heart
text: CAN you remember the last time you were in a public space in America and didn’t notice that half the people around you were bent over a digital screen, thumbing a connection to somewhere else?

headline: Buck Gives Mets Pitchers a Mentor Behind the Plate
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Catcher John Buck meant no offense, but his sense of plain-spoken realism had developed over nearly a decade as a major leaguer.
