text: The field of digital music services is getting as crowded as CBGB was when the Ramones played. So major competitors are spending large sums on advertising campaigns that are meant to generate awareness, consideration and trial.

headline: The Hotel del Coronado’s Past Lives
text: As anyone who’s walked the grounds of the famed Hotel del Coronado knows all too well, the past has a way of catching up with you. There’s the ghost of Kate Morgan, whose dead body was found on Nov. 29, 1892, five days after she’d checked in under the alias Lottie A. Bernard. The San Diego coroner ultimately determined that the gunshot wound to her head was self-inflicted. Today, those who stay in her room (3327, previously No. 302) — the most requested one in the hotel — continue to report paranormal activity, including a television set that randomly turns on. Ms. Morgan is not the only famous name on the hotel’s guest register. Previous guests have included Frank Sinatra, Lucille Ball, Desi Arnaz, Charlie Chaplin, Charles Lindbergh and Marilyn Monroe, whose film “Some Like It Hot,” was shot here. This year, the hotel celebrates its 125th anniversary with a series of events and a new commemorative book, “Hotel del Coronado History.”

headline: Drone Disdain
text: Each time a reporter or an elected official questions the Obama administration about its theory that the president may order the killing of an American citizen that he considers an actual or even potential terrorist threat, the same thing happens. The administration reacts with ill-concealed disdain.

headline: Paul Rose, Quebec Separatist Involved in Kidnapping, Dies at 69
text: Paul Rose, a strident Quebec separatist leader who in October 1970 helped kidnap and, he claimed, strangle a provincial official, inflaming a crisis that pitted terrorists against the Canadian prime minister, Pierre Trudeau, died on March 14 in Montreal. He was 69.

headline: Cornell Wrestler Savors 4th Title in 4th Weight Class
text: By winning the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships in Des Moines over the weekend, Kyle Dake became the first collegiate wrestler to win four national titles in four weight classes and the third to win four titles over all.

headline: Q. and A.: A Decisive Moment on Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear an hourlong argument on Tuesday morning over the constitutionality of Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage. Here is a look at the background of the case, Hollingsworth v. Perry, No. 12-144; the issues it raises; the lawyers who will argue it; and the possible outcomes.

text: President Obama presided over a ceremony swearing in new American citizens at the White House on Monday as part of his pitch for legislation that would overhaul the nation’s immigration laws.

headline: Indian Car Ad Goes Viral, Not in a Good Way

headline: Worries Over Violence Prompt Shutdown in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK — A major commercial area of Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, shut down on Monday after rumors spread there of sectarian attacks on Muslims. The shutdown reflected the nervous mood in the country after deadly rioting last week by Buddhist mobs.

headline: Cyprus Rescue Deal Addresses Important Principles
text: Cyprus’s economy is going to suffer terribly in the next few years. Some of that is inevitable given how bloated its banking system has become. But the disastrous handling of the crisis, especially in the last week, will make things much worse.

headline: In an Area Plagued by Violence, a ‘God Squad’ Hits the Streets
text: The Rev. Gilford Monrose was asleep in his Brooklyn apartment on March 9, when a text message from another pastor knocked him from his slumber: BROOKLYN: *POLICE SHOOTING* E52 ST X SNYDER AVE, LEVEL 1 MOBILIZATION CALLED. It was 11:39 p.m., and Mr. Monrose was about to begin the most trying week of his life.

headline: “House of Cards” Episode 10, the Recap: Frank Forgets How to Count and Peter Tumbles
text: We are now officially headed toward end-of-season recess on “House of Cards” and Ashley Parker and David Carr take a look at episode 10. If you like reading their take on the political and media dimensions of the rest of the season, you can find episode one, two,three, four, five, six,seven , eight or nine here. Spoilers are thicker than plots on “House of Cards,” so consider yourself warned.

headline: China’s Leader Tries to Calm African Fears of His Country’s Economic Power
text: HONG KONG — China’s new president, Xi Jinping, sought to assure African countries on Monday that his government would heed complaints that relentlessly competitive Chinese companies were suffocating African efforts to nurture industry and jobs, and he promised aid, scholarships and technology transfers in an effort to counter those fears.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Paul Caine joined Dial Global, New York, a radio syndication company, as chief executive. He succeeds Spencer Brown, who is leaving, the company said. Mr. Caine had been executive vice president and president for advertising, as well as chief revenue officer, at Time Inc., New York, part of Time Warner.

headline: ‘The Flick’ Prompts an Explanation From Playwrights Horizons
text: The artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, a leading Off Broadway company that produces new American plays, took the unusual step on Saturday of e-mailing 3,000 of the theater’s subscribers to explain his decision to produce Annie Baker’s new play “The Flick,” whose three-hour length and periods of long silence have infuriated some audience members.

headline: MTV Video Music Awards Show Coming to Brooklyn
text: Some things just get better when they move to Brooklyn — Walt Whitman; Arthur Miller; the former New Jersey Nets — and MTV is hoping that one of its signature institutions will benefit from the aura exuded by the borough of Spike Lee, Chris Rock, Coney Island and artisanal pickles. On Monday the network said that its 2013 MTV Video Music Awards will be held on Aug. 25 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, marking the 30th year of that program, which in recent years has been held either in Manhattan or Los Angeles.

headline: New Roku Box Makes Streaming TV Even Easier
text: Roku’s new streaming media player, the Roku 3, looks remarkably like its predecessors: a hockey puck. Instead of upgrading the appearance, the company has improved the way the device works, while keeping the price at $100.

headline: Temp Tee Urges Shoppers to ‘Whip’ Up Passover Dishes
text: Decades ago, ads pitched Geritol tonic as the cure for “tired blood.” Now, a dairy product is being proposed as the antidote to “matzah fatigue.” Matzah fatigue could be classified as among “Passover problems,” the puzzles that perplex Jews who celebrate the eight-day holiday, which begins at sunset on Monday. It is a fanciful expression, to be sure, but it does address what is, for many, an issue each year: Around the third day, the palate often begins to rebel against a steady diet of foods that are kosher for Passover like matzah, the unleavened bread also known as matzo or matzoh.

headline: First Hint of Spring Links
text: Diet News: The Mediterranean diet is not just good for your health, but also improves food security. Is there nothing this way of eating can’t do? Less encouraging is that Mississippi, the most obese state in the nation, is banning Bloomberg-style portion control. No, really — the bill is called the “The Anti-Bloomberg Bill.”

headline: To Whom It May Concern
text: Q. Do the spacecraft we have sent to investigate the universe carry any identification of their human and earthly origin?

headline: Swinton Under Glass: New Offering From MoMA
text: Among the second-floor contemporary-art galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, visitors on Monday were happening upon an unexpected sight: the actress Tilda Swinton lying on a mattress in a glass box, apparently asleep. Ms. Swinton, an Oscar winner for the 2007 film “Michael Clayton,” has brought her performance piece “The Maybe” to MoMA, 18 years after she first performed it for a week in the Serpentine Gallery in London.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: At Brushstroke, 30 Hudson Street in TriBeCa, Isao Yamada, the chef, and Eric Hastings, the sommelier, are putting together an eight-course tasting menu for dinner on Wednesday that includes old-world wines and artisanal sake. The meal is $250 per person, and reservations can be made online.

headline: Free Checking Still Widespread at Credit Unions
text: Nearly three-quarters of the country’s largest credit unions still offer no-strings-attached free checking accounts, a new report from Bankrate.com finds.

headline: A Sea Change in Less Than 50 Years as Gay Rights Gained Momentum
text: WASHINGTON — The struggle for African-Americans’ rights, symbolized by the bloody 1965 Selma march, is as old as the nation. The effort for American women’s rights began at Seneca Falls, N.Y., more than 150 years ago.

headline: Scalia’s Gay Marriage Problem
text: With the Supreme Court set to hear oral arguments tomorrow and Wednesday in a pair of same-sex marriage cases, there are two questions preoccupying legal writers: How will Justice Anthony Kennedy, the court’s wild card, vote, and how will Justice Antonin Scalia behave?

headline: Chandler Practices, a Little, and Eyes Knicks Return
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – Tyson Chandler spent a few minutes on the court Monday morning, practicing post defense and testing his sore neck. But it was for only a few minutes.

headline: An Old Prescription for Sour Faces
text: When the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus made its first appearance at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last week, it marked a return to the borough where it was born in the 19th century. The circus revived another tradition on Monday, when it staged a performance for young patients, staff members and other guests at the Brooklyn Hospital Center.

headline: Leader of Central African Republic Fled to Cameroon, Official Says
text: JOHANNESBURG — A day after being ousted by rebel forces, President François Bozizé of the Central African Republic surfaced in Cameroon on Monday, according to a statement read on state radio by a senior Cameroonian official. He will remain there until he finds a more permanent refuge, said the official, Ferdinand Ngoh Ngoh.

headline: Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Knocks at Australia’s Door
text: Australia’s first death from XDR-TB — extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, which is nearly incurable — has alarmed health officials and added new heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous diseases. That debate echoes one on the United States’ southern border.

headline: The Secret May Be in the Coffee
text: People who live on the Greek island of Ikaria are known to have remarkably high life expectancies, and researchers have been studying them carefully to learn why. Now a new report suggests that one reason may be the coffee they drink.

headline: Malaysia to Relocate Residents of Contested Areas
text: MANILA  — The Malaysian authorities will resettle residents of remote coastal areas near the southern Philippines amid fighting that has killed more than 70 people, officials said Monday.

headline: Made in L.A. | Modernism at Sunset
text: A residence made mostly of glass and wood, surrounded by trees, tucked neatly behind a modernist building. The interior designer and writer David Netto leads a tour of the VDL Research House, the former home and studio of Richard Neutra located on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles. Netto describes Neutra, the architect originally from Austria, as “the shaper of the future of California,” and demonstrates how the house reflects the architect’s point of view.

headline: Portman’s Son Describes Personal Side of Senator’s Shift on Same-Sex Marriage
text: 4:58 p.m. | Updated When Senator Rob Portman, the Ohio Republican, announced his support for same-sex marriage, he said his son’s admission that he was gay prompted the change of heart. But the timeline left some puzzled: If the son, Will, came out two years ago, why did the senator’s announcement come 10 days ago?

headline: Is It Ever O.K. for Christian Kids to Have a Bar Mitzvah?
text: In this week’s Riff essay, Maud Newton writes about the popularity of traditional Jewish rituals among American evangelical Christians — specifically, but not limited to, holding bar mitzvahs for their kids. Here, in a bonus to Riff, Newton explains a bit of her own back story and provides further explanation of this curious, and controversial, phenomenon. Newton has previously written Riff essays on the lingering linguistic influence of David Foster Wallace and the best-selling book “Heaven Is Real.”

headline: A Clearer View of the Space Bullet That Grazed Russia
text: Using an eclectic mix of crowd-sourced video, information from Google Earth and data from nuclear test-ban sensors, scientists have gotten a much more accurate picture of the small asteroid that exploded near the Russian city of Chelyabinsk last month.

headline: Prisoner X of Israel Is Said to Have Exposed Top Spies
text: JERUSALEM — Israel has revealed very little about the man known as Prisoner X, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed here in 2010 after apparently getting caught in a web of espionage and intrigue, other than how he died: alone, by asphyxiation, after hanging himself in the shower of his cell.

headline: Photo Replay: March 25
text: A view of the day in sports, including a car rally in Saudi Arabia and Tiger Woods at Bay Hill.

headline: Decoded: Steve Harvey’s Daytime Success
text: The Times’s Brian Stelter decodes Steve Harvey’s talk show success.

headline: Tibetan Mother of 4 Self-Immolates to Protest Chinese Rule
text: A Tibetan mother of four killed herself by self-immolation on Sunday to protest Chinese rule, according to a report on Monday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The report said Kalkyi, 30, set fire to herself near a monastery in the county of Dzamthang in Ngaba Prefecture, which has been a focal point of the wave of Tibetan self-immolations that began in 2009. At least 110 people in Tibetan regions of China have set fire to themselves, and the vast majority have died. Ms. Kalkyi’s self-immolation took place around 3:30 p.m. Sunday, and her body was taken by locals to the Jonang monastery, according to Radio Free Asia, which cited sources inside Tibet. Ms. Kalkyi had three sons and one daughter, all under the age of 15. Radio Free Asia said that Ms. Kalkyi was the 16th woman to self-immolate since 2009. On March 13, a woman, Konchog Wangmo, 31, killed herself by self-immolation in Ngaba Prefecture, and her husband, Drolma Kyab, was later detained by the authorities, the news service reported.

headline: Bankia Stock Value Is Nearly Wiped Out Under Recapitalization Plan
text: MADRID — Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender whose collapse last year led to a banking crisis in Spain, slumped Monday in the first day of trading after regulators wiped out most of the stock’s value.

headline: Rice Pudding
text: Melissa Clark shows how to make rice pudding that is simple, luscious and creamy.

headline: Back at No. 1, Woods Shifts Gaze to Augusta
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — A few miles from Bay Hill Club and Lodge, Tiger Woods ran into a fire hydrant, and out gushed sordid details of his private life. Two years later, in November 2011, he reached rock bottom in his professional life, dropping to No. 58 in the world rankings.

headline: How Many Vietnam Veterans Are Still Alive?
text: The approximate percentage of Vietnam-era veterans who are still alive in 2013 is 75.

headline: Hachette Delaying Goodall Book With Borrowed Passages
text: After revelations that Jane Goodall’s forthcoming book “Seeds of Hope” contains passages copied from various Web sites, the Hachette Book Group has decided to delay its publication. The book was set to be published April 2. No new date has been set.

headline: Fold Up Your Handkerchiefs: Books Have Gotten Less ‘Emotional,’ Study Says
text: If you find you’re crying less while reading and throwing fewer books across the room, there may be a good reason. English-language books became steadily less “emotional” over the 20th century, according to a new study crunching billions of words via Google’s Ngram database.

headline: Qatalyst Hires Morgan Stanley Banker
text: Qatalyst Group, the West Coast boutique advisory firm led by Frank Quattrone, has hired Marcie Vu as a partner.

headline: The Tournament’s Biggest Surprise? La Salle
text: Right now, Florida Gulf Coast is everybody’s darling.

headline: Sale of Pre-Columbian Art Falls Short of Expectations
text: Sotheby’s weekend sale in Paris of pre-Columbian artifacts earned about $13.3 million, well below the pre-sale estimate of $19 million to $23 million, according to the auction house.

headline: France Seeks Slower Pace of Negotiations for a U.S.-Europe Trade Pact
text: PARIS — If anyone thought working out a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union was going to be easy, France has a message: Slow down.

headline: The Iraq War and Domestic Politics
text: There was a lot of pushback, much of it from liberals, to my column yesterday arguing that the Obama era as we know it has been made possible by George W. Bush’s decision ten years ago to launch an invasion of Iraq. Some of this pushback, on Twitter and elsewhere, reflects a slight misreading of my point, so let me clarify: I was not arguing that absent the Iraq War, the Democratic Party would necessarily still be in the minority today, or that the Democratic presidential nominee would necessarily have lost the elections of 2008 and 2012. As I said at the top of the piece, it’s entirely plausible that in a world with no Iraq invasion we would be presently entering Hillary Clinton’s second term, and I agree (and have acknowledged many times before) that the current Democratic advantage is founded on deep demographic and social trends as well as the accidents of politics.

headline: In Praise of Pale Food
text: IT’S ONE OF THE FIRST THINGS people mention when they learn I have a 4-year-old daughter.

headline: Looking for Evidence That Therapy Works
text: Mental-health care has come a long way since the remedy of choice was trepanation — drilling holes into the skull to release “evil spirits.” Over the last 30 years, treatments like cognitive-behavioral therapy, dialectical behavior therapy and family-based treatment have been shown effective for ailments ranging from anxiety and depression to post-traumatic stress disorder and eating disorders.

headline: Look of the Moment | Charlotte Casiraghi
text: The Girl: The Monaco royal at the Bal de la Rose du Rocher in Monte-Carlo, Monaco.

headline: A Rice Pudding for Anyone
text: As an ardent fan of rice pudding, I’ve made many versions over the years, most involving an egg custard and many baked in a water bath. While none are difficult, they are all more elaborate than the simple pudding I wanted for this week’s column about white food.

headline: Suit Offers a Peek at the Practice of Inflating a Legal Bill
text: 8:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kyle Busch Wins as Hamlin and Logano Wreck
text: Feuding former teammates Denny Hamlin and Joey Logano crashed into each other while battling for the lead on the final turn, and Kyle Busch squeezed past them to take the victory in Sunday’s 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Auto Club Speedway in California.

headline: Channing Tatum Has the Most Anagrammable Name in Hollywood
text: As a recurring bonus to the Riff essay, we sporadically present Five-Ku: five haiku poems about a current celebrity or cultural phenomenon. (Past examples include haikus about Susan Sarandon, Russell Crowe and classic horror films.)

headline: In Performance: Tina Packer’s ‘Women’
text: Tina Packer plays Queen Margaret in a scene from Shakespeare’s “Henry VI (Part III),” part of her show “Women of Will.”

headline: Following Your Bliss, Right Off the Cliff
text: SO you want to be a writer. Or an artist. Or to open a cupcake shop. What you’ll hear, often, is that you should pursue your dream. Follow your passion. Quit your job and live the life you want.

headline: Brother of a Fallen Hedge Fund King Pleads Not Guilty
text: 5:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: Made in L.A. | The House of Neutra
text: The interior designer and writer David Netto takes a tour of VDL Research House on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra to Collaborate With Opera on ‘Salome’
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra has programmed a concert performance of the Strauss opera “Salome” for next season. Now, they are calling in the experts. The orchestra said on Monday it would be collaborating with Opera Philadelphia to create a semistaged version of the work, to be performed in May 2014. Kevin Newbury is to direct and Vita Tzykun will design the production, to be performed in the orchestra’s home, Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center, which has no proscenium. “It’s a bit of a feat to try to imagine a theatrical mash-up, if you will,” said Allison Vulgamore, the orchestra’s chief executive and president.

headline: Minnesota Women’s Hockey Wins 49 in a Row to Win Title
text: The Pittsburgh Penguins have won 12 games in a row. The Miami Heat have won 26 in a row. The Baylor women’s basketball team has won 31 in a row. But they have a ways to go to catch the University of Minnesota women’s hockey team. The Gophers completed a 41-0 season Sunday by winning their second straight national championship with a 6-3 victory over Boston University.

headline: Nick Cave: HEARD NY
text: For a week at Grand Central station, students from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will move through the station wearing Nick Cave's Soundsuits as part of the station's centennial celebration.

headline: ‘A Renaissance Globemaker’s Toolbox’
text: Introduction

headline: Why America Is Called America
text: A DECADE AGO, the Library of Congress paid $10 million to acquire the only known original copy of a 1507 world map that has been called “the birth certificate of America.” The large map, a masterpiece of woodblock printing, has been a star attraction at the library ever since and the object of revived scholarly fascination about the earliest cartography of the New World. The research has also rescued from obscurity a little-known Renaissance man, the 16th-century globe maker Johannes Schöner, who was responsible for saving the map for posterity.

headline: With Acquisition, Apple Looks Indoors for Future of Maps
text: It appears Apple is thinking seriously about what the mobile maps of tomorrow will look like, not just fixing the maps service it has today.

headline: When Fig Wasps Can’t Take the Heat
text: There are more than 700 species of wild fig in the tropics. Remarkably, most can be pollinated only by a unique species of fig wasp. In turn, the wasps rely on fig plants as hosts for their eggs. Neither species can survive without the other, a relationship known as obligate mutualism.

headline: Cold, Wet Wait for Tickets to Supreme Court’s Same-Sex Marriage Cases
text: WASHINGTON — Being a witness to history can be messy business. And for those waiting outside the Supreme Court on Monday for one of the few coveted tickets to hear oral arguments in a pair of same-sex marriage cases this week, it was also cold, wet and tedious.

headline: Go Find Your Flippers
text: The real estate, and dunes, on Fire Island qualified for a post-mortem in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. Besides the dozen or so homes swept into the sea, nearly 1,600 sustained significant damage — by wind or saltwater or a combination. The Army Corps of Engineers, which so far has five demolition permits for homes too ravaged to repair, is handling the removal of tons of debris.

headline: More Join Hunger Strike at Guantánamo Prison
text: A  hunger strike among detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who have been imprisoned by the United States military without trial — some for more than a decade — is continuing to grow, although there is sharp disagreement between the military and lawyers for the detainees about how many are participating.

headline: With or Without Bailout, Cypriots Lose Trust in Banks
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With her wedding day three months away, Despina Charalambous is desperate to gain access to her savings, which have been frozen at the Bank of Cyprus for more than a week. She plans to take out all her money once the banks reopen, even though the new bailout plan for her country supposedly guarantees the safety of her deposits.

headline: A Russian Supper Club for ‘Natasha’ Musical
text: A vacant lot in Manhattan’s meatpacking district is being transformed into New York’s latest theater spectacle, a sexy Russian supper club that will be the new home of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” Dave Malloy’s acclaimed electropop opera that ran at Ars Nova last fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Myanmar and Yemen.

headline: In the Shadow of LaFerrari, the Pininfarina Sergio
text: Almost overlooked at the Geneva auto show earlier this month was the Pininfarina Sergio concept. Normally, the product of the world’s most famous Italian coach builder would be a headliner. But this year was different. The show was dominated by the impact of the LaFerrari, the powerful supercar from Ferrari.

headline: Walkabout – 3/25: No Carry-on? Go to Front of the Line, Says American
text: Flying Light American Airlines is testing new boarding procedures that award passengers who don’t bring any carry-ons by allowing them to board before others in economy class. (Today)

headline: A Push for HPV Vaccinations
text: The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.

headline: Female Business Travelers Make a Case for Pen Knives
text: HERE is what the Transportation Security Administration said its screeners discovered in passengers’ carry-on bags at airport security in the seven days that ended last Thursday: 32 guns, 23 of them loaded and seven with rounds in the firing chamber; eight stun guns; a four-inch knife concealed in a suitcase lining; and an eight-inch tactical spike hidden in a sock.

headline: Clearing the Jungle (Barely) on a Wing and a Pilot’s Prayer
text: SINCE I’m in charge of international sales and product development at Numi Organic Tea, my business travel can be crazy. I may not have to leave California, our headquarters, for a few weeks, and then I may be gone for four or five weeks visiting farms overseas, or looking for new business opportunities or potential partners. Much of my travel can be dictated by growing seasons.

headline: Avicii Turns to Nashville for Ultra Music Festival Show
text: 1:31 p.m. | Updated  MIAMI — Avicii, the Swedish music producer and D.J., is known for catchy house music like the hits “Levels” and “Silhouettes.” But on Friday, at the Ultra Music Festival here, his one-hour set more resembled a Nashville concert than a performance by one of the stars of electronic dance music.

headline: The Mouth’s Guard
text: Humans secrete two kinds of saliva, stimulated and unstimulated, no more alike than most siblings. The prettier child is stimulated saliva. It comes from the parotid glands, between cheek and ear. When a plate of spaghetti carbonara makes your mouth water, that’s stimulated saliva. It makes up 70 to 90 percent of the two to three pints of saliva each of us generates daily. Stimulated saliva looks, tastes and flows like water — it is, in fact, 99 percent water with some proteins and minerals. Each person’s saliva contains minerals in unique proportions.

headline: The Marvels in Your Mouth
text: WAGENINGEN, THE NETHERLANDS — When I told people I was traveling to Food Valley, I described it as the Silicon Valley of eating. At this cluster of universities and research facilities, nearly 15,000 scientists are dedicated to improving — or, depending on your sentiments about processed food, compromising — the quality of our meals.

headline: Gulp! The Quiz
text: Chew, swallow, digest, repeat. You probably don’t think much about your digestive tract, but there are some amazing things going on in your gut. Take this quiz, based on the new book “Gulp!” by Mary Roach, excerpted in this week’s Science Times, to find out how intimately you know your innards.

headline: Vain Glorious | Kiehl’s Stress Relief
text: Stress. Our bodies are engineered to cope with a certain amount comfortably, but sustained, intense stress is an entirely different matter. It can negatively impact our minds, our hearts, and our body’s largest organ, skin. “Its effects are particularly harsh, causing premature aging and advancing the symptoms of every common skin condition from sensitive skin to eczema and psoriasis,” says Dr. Cynthia Ackrill, a fellow at the American Institute of Stress.

headline: A Meteor’s Data Trail, Journey on the Alimentary Canal and Using the Body to Fight Cancer
text: Henry Fountain on how science is tracking the meteor that exploded over Russia back to its source; Mary Roach on our fascinating guts; Denise Grady on a novel treatment for some cancers of the blood.

headline: The Multipurpose Airport
text: Jim Rosenberg, the head of online and social media for the World Bank, can vouch that some airports offer a lot more than places to eat and newsstands filled with gossipy magazines.

headline: Beware of the High Cost of ‘Free’ Online Courses
text: That the acronym MOOCs rhymes with “nukes” seems apt. Massive open online courses, or MOOCs — led by two profit-making start-ups, Coursera and Udacity, founded by entrepreneurial Stanford professors — are a new disruptive force in education. Leading universities have scrambled to join or offer alternatives like edX, a collaboration of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Harvard University and others.

headline: Different Versions of a Life, All Lived
text: In the midst of a secret love affair, Ursula Todd discovers that she is an excellent liar. The same can be said admiringly of Kate Atkinson, whose latest novel, “Life After Life,” is her very best. Ms. Atkinson’s wide-ranging body of work includes several novels that resemble mysteries, but she has never had the narrowly deductive mind to suit that genre. “Life After Life” is a big book that defies logic, chronology and even history in ways that underscore its author’s fully untethered imagination.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  After Google Reader, and Steve Jobs Manga
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Solid Sales for ‘Pippin’ and ‘The Nance’ on Broadway
text: Two of the highest-profile Broadway shows this spring, the revival of the musical “Pippin” and the new Nathan Lane play “The Nance,” had solid ticket sales during their first weekend of performances, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: A Highly Public Trip for China’s President, and Its First Lady
text: President Xi Jinping of China is on his inaugural overseas trip. Mr. Xi stopped first in Russia, went to Tanzania, and will then  visit the Republic of Congo and South Africa, where he will also attend a summit meeting of emerging BRICS economies — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.

text: To the Editor:

headline: YouTube Videos Unlock Meteor’s Secrets
text: Scientists around the world have been using videos made by Russian citizens and uploaded to YouTube to figure out exactly where the meteor that exploded over Russia on Feb. 15 came from.

headline: Exploring the Language That Speaks the Inexpressible
text: Listening to the pianist Jeremy Denk play, you never doubt that he is someone who thinks about music deeply and rather a lot. It’s not that you sense that he fusses overmuch about tempos and dynamics, or that he’s out to demonstrate his awesome cleverness through programming juxtapositions. Rather, what Mr. Denk’s playing conveys most is an inclusive consideration of where each piece came from, what it reflects about its composer and how music connects to a life’s broader concerns.

headline: Where Bowls and Bodies Fly Though the Air
text: What’s the next level after impressed? Amazed? Awe-struck? Whatever it is, that emotion arrives often in “Totem,” the newest show from Cirque du Soleil.

headline: A Beige Wine for a Beige Meal
text: For a meal of relentlessly beige food, may I suggest the beigest of wines? That would be chardonnay, which will go beautifully with Melissa Clark’s chicken potpie. I call it beige in the most insulting way, as chardonnay long ago became kind of a generic term for a glass of insipid white wine in any bar in the land. But of course chardonnay also makes some of the greatest, most distinctive white wines in the world. This potpie calls out for a crisp wine, with no oakiness and plenty of lively acidity and herbal-citrus zest to cut through the richness of the filling.

headline: Librarian Lets Down Hair and Downs Many Drinks
text: The history of romantic comedies would be considerably shorter without the presence of the shy girl. You know, the mousy one who’s overlooked until that magic moment when she. ... (Insert standard plot twist leading to capture of Prince Charming.)

headline: A Concerto for a First Among Equals
text: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra is celebrating its 40th anniversary this season with a roster of new collaborators, including the jazz greats Wayne Shorter and Brad Mehldau, and the contemporary composer-performers Timothy Andres and Gabriel Kahane. But on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall this conductorless orchestra teamed up with an old friend, the pianist Richard Goode, who joined the players in a lucid performance of Schumann’s Piano Concerto.

headline: What You Didn’t Post, Facebook May Still Know
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Debra Aho Williamson, an advertising industry analyst and devoted coffee drinker, was intrigued by a promotion that popped up on her Facebook page recently. Sign up for a Starbucks loyalty card, it said, and get $5 off.

headline: Salesmen in the Surgical Suite
text: When Fred E. Taylor arrived at Harrison Medical Center in Silverdale, Wash., for a routine prostatectomy, he expected the best medical care new technology had to offer: robotic surgery, billed as safer, less painful and easier on the body than traditional surgery.

headline: The Grown-Up Behind a Tween Phenomenon
text: CHANTILLY, Va. — If you are one of those people whose lives do not include a girl under the age of 12 — and in that case, OMG I am SO SORRY for you!!! — then the “Dork Diaries,” a series for tweens that has sold over 10 million copies in less than four years, may have escaped your notice.

headline: Hearts Suffer and Crumble When Mourning the Loss of Children
text: We see Antony Tudor’s “Dark Elegies” (1937) too seldom. There are many who consider it one of the foremost dance masterpieces of the last century; for a few it’s the greatest. Though I’m not among its ardent admirers, I certainly think it’s an important, compelling and finely made piece — well worth seeing and arguing about.

headline: TimesTalks: David O. Russell
text: The film director David O. Russell speaks with The Times's Melena Ryzik about how his craft has evolved over the years.

headline: Baseball Fan Clubhouse Gets an Art Gallery
text: An art gallery in the middle of a building devoted to baseball may strike some as a culture clash, but Major League Baseball will try to change that view with the launch of the M.L.B. Fan Cave Art Gallery on April 4 in Manhattan.

headline: Caregiver for Disabled People Sues New York State
text: ALBANY — A New York State-employed caregiver for people with developmental disabilities sued the state on Monday, accusing it of retaliating against him for whistle-blowing.

headline: The Place That Makes a Riddle of Pitching
text: Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Festival Glimpses the Future of Film
text: The post-Oscar scarcity of interesting movies in theaters is relieved, as always, by New Directors/New Films, the annual spring festival presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, which continues through Sunday. It is also a place to glimpse the future of movies, as fledgling careers take wing, and new hybrid forms (of science fiction and melodrama, of documentary and personal narrative) are explored. Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, chief film critics of The New York Times, discuss this week’s highlights below.

headline: Albums by Dido, OneRepublic, Thompson Square, Tomasz Stanko
text: Dido

headline: Watching the Choreographer’s Mind Churn
text: The format of this year’s Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y requires choreographers to discuss their work, lecture-demonstration style, before the dancers perform with lights and costumes. On Friday night the choreographer Kate Weare began her weekend at the Y by explaining how hard it was for her to explain. Her creative process, she said, contains mysteries she is resistant to analyzing.

headline: Emblem3 at Irving Plaza
text: The trio, which placed fourth on “The X Factor” last year, performed at Irving Plaza on Friday night.

headline: New Onstage, but Sounding Familiar
text: The modern era of reality-TV singing competitions has been with us for just over a decade, and even though in that time they have minted a few stars — Kelly Clarkson, Carrie Underwood, Jennifer Hudson — it’s arguable that in terms of impact on the shape of pop music, they’ve served absolutely no purpose at all.

headline: Art Worth Millions, Yet No Cash for Burial
text: Family and friends gathered in Charleston, S.C., on Friday for the funeral of the New York-based artist Merton D. Simpson, a painter and pioneering champion of African art who accumulated a collection said to be worth millions of dollars. Gathering in the city of his birth, eulogists celebrated Mr. Simpson’s expertise on the saxophone, his generosity and his visionary artistic taste.

headline: NASA Engines Found, News About Squid and More
text: So few people do favors for NASA these days. So when Jeff Bezos, the Amazon.com founder, announced last week that an expedition he financed had hoisted two F-1 rocket engines from an Apollo mission off the ocean floor, the agency was understandably grateful.

headline: Hopes Outside the Supreme Court
text: Protesters and supporters explain why they are standing in freezing rain for a chance to witness hearings on same-sex marriage.

headline: Taking Safety Agency’s App for a Test Drive
text: Although it has concerns about consumers using smartphones behind the wheel, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration now has its own app.

headline: Wood Creek Adds to Music Holdings, Acquiring Concord
text: The Concord Music Group, an independent music company with an artist roster that includes Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and Creedence Clearwater Revival, has been sold to Wood Creek Capital Management, a private equity firm that has been quietly building a collection of music assets.

headline: The Emotional Lure of Prepaid College
text: MATTHEW ROGERS’S infant daughter was just weeks old when he learned that her grandfather already had plans for her.

headline: Among Young Inheritors, an Urge to Redistribute
text: MOST people would probably be quite happy to receive an inheritance. They would pay off debt, maybe their mortgage; save for retirement; take a trip or two. It would be blissful, and it would make their lives easier.

headline: After You Read the Listings, Your Agent Reads You
text: EVERY saleswoman will tell you that the customer is always transparent. Maybe not entirely, completely, but compared with the poker face a buyer thinks that he or she is wearing, there are always expressions and signals that are obvious to the practiced observer.

headline: Money Talk Before Marriage a Tip You Can’t Disparage
text: WHEN Joe, 64, a computer professional in Massachusetts, married for the first time, he was 31 and very in love.

headline: For Older Americans, a Deepening Debt Problem
text: OH, to be young and in debt.

headline: To Avoid the Biggest Investing Mistake, Stay Strong
text: IF you have been awake for the last five years, your investing experience has probably been anything but smooth. Scary markets like the one that bottomed out in March 2009 often cause us to do crazy things. This craziness may be temporary, but it doesn’t take long to make what I call the big mistake: ditching your well-designed investing plan to either buy high or sell low.

headline: Growing Up With a Trust
text: STUART LUCAS learned about his trust fund the old-fashioned way: when he was 18 and went east to Dartmouth College.

headline: Expense and Emotions in Preparing for Long-Term Care
text: ANDY SHAPIRO had never given much thought to whether he would need help with daily activities as he aged. After all, the 61-year-old software consultant figured, he kept himself in good shape.

headline: Emotion, Wild Card of Finances
text: Few topics are as emotionally charged as money.

headline: Saving for Retirement as an Act of Wild Optimism
text: WHEN I was 30, the ovarian cancer I’d had as a child returned after a 20-year hiatus. The new diagnosis arrived dramatically, when a trip to the emergency room revealed a tumor that was causing internal bleeding. During the week I spent in intensive care, my son, Leo, stopped speaking aloud and talked only in a whisper. He was almost 4.

headline: How to Set a Price on the Life of a Beloved Pet?
text: I COULDN’T begin to add up the number of times my husband and I have had the Talk. We know illness and death are two of life’s certainties. And we’ve taken care of the issue when it comes to ourselves. We’ve signed medical directives saying we want no extraordinary measures taken to extend our lives if we become incapacitated to the point that we’re a burden, emotionally and financially, to our families.

headline: A Family Manipulated by an Economic Crisis
text: There’s no need to condescend to puppets anymore.

headline: Still Bleeding, 10 Years Later
text: Chasing WarThe blades wore a darkened silver sheen, dulled at the edge. Bits of hair, dried salt-sweat and dung-powdered dirt clogged the head so that with each firm scrape, tiny beads of crimson and pus dried into little scab islands in the crease of my neck. There was no water, no cream, no electrical outlets — just a cracked Humvee mirror and the light from the rising sun. My Mach3 wouldn’t skive the glaze from a stick of butter, but still I bled.

headline: Stricter Rules but Signs of Disarray in Cyprus Deal
text: PARIS — The Cyprus deal announced Sunday, another late-night showdown in Brussels that looked like a shambles, laid down some important new markers for the future of the European Union and the countries that use the euro. The big European powers used the crisis to establish some new, more punitive rules for countries needing emergency aid.

headline: Jozy Altidore: One Down, One to Go
text: MEXICO CITY — Warmth, sunshine and clear skies. Just some of the things we all take for granted in everyday life.

headline: Mets Executive Moves to MSG
text: Dave Howard, a top executive of the Mets, is leaving Flushing for Manhattan to become the president of MSG Sports, the sports division of Madison Square Garden.

headline: Post-Mortem for Russian Finds No Sign of a Struggle

headline: Shaving Below a Man’s Neck, if That’s What She Wants

But look at magazines like Men’s Health and Men’s Fitness in recent years, and the vast majority of the shirtless cover models have polished torsos, well-defined six-pack abs and pectoral muscles.

headline: A 50-State Ruling

headline: The Killing Chain

headline: Anthony Lewis, Champion of the Law
text: My introduction to Anthony Lewis, who died on Monday at 85, came late one afternoon in 1963 in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, where I was a microscopically junior editor and he was one in a towering cast of journalistic stars assembled by James Reston, the bureau chief. It was decision day at the Supreme Court, and Tony handed me brief summaries of three or four articles he intended to write by the time his bus to suburban Virginia left at 6:30. And so, to my astonishment, he did — one big piece on the most important case; smaller ones on the others; each one crisp, learned and requiring almost nothing in the way of editorial improvement.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) TAVIS SMILEY REPORTS: EDUCATION UNDER ARREST Mr. Smiley travels to Washington State, Louisiana, Missouri and California to examine the connection between the juvenile justice system and the dropout rate among American teenagers; as many as three-quarters of those incarcerated in detention centers withdraw from high school. Along the way he speaks with educational experts on the front lines of reform, including Jimmie Edwards, a juvenile court judge and the founder of the Innovative Concept Academy in St. Louis, who believes that the zero-tolerance policy applied by some schools — under which minor infractions, including disruptive behavior, foul language and truancy, can escalate into jail time — is not the best route; and the Loyola and Tulane University law students who work for Stand Up for Each Other!, an advocacy group for children who have been expelled from school. Part 2 of “180 Days: A Year Inside an American High School,” which chronicles one year in the life of the first graduating class of Washington Metropolitan High School — a public school where only 7 percent of students are deemed proficient in math, and only 19 percent in reading — follows at 9. (Mr. Smiley, above right, with Michael Triplett, principal of the Innovative Concept Academy.)

headline: News Quiz | March 26, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: U.S.A.I.D. Administrator Rajiv Shah
text: MUMBAI— Each year, about 1.5 million children under 5 years old die in India, which has the largest number of such deaths worldwide. A majority of these deaths stem from pneumonia, diarrhea, malnutrition and complications at birth and can be prevented. In February, at the India Call to Action on Child Survival and Development Summit, India’s Ministry of Health and Family Welfare released a strategic road map to tackle preventable child deaths and introduced a National Child Survival Score Card and a dashboard to track progress on child survival and development.

headline: Bachmann Is Subject of Ethics Investigation
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, is the subject of an ethics investigation examining allegations of wrongdoing that emerged in the aftermath of her failed bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012, a lawyer for the lawmaker confirmed Monday.

headline: Agent G.M.O.
text: HO CHI MINH CITY — It’s 5 a.m. and the streets already are buzzing. People know that the best time to shop at open-air markets is before daybreak. And they know to ask for fresh, firm vegetables grown locally, rather than in China, where dangerous pesticides are routinely overused.

headline: As Scotland Turns the Page, a Lesson for Other Teams
text: When the Scottish Football Association drew up a short list of potential successors to the fired Scotland manager Craig Levein last year, the country’s news media and the team’s supporters did the same. Naturally, the lists differed, but there was one commonality: everyone linked with the vacant post was a Scot.

headline: Italy’s Highest Court Overturns Acquittal of Amanda Knox
text: ROME — Italy’s highest court on Tuesday ordered a new trial in the sensational case of Amanda Knox, an American student accused of murdering her 21-year-old roommate, Meredith Kercher of Britain, in 2007.

headline: Raising a Hindu Kid in New York
text: How do you teach your children about religion, particularly your own? Are the parents responsible for this vital task, or should they call in some outside help? It’s a question I faced when I became a parent almost five years ago.

headline: Do Millennials Stand a Chance in the Real World?
text: When I was a kid, my grandmother used to spirit packets of oyster crackers from restaurants. She unwrapped gifts meticulously, peeling back the tape with her nails so that she could reuse the paper. She also stockpiled so many coupon-bought cans that she probably could have had her own show on TLC.

headline: See the Play, Don’t Miss the Program
text: LONDON — One of the pleasures and privileges of theatergoing in London — in addition to those little wooden spoonlets that come with the interval ice cream — is the beauty of the printed theater program. Rather than the advertising-heavy publications of many cities, particularly New York, chock-full of fluffy profiles of the newest musical star and features on the favorite Thai restaurant of a chorus member of “Wicked,” a London theater program is often a quick study guide — a cheat sheet for the high-brow pop quiz of theater about to unfold.

headline: Justices Say Time May Be Wrong for Gay Marriage Case
text: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court on Tuesday weighed the momentous question of whether gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, six justices questioned whether the case, arising from a California ban on same-sex marriages, was properly before the court and indicated that they might vote to dismiss it.

headline: My Search for Reasonable and Understandable Credit Card Processing
text: I have been accepting credit cards at my business for many years. My recollection is that I first signed up to take them in 1994. During most of that time, I have used my regular business bank, PNC, to process the transactions. When I signed up for PNC’s merchant-processing services, I knew that I would be paying fees for the services, but I was wrapped up in other business issues at the time and paid little attention to the details.

headline: T-Mobile Unveils New Pricing Plan, Kind Of
text: T-Mobile has unveiled what is presumably its new pricing plan. I say presumably because the company will not confirm or deny that the plan appearing on its Web site is its new plan.

headline: The Record Keepers
text: MEXICO — Saturday, March 16, was a sad day for Mexican chefs. A group of 2,333 cooks, all dressed up in their whites, most wearing tall toques, formed a very long line along Paseo de la Reforma, in the heart of the city. But they were 511 short.

headline: In Dell, Shifting Attitude Toward Buyouts
text: IN DELL OFFERS, SHIFTING ATTITUDE TOWARD BUYOUTS  |  The battle over Dell puts into focus the question of whether management-led buyouts are in shareholders’ best interests, and it reflects a shifting ethos on Wall Street, “one that might be slightly less short-term greedy than that of previous generations,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. “It appears that some shareholders of companies involved in buyouts would prefer to ride a wave of gains alongside the buyout kings rather than cash out immediately.”

headline: Bright Passages
text: Don’t worry: the fault-finding proceeds as usual in the “In a Word” section below. But first, a small and subjective sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions. Nominations are always welcome.

headline: In Performance: Tina Packer of ‘Women of Will’
text: In “Women of Will” the actress Tina Packer, the founder and former artistic director of Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Mass., explores Shakespeare’s heroines. In this excerpt from “Henry VI, Part III,” Ms. Packer plays Queen Margaret of Anjou, who has captured the Duke of York and is about to have him killed for usurping the English crown for his children, even though Margaret’s children are the rightful heirs. The show, which also stars Nigel Gore, continues through June 2 at the Gym at Judson Memorial Church.

headline: Oral Arguments Echo in Gatherings Across Nation
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Most United States Supreme Court cases, however significant, pass largely unnoticed when they are argued. But the opening of hearings over the legal definition of marriage was a cultural moment that brought America to its front porch.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Yahoo’s Big Hire Is 17, and Anthony Lewis Dies at 85
text: Nick D’Aloisio is living the technology entrepreneur’s dream: he sold his news-reading app, Summly, to Yahoo on Monday for tens of millions of dollars and became the resurgent Web giant’s newest employee, Brian Stelter writes. The only problem is that Mr. D’Aloisio still has to finish high school; the British programmer is only 17. Mr. D’Aloisio received venture capital from high-profile investors like Yoko Ono, Wendi Murdock and Li Ka-Shing, the Hong Kong billionaire, when he was just 15. Yahoo plans to incorporate Summly, which summarizes long-form stories for smart phones, into Yahoo’s suite of mobile apps.

headline: The Unnatural Rate Hypothesis
text: When I read opinion pieces by insiders, I often find the ostensible argument less interesting than what is taken for granted. It’s the throwaway lines, the statements that obviously are meant to refer to what “everyone knows”, that can be truly revealing about the state of conventional wisdom.

text: A push for HPV vaccinations, setting a price on the life of a beloved pet, T-Mobile unveils new pricing plan (sort of) and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Cyprus Deal Sparks Anti-German Mood — and Defenders
text: LONDON — In the overheated atmosphere of the Cyprus bailout crisis, Germany has once more been portrayed as a bullying villain wielding its economic power to dominate a struggling Europe.

headline: Questions About Pet Health Care
text: Decisions about end-of-life care for pets are heart-wrenching for their owners. That’s even more so now than 10 or 20 years ago because new technology and advances in medical treatments have made their way down to pet care, meaning there are more ways to save or extend your pet’s life. But it also means more expense, if you choose to do so.

headline: What Next From North Korea?
