headline: China’s New-Style First Lady and Old-Style Fears
text: BEIJING — When Peng Liyuan, China’s glamorous, new first lady, stepped out of the Air China airplane in Moscow next to her husband on his inaugural trip abroad, an old fear stepped out too: as a woman close to power might she bring disaster on the country?

headline: The Mideast Peace Gap
text: Regarding “Bits, bytes and bombs” (Views, March 25): Thomas L. Friedman aptly criticizes Israel’s dream of permanent occupation of the West Bank — especially now with extreme annexationists in the cabinet. Of course not all Israelis have this dream, but many do, and many more wish for more continued settlement expansion beyond today’s 320,000 settlers. What is hard to square with either of these wishes is the other wish that Israel claims to have — for peace. Doubtless Israel does want peace. The important question is not whether Israel does want peace — for who doesn’t — but just how much it does.

headline: Europe Expands Investigation Into Derivatives Market
text: BRUSSELS — European Union antitrust regulators have expanded their investigation into whether a small network of big banks unfairly controls the derivatives market.

headline: Q&A: Erasing Saved Web Site Passwords
text: March 29, 2013, 4:03 p.m. | Updated  Added alternate ways to reach the Settings screen on Chrome for the Macintosh in response to reader questions.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Victoria Beckham
text: Victoria Beckham, whose eponymous fashion line was heretofore available exclusively at specialty retailers including Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and FortyFiveTen and online powerhouses Net-A-Porter and MyTheresa, is now offering e-commerce for her Victoria, Victoria Beckham label and accessories like handbags, denim and eyewear. “It’s all about modern luxury, and the ability to shop online and have anything delivered to your door is very much a modern convenience,” says Beckham. Although her mainline collection is not currently available on the site, a new collection called ICON, which Beckham created exclusively for online shoppers, will feature a selection of her iconic dresses.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Mother Jones: As long as moms and dads are getting worked up over the yellow dyes in Kraft Macaroni and Cheese, they might want to look at the product’s other ingredients. The authors here found them not that different from the stuff in Cheez-Its – which use natural coloring. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Oscar Dates Set for Next Year and 2015
text: LOS ANGELES — The Oscars will be held on March 2 next year, slightly later than this year’s Feb. 24 date, and on Feb. 22 in 2015, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said. The date for next year is the first Sunday after the end of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Woods’s Return to No. 1 Soothes Golf
text: For the traditionalists who had a tough weekend, the status quo fought back for you Monday. There were a lot of people rattled by the rise of Florida Gulf Coast and La Salle and Wichita State — you could spot them staring balefully at brackets dominated by colleges they had actually heard of — but their world grew a little brighter Monday. That is because Tiger Woods showed he could dominate golf again, returning to No. 1 after a long climb from his ignominious fall. This comforted people, unlikeable as he has become. If you cannot count on Woods scowling his way around postcard-pretty golf courses and collecting gobs of money, what can you count on in this world?

headline: Shape Up or Don’t Fly, Air India Tells Cabin Crew Over 40
text: NEW DELHI — Air India is cracking down on its cabin crew over the age of 40, who could be grounded in coming weeks if they are found to be unfit or overweight.

headline: March 26 Updates on Supreme Court Same-Sex Marriage Hearing
text: That’s a wrap for today, but we’ll be back on Wednesday with live updates from the oral arguments as the high court weighs the Defense of Marriage Act. For now, The Times’s Adam Liptak and Scott Shane report that the justices might be nervous about acting too quickly on gay marriage, and Jeremy Peters writes about the people who waited for days to witness the discussion. Don’t want the argument to end? Room for Debate has a discussion about whether gay marriage is best left to the courts or to states.

headline: Feliciano Will Stay With Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — One day after it appeared he would seek a new employer, Pedro Feliciano, one of the last links to the Mets’ playoff run in 2006, said he would stay with the team somewhere in the organization.

headline: How Opinion on Same-Sex Marriage Is Changing, and What It Means
text: The Supreme Court will hear arguments this week on two cases related to same-sex marriage, the first involving a California referendum that barred gay marriage, the other involving a federal law that prevents the government from recognizing same-sex unions. A variety of outcomes are possible, but it seems prudent to take stock of public opinion on same-sex marriage before the decisions come down.

headline: $616 Million Poorer, Hedge Fund Owner Still Buys Art
text: Less than two weeks after SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire trader Steven A. Cohen, agreed to pay the government $616 million to settle accusations of insider trading, Mr. Cohen has decided to buy a little something for himself.

headline: The Gun Report: March 26, 2013
text: Every day we cite gun death statistics culled by Slate, which has been publishing the number of gun deaths since the Newtown massacre last December. Slate’s initiative was prompted in part by the fact that the F.B.I. statistics on gun deaths are woefully outdated, and that there is a void that needs to be filled: no research organization is even trying to “create a real-time chronicle of the death attributable to guns in the United States,” as Slate puts it. How does Slate compile its information? It uses crowdsourcing techniques, relying especially on a Twitter feed, @GunDeaths, which is run by an anonymous researcher who has been tweeting every reported gun death he can find since the mass shooting in Aurora.

headline: Digging Through Mounds of Storm Debris, Seeking Recyclable Objects
text: In the weeks and months since Hurricane Sandy pummeled the New York City area, cleanup crews have hauled off thousands of tons of wreckage, much of it left on city streets by people trying to piece their lives back together.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Regrets
text: The Times’s Peter Baker on why the former president says signing the Defense of Marriage Act was a mistake.

headline: Cahill Scores … for Australia
text: In his 15-game career (so far) in Major League Soccer, Tim Cahill has scored only one goal.

headline: Goldman Amends Warrants Deal With Buffett
text: Goldman Sachs is about to join a rarefied club: the group of banks that count Warren E. Buffett as a big investor.

headline: Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles Says Its Endowment Will Reach Record Level
text: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which has been beset by financial struggles and board defections, announced Tuesday that it had been promised donations that would raise its endowment to more than $60 million, the highest in the museum’s 34-year history.

headline: Petrobras, Once Symbol of Brazil’s Oil Hopes, Strives to Regain Lost Swagger
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s oil production is falling, casting doubt on what was supposed to be an oil bonanza. Imports of gasoline are rising rapidly, exposing the country to the whims of global energy markets. Even the nation’s ethanol industry, once envied as a model of renewable energy, has had to import ethanol from the United States.

headline: In Egypt, Five Face Charges of Urging Violence in Postings
text: CAIRO — Supporters of President Mohamed Morsi on Tuesday defended an arrest warrant for five activists on charges of using social media to incite attacks against Mr. Morsi’s allies in the Muslim Brotherhood that took place last Friday.

headline: Federal Reserve Faults Citigroup Over Money Laundering Controls
text: The Federal Reserve hit Citigroup with an enforcement action on Tuesday over breakdowns in money laundering controls that threatened to allow tainted money to move through the United States.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Legalizing Aid in Dying
Image of the Day: March 26
text: Festival of Panguni Uthiram being celebrated in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Coming to New York, a Smorgasbord Auto Show
text: Arriving in Manhattan a week after the Ringling Brother and Barnum & Bailey Circus rode the rails to Brooklyn’s Barclays Center, the New York International Auto Show opens its doors just as the populace emerges from its winter isolation and spring teases an appearance — and as the car-shopping season starts to warm up. The show opens to the public on Friday and continues through April 7.

headline: Talking Talent | George C. Wolfe
text: The American playwright and director George C. Wolfe, who has won Tonys for “Angels in America: Millennium Approaches” and for “Bring in ‘da Noise/Bring in ‘da Funk,” is the director of “Lucky Guy,” opening at the Broadhurst Theater on April 1. It is the last play Nora Ephron wrote before her death last year, and stars Tom Hanks as Mike McAlary, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper journalist who covered the police beat in New York in the 1980s and ’90s. A resident of the city during those years, Wolfe was drawn to the pulse of Ephron’s script and the challenge of recreating such a dynamic time in New York’s history.

headline: The GoogaMooga Festival Will Return in May
text: The Great GoogaMooga festival of food, drink and music in Prospect Park, which drew thousands of people to its first outing last spring, will return. And there will be improvements to the festival, where general admission attendees complained last year of hourlong waits for food, drinks and bathrooms at the two-day event. Those who bought $250 tickets for Extra Mooga, the V.I.P. section of the festival, received refunds after organizers acknowledged that the experience was not commensurate with the price tag. (General admission tickets were, and will remain, free for Saturday and Sunday.)

headline: A Narrow Escape, and Lasting Guilt
text: I was a new mom at 36, and there was a lot about motherhood that terrified me. I had no experience with infants, nor did my husband,  Michael. As happy as we were to be expecting, I was filled with fear and trepidation. How on earth would I know what to do?

headline: Publishers Revel in Youthful Cruelty
text: Nobody likes a bully — but these days the book industry loves having them to kick around.

headline: A Doll Helps Disabled Women Find Their Voices
text: NEWCASTLE, England — Josephine, a life-size doll, sat on a chair in the middle of a community center in this city in northeast England.

headline: Howard Can’t Play, So He’d Prefer Not to Watch
text: LONDON – Tim Howard likely won’t be watching his United States teammates when they face Mexico in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier.

headline: Edward Bland, ‘Cry of Jazz’ Filmmaker and Composer, Dies at 86
text: Edward Bland made only one film before deciding to pursue a career as a musician, composer and arranger. And that film, “The Cry of Jazz,” a 34-minute documentary explaining jazz in the context of black history, was by his own account amateurish.

headline: D.H. Lawrence’s War Poems to Be Published, Dirty Words and All
text: Various unprintable words kept the unexpurgated “Lady Chatterley’s Lover,” D.H. Lawrence’s classic 1928 novel of sexual congress across class lines, off bookshelves for more than three decades. But who knew that words like “Salonika” and “Mesopotamia” would keep some of Lawrence’s poetry out of print until 2013?

headline: To Save the King of the Jungle, a Call to Pen Him In
text: After 35 years of field research in the Serengeti plains, Craig Packer, director of the Lion Research Center at the University of Minnesota, has lost all patience with the romance of African wilderness. Fences, he says, are the only way to stop the precipitous and continuing decline in the number of African lions.

headline: After a Series of Setbacks, a Music Collective Reopens Its Doors
text: To compare the challenges faced by the Issue Project Room, an experimental music collective in Brooklyn, to Homer’s Odyssey might be a stretch, but the challenges faced by the group certainly have all the trappings of an ancient tragedy. The recent performance of “November” — a five-hour piano performance written by Dennis Johnson — was yet another triumph for the organization, which has oscillated between progress and defeat for nearly a decade.

headline: As Supreme Court Deliberates, Jeb Bush Speaks
text: Quite a few Republicans have been announcing new stages in their “evolution” on same-sex marriage, which is being debated in the Supreme Court today and tomorrow. Senator Rob Portman of Ohio said earlier this month that he was prompted to reverse his position when he learned his son was gay – after a two-year period of reflection that included having his name floated as a potential running mate for Mitt Romney, a staunch opponent of gay marriage.

headline: If You Like ‘Horse With No Name,’  Try Band of Horses
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: For Cohen, a Big Art Deal
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager is paying $155 million for Picasso’s “Le Rêve,” according to The New York Post’s Page Six. The painting is the one that casino magnate Stephen A. Wynn accidentally — and famously — damaged with his elbow.

headline: Your Carriage, Ma’am
text: Queen Elizabeth II marking the 150th anniversary of the London Tube. Those who ride regularly can view historic posters at the Transport Museum.

headline: New Laws Ban Most Abortions in North Dakota
text: FARGO, N.D. — Gov. Jack Dalrymple of North Dakota approved the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions on Tuesday, signing into law a measure that would ban nearly all abortions and inviting a legal showdown over just how much states can limit access to the procedure.

headline: Pardon Me, Is That Rihanna in Your Purse?
text: Was I expecting too little of the Stellé Audio Couture Audio Clutch?

headline: Justices Hear Gay Marriage Arguments
text: After witnessing the same-sex marriage hearings, The Times’s Scott Shane assesses the questions posed by the Supreme Court justices.

headline: Locking Horns Where Others Might Sing ‘Kumbaya’
text: The inevitable “Portlandia” sketch about “The Real World: Portland” will probably go something like this: Jocks and cheerleaders and assorted dunderheads converge on an organic farm on the outskirts of Portland, Ore., ready for what happens when people stop being polite and start getting real. One by one, as in most contagion films, the subjects flip. Soon they’re crocheting sweaters, singing indie-rock karaoke, digging in thrift-store bins, pickling vegetables.

headline: Cancer Diagnosis: Less Can Be More
text: Dr. Peter Scardino of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center says current prostate cancer screening is painful and imprecise but vastly improving.

headline: New Ways to Assess Prostate Cancer
text: New tests that supplement the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.

headline: New Prostate Cancer Tests Could Reduce False Alarms
text: Sophisticated new prostate cancer tests are coming to market that might supplement the unreliable P.S.A. test, potentially saving tens of thousands of men each year from unnecessary biopsies, operations and radiation treatments.

headline: Hotel Partners, Strange Bedfellows
text: The parent company of the design-driven furniture maker IKEA and the untrendy Marriott International announced this month that they are teaming up to create Moxy, a chain of budget hotels across Europe, news that strikes many travelers as an odd coupling. (And inspires questions, like, will you have to put together your nightside table with an Allen wrench?)

headline: Soros to Give $1 Million to NAACP Legal Fund
text: George Soros, the billionaire financier and philanthropist, has pledged $1 million to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, the country’s leading civil rights legal advocacy group, officials there said Tuesday.

headline: Sampling Island Flavor With Amber Ales
text: Assuming the occasion does not demand fancy fare, there is very little you can’t enjoy with American amber ales. I proved that at a recent Sunday lunch. We had just spent a long weekend at the home of friends in the Grenadines, where Venita Alexander, an accomplished local cook who adds island flavor to some of her meals, made an impossible quantity of conch fritters for lunch one day. We ate them all with Hairoun, the local lager, but it could just as well have been an American amber ale. What made her fritters unusual was that she didn’t deep-fry them; rather, she used much less oil to sizzle them like pancakes. I stole her idea, replacing the conch with more easily obtained squid and adding beer (instead of milk) to my batter. FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: Detroit’s Contemporary Art Museum Finally Has a New Director
text: Detroit might not be doing so well – it was placed this month under the control of an emergency manager as it tries to stave off financial default. But its contemporary-art scene is thriving and on Tuesday the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit announced that it had selected a new director after more than a year and a half without a permanent leader. Elysia Borowy-Reeder, who was most recently the director of the Contemporary Art Museum in Raleigh, N.C., where she focused on strengthening that museum’s education programs, will take over in early April.

headline: Buyers of Long-Term Care Insurance Prefer Home Care
text: Long-term care insurance, which can help cover the cost of extended care if you’re unable to care for yourself, is something no one really wants to think about. It’s a product you buy, after all, in the hope that you will never have to use it.

headline: Bakery Owner Talks About Coping With Health Insurance Changes
text: Last week, we published a case study about Baked in the Sun, a wholesale bakery and distributor that is trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act. Starting in January, the new law requires businesses with 50 or more full-time employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. Owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, husband and wife, the company employs nearly 100 workers to bake and deliver freshly made pastries to coffee shops, hospitals and hotels in Southern California.

headline: T-Mobile Shakes Up Its Service
text: T-Mobile USA, long trailing its rivals in the cellphone industry, is trying to catch up by changing the conversation: it is selling the iPhone cheaper than the competition, and most important, customers would not have to sign a contract.

headline: Syrian Opposition Joins Meeting of Arab League
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — To the outrage of Syria’s embattled government, the opposition coalition leader formally took its vacant seat at an Arab League summit meeting on Tuesday and immediately requested broader recognition, including from the United Nations, as part of an effort to further ostracize President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Shrimp and Broccoli Rabe, Done in a Flash
text: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Rangers, Free to Spend, Don’t Spend Freely
text: Surprise, Ariz.

headline: Living in High Bridge, the Bronx
text: The neighborhood offers a mix of income-restricted and market rate properties at prices lower than in nearby Manhattan.

headline: Buffett and Goldman Scratch Each Other’s Backs
text: Goldman Sachs and Warren E. Buffett have found a way to scratch each other’s backs — again.

headline: Name to Get Its Meaning Back
text: Straddling a high point in the Bronx, High Bridge takes its name from a near-forgotten pedestrian crossing into Manhattan, closed off in the early 1970s. But in recent years, given plans to reopen the restored High Bridge next year, both it and the neighborhood have been rediscovered by growing numbers of would-be buyers and renters.

headline: Photo Replay: March 26
text: A view of the day in sports, including World Cup qualifying soccer matches in Sydney, Australia, and Amman, Jordan.

headline: States Chipping Away at Roe v. Wade
text: A number of states in recent years have passed restrictions on abortion rules that give women the right to an abortion until the fetus is viable outside the womb, usually about 24 weeks into pregnancy.

headline: Qatar Proposes $1 Billion Jerusalem Heritage Fund
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Qatar’s emir proposed on Tuesday that the Arab League create a $1 billion fund to protect the Arabic and Islamic heritage of Jerusalem, the disputed holy city that remains one of the most intractable issues in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: N.F.L. Free Agents Who Are Still Worth Signing
text: It has been an unusually soft free-agent market this year. There could be multiple reasons for that: the salary cap’s lack of growth, a deep pool of draft prospects at the same positions that are deep in free agency (defensive end, for example), a subtle leaguewide shift in the way free agents are viewed, perhaps. Whatever the case, it’s left a lot of really good buys on the market. True, every unsigned veteran has a flaw or two. (After all, there’s a reason he’s still unsigned.) But a lot of these players still have valuable attributes that can fill an important niche for a team. These unsigned veterans should not be viewed in terms of what they once were; they should be viewed in terms of what they are now. Here are 10 who are worth signing:

headline: The Dining Room at the Modern
text: Inside Danny Meyer’s eight-year-old restaurant in the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Florida Gulf Coast Point Guard Takes Turn in Spotlight
text: Florida Gulf Coast point guard Brett Comer has enjoyed tournament success before, but even then he was used to being overshadowed.

headline: Art on the Walls and on the Plates
text: WHEN MY GUEST in the Dining Room at the Modern realized he could order three courses of foie gras, he looked like somebody who had just found a $50 bill on the street. He would have extended his streak to four courses, I think, had the menu offered a foie gras dessert.

headline: Copyright Ruling Rings With Echo of Betamax
text: Before Napster and LimeWire, before Megauploads and the Pirate Bay, media companies’ epic struggle against copying, piracy and generally losing control over their creations can be traced to a legal fight more than 30 years ago over a device that has long since passed on to the great trash heap in the sky: the Sony Betamax.

headline: Does Victoria’s Secret Care That Parents Hate Pink?
text: Victoria’s Secret manufactures, markets and sells clothes and lingerie intended to make women look and feel sexy. That’s its mission (if not its formal mission statement): to sell more stuff to more people.

headline: Orchestra Turns 50, Its Youthful Fire Coming Through
text: It can be inspiring to hear standard repertory works played by young musicians discovering them for the first time. Whatever such performances may lack in assurance is usually compensated for by the involvement and freshness that comes through.

headline: In a Chinese Alley, an $8 Tasting Menu
text: Even the strictest of budget should allow for occasional splurges: a modest hotel room after a string of hostel bunks; a just-this-once late-night cab; a beer upgrade from P.B.R. to I.P.A. But some luxuries never enter the frugal equation. Take, for example, the restaurant tasting menu — those drawn-out dinners of 8 or 10 or 25 courses, exquisitely designed (and sometimes served) by the chef. Or so I’ve heard.

headline: In a Faded Wall St. Scandal, Lessons for a Current One
text: Remember Jacob Alexander? Perhaps you should. For as financial crisis prosecutions seem to fizzle out, his tale is a lesson: not only do financial scandals fade quickly from memory, but sometimes corporate executives really do pay for bad choices.

headline: Reader Idea | Discussing Junk Food With English-Language Learners
text: This week, in lieu of our own lesson plans, we’ll be publishing new entries in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: An Interview With Ken Mehlman
text: Ken Mehlman, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, discusses the arguments before the Supreme Court.

headline: Yahoo’s ‘Acqui-Hiring’ and Its Tax Implications
text: On Monday, Yahoo announced that it was buying the mobile news reader app Summly for about $30 million. Summly has a staff of five and no revenue. It was also reported Monday that Apple was buying the indoor-GPS company WifiSLAM for $20 million. That start-up, only two years old, has a handful of employees.

headline: Olivier Awards Nominations Announced
text: The Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys, announced its 2013 nominations on Tuesday, a list brimming with big names: Helen Mirren in “The Audience”; Rupert Everett in “The Judas Kiss”; Kristen Scott Thomas in “Old Times”; and Mark Rylance, a two-time Olivier winner, in an all-male production of “Twelfth Night.”

headline: Tax-Abatement Changes Affect Many Unit Owners
text: Tens of thousands of co-op and condominium owners across New York City are facing a tax increase this year after the recent tweak of tax-abatement regulations.

headline: One on One: Nolan Bushnell, Video Game Legend and Steve Jobs’s Boss
text: There are a lot of highlights to Nolan Bushnell’s career – he was a founder of Atari, the pioneering video game company, as well as of the Chuck E. Cheese’s Pizza Time Theater chain – but one of the more glorious footnotes is that he was one of Steven P. Jobs’s first and only bosses.

headline: The Dell Deal Scorecard
text: With three suitors now in the mix for Dell Inc., it can be a little tough remembering who’s offering what and who’s working with whom. We’re here to help.

headline: FIFA Dismisses Costa Rica Appeal
text: Quicker than it takes snow to melt, FIFA on Tuesday dismissed Costa Rica’s protest of last Friday’s match against the United States that was played in a snowstorm in Commerce City, Colo. The U.S. won, 1-0.

headline: First Woman Is Chosen to Lead Secret Service
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday appointed Julia A. Pierson, a longtime Secret Service agent, as the first woman to head the agency best known for protecting the president, vice president and their families.

headline: To Join This Club, Be a Star
text: Chefs Club, a showcase for culinary stars, is having its initial run in Aspen, Colo. But like many a big production, it’s headed for a New York opening.

headline: Son and Lawyer Lose Appeal in Looting of Astor Estate
text: More than three years after they were convicted of looting the estate of Brooke Astor, her son and a lawyer for the estate lost a significant appeal on Tuesday, moving them much closer to being forced to serve their prison sentences.

headline: Congolese Rebel Commander Tells War Crimes Court He Was Just ‘a Soldier’
text: PARIS — Bosco Ntaganda, the rebel commander in the Democratic Republic of Congo with a reputation for extreme brutality, did not live up to his nickname “The Terminator” on Tuesday when he appeared for the first time at the International Criminal Court on charges of rape, murder, sexual slavery and using children as soldiers.

headline: War on the Heels of a Wedding
text: I remember exactly where I was when American troops invaded Iraq. I was in a newsroom in Fayetteville, N.C., which was closer to war than I ever imagined I would be.

headline: In Cyprus, Big Losses Expected on Deposits
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With time running out until Cyprus’s devastated banks must reopen their doors to the public, Cypriot and European officials are scrambling to put in place a set of measures that would allow jittery depositors access to their savings while preventing many billions of euros from fleeing the country.

headline: Crystal Bowersox to Play Patsy Cline on Broadway
text: Crystal Bowersox, the runner-up on the 2010 edition of “American Idol,” will play Patsy Cline on Broadway this summer in a new production of the musical “Always … Patsy Cline,” a tribute show featuring classic songs performed by the country singer like “Crazy,” “Walkin’ After Midnight” and “I Fall to Pieces,” the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner

headline: Polls Show Consistent Gains in Support for Same-Sex Marriage
text: With the Supreme Court hearing arguments on Tuesday about the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the 2008 California ban on same-sex marriage, a number of recent polls show that a majority of Americans support legalizing it.

headline: Light as a Feather, Hard as a Brick: Harsh Realities at Warp Speed
text: Twenty-six years ago the Belgian choreographer Wim Vandekeybus founded a company called Ultima Vez and staged his first work, “What the Body Does Not Remember.” The piece made a splash, earning acclaim for its aggressive physicality and brutal confrontations. Now it’s on an anniversary tour, and at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts this past weekend, as part of Pace Presents, it still made waves.

headline: Steinway to Sell Its Famed Showroom Building
text: Steinway Hall, the 88-year-old building down the block and across the street from Carnegie Hall where generations of famous and not-so-famous pianists have tried out pianos, is being sold, the piano company and the buyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: High-Tech Bike Helmets and Great Swedish Words
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Same-Sex Marriage
text: The court considered Hollingsworth v. Perry, a case challenging California’s ban of same-sex marriage, on Tuesday.

headline: Key Moments From the Hearing on Proposition 8
text: Times reporters offered analysis of the hearing, with audio excerpts, over the constitutionality of California’s law banning same-sex marriage.

headline: Cyprus, Seriously
text: A correspondent whom I respect has (gently) challenged me to say plainly what I think Cyprus should do — leaving aside all questions about political realism. And he’s right: while I think it’s OK to spend most of my time on this blog working within the limits of the politically possible, and relying on a combination of reason and ridicule to push out those limits over time, once in a while I should just flatly state what I would do if given a chance.

headline: A Poet in Hiking Boots (Not the Happy Wanderer)
text: One of the surprise best sellers of 1998 was “A Walk in the Woods,” Bill Bryson’s account of five months slogging it along the Appalachian Trail. His book made many readers want to hike that route themselves, which bewildered me.

headline: Rabbi Herschel Schacter Is Dead at 95; Cried to the Jews of Buchenwald: ‘You Are Free’
text: The smoke was still rising as Rabbi Herschel Schacter rode through the gates of Buchenwald.

headline: Pushback on Nike Ad Celebrating Woods
text: On one hand, Nike’s exuberance over Tiger Woods rising again to No. 1 in the world is understandable. The company stood by Woods through his infidelity-fueled fall from grace — unlike dumping the likes of the cyclist Lance Armstrong and the runner Oscar Pistorius for far more serious offenses — and quietly waited for their superstar to start winning again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, South Korea and Afghanistan.

headline: Entrances and Exits, Now Erased
text: When you say “Band X played at Madison Square Garden,” the second half of the sentence is at least as important as the first. A concert there is a moment for Band X to make a statement that is philosophically incontestable, full of territory marking and implied significance: I am here now.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Graze: Evenings Meant for Snacking

headline: Plans for Ground Zero Arts Hub Shift Again
text: And then there were none.

headline: Middle-Aged, Yet a Prince, Slouching but Haunted
text: NEW HAVEN — “To be or not to be,” Shakespeare’s immortal head-scratcher, obviously does not vaporize into irrelevance as you grow older. It may burn with raging persistence when you’re a college student philosophizing with your dorm mates late into the night, but the question settles more deeply in the soul as the years pass and life’s trials pile up. To hear it posed by Paul Giamatti, in the Yale Repertory Theater production of “Hamlet” here, is to be reminded that slings and arrows can find their mark no matter your age, and that pushing through them may only get tougher.

headline: Writer, and Bird Lover, at Center of a Dispute About Cats Is Reinstated
text: Nature can be harsh and unforgiving; so, too, can nature writing.

headline: This Week’s Links
text: This is a weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Off the Eaten Path
text: Pete Wells explores the tastes of Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Composers Explain Whys and Wherefores
text: What compels a composer to write a piece? Presumably there are as many answers to that question as there are composers to ask. On Monday evening at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music four of the five composers whose works were being played in a concert by the American Modern Ensemble took turns answering during an onstage interview midway through the show.

headline: DLA Piper Calls E-Mails Cited in Lawsuit an ‘Offensive’ Attempt at Humor
text: After a lawsuit involving the billing practices of DLA Piper, the law firm on Tuesday issued a memo to its lawyers, calling language in e-mails written by its lawyers “unprofessional.”

headline: Instagram and the New Era of Paparazzi
text: Earlier this week, a rare and new photo of the pop star Beyoncé and her daughter, Blue Ivy, quickly spread around the Internet, on various celebrity and gossip sites.

headline: A Sleek Office Building Rises Over Gritty Astor Place
text: For decades, the jobs associated with Astor Place in the East Village usually involved selling Beat Generation paperbacks on a blanket on a sidewalk or, maybe, inking tattoos.

headline: An Investor Adjusts His Ambitions
text: For many observers of the arcane world of commercial real estate investment, Scott Lawlor became a tarnished emblem for the aggressive investors who poured other people’s money into major office buildings at the height of the market, driving values into the stratosphere until the bubble burst.

headline: Smooth Operators Slink Into the Desolate Night
text: Watching “Welcome to the Punch” I kept hoping for clowns, the inflatable kind that you sock in the head and that bounce back again and again — or maybe a couple of pugilists with tragic faces and Michelangelo musculature. While this curiously titled, intently self-serious British cops-and-robbers showdown doesn’t feature any clowns, it does include plenty of mano-a-mano action and a clutch of presumably unintended laughs. This isn’t a warning. It’s a recommendation.

headline: Treasures on Every Block
text: RED HOOK IS A STRANGE PLACE to choose for a day trip. The nearest subway stop isn’t near at all, and it’s closed for repairs until next month at least. Driving to Van Brunt Street, the main drag, means a turbulent ride on 19th-century Belgian-block roads that are apt to end with no warning. None of the restaurants are on a fast track to the World’s 50 Best, and none of the food businesses, except perhaps Fairway Market, can be called a destination.

headline: Debate Over Music Piracy Writ Large, on Billboard
text: Plenty of unknown musicians start arguments over online piracy. Few get the chance to do so on a 15,000-square-foot video billboard overlooking Times Square.

headline: NBC Lures Back Viewers With ‘The Voice’ and ‘Revolution’
text: NBC had a lot riding on the comeback of its twin hits from the fall — “The Voice” and “Revolution” — with “The Voice,” in particular, taking a big chance by coming back for a second arc in the same season (no singing competition had done that before) and with a new lineup of judges.

headline: Ross Adam Cole
text: Mr. Cole, 50, is a founder and a principal of BAM Architecture Studio, a design firm based in New York whose focus has been in the entertainment and health care industries. Mr. Cole started the firm in 2000 with his wife, Pamela J. Cole, and Brian Spence.

headline: Yankees Sign Overbay to Minor League Deal
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees’ seemingly unending pursuit of castoffs continued Tuesday when Vernon Wells showed up in camp and just an hour later they signed first baseman Lyle Overbay to a minor league deal.

headline: Pro-Obama Group Details Fund-Raising and Policy Goals
text: New details are emerging about the ambitious financial goals of Organizing for Action, the tax-exempt group created by former Obama campaign operatives to advance the president’s agenda.

headline: A Plan of Attack for the Urban Antique Hunter
text: Stepping into a Jack Spade store, you might wonder who the fabulous, well-traveled gent was who lived there. The clothing store pulls off a deft, eclectic, lived-in look: classic midcentury armchairs, salvaged-wood tables, a quirky collection of salt figurines amid the clothing.

headline: CBS Acquires 50% Stake in Former TV Guide Network
text: CBS announced on Tuesday that it had completed a deal to buy a half-interest in TVGN, formerly the TV Guide Network, fulfilling a longstanding goal of adding a general entertainment basic cable network to the company’s media portfolio.

headline: Reproductive Restrictions Accelerated
text: Cecile Richards, president of Planned Parenthood, reacts to new laws that nearly eradicate abortion rights in North Dakota.

headline: Admiral at Center of Inquiry Is Censured by Navy
text: The Navy on Monday officially disciplined the admiral who had commanded a carrier strike group until being abruptly removed from the position last fall while the vessels patrolled the North Arabian Sea.

headline: A Marriage Born Where Tables for 2 Women Were Common
text: Among many Italian restaurants around Greenwich Village in the early 1960s, Portofino was known for celebrity-spotting, a relaxed atmosphere and dinners that were abundant but affordable.

headline: Shopping Shapshots: March 28
text: Atlanta de Cadenet Taylor, daughter of the photographer Amanda de Cadenet and John Taylor of Duran Duran, has fashion and music in her DNA; Cargo pants are even more relaxed this time around; and more shopping snapshots.

headline: A Top Agency Expands Its Social Footprint
text: ONE of the largest agencies on Madison Avenue, McCann Erickson New York, is ramping up its efforts in social media to reflect the rapidly growing interest among marketers in reaching consumers through platforms like Facebook, Pinterest, Tumblr, Twitter and blogs.

headline: A Mortgage Practice Gets a Closer Look by Regulators
text: WASHINGTON — Among the conditions imposed on most people who borrow money to buy a house, maintaining property insurance is one of the most common. If a borrower lets such a policy lapse, the lender will often protect its investment by purchasing a policy and billing the homeowner for it.

headline: McIlroy Has a Change of Scenery and of Mind-Set
text: During his week off in Key Biscayne, Fla., Rory McIlroy practiced at a public course. It was not quite like the tennis star Novak Djokovic’s hitting on a neighborhood court surrounded by a chain-link fence, with grass growing out of the cracks in the concrete. Crandon Park Golf Course, where McIlroy made himself at home, has been ranked one of the top public courses by various golf publications.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Founder of Yoga Empire of Misconduct
text: A former student has sued Bikram Choudhury, the millionaire founder of a wildly popular yoga franchise, accusing him of sexual harassment, discrimination and defamation.

headline: Kerry Hears Afghan Fears From Women in Business
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After meeting again with the leader who is at the top of the Afghan pyramid, Secretary of State John Kerry paid a visit on Tuesday to a group of women who have managed to make their way in male-dominated Afghan society.

headline: The Fine Print on T-Mobile’s New No-Contract Cellphone Plans

headline: Officials to Review Immigrants’ Solitary Confinement
text: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Tuesday that she had asked federal immigration officials to provide her with more information about immigrants being held in solitary confinement at federal facilities.

headline: Europeans Planted Seeds of Crisis in Cyprus
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — When European finance chiefs explained their harsh terms for rescuing Cyprus this week, many blamed the tiny Mediterranean nation’s wayward banking practices for bringing ruin on itself.

headline: Monsanto and DuPont Settle Fight Over Patent Licensing
text: Monsanto and DuPont, which have bitterly battled for dominance in the seed business, have settled their major disputes with a broad patent-licensing deal.

headline: A Rookie Unheralded, Undrafted and Unfazed
text: Cory Conacher is a 5-foot-8 center in a league that still looks askance at small players. He played four years at Canisius College, which had never sent a player to the N.H.L. Undrafted, he tried out with three minor league teams before signing a pro contract. He has Type 1 diabetes. Yet there he is, racing all over the ice for the Tampa Bay Lightning and becoming the N.H.L.’s top rookie scorer this season.

headline: South Dakota Senator Won’t Run Again
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Tim Johnson, the South Dakota Democrat who suffered a major brain hemorrhage a month after his party retook the Senate in 2006 and recovered enough to run again two years later, announced Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2014.

headline: Slow Food Quickens the Pace
text: AMSTERDAM — It may be that Slow Food’s original focus on taste and the quality of food — on gastronomy — simply seemed too narrow, and therefore elitist. But at least since its “Puebla Declaration” [1]in 2007, Slow Food has become a force to be reckoned with, probably the only international organization that integrates concerns about the environment, tradition, labor, health, animal welfare … along with real cooking, taste and pleasure.

headline: Quinn Is Said to Be in Talks Over Sick Time
text: Her stance on the issue has been loudly booed at public forums, picked over in newspaper editorials and derided at weekly news conferences by a leading rival in the race for mayor.

headline: Clothes Make the Coach, Whatever He Says
text: LOS ANGELES — For college basketball coaches, N.C.A.A. tournament preparation extends beyond white boards and practices and game strategy. This advance work is less about their preferred style of play and more about their preferred style of dress.

headline: New Mexico Farmers Seek ‘Priority Call’ as Drought Persists
text: CARLSBAD, N.M. — Just after the local water board announced this month that its farmers would get only one-tenth of their normal water allotment this year, Ronnie Walterscheid, 53, stood up and called on his elected representatives to declare a water war on their upstream neighbors.

headline: Group of Emerging Nations Plans to Form Development Bank
text: JOHANNESBURG — A group of five emerging world economic powers met in Africa for the first time Tuesday, gathering in South Africa for a summit meeting at which they plan to announce the creation of a new development bank, a direct challenge to the dominance of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Bloomberg Seeks End to Cheap Cigarettes
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened a new front in his antismoking campaign last week when he proposed new legislation that would require stores to keep tobacco products out of sight, making New York the first city in the nation to do so.

headline: Parts of Low Country Are Now Quake Country
text: LOPPERSUM, the Netherlands — Jannes Kadyk’s modest brick home suffered more than $5,000 in damage. Bert de Jong’s more stately home will need about $500,000 to get back into shape.

headline: H.G.H. Case Could Affect N.F.L. Talks
text: The Court of Arbitration for Sport on Tuesday questioned the reliability of limits set for positive tests for human growth hormone, which could complicate N.F.L. negotiations to establish an H.G.H. testing program for players.

headline: Italy’s Foreign Minister Resigns Over Marine Case
text: ROME — Foreign Minister Giulio Terzi resigned Tuesday over the government’s decision to return two Italian marines to India to stand trial for killing two local fishermen in a case that has soured diplomatic ties between the countries.

text: A squabble between a group fighting spam and a Dutch company that hosts Web sites said to be sending spam has escalated into one of the largest computer attacks on the Internet, causing widespread congestion and jamming crucial infrastructure around the world.

headline: Rebel Chief Suspends Constitution for 3 Years
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The leader of the rebel group that seized power in the Central African Republic, Michel Djotodia, announced Monday that he was suspending his country’s Constitution, dissolving its Parliament and initiating a three-year “consensual transition.”

headline: Querrey’s Loss Completes a U.S. Shutout
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Sam Querrey helped create a first on Tuesday at the Sony Open, but not the way he would have liked.

headline: Good Friends, Same Party but Legal Opponents
text: WASHINGTON — In the conference room at the Justice Department’s august Office of Legal Counsel, portraits of Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper hang side by side. Both men headed the office under President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, with Mr. Cooper succeeding Mr. Olson. Both went on to stellar legal careers on the conservative side of Washington’s divided political universe.

headline: In Japan, a Portrait of Mistrust
text: Two years after a tsunami and nuclear meltdown in Fukushima, Japan, the filmmaker Itai Keshet presents a documentary portrait of public fear, mistrust and suspicion about the safety of food.

headline: ‘In Japan, a Portrait of Mistrust’
text: Two years after a huge earthquake, giant tsunami and nuclear meltdown ravaged parts of Japan, life has only seemingly returned to normal. Authorities say that outside the evacuation zone in Fukushima, there is at most a very low amount of radioactive contamination — that everything is safe. But after the tragedy, many citizens ask themselves if they can believe the government.

headline: 3 Officers, Prolific at Stops, Will Get Their Say at Trial
text: One officer described how car thieves might pretend to be beggars, sifting through curbside trash. “If someone is in the middle of a dark street, staring into the car and then when we drive by, they start ripping up garbage bags,” the police officer, Michael Noboa, said, “that would give me reasonable suspicion to conduct a stop, question” and possibly frisk.

headline: Berezovsky’s Death Is Unlikely to Be Mourned in Russia
text: MOSCOW — At the end of his extravagant, intrigue-filled and ultimately solitary life, Boris A. Berezovsky, the post-Soviet robber baron who was the consummate Kremlin insider before he became a detested outcast, wondered if he would have been better off had he never fled Russia for England, if he had been thrown in jail like his fellow oligarch-turned-inmate, the oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, another antagonist of President Vladimir V. Putin who remains in a northern Russia prison camp.

headline: Jeter Confirms Stint on Disabled List
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter finally acknowledged the sobering reality Tuesday that he will start the season on the disabled list, forcing him to miss his first opening day game since 2001.

headline: Caution, Curves Ahead
text: There are mounting reports that the U.S. is getting more deeply involved in supporting the Syrian rebels trying to topple President Bashar al-Assad. There is a strong argument for everyone doing more to end the Syrian civil war before the Syrian state totally collapses and before its sectarian venom and refugees further destabilize Lebanon, Iraq and Jordan. But I hope that before President Obama gets more deeply involved in Syria, he gets satisfactory answers to the following questions:

headline: China: Vietnam Alleges Attack
text: Tensions between China and Vietnam sharpened Tuesday after Vietnam said that a Chinese vessel fired flares and damaged a Vietnamese fishing vessel last Wednesday in a disputed area of the South China Sea. Vietnam said it had lodged a formal complaint with China and asked for an investigation and compensation for the damaged vessel, which was fishing in a region claimed by both countries. The episode was the latest in a series of disputes between China and some of its neighbors in the South China Sea. In Beijing on Tuesday, a Chinese government spokesman did not say whether a government ship had fired flares but said that any action taken was “necessary and justified.” China said that the territory near the Paracel Islands is clearly Chinese and that the Vietnamese boat was fishing illegally. China also denied the vessel suffered damage.

headline: Sales Tax Fairness
text: At long last, Congress may finally be ready to pass a bill allowing states to require online retailers to collect sales taxes. Under federal law, which largely predates the Internet, online retailers are required to collect sales tax only if they have a physical presence in the customer’s state. That lets many online retailers off the hook for sales-tax collection, giving them an unfair advantage over bricks-and-mortar stores and depriving states of an estimated $11 billion in annual sales-tax revenue.

headline: Picking New York’s State Soil? Not So Fast
text: ALBANY — If ever there was a process that should have been as dull as dirt, it was the naming of New York’s state soil.

headline: Gen. Musharraf Returns
text: Gen. Pervez Musharraf has returned to Pakistan, proclaiming an intention to “save” his country. If there is anyone capable of saving Pakistan, he is not it.

headline: State Tells Investors That Climate Change May Hurt Its Finances
text: ALBANY — In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has started to caution investors that climate change poses a long-term risk to the state’s finances.

headline: Down to the Wire
text: We are now approaching the 11th hour for an international treaty intended to keep conventional weapons out of the hands of unscrupulous regimes, militants and criminals. Negotiators at the United Nations are supposed to complete the document by Thursday, but they are still battling over what many governments and arms-control activists consider serious flaws.

headline: Justices, Citing Ban on Unreasonable Searches, Limit Use of Drug-Sniffing Dogs
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday limited the ability of the police to use drug-sniffing dogs outside homes.

headline: The California Marriage Case
text: Before the Supreme Court justices turned to the merits of the case on Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage, they seemed perplexed by a procedural issue: whether the petitioners had legal standing to appeal a lower-court ruling that struck down the ballot measure. Having taken the appeal, they cannot easily decide to avoid the substantive question of whether same-sex couples have a constitutionally protected right to marry in California and elsewhere in the country.

headline: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. vs. Mexico at the Azteca
text: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann made only two changes to his lineup for Tuesday night’s World Cup qualifier at Mexico, inserting Sporting Kansas City’s Matt Besler in central defense and Maurice Edu in the midfield.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Faces Full-Court Press of Federal Investigations

Not to worry, though; we’ll be stopping at all floors as we proceed. Please keep your limbs out of the way of the doors, and face to the front of the blog.

headline: Legislature Set to Pass Budget and Extend On-Time Streak to 3rd Year

And this week, after weeks of haggling with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the State Legislature is poised to approve it.

headline: Plan to Allow Investment in 2 Hospitals Is Dropped
text: A proposal to allow for-profit investment in two hospitals in New York State has been dropped from the budget, an unexpected setback to a push to open health care systems to private investors for the first time.

headline: Musician’s Cry: Take the Lien Off, Landlord
text: KINGSTON, N.Y. — In the decade that Michael Piazza has been a landlord in this small Hudson Valley city, he has dealt with only a handful of nonpaying tenants.

headline: Knicks Poised to Take Celtics’ Crown
text: BOSTON — It will be at least another month, perhaps in a first-round playoff series, before declarations can be made, or conclusions drawn, or torches passed — or wrested away. After five years of pre-eminence, the Boston Celtics have at least earned a withholding of judgment until the games really matter.

headline: Massachusetts: Bulger Trial Will Proceed on Schedule
text: The new judge in the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, the Boston gangster, held her first hearing with lawyers for Mr. Bulger and government prosecutors on Tuesday, and said that the trial would begin on June 10, as scheduled by her predecessor. The new judge, Denise J. Casper of Federal District Court, was assigned the case this month after an appeals court removed Judge Richard G. Stearns because his previous career as a federal prosecutor was found by a federal appeals court to feed the perception of bias in his handling of the case. Mr. Bulger faces a sweeping racketeering indictment that charges him with involvement in 19 murders. Lawyers on both sides of the case said Tuesday that they expect the trial to last through the summer.

headline: Indiana: Voucher Program Ruled Constitutional
text: The Indiana Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the state’s two-year-old school voucher program allowing low- and middle-income families to use public funds to attend private schools was constitutional. In a 5-to-0 decision, the court said that the voucher program did not violate the state’s prohibition against using state funds to benefit religious institutions because the primary beneficiaries of the vouchers were the families who used them. Since the state legislature enacted the voucher program, about 9,000 families have taken advantage, and the vast majority are sending their children to parochial schools. Glenda Ritz, Indiana superintendent of public instruction, said she was disappointed in the court’s decision. “I personally believe that public dollars should go to public schools,” she said in a statement.

headline: The Fight for Water in New Mexico
text: The drought-fueled anger of southeastern New Mexico’s farmers and ranchers is boiling, and there is nowhere near enough water in the desiccated Pecos River to cool it down.

headline: ‘Oh, Boy’: More Woes for Mets’ Pitching Staff
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The adjective snakebit is usually applied to teams on an unlucky streak during the season. In the Mets’ case, it could be applied to their spring training.

headline: Shore Rebuilding, Renters Go South for Summer
text: ORTLEY BEACH, N.J. — In a typical summer, Terriann and Joseph LoVerde’s rental here makes for a listing a real estate broker called a real moneymaker.

headline: If This Were 2006, Yanks Would Be in Great Shape
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Inside the Yankees’ clubhouse Tuesday afternoon, parallel universes swirled about each other. While the injured stars that have helped the Yankees make the playoffs the last three years tended to their wounds, the new veterans who were brought in at the last moment to replace them embraced each other.

headline: A New Range Rover Sport Arrives With 007 at the Wheel

headline: Jason Molina, a Balladeer of Heartbreak, Dies at 39
text: Jason Molina, an influential singer-songwriter whose relentlessly sad lyrics and clear and urgent tenor defined the two alternative bands he led, the lo-fi Songs: Ohia and the only slightly more energetic Magnolia Electric Co., died on March 16 at his home in Indianapolis. He was 39.

headline: Lori March, ‘Secret Storm’ Actress, Dies at 90
text: Lori March, who reigned as the matriarch of the long-running daytime television drama “The Secret Storm” for 13 years, died on March 19 in Redding, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Final Outing a Little Shaky, Sabathia Says He’s Ready for Opener
text: TAMPA, Fla. — C.C. Sabathia made his final spring training start Tuesday and it was not very convincing. His slider flat early, Sabathia gave up three runs in the first inning four over all in five innings, including a home run to Brandon Barnes.

headline: Virgil Trucks, Who Threw 2 No-Hitters in 1952, Dies at 95
text: Virgil Trucks, a flame-throwing right-hander who tossed two no-hitters for the 1952 Detroit Tigers, a team that finished in last place, died on Saturday in Alabaster, Ala. He was 95.

headline: Train Kills Youth on Subway Track
text: A teenager was fatally struck by a No. 2 subway train on Tuesday when he jumped off the platform and tried to dash across the tracks with another teenager, the police said. The other youth made it across.

headline: Battered and Beaten, Celtics Play as if Best Days Are Behind Them
text: BOSTON — A fifth straight defeat, even at home to the hated Knicks, somehow seemed almost preordained for what remains of the Boston Celtics these days. Coach Doc Rivers drew up his 17th starting lineup Tuesday night — and then watched his injury-ravaged team drop a 100-85 decision to the Knicks, the Celtics’ 11th — and worst — home defeat of the season.

headline: The Rise of the Well-Dressed Man
text: Designer fashion is no longer just for gay men and Europeans. Welcome to the age of sartorial enlightenment, in which the average male has shed schlumpiness for style.

headline: Easing Brain Fatigue With a Walk in the Park
text: Scientists have known for some time that the human brain’s ability to stay calm and focused is limited and can be overwhelmed by the constant noise and hectic, jangling demands of city living, sometimes resulting in a condition informally known as brain fatigue.

headline: As Apps Race to Car Dashes, Walking a Line on Safety
text: SEATTLE — Nestled in the driver’s seat of a Mini, one of the stylish, pint-sized coupes, Bryan Trussel fiddled with an app called Glympse that allows people to share their locations with others for short periods.

headline: BMW Thinks Small With a 3-Cylinder Engine
text: The hatchback looked like a production Euro-spec 1 Series BMW. On the roads around company headquarters in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., it drove like one, too. But the car is a work in progress, a prototype powered by BMW’s new 1.5-liter 3-cylinder gasoline engine, which next year will go into the i8 plug-in hybrid.

headline: For U.S., Tie in Mexico Feels a Lot Like Victory
text: MEXICO CITY — It is one thing to defeat Mexico at Estadio Azteca in a friendly match, as the United States did last summer. It is something much more vital and rewarding to forge a tie in a World Cup qualifying match, as the Americans did with a 0-0 draw on Tuesday night.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 2:15 P.M. (Comedy Central) POOTIE TANG (2001) Lance Crouther is Pootie Tang, a modern-day renaissance man whose talent, we’re told, in the fields of music, film, martial arts and pottery are exceeded only by his skills in crime fighting, in this comedy written and directed by Louis C. K. Pootie Tang uses these powers for good, battling drug dealers and corporations with the support of his friends, J. B. (Chris Rock), Trucky (J B Smoove) and Biggie Shorty (Wanda Sykes). “ ‘Pootie Tang’ may be raw and slovenly — hey, it often is raw and slovenly — but it succeeds as a laugh getter because of the spot on satirical notes,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “You might say that the movie walks it like it talks it; I’m not sure what Pootie would say.” (Above, from left, Mr. Rock, Mr. Smoove, Mr. Crouther and Mario Joyner.)

headline: As Media Deal in Taiwan Collapses, Political Fallout Lingers
text: HONG KONG — Today was the deadline for two liberal publications in Taiwan to be sold off to investors who favor stronger ties with mainland China, a deal that alarmed many in Taiwan who are suspicious of the current government’s warming ties with Beijing.

The seas around Hong Kong draw vessels from all over the world and thousands arrive every year.

text: In “Watch Out for the Horses on Your Way to the Train,” Melena Ryzik writes about a dance piece to be performed this week.

Visiting small villages and overcoming barriers of language and distrust, he documented the tales of women — some barely teenagers — who had been forced into sexual slavery during World War II by the Japanese Army.

headline: The Ruptured Disc Solution

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: North Korea Cuts Off the Remaining Military Hot Lines With South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea cut off the last remaining military hot lines with South Korea on Wednesday, accusing President Park Geun-hye of South Korea of pursuing the same hard-line policy of her predecessor that the North blamed for a prolonged chill in inter-Korean relations.

headline: The Generosity of Key and Peele
text: To illustrate the work of Adam Grant and his theories on the benefits of helping others, we asked the comedy duo Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele to demonstrate the art of workplace altruism.

headline: My Search for a Credit Card Processor, Part 2
text: At the conclusion of Tuesday’s post, I had just applied for cheaper credit card processing from Emerald World, and I had received an unsettling phone call about the status of my application. The events I am about to describe took place in June 2012, at a time when my business was experiencing a sales slump. We were about to come out of it, but I didn’t know that at that time. Cash was tight, and the prospect of saving money on my credit card processing was very attractive.

headline: Is Giving the Secret to Getting Ahead?

headline: Daily Report: Dispute on Spam Stirs Big Assault on the Internet
text: A squabble between a group fighting spam and a Dutch company that hosts Web sites said to be sending spam has escalated into one of the largest computer attacks on the Internet, causing widespread congestion and jamming crucial infrastructure around the world, John Markoff and Nicole Perlroth write on Wednesday in The New York Times.

headline: British Banks Told to Raise $38 Billion in Capital
text: LONDON — British banks must raise a combined £25 billion, or $38 billion, in new capital by the end of the year to protect against future financial shocks, according to a report on Wednesday from the country’s authorities.

headline: Subways Pay
text: Here’s an interesting new working paper: Subways, Strikes, and Slowdowns. Unfortunately, there doesn’t seem to be an ungated version. But here’s the summary: the author argues that mass transit has a significant impact in reducing traffic congestion, even when it carries only a small fraction of commuters. Why? Because commuters who take mass transit are, very disproportionately, people who would otherwise be driving on the most congested routes. So even the small number of people taken off the roads has a surprisingly large effect in reducing travel delays.

headline: Myanmar Jarred by Peace Laureate at Military Parade
text: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s military asserted its role in the country’s politics at a ceremony on Wednesday that featured a prominent guest, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, whose presence among the generals would have been unthinkable a few years ago.

headline: British Regulator Fines Prudential Over Lack of Deal Disclosure
text: As Prudential of Britain was planning an ambitious $35.5 billion bid for one of Asia’s biggest life insurers three years ago, the company was worried about details of its deal leaking to the outside world.

headline: Debt and Devaluation, Mediterranean Edition
text: When I talk about Cyprus and the possibility of leaving the euro, one immediate question people raise is what about the government’s debt, which is of course in euros. Wouldn’t an exit make that debt unsupportable, and force default?

headline: JPMorgan’s Friction With Washington
text: JPMORGAN’S FRICTION WITH WASHINGTON  |  It was not long ago that JPMorgan Chase and its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, held special sway in Washington. But that status may be fading, as the bank “increasingly finds itself in the cross hairs of federal authorities,” Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

headline: A Look at the Issues in the Defense of Marriage Act Case
text: WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear almost two hours of arguments on Wednesday morning over the constitutionality of a part of the federal Defense of Marriage Act of 1996. Here is a look at the background of the case, United States v. Windsor, No. 12-307; the issues it raises; the lawyers who will argue it; and the possible outcomes.

headline: Nomura Hires Former Bank of America Merrill Lynch Banker
text: HONG KONG—Nomura has hired a former high-ranking investment banker at Bank of America Merrill Lynch to serve as the Japanese bank’s new head of equities for Asia excluding Japan, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook.

headline: Tour of ‘Thrones’
text: With “Game of Thrones” set to return for its third season on March 31, the cast and producers recently undertook a promotional tour of the West Coast.

headline: Soaring Like Dragons
text: LOS ANGELES — In the time that Peter Dinklage has portrayed the cunning nobleman Tyrion Lannister on the HBO fantasy series “Game of Thrones,” he has calculated his way out of life-or-death situations, led victorious armies on battlefields and won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his work. But he had never been to a gala premiere for “Game of Thrones,” because HBO had never held one.

headline: Kurdish New Year’s Resolutions
text: ISTANBUL — Last Thursday was the start of the Kurdish New Year and, if all goes according to plan, the advent of a new era in Turkey’s relationship with its own Kurdish population. In Diyarbakir, the largest city in southeastern Turkey, a few hundred thousand people converged to listen to a proclamation, read — first in Turkish, then in Kurdish — on behalf of Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned founder of the Kurdistan Workers Party, also known as P.K.K.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Publishers Tackle Bullies, and Columnist Sparks Cat vs. Bird Dispute
text: The publishing industry has taken a real shine to bullies of late, Leslie Kaufman writes. According to World Cat, a catalog of library collections worldwide, the number of English-language books tagged with the key word “bullying” in 2012 was 1,891, an increase of 500 in a decade. Several publishing houses, including Random House, Simon & Schuster and Harlequin, have even started antibullying campaigns pegged around the books. The surge reflects the broader cultural recognition of the problem, spurred in part by several high-profile cases of cyberbullying that resulted in suicide.

headline: In Fight for Marriage Rights, ‘She’s Our Thurgood Marshall’
text: PORTLAND, Me. — Most Americans have never heard of Mary Bonauto. But inside the tightknit world of gay legal advocacy, Ms. Bonauto is a quiet celebrity — a lawyer and mother of twins who some say is almost single-handedly responsible for the same-sex marriage cases now pending before the Supreme Court.

headline: The Destructive Influence of Imaginary Peers
text: We humans irrationally think we’re rational. We think that we decide how to behave by weighing the pros and cons. In reality, the strongest influence on our decisions is the example of the people around us — even, oddly enough, when they are imaginary.

headline: Designing Big Data That Works
text: Whether the move is from mainframes to minicomputers, or from there to personal computers and servers, and now to mobile devices and cloud computing, we are witnessing one grand process of moving machine intelligence closer to the people on the front lines, even as the computing at the center gets more powerful.

headline: Spies and Big Business Fight Cyberattacks

Jargon incomprehensible to civilians. Puzzling explanations of military jobs. An inability, or unwillingness, to take credit for awards, specialized training or even leadership positions.

headline: Wanelo, Social Commerce Site, Picks Up Speed
text: Wanelo, the social shopping site that resembles a well-designed window display, is quickly gaining fans online,  despite being largely under the mainstream radar.

headline: The Gun Report: March 27, 2013
text: Crowdfunding has become a popular way to raise money for music, art projects, and even small business start-ups. But gun research? Given the lack of federal funds available for such research, why not? (A quick reminder: In 1996, the National Rifle Association lobbied Congress to cut all funding to the Center for Disease Control for gun-related research.) That hasn’t stopped researchers at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, however. Last year, a U.A.B. study found that increased gun background checks correlate with fewer homicides and suicides. The study concluded that more comprehensive background checks at the state level may reduce firearm deaths, but “more research is needed.”

headline: Easter vs. Passover: In Interfaith Marriages, Mom’s Faith Wins Out
text: I never thought of myself as part of an interfaith marriage — more of a faith/no-faith marriage. I am a Conservative Jew and my husband is a former Jehovah’s Witness, now an “aspiring atheist.” I told him on our first date that our children would be raised Jewish — indeed that they would go to Jewish day school. A little forward, perhaps, but I had friends who spent years arguing over faith until they finally decided their relationship just wasn’t going anywhere. And I had friends who wanted to expose kids to “a little bit of both” and then let them decide. Bringing up children as Unitarians or Jews for Jesus wasn’t in the cards for me.

headline: On Illegal Betting Slips, a Three-Digit Mystery
text: So what do all those numbers in a so-called numbers-running racket mean, anyway?

headline: Screening Checkpoint Delays
text: Charter flight passengers are more likely to slow down airport screening than scheduled passengers, suggests a study of a European regional airport by Kirschenbaum Consulting, an Israel-based security firm. Among the findings: a lower percentage of scheduled passengers among those interviewed carried prohibited items compared with charter passengers, and a lower percentage of scheduled passengers than charter passengers needed to be re-examined by security employees.

headline: Impressed in the South
text: In August 1862, the popular journalist, planter and politician J. F.H. Claiborne voiced a concern shared by thousands throughout the Confederacy. “We are now proving our loyalty by starvation,” he wrote to Gov. John Pettus of Mississippi. Claiborne’s plaint exposed the very real fear that spiraling inflation would combine with the military’s growing demands for food and supplies, and the central government’s ill-defined policies of how to satisfy them, in creating drastic food shortages, particularly in the South’s cities.

headline: Mark Leyner on the Art of Being ‘Sufficiently Carnivalesque’
text: As part of its 60th anniversary issue, The Paris Review has a great, long interview with Mark Leyner, author of, most recently, “The Sugar-Frosted Nutsack.”

headline: Buchenwald’s Liberation, as Seen by Louis Nemeth
text: In April 1945, Mr. Nemeth, a U.S. Army Signal Corps photographer, witnessed the horrors of the newly-liberated Buchenwald concentration camp.

headline: Some Vintages of Soldera Wine Survive a Vandalism
text: Case Basse di Soldera, the great Brunello di Montalcino estate where more than 60,000 liters of wine were destroyed last year by a disgruntled former employee, apparently did not lose all the wine from six vintages from 2007 through 2012. The proprietor, Gianfranco Soldera, announced recently that the estate had been able to salvage small parts of each of those vintages, at least preserving the opportunity to see how those wines will age and evolve.

headline: Cash-Hungry States Eye Sports Betting, to Leagues’ Dismay
text: LAS VEGAS — It is a lucrative time of year for Nevada, where more than $200 million will be wagered in sports books on the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, a pot of money that has budget-crunched states across the country pushing for a piece of the action despite strong opposition from the N.C.A.A. and professional sports leagues.

headline: Before Attack, Parents of  Gunman Tried to Address Son’s Strange Behavior
text: TUCSON — The parents of Jared L. Loughner, the man who killed six people and wounded 13 others during a meet-and-greet event hosted by former Representative Gabrielle Giffords in 2011, told the authorities after the mass shooting that they had become so concerned about their son’s strange behavior in the previous months that they had taken away his shotgun, insisted he get psychological counseling and had even begun to disable his car so that he could not go out at night, according to thousands of pages of documents related to the case released Wednesday.

headline: Call to a CNN Host Hints at a Shifting ‘Today’
text: Last week, it was Jay Leno who learned what NBC imagined his future to be. This week, it is Matt Lauer’s turn in the spotlight.

headline: Brother (and Rival) of British Party Leader Quits Politics
text: LONDON — David Miliband, the former British foreign secretary who lost a party leadership contest to his younger brother, said Wednesday that he was quitting front-line politics, drawing to an end a fraught sibling rivalry that had divided both a family and a political party.

headline: Obama’s Public Lands Record
text: President Obama’s decision to designate five new national monuments is a warm farewell present to the outgoing Interior secretary, Ken Salazar, who has been trying without great success to get Mr. Obama to protect more public lands from development. It also makes a nice welcoming gift for Sally Jewell, the presumed incoming secretary, whose life will be much happier if the President continues along this path. But environmentalists are not dancing in the streets, at least not yet. Conservation issues still do not loom large in this White House, and the lands Mr. Obama has protected over the course of his administration are small change compared to the efforts of his recent predecessors.

headline: ABC Family Plans Spinoff of ‘Pretty Little Liars’
text: Here’s a way to make fans of your television series very happy: Announce another season of the show and a new spinoff series at the same time. That’s what the ABC Family channel did on Tuesday when it renewed “Pretty Little Liars” for a fifth season (before the fourth one even starts), and revealed plans for a spinoff called “Ravenswood.”

headline: Video of Petraeus Apologizing for Extramarital Affair
text: In his first public appearance since resigning last November as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, David H. Petraeus apologized for the “circumstances” that led him to step down and cause so much pain for his family and friends.

headline: Big Moments in the Women’s Game
text: Were you wondering if there was a record Brittney Griner hadn’t set? Were you hoping she might use the occasion of her final home game to do yet another stupendous thing?

headline: An Emotional Investment in Saving for College
text: One of the first things we did when our children were born was contribute to a state-sponsored 529 college savings plan for each of them. Saving for their education is, for us, as much of an emotional investment as a financial one.

headline: Timeline: The London Whale’s Wake
text: JPMorgan incurred a huge trading loss in a complicated trading strategy that involved derivatives, financial instruments that derive their value from the prices of securities and other assets. The bank most likely structured the trade in a way that magnified losses.

headline: Deke Richards, Creator of Motown Hits, Dies at 68

headline: Radwanska’s Incredible Twist Vies for Shot of the Year
text: On an unusually brisk Miami evening Tuesday, an absurd Agnieszka Radwanska shot, a fade-away twirl, left her opponent completely frozen.

headline: Anthony Lewis in the West Bank
text: RAMALLAH — In 1991 I went for a hike in the hills north of Ramallah with the journalist Anthony Lewis, who passed away on Monday. He was in his early 60s at the time and was not in the best of shape, but he was game, as always.

headline: What Was the Family’s ‘Least Bad Decade’?
text: During yesterday’s excitement surrounding the Supreme Court and gay marriage, David Frum linked back to his 2011 column explaining why he had changed his mind on same-sex wedlock. Given my own fascination (obsession?) with family structure in America, I was struck by this passage:

headline: Cyprus Sets Up Tight Controls as Banks Prepare to Reopen
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The Cypriot government on Wednesday announced severe restrictions on access to funds held in the country’s banks, hoping to control a rush to withdraw money when the banks open Thursday for the first time in nearly two weeks.
