headline: Montenegro’s Rapid Ascent Stuns England
text: In England’s World Cup qualifying match against the tiny nation of Montenegro on Tuesday night in the Montenegrin capital of Podgorica, there were no bullying tactics by the Montenegro team, as the English press claimed there had been when the teams played to a draw on the same pitch two years ago. There weren’t any chairs thrown at the visiting team’s goalkeeper as there had been in Montenegro’s match against Poland last fall.

headline: Covered in Pacifiers, Trees Signal a Rite of Passage
text: Rachel Rhine’s apartment in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has a strange view: two small trees standing sentinel at the entrance of her building are covered in used pacifiers.

headline: For LaBeouf, a Front-Row View of Production That Fired Him
text: Shia LaBeouf, who was fired from the Broadway play “Orphans” last month after clashing with the director, Daniel Sullivan, and his co-star Alec Baldwin, attended the first preview performance of the play on Tuesday night at the Schoenfeld Theater – sitting in the first row on the aisle and leaping to his feet before any other audience member to give a standing ovation at the end.

headline: Flags’ Waving Doesn’t Come Cheap

headline: Balance Restored, Shard by Shard
text: PHILADELPHIA — The art collector Albert C. Barnes had no compunction about letting people know precisely how much he wanted things his way. In a 1939 letter to the auto scion Walter P. Chrysler Jr. he gleefully torpedoed a request — as he did frequently, especially from the rich and powerful — to visit his personal foundation near Philadelphia, where he housed his world-class works.

headline: Digging for Feasts Across the Florida Panhandle
text: I should’ve known this would happen: oyster withdrawal. More than 24 hours had passed since my last dozen. My stomach was making fearsome noises, and my mind was starting to slip. Was that a giant bottle of cocktail sauce in the distance? No, merely a water tower. Perhaps these car seat cushions were edible?

headline: Is Abortion Heading Back to the Supreme Court?
text: Forty years after the Roe v. Wade decision made abortion legal and recognized a woman’s right to control her body and her life, the issue may well be headed back to the Supreme Court.

headline: A New Variation of a Costly Tax-Time Offer
text: Tax refund anticipation loans, which are short-term advances made at tax time at high interest rates, are far less prevalent now partly because of a federal crackdown on banks that had been making the loans, according to a new report.

headline: Assad Sends Letter to Emerging Powers Seeking Help to End Syrian War
text: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria beseeched a five-nation group of emerging powers on Wednesday to help halt the Syrian conflict, one day after the Arab League moved to further isolate Mr. Assad by ceremoniously filling his government’s vacant seat with the opposition coalition that has sworn to topple him.

headline: Stepping Outside Manhattan
text: New York City this month introduced a Web guide called Neighborhood x Neighborhood, which highlights areas outside of Manhattan on the city’s tourism site. The first featured guide was for Brooklyn, focusing on haunts in Bushwick, Fort Greene and Williamsburg (above) that are not on the well-worn tourist path. Fans of Fette Sau, prepare for an even longer wait.

headline: A Start-Up Tries to Give Wine Spritzers a New Image and a Second Wind
text: During the seven years she did product development and design for both Diesel in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Burton Snowboards in Burlington, Vt., Jayla Siciliano attended a lot of work-related parties and dinners and did plenty of social drinking. The problem was that she also had to get up the next morning and work, so during social events she started pouring sparkling water into her wine. “It was perfect,” she said. “I could sip that all night and I would wake up feeling fine.”

headline: It’s Personal
text: To the editor: In Mr. Keller’s article [States Gone Wild, Monday, March 25] he repeatedly mentions his strong aversion to restrictive abortion rules…Has Mr. Keller previously shared his rationale for this strong opinion? For example, is it based on his interpretation of the Constitution or perhaps a personal understanding of when life commences. I ask if he might consider replying to this inquiry with a succinct summary of his position. Thank you.

headline: In the Wee Hours in Albany, the Talk Turns to Kumquats
text: ALBANY — The great kumquat debate began around 1 a.m. on Wednesday, when State Senator George S. Latimer, a Westchester County Democrat, likened a voluminous budget bill to a Christmas gift basket that contained some items that were desirable, and others that were not.

headline: Jetsons in Their Comfort Zone
text: SOMETIMES THE BEST SHOPPING is watching — seeing how other people move through a space, whether their fingers lightly flit over fabric or linger on the details, if they stop for the obvious blaring-siren pieces or dig out the ones that hang at a low hum. We all have our rhythms and rituals. I’m often far more comfortable in a crowded store, where my quirks might pass unnoticed, than stalking a store alone, the only thing moving.

headline: Bacteria in the Intestines May Help Tip the Bathroom Scale, Studies Show
text: The bacterial makeup of the intestines may help determine whether people gain weight or lose it, according to two new studies, one in humans and one in mice.

headline: Few Know How to Enter; Fewer Finish
text: WARTBURG, Tenn. — On Friday night, in the Cumberland Mountains of eastern Tennessee, 28 men and 7 women will lie in tents half asleep in anticipation of hearing a conch shell being blown at Big Cove Campground in Frozen Head State Park. When they hear the call, which will arrive sometime between 11 p.m. that night and 11 a.m. Saturday, they will know they are 60 minutes from the start of an ordeal once referred to as a “satanic running adventure.”

headline: Hair on the Street
text: One of the biggest growth areas on Wall Street? It may just be on the faces of some executives. Carl Icahn has now joined Lloyd Blankfein as one of the bearded elite of finance.

headline: Sit! Staaayyyy. Play Music! Good Dog!

headline: A Potential Potemkin Fight Over Dell
text: Even losers could emerge as winners from the Dell takeover battle. Blackstone Group, Silver Lake Partners, the Dell board and founder Michael S. headline: It’s Back. But What Does It Mean?
text: Did you watch the classic 1980 horror film “The Shining” and think it was about a man driven to insane and murderous rage by a haunted hotel? If so, you blew it. Or rather, you missed profound messages subtly embedded in the film by its enigmatic director, Stanley Kubrick.

headline: Kenya Opens Hearing on Vote Results
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — With millions of Kenyans staring raptly at television sets and glued to radios, Kenya’s Supreme Court began hearing evidence on Wednesday to resolve the nation’s disputed presidential election as lawyers claimed there had been instances of blatant voter fraud.

headline: Sweet Suits
text: The motivation behind the sustainable clothing line Popupshop is clear: create simple, chic, wearable and environmentally defensible garments for women and children. The usual pieces are mostly neutral and work well as basics for everyday mixing and matching. It may be easy to outfit children aged 2 to 10 in a uniform of mostly beige and navy blue, but Popupshop is changing things this season with little swimsuits covered in colorful, tropical birds, nuzzling zebras and dancing flamingos (in the same organic and sustainably sourced cotton it has used in the past). Cotton tees, leggings, jumpers and rompers are also available in bright animal prints, and range from $38 to $78 at Sweet William LTD, the children’s clothing store in downtown Manhattan and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Popupshop fits right in with the store’s stock of other ethically responsible, and mostly independent, brands.

text: The Times’s David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the possibility of CNN’s Anderson Cooper replacing NBC’s Matt Lauer.

headline: Wal-Mart Introduces Lockers as It Battles Amazon in E-Commerce
text: Following Amazon.com, Walmart will soon allow shoppers to order items online and pick them up from lockers in local stores.

headline: Italy’s Talks on New Government Stumble
text: ROME — Italy’s political gridlock deepened on Wednesday as talks to form a government broke down between the center-left leader, Pier Luigi Bersani, and the upstart Five Star Movement, a month after national elections failed to yield a majority.

headline: Before They Were Legendary
text: WERE THEY INNOCENT, IRREDEEMABLY wicked or perhaps a little of both? Lloyd Ziff’s haunting portraits of Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe, shot in the late 1960s, captured those alternating currents in his subjects’ personalities, which in those days had yet to take definitive form.

headline: Living the B&B Dream, a Couple Plans to Update an Inn’s Web Site
text: Nancy Galloway and Andre Laporte are living what is, for many, the ultimate retirement dream: owning and operating a bed & breakfast. Their current challenge is figuring out the best ways to attract visitors to their Web site and, ultimately, to a very remote part of Canada where the nearest traffic light is an hour away.

headline: Quinn, on CNN, Denies Being Vindictive
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, denied on Wednesday that she had used the power of her office to avenge grievances with elected officials who disagreed with her.

headline: $17 Million Gift to Bolster Old Master Collection at Dallas Museum of Art
text: Maxwell L. Anderson, the suave former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, swung through New York on Wednesday to update folks in the media about goings-on at his latest gig — the Dallas Museum of Art, where he became director 15 months ago.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Paris often becomes the main character in novels, but this month Tulsa, Okla.; Anchorage; and the fictional Illinois town of Marah make an appearance as well, likewise serving as far more than backdrop.

headline: Rewriting His Own Meal Ticket
text: When Ben Pundole announced last summer that he had left King & Grove, the boutique hotel chain he helped found, a lot of people wondered what the man behind Ruschmeyer’s and the Surf Lodge, two hot spots in Montauk, N.Y., was going to do next.

headline: In the CLA45, Mercedes Unleashes a Beginner’s AMG
text: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG sedan

headline: Banks Seek to Overturn Judge’s Ruling in Critical Mortgage Case
text: The nation’s largest banks, facing a torrent of lawsuits over shoddy mortgage securities, are pushing to overturn a series of tough rulings in an important case.

headline: Indomitable Yet Prone to Grieving
text: On Tuesday the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company began a two-week 30th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater. After the performance the audience members applauded enthusiastically, but Mr. Jones quieted them with the pall of death. He spoke of Mr. Zane, his former partner, who died of AIDS in 1988, and of Demian Acquavella, a company member who died of AIDS in 1990. “There are ghosts in this piece,” he said, twice.

headline: Mr. T Does Hockey
text: In their current era, you can’t fault the Chicago Blackhawks for not making their games entertaining. From the raucous national anthem to the infectious goal song to the fast-paced playing style they employ on the ice, games at United Center are certainly feasts for the eyes.

headline: Connecting With the Classical
text: The setting was generic Midtown office building, and possibly even less exciting was a yawning space there filled with rows of straight-back chairs. The audience’s long wait for seats was the only glimmer one evening this winter that an experience unrelated to everyday business might occur.

headline: Table Talk | The Clove Club
text: With arguably one of the most anticipated London restaurant openings this year, the Clove Club — on Old Street in the vibrant and edgy neighborhood of Shoreditch — is the creative and culinary collaboration of Daniel Willis, Johnny Smith and the chef Isaac McHale. After receiving much critical acclaim for their first restaurant, Upstairs at the Ten Bells, they felt it was time to make a bigger, bolder move. And to the historic Shoreditch Town Hall they decamped. It’s impossible not to be impressed by the restaurant’s ground-floor space, with its soaring high ceilings; original period features; bare, white walls; and dark, reclaimed wood. In the dinner-only room, McHale serves a constantly rotating five-course tasting menu; in the more casual bar area, an assortment of small, shared plates is available.

headline: Google Street View Captures Ghost Town in Fukushima’s Evacuation Zone
text: The eerily empty streets of Namie, a town deep in the evacuation zone around the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, are featured in the latest images captured by Google for its Street View mapping project.

headline: Lorne Michaels and ‘Louie’ Are Among Peabody Award Winners
text: Lorne Michaels, the creator of “Saturday Night Live,” as well as Scotusblog, the widely followed Supreme Court news source, and the FX series “Louie,” created by the comic Louis C.K., were among the recipients of the 2012 George Foster Peabody Awards, announced on Wednesday.

headline: New Director Selected for Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
text: After 15 months without a director, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco announced Wednesday that the board has chosen Colin B. Bailey, a deputy director at the Frick Collection in New York, as the new chief. Mr. Bailey said in an interview that he is excited about his new position and unfazed about the turmoil among the staff that the museums have been experiencing.

headline: Kia Adds Some Upscale Touches to the Soul
text: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27, 2013: 2014 Kia Soul

headline: Padres Know the Fragility of Pitching
text: Peoria, Ariz.

headline: How 3-D Printers Are Now Making Weapons
text: In October, I wrote a column about 3-D printed guns, and profiled Cody Wilson, a 24-year-old law student at the University of Texas, who was building a completely functional printed weapon.

headline: Stretching From Opera to Saloons
text: The soprano Patricia Racette, celebrated for her portrayals of Puccini heroines, is the latest in a lengthening list of classical singers to venture into cabaret, with her show “Diva on Detour” at 54 Below. That is also the title of her new album recorded with Craig Terry, her accompanist at Tuesday evening’s opening-night performance.

headline: Electric Blue Is the Spring Look for Men
text: Lately a kind of analog has emerged: shocking blue, a bright electric blue that is a far cry from the navy suits and light-blue business shirts of traditional men’s wear.

headline: Shock Value
text: Over the last decade, shocking pink has become so popular that it has lost virtually all of its power to do just that. Once distressingly linked with racy lingerie, Barbie dolls and bad taste, the color has amped, ramped and vamped up those associations and become a tongue-in-cheek beacon of femme feminism.

headline: CBS Renews 18 Prime-Time Shows
text: Flaunting the stability that has made it the top-rated network, CBS on Wednesday announced the renewal of 18 of its prime-time shows in one swoop, assuring that most of the network’s lineup will return next season.

headline: Jared Loughner Files From Pima County Sheriff
text: A selection of crucial documents released from authorities in Tucson about the arrest and investigation of the gunman who killed six people and left Representative Gabrielle Giffords wounded.

headline: Fake Ads in India Showing Bound and Gagged Women Lead to Firings
text: The Indian operation of a worldwide advertising agency has fired employees and apologized after an uproar over fake celebrity poster ads that were created for a real agency client, Ford Motor, without Ford’s approval or authorization.

headline: Key Moments From the Hearing on the Defense of Marriage Act
text: The Supreme Court heard arguments over a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman.

headline: A Nifty 50th for the Porsche 911
text: Not many car companies are associated with a single automobile. Fewer still continue to produce the very car that made the marque. So the 50th birthday of the Porsche 911 is definitely noteworthy.

headline: Clip: 'Evil Dead'
text: A scene from "Evil Dead," directed by Fede Alvarez.

headline: On Mundell-Fleming (Very Wonkish)
text: Aha. I see that Simon Wren-Lewis is on a campaign against the use of the Mundell-Fleming model, a simple international macroeconomic extension of IS-LM analysis, because of the way it handles the relationship between interest rates and exchange rates. And it’s true that the simplest version of Mundell-Fleming assumes that interest rates are equalized by capital flows, taking no account of expectations of future exchange rate changes.

headline: Court Hears Arguments on Defense of Marriage Act
text: The Supreme Court appeared ready on Wednesday to strike down a central part of a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman. It was the second day of intense arguments over the volatile issue of same-sex marriage.

headline: Faulkner’s Past Isn’t Dead; You Can Buy It at Auction
text: William Faulkner typed the story on the back of University of Mississippi letterhead, an early exercise in fiction writing about a fur trapper’s trip to a big city. Its 13 browned pages, stashed in an old, mismarked box in a barn on the Faulkner family farm in Charlottesville, Va., were discovered just last year. Now they, along with a stack of hand-corrected manuscripts, letters, a hand-bound poetry book and Faulkner’s Nobel medal, are headed to Sotheby’s for auction in June.

headline: Pig’s Head Is Just One Plot Point of Many
text: “The Burgess Boys” has the ring of a story about outlaws in the old West. But it’s about lawyers from small-town Maine instead. This new novel by Elizabeth Strout, the 2009 Pulitzer Prize winner for “Olive Kitteridge,” features two Burgess brothers, as well as a Burgess girl. Ms. Strout, whose first books were “Amy and Isabelle” and “Abide With Me,” writes most comfortably about women, but this book is mostly about the midlife crises of men.

headline: For Cyprus, a Sudden Need to Play Nice With Turkey
text: BRUSSELS — With its economy in tatters, Cyprus urgently needs to tap its natural gas deposits. But opening the spigot will force the easternmost member of the European Union to make the tough choices it has long been loath to confront.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Directions in Start-Ups, and  iCloud Trouble
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Didn’t Like Our Play? You’re Right. Very Sorry.
text: Never apologize, never explain: the familiar aphorism is usually invoked after the fact, when the apologizing or explaining has been done, to deleterious effect. It sprang to mind again as I read the letter that Tim Sanford, the artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, sent to some subscribers of that Off Broadway theater, offering a long and eloquent explanation (with a spoonful or two of apology) of the theater’s decision to mount “The Flick,” the new play by Annie Baker.

headline: New Ugliness in a Little Cabin of Horrors
text: Zack Carlson is a huge fan of the 1981 horror film “The Evil Dead.” That’s why he won’t be seeing the new “Evil Dead” when it opens on Friday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, Syria, Spain and the Vatican.

headline: A Garden of Delights, Mapped Out in Your Hand
text: The sun and the earth have revolved to the relevant positions in space and spring, ladies and gentlemen, has definitely sprung. While I have the opposite of green thumbs, I now have a handy arsenal of gardening apps to help me in my springtime garden.

headline: Are You a Giver or a Taker?
text: The Times’s Susan Dominus talks to the organizational psychologist Adam Grant about givers, takers and succeeding in the workplace.

headline: Tap’s Present and Future, in a Meeting of Minds, Hearts and Feet
text: On Sunday, near the start of “Rhythm in Motion,” the second of two shows that the American Tap Dance Foundation presented at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, the event’s director, Tony Waag, made an announcement and gave a warning. The announcement: All nine of the works on the program had been created within the last year at his American Tap Dance Center. The warning: The show would be “a bit moody.”

headline: Scene City: Dinner and Dance for Hermès
text: Socialites fete a new Hermès watch collection.

headline: Hermès Introduces a Watch With a Dance Performance
text: On Monday night, Hermès hosted a dinner party celebrating its latest watch, the Dressage Chrono. And everything about it was serious. Very serious.

headline: The N.C.A.A.'s Thankless Task
text: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, The Times’s William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.

headline: Trying to Testify Before the Court
text: For much of Tuesday, the trending topic on Twitter wasn’t Kimye baby names, LiLo’s prehab or Shakira on “The Voice.” Rather, it was the Supreme Court’s hearing of arguments in a same-sex marriage case. Celebrities lent their support for #MarriageEquality. But none of the justices, it should be noted, seem to be active on Twitter.

headline: Jaguar High Performance Comes in Threes
text: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27, 2013: 2014 Range Rover Sport, Jaguar XJR and XKR-S GT

headline: Video: The N.C.A.A.’s Thankless Task
text: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.

headline: The Timberlake Brand, Carried Along on a Media Storm
text: What does it really mean for an entertainer to be a “brand”?

headline: Controlling the ‘Smart Home’ With Tablets and Smartphones
text: A few years ago, I bought a $25 wall switch that could automatically turn my porch light on at dusk and off at sunrise, hoping to make my 1920s-era home a bit smarter.

headline: The War in Syria Through a Child’s Eyes
text: This week, Britain’s Channel 4 News broadcast a devastating video report by the German photojournalist Marcel Mettelsiefen on the impact of the war in Syria on the children of Aleppo, the country’s ruined commercial capital. The film, which contains some disturbing images, focuses on the life of a 12-year-old boy named Mohamed Asaf, who spends long days and nights working in a medical clinic that treats residents and rebel fighters.

headline: He Speaks Country in a Dialect of His Own
text: There is no parental advisory warning label on the new Blake Shelton album, “Based on a True Story,” no special Walmart clean edition.

headline: In New Jersey, a Resignation, Then a Search for Redemption
text: Maybe it’s the shallow, overly friendly filmmaking, or maybe it’s some kind of former politician’s curse, but “Fall to Grace,” a documentary about what James E. McGreevey has been doing since resigning the New Jersey governorship in 2004, never feels as if it got to the core of the man.

headline: New York as a Work in Progress
text: James Gulliver Hancock is one of those people who set impossible tasks for themselves that evolve into blogs and then into books. For Mr. Hancock, a 35-year-old Australian artist and illustrator, the task has been to draw every building in New York. He started in April 2010, while living in Brooklyn. Now back home in Sydney with his wife and year-old son, he returns to the scene of his ambition from time to time and otherwise works from photographs and Google Maps. The drawings are posted on his Web site, allthebuildingsinnewyork.com, where they often inspire commissions, leading Mr. Hancock’s pen on an erratic course from Staten Island to the Bronx and from squat warehouses to soaring landmarks. Next week, Universe Publishing will release “All the Buildings in New York: That I’ve Drawn So Far” ($19.95), a sampler of the more than 500 drawings he has executed. Mr. Hancock spoke of his starry-eyed project on the phone from Sydney.

headline: The JCP Monogram
text: Seeking the cachet of specialty stores, J. C. Penney (recently rebranded as JCP) is installing home-furnishings boutiques in almost half of its 1,100 stores. These shops will offer dedicated collections by well-known designers. “We wanted good partners who could appeal to a wide variety of people,” said Paul Rutenis, general merchandise manager for JCP Home.

headline: Island Fever in Italy
text: The word “bikini” became popular referring to minimalist beachwear and to the South Pacific atoll where nuclear tests were conducted. It is also the name of two new furniture projects by Werner Aisslinger for the Italian company Moroso. This work, which is to be introduced next month at the Milan Furniture Fair, is neither lethal nor scandalous, but it does disrupt convention.

headline: Within a Sconce, Reflections of Infinity
text: To look into Stella, a sconce from the Brooklyn lighting company Roll & Hill, is to peer at infinity. The fixture has a prismatic lens formed by three one-way mirrors that reflect and multiply the appearance of LED strips within an ebonized ash wood frame. “The idea was to maximize volume with very minimal space,” said the designer, Rosie Li, a 2011 graduate of the furniture-design program at the Rhode Island School of Design. “I was really interested in playing with perspective.”

headline: A Different Time Stamp
text: You have to root a little for Yellow Owl Workshop, a San Francisco company that makes beautiful paper products in this paperless age. Their newest offering is the Carve-A-Stamp-Kit, a D.I.Y. set for creating ink stamps to adorn thank-you cards or envelopes. The $28 kit includes a rubber stamp block, a carving tool, an ink pad, tracing paper and 25 designs (or create your own).

headline: Traditions Honored, Then Sidestepped, at Salzburg Easter Festival
text: SALZBURG, Austria — This year’s Salzburg Easter Festival began on Saturday with a production of Wagner’s “Parsifal” that imagined the sorcerer Klingsor’s castle of false pleasures as a museum.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Sferra and Others
text: During Broadway Panhandler’s knife sale, through Sunday, knives are up to 80 percent off (a Wusthof Grand Prix II 7-inch hollow-edge Santoku, shown, regularly $125, is about $50; a Global 8-inch cook’s knife, with MinoSharp sharpener, regularly $206, is $118); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: The Art of Unjumbling
text: ZURICH — It may come as a bit of a disappointment to certain design blog fans to learn that Ursus Wehrli is not exactly a neatnik, or in any way obsessive or compulsive. While Mr. Wehrli, 44, is famous in his country for being half of the anarchic comic duo Ursus & Nadeschkin (think Groucho and Harpo, but in German and with circus skills), he has lately accrued another sort of fame as an author with a particularly fastidious worldview.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. The wood on my dining table is scratched, and it makes the room look kind of scruffy. Although I plan to take the table with me when I move, should I have it repaired before trying to sell my home?

headline: The Art of Heavy-Metal Blunders
text: A look at some of the ineffective album cover art from “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists.”

headline: Sleeper Sofas
text: Ron Marvin didn’t set out to become an authority on small spaces. But then his handsome 300-square-foot Chelsea apartment was featured in Metropolitan Home and on Apartment Therapy. And before long, Mr. Marvin, a New York interior designer, found he had a string of clients with space-challenged homes, and was making regular appearances as an expert on the HGTV show “Small Space, Big Style.”

headline: Shopping for Sleeper Sofas
text: The sleeper-sofa, your extra bedroom for that occasional overnight guest.

headline: Scouting Report
text: Dress for Less

headline: Cleaning Up
text: The comedian Ursus Wehrli has been accruing another sort of fame as a best-selling author of picture books based on a simple but satisfying sight gag. His latest is “The Art of Clean Up: Life Made Neat and Tidy.”

headline: Design in the Round
text: A selection of bowls from “Object Focus: The Bowl” at the Museum of Contemporary Craft in Portland, Ore.

headline: Enter the Lighting Expert
text: David and Dorothy Measer’s house in Los Angeles is neither a cottage nor a bachelor pad, but when the couple met nine years ago, it was both.

headline: Finally, the Bowl Gets Its Due
text: Last week, a media frenzy erupted when a small white ceramic bowl carved with a pattern of lotus blossoms sold for more than $2.2 million at auction in New York. That price, which included the buyer’s premium, was 10 times what the auction house, Sotheby’s, expected the bowl to fetch, and more than 700,000 times what the sellers had paid for it.

headline: A Driving Force Behind Wikipedia Will Step Down
text: Sue Gardner, who oversaw a period of rapid growth and evolution of Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia, said she would step down as executive director of the nonprofit foundation that runs it.

headline: Better Than a Bachelor Pad
text: Turning a Venice Beach cottage into a house fit for a growing family.

headline: Where in the World Are Windows Phones Outselling iPhones?
text: On Wednesday morning, Frank Shaw, the head of public relations at Microsoft, published a blog post tallying Microsoft’s progress across several different product areas, including Windows Phone, its operating system for smartphones.

headline: Elite in China Face Austerity Under Xi’s Rule
text: BEIJING — Life for the almighty Chinese government official has come to this: car pools, domestically made wristwatches and self-serve lunch buffets.

headline: A Palm Beach Society Writer’s Own Boldface Name
text: Shannon Donnelly, the society editor of the Palm Beach Daily News — the small, must-read chronicle of the outlandishly rich — can’t get to every party during the high season.

headline: Ready to Talk Amps and Ohms?
text: When the February blizzard unplugged my Connecticut home from the power grid for the fourth time in recent years, the whining started immediately: here we go again with the spoiled food, the lack of running water, the dormant oil burner.

headline: North American Championships
text: ST. LOUIS — On Sunday evening, the last day of the American Contract Bridge League’s North American Championships here, with some 10 inches of snow falling outside, three national titles were decided.

headline: Tucker Carlson Takes Over ‘Fox & Friends’ Weekend Edition
text: Tucker Carlson is the new co-host of the weekend editions of “Fox & Friends,” the Fox News Channel’s popular morning talk show.

headline: A New Cherokee for Jeep’s Next Generation
text: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 Jeep Cherokee

headline: Ashley Judd Passes on Senate Run in Kentucky
text: After a high-profile flirtation with a Senate race, the actress Ashley Judd announced Wednesday that she would not seek the Democratic nomination in 2014 from Kentucky.

headline: James McGreevey, This Side of Redemption
text: Cloaked in ivy, the Wedgwood-blue Georgian Revival in Plainfield, N.J., has the air of an upper-crust fortress. Surrounded by 1.7 leafy acres landscaped by the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted, the 17-room house offers few clues about its owners. On a recent afternoon, a black Prius is parked in the drive and Easter-bunny cutouts romp across a lawn that slopes down to the quiet street.

headline: The Third Man
text: ON A BLOCK ALREADY filled with a Bavarian biergarten (Zum Schneider), a Serbian restaurant (Kafana) and an Austrian gastro pub (Edi and the Wolf) comes another Eastern European-inspired import: the Third Man, a Viennese-style bar that channels Marshall Plan scruffiness (the mirrors are distressed, the bricks, exposed) with elegant cocktails and Austrian hors d’oeuvres.

headline: Hedge Fund Titan Buys Hamptons Property for $60 Million
text: Steven A. Cohen is known for his rapid-fire trading style, moving in and out of stocks with dizzying speed at his hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Obama to Visit Mexico and Costa Rica in May
text: In a trip aimed at reinforcing cultural, familial and economic ties with Mexico and Central America, President Obama will visit Mexico and Costa Rica in May, the White House announced Wednesday.

headline: Favorite Brands at Whole Body
text: Whole Body, the beauty department of Whole Foods Market, has provided several niche brands with a national stage. Below, four favorites.

headline: Beauty Products in a Health-Food Store
text: Whole Body has been a department in Whole Foods stores since the company started in 1980.

headline: Hughes Is Set for D.L.
text: Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes will begin the season on the 15-day disabled list, Manager Joe Girardi said, and may not start until April 11, or even later. Hughes pitched in a minor league game Wednesday and threw 81 pitches, but it was only his second spring game. He had to take two weeks off earlier in spring training because of a back problem that slowed his progress and arm conditioning. Until Hughes comes back, the Yankee rotation will consist of C. C. Sabathia, Andy Pettitte, Hiroki Kuroda, Ivan Nova and David Phelps.

headline: For a Holistic Lifestyle, Go to Aisle 2
text: Shortly after New York Fashion Week, I stood with my umbrella dripping on the concrete floor of Whole Body, the health and beauty department of the Whole Foods Market in Chelsea. After days of Champagne and late nights, the thought of rejuvenating with natural beauty products had conjured visions of “Sound of Music” bliss, but the aisles were jammed with more labels and products than I could easily navigate.

headline: Chief Who Led Expansion at Hearst Will Step Down
text: After nearly 30 years of running the Hearst Corporation, the privately held media company, Frank A. Bennack Jr. has announced that he is stepping down.

headline: With Trial Suddenly Looming, Russian Activist Expects the Worst
text: MOSCOW — Since his earliest days as an opposition blogger, Aleksei A. Navalny has known that a prison sentence loomed as a possibility.

headline: Job Prospects Are Dimming for Radiology Trainees
text: For years, medical students who chose a residency in radiology were said to be on the ROAD to happiness. The acronym highlighted the specialties — radiology, ophthalmology, anesthesiology and dermatology — said to promise the best lifestyle for doctors, including the most money for the least grueling work.

headline: Hjalmar Andersen, Norwegian Speedskater, Dies at 90
text: Hjalmar Andersen, a Norwegian speedskater who broke world records in the early 1950s and won three gold medals at the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo, died on Wednesday in Oslo. He was 90.

headline: U.S. Road Opens on Way to Brazil
text: MEXICO CITY

headline: After Plan for Speed Cameras Fails in Albany, a Tirade From Bloomberg
text: As it became clear that a proposal to place speed-tracking cameras on New York City’s streets would fail in Albany, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg let fly a charged and unusually personal attack against state lawmakers on Wednesday, blaming state senators, by name, for the future deaths of children killed by speeding cars.

headline: Plaintiff, 83, Is Calm Center in a Legal and Political Storm
text: WASHINGTON — When Edith Windsor and her girlfriend got engaged in 1967, she was too nervous about how to answer the inevitable “Who is he?” queries to wear an engagement ring. So they compromised on a ring-shaped diamond brooch instead.

headline: Riddle Posed by Orange Doesn’t Change, or Get Easier
text: WASHINGTON — It is one of college basketball’s great riddles. Every season, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim unveils another iteration of his 2-3 zone defense and dares opponents to concoct solutions.

headline: Dolan Goes Behind Bars to Commune With Inmates
text: WALLKILL, N.Y. — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan gazed at a group of well-behaved and truly captivated worshipers, flashed a big smile, and launched into a story about his recent participation in the papal conclave in Rome, where he helped elect Pope Francis.

headline: Ex-Prisoners Bring Taste of West Bank to Gaza
text: GAZA — Nader Abu Turki first gained a reputation as a confectioner while serving time as a prisoner in Israel.

headline: 3rd Oral Drug to Treat MS Is Approved by the F.D.A.
text: A chemical once used to treat sofas — until it was found to cause rashes and blisters in people who sat on them — is now poised to become a major therapy for multiple sclerosis.

headline: Officer Tied to Tapes’ Destruction Moves Up C.I.A. Ladder
text: WASHINGTON — A C.I.A. officer directly involved in the 2005 decision to destroy interrogation videotapes and who once ran one of the agency’s secret prisons has ascended to the top position within the C.I.A.’s clandestine service, according to current and former intelligence officials.

headline: Attacks Used the Internet Against Itself to Clog Traffic
text: An escalating cyberattack involving an antispam group and a shadowy group of attackers has now affected millions of people across the Internet, raising the question: How can such attacks be stopped?

headline: Dairy Finds a Way to Let Cows Power Trucks
text: FAIR OAKS, Ind. — Here at one of the largest dairy farms in the country, electricity generated using an endless supply of manure runs the equipment to milk around 30,000 cows three times a day.

headline: Dribbling Prodigy Now a Coach
text: LOS ANGELES — It seemed inevitable that Sean Miller would end up here, with a permanent home underneath Hollywood’s bright lights, where his prodigious childhood talent for dribbling and handling a basketball drew the attention of film and movie types.

headline: Getting to Know Wichita State’s Mascot WuShock
text: LOS ANGELES — Wichita State will play an N.C.A.A. tournament game here Thursday. For the uninitiated, the team’s nickname is the Shockers, shortened from Wheat Shockers.

headline: Court Rejects Antitrust Suit in Victory for Comcast
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday threw out a proposed class-action antitrust lawsuit against Comcast, the nation’s largest cable television company, in which a group of more than two million current and former Comcast subscribers sought to prove that the company had unfairly eliminated competition and overcharged customers.

headline: U.N. Close to Curbing Arms Trade With Treaty
text: UNITED NATIONS — The effort over many years to forge an international treaty regulating the booming $70 billion annual trade in conventional weapons headed toward fruition on Wednesday with a final draft sent to the governments of all United Nations member states for approval.

headline: New Problem for Boeing 787 Battery Maker
text: TOKYO — Two lithium-ion car batteries produced by GS Yuasa, the same Japanese company that supplies batteries for the grounded Boeing 787 jetliner fleet, have overheated in recent days.

headline: James M. Nabrit, a Fighter for Civil Rights, Dies at 80
text: James M. Nabrit III, a civil rights lawyer who fought school segregation before the Supreme Court and helped ensure that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., was allowed to go forward, died on Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 80.

headline: Beleaguered? Not Teachers, a Poll on ‘Well-Being’ Finds
text: Recent battles over school funding, performance evaluations and tenure have given rise to public perceptions of a beleaguered teaching corps across the United States.

headline: N.F.L. Doctor Says Disease Is Overstated
text: When a government agency prepared a workplace safety fact sheet based on a study of degenerative brain disease in retired N.F.L. players, the organization invited several people to comment on a draft.

headline: On the Brink of Justice in Guatemala
text: Haverford, Pa.

headline: Twitter Posts Lead Weight Watchers Online to a New Spokeswoman
text: WEIGHT WATCHERS is closely associated with celebrity endorsers like Jennifer Hudson, Jessica Simpson and Charles Barkley, but some celebrities end up joining the program on their own.

headline: A Republican Left Turn?
text: If the Republican Party concedes defeat in the culture war, as a number of commentators on the right and the left argue it should, what what will happen to the conservative coalition? Can hard-line stands on social issues be set aside?

headline: Antibiotics and the Meat We Eat
text: San Francisco

headline: A No-Fly Zone for Knives
text: Washington

headline: Immigration in Spotlight as Senators Tour Arizona
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — Four United States senators came to this bustling city on the Mexican border on Wednesday searching for answers to the question that has ensnarled the debate over immigration reform: How secure is that border?

headline: Cypriots’ Criticism of Bailout Rattles Nerves and Raises Ire in Germany
text: BERLIN — If Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is bothered by images of her wearing a mustache like Hitler’s, which are being waved in streets from Cyprus to Spain, she has yet to show it, choosing instead to stress the importance of the protesters’ freedom of expression.

headline: A Vote on Scottish Independence
text: Scottish voters will decide on Sept. 18, 2014, whether Scotland should remain part of the United Kingdom or become an independent nation. After more than three centuries of political union, breaking up would be complicated.

headline: Monitoring New York City’s Police
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York and Commissioner Raymond Kelly are apoplectic about a bill pending in the City Council that would create the position of inspector general, an official with broad powers to review the policies of the nation’s largest police department. Given the department’s long history of episodic misconduct, the idea is one whose time has clearly come. The City Council should press ahead with the bill and be prepared to override a veto by the mayor.

headline: Down Syndrome and a Death
text: A grand jury in Frederick County, Md., decided last week not to bring criminal charges in the death of Robert Ethan Saylor, a 26-year-old man with Down syndrome who was killed in a struggle with three off-duty county sheriff’s deputies at a movie theater in January. Advocates for people with intellectual disabilities are bewildered and furious, and it is easy to see why.

headline: The Indefensible Marriage Act
text: The discrimination embedded in the Defense of Marriage Act is precise yet sweeping. The 1996 statute defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman, and applies that definition to about 1,100 federal laws and programs. One of its many discriminatory results is that same-sex couples are prohibited from collecting many federal benefits available to other couples.

headline: Defense in Colorado Killings Seeks Plea Deal
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Defense lawyers for James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people and wounding dozens more at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater last summer, signaled in court filings on Wednesday that they were willing to have Mr. Holmes plead guilty if he was spared the death penalty.

headline: History in Real Time
text: Witnessing a historic moment is such an odd and exhilarating thing. It is hard to register the full scope of it because you are chest deep in it.

headline: Cooling on Warming
text: Is spring actually here? We are definitely getting tired of snow stories. It’s time for some sun. And then the drought stories!

headline: Miami Coach Left a Mark With a Run in 2006
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — The basketball commemorating George Mason’s run to the Final Four in 2006 is perched inside a modest trophy case near an obscure back entrance of the university’s basketball arena. Embossed with the score of the East Region final — George Mason 86, Connecticut 84 — the basketball is not all that easy to find in this sprawling suburban campus 20 miles from Washington, and hundreds of students pass it without notice each day.

headline: Hague: 2 Serb Police Chiefs Convicted
text: The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal on Wednesday convicted two Bosnian Serb police chiefs for participating in a violent ethnic cleansing campaign that aimed to drive non-Serbs from their homes in 20 municipalities of Bosnia during the war of early 1990s. The two, Mico Stanisic and Stojan Zuplanin, were each handed a 22-year prison sentence. The verdicts underscored the crucial roles played by the police and armed militia in the notorious persecution of Croats and Muslims, many of whom were beaten, tortured, raped or otherwise abused in as many as 50 wartime detention centers run by Bosnian Serbs. The judges said that many civilians were killed or died from hunger, illness and mistreatment during the campaign to create zones for Serbs only in Bosnia.

headline: Connecticut and Shore on Itinerary for a Prince
text: A charming prince is coming and there are no official plans for him to get naked.

headline: For La Salle, a Calming Influence at the End of the Bench
text: LOS ANGELES — Before 13th-seeded La Salle upset No. 4 Kansas State last week, the Explorers huddled in the locker room and bowed their heads. Brother Ed Sheehy stood beside the players, dressed in his traditional dark sweater, black shirt and white collar.

headline: Automakers Take the Wraps Off Luxury
text: Automakers are filling their showrooms with expensive new models like the ones on display at the New York auto show. The market for high-end cars and S.U.V.’s has outstripped overall car demand in the United States, a surge that  analysts see as a sign that wealthy consumers sense the nation’s financial health is solidly improving.

headline: With Vouchers, States Shift Aid for Schools to Families
text: PHOENIX — A growing number of lawmakers across the country are taking steps to redefine public education, shifting the debate from the classroom to the pocketbook. Instead of simply financing a traditional system of neighborhood schools, legislators and some governors are headed toward funneling public money directly to families, who would be free to choose the kind of schooling they believe is best for their children, be it public, charter, private, religious, online or at home.

headline: Manure Becomes a Fuel Supply
text: At one of the largest dairy farms in the country, electricity generated by an endless supply of manure runs the equipment to milk around 30,000 cows three times a day.

headline: Close Wins Set Penguins Apart
text: The Pittsburgh Penguins go into Thursday’s game against the Winnipeg Jets with 13 straight victories, tied for the fifth-longest winning streak in N.H.L. history. The Penguins, who lead the Eastern Conference with 52 points, have not lost in March, their last defeat coming Feb. 28 at Carolina. Pittsburgh has outscored opponents by 47-26 during the streak, but nine of the victories have been by a single goal, including two wins in overtime and one in a shootout. Below, a look at the longest N.H.L. winning streaks, including one-goal games. (The N.H.L. introduced an overtime period for regular-season games in the 1983-84 season and started the shootout in the 2005-6 season.)

headline: Porsche 911 GT3: They’ll Be Racing in the Streets

headline: Governor of Tennessee Joins Peers Refusing Medicaid Plan
text: Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee said Wednesday that he would not expand Medicaid in his state as called for in the federal health care overhaul, joining 18 other Republican governors who have rejected expansion for now.

headline: Study Shows Bacteria Moves From Animals to Humans
text: A new study used genetic sequencing to establish that a strain of antibiotic-resistant bacteria has been transmitted from farm animals to people, a connection that the food industry has long disputed. Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, said the study by researchers in Britain and Denmark, which drew on data from two small farms in Denmark, “ends any debate” about whether giving antibiotics to livestock is a risk to humans. Scientists had shown a connection between animals and people before, but never in as much detail, said Keeve Nachman, a scientist at the Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future.

headline: Link Is Found Between Stressful Events and Stillbirths
text: Pregnant women who have stressful experiences in the year before giving birth are more likely to deliver stillborn babies, a new study reports. The study, by the National Institutes of Health, asked 2,000 women in five states about specific events, like losing a job, moving or losing a close friend or relative. Stillbirth risk increased with each event. Non-Hispanic black women were most affected. Experiences most correlated with stillbirth included being in a fight, going to jail and hearing a partner express opposition to the pregnancy.

headline: Miami Absorbs Hard Hits and, for Once, a Loss
text: CHICAGO — Before Wednesday’s tip-off at United Center, LeBron James lay on a towel in the Miami locker room as a team assistant helped him stretch. James rapped along to a song on his iPod as his thighs were kneaded and his long limbs were pushed and pulled. Nearly 20 reporters and cameramen watched his every movement.

headline: 27-Game Streak? For Heat, 50-1 Shot
text: They lost Wednesday night to the Chicago Bulls, but the Miami Heat still put an impressive 27-game winning streak in the books, the second longest in N.B.A. history. Just how unlikely is such a streak?

headline: Living With Cancer: The Scar Project
text: In the documentary “Baring it All,” a young woman declares, “The scar represents everything I’ve been through. I’m proud of what I’ve been through.” The film focuses on the fashion photographer David Jay, who created a pictorial series about breast cancer called “The Scar Project.”

headline: Once More Through the Revolving Door for Justice’s Breuer

headline: Another Met Is Hurt as Turner Leaves Game With Leg Cramps
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Another day, another injury. With the Mets already dealing with questions about their rotation, they received another jolt on Wednesday when Justin Turner left a game against the Houston Astros with cramps in his left calf.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: MIDNIGHT (BBC America) GATTACA (1997) In the not-too-distant future, when people’s social standing is determined by the strands of their DNA, Vincent Freeman (Ethan Hawke, above) tries to become an astronaut by assuming the identity of Eugene (Jude Law). “Imagine an Orwellian story presented with a cool, eerie precision like Peter Greenaway’s and you have some sense of ‘Gattaca,’ a handsome and fully imagined work of cautionary futuristic fiction,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Andrew Niccol. She also appreciated the decision to set a space agency’s headquarters in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Marin County Civic Center in San Rafael, Calif. “The building becomes a perfect reflection of the film’s spare, controlled state of mind,” she said.

headline: Wichita State and La Salle Become Acquainted
text: LOS ANGELES — Come Thursday night, either No. 9-seeded Wichita State or No. 13-seeded La Salle will advance to the Round of 8, to the West Region finals. This is inevitable. Either the Shockers or the Explorers will advance, no matter how obscure their universities, or their mascots, may be.

headline: Timeline of the Miami Heat’s Winning Streak
text: The Miami Heat achieved the second-longest winning streak in N.B.A. history at 27 games, starting Feb. 3 and spanning 53 days. They fell six victories shy of the league record.

headline: Evans Guides Nets to Another Road Victory
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Nursing an eye problem, Reggie Evans looked ahead, large black-and-gold-rimmed designer sunglasses blocking out the light of the Rose Garden’s visitors locker room. Evans had tied his career high with 22 points and snared a career-high 26 rebounds, and the Nets had pushed their circus road trip record to 4-1 with a blowout victory over the Trail Blazers on Thursday night.

headline: BRIC, BRICS or BRICSI? The Growing Challenge
text: BEIJING — First it was called BRIC, a group of emerging economies thought up in 2001 by a Goldman Sachs economist, Jim O’Neill, made up of Brazil, Russia, India and China. Then it acquired an “s” for South Africa and become BRICS. Now there’s talk of Indonesia, which has a strongly growing economy, maybe wanting in: BRICSI, anyone?

headline: Iginla’s Choice of the Penguins Surprises Even Them
text: Jarome Iginla could not pass up an opportunity to play with Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin. headline: Edgy Calm as Banks in Cyprus Reopen
text: AKAKI, Cyprus — As Cyprus cautiously cracked open the doors of its crisis-ridden banks on Thursday, Stelios Sofroniou, a pig farmer, fumed at being able to withdraw only 300 euros, about $385. That would buy one ton of feed, not the 30 he needed for his 15,000 increasingly hungry pigs.

If the justices strike the provision, same-sex spouses in jurisdictions where their marriage is legal would start to receive federal benefits.

headline: My Search for a Credit Card Processor, Part 3
text: In Wednesday’s post, I wrote about my decision not to accept the credit card processing offer I had received from Emerald World. That left me at PNC, where I had my business accounts and where I now understood that I was probably paying more than necessary for card processing.

headline: That Other School Shooting
text: On April 2 last year, a 43-year-old former nursing student named One L. Goh walked into Oikos University in Oakland, Calif., with a .45-caliber handgun. He killed six people and wounded three others, then exited the building and shot and killed Tshering Bhutia, a former classmate, in the school’s parking lot. Goh then climbed into Bhutia’s car and drove to a Safeway in the nearby city of Alameda, where he ultimately surrendered to police.

headline: East Meets West Indies
text: This weekend’s meal takes us to the bottom corner of Port of Spain, in Trinidad, where Kevin Yarna and his father, Pancho, spend Fridays serving Chinese-style chicken at Pancho’s Snackette, near the modern rise of the National Library.

headline: Daily Report: Attacks Used the Internet Against Itself to Clog Traffic
text: A huge denial-of-service attack that eventually slowed traffic across much of the Internet relied on vulnerabilities in the network’s own hardware to amplify its effects, John Markoff and Nicole Perlroth report on Thursday in The New York Times.

headline: For Cohen, Another Big Purchase
text: FOR COHEN, ANOTHER BIG PURCHASE  |  Steven A. Cohen has been in a harsh spotlight as he contends with an insider trading investigation into his hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors. But that hasn’t stopped the billionaire from going shopping: He reached a deal last week to pay $60 million for an oceanfront property in East Hampton, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. At the same time, he has put his duplex apartment on the East Side of Manhattan up for sale, seeking $115 million, Mr. Lattman reports, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: The Lunatic Is on the Air: A Stoppard Radio Play for Pink Floyd’s ‘Dark Side of the Moon’
text: The 40th anniversary of the release of “The Dark Side of the Moon,” that best-selling Pink Floyd album, technically occurred earlier this month. But in the case of a seminal prog-rock record that deals with the nature of time (and the slowing-down thereof), we’ll forgive Tom Stoppard if his unique effort to celebrate this milestone doesn’t actually arrive until the summer.

headline: A Marshall McLuhan Approach to Weather Forecasting
text: If Marshall McLuhan  had been a rocket scientist, he might have liked PlanetIQ’s approach to forecasting the weather. It uses signals from GPS satellites, but not for positioning. Instead, it measures distortion in these signals to learn about the atmosphere through which they passed. To quote McLuhan out of context, the medium is the message in this case: the manner of acquiring the information is more important than the information itself.

headline: Pickles Aplenty at This Upper East Side Hangout

headline: ‘Running with the Big Boys’ in Iraq, a Female Soldier Paves the Way
text: If or when a female soldier someday enlists in the Army infantry, she will probably look a lot like Sgt. Amber Sellers, 29, from Cullman, Ala.

headline: Black Magic
text: Matthew Shlian is an artist and paper engineer whose work combines science and the age-old Japanese practice of origami. His new series, now on sale at the online art and music concept shop the Ghostly Store, is called “Apophenia,” an interesting word that describes the tendency to see patterns in random data, to recognize order in chaos. By dissecting and then recombining different patterns, Shlian’s piece achieves this strange effect. The work is broken down into four formations — almost like freeze frames — each of which is made by hand with only black Strathmore paper and glue. From $150; theghostlystore.com.

headline: How About a Little Luxury?
text: Luxury vehicles have long pushed the limits of size, but automakers are now whipping up fancy bite-size models, confident that Americans are seeing the upside of small, yet artful, portions.

headline: After Casting Wide Net, CNN Finds Co-Host for Morning Show
text: In his search for a new morning television host that lasted months, the new head of CNN, Jeffrey Zucker, considered dozens of names, some boldface and some unknown. It wasn’t until he paired Christopher Cuomo, the former ABC anchor he hired in January, with a young Washington correspondent named Kate Bolduan that he thought he had a perfect match.

headline: Journey, an Indie Video Game, Wins Top Prizes
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Journey, a downloadable video game made by the independent studio thatgamecompany for the PlayStation 3, took home 6 of the 11 Game Developers Choice Awards, including game of the year, handed out here on Wednesday night at the Game Developers Conference.

headline: American Republicans Visit Modi in Gujarat
text: Gandhinagar, GUJARAT —A group of Republican representatives from the United States Congress traveled to Gujarat Thursday to meet the state’s controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi.

headline: City Has Financial Ties to Carwashes Under Investigation, Report Says
text: The owners of a string of carwashes with a history of labor law violations and who are under investigation by the state attorney general’s office are paid by the city to clean city-owned cars, according to a new report.

headline: The Ruins of Cyprus the Tax Haven
text: Visiting the future ruins of Cyprus.

headline: Losing Her Audio, but Never Her Nerve
text: NEWARK — An arena show, for all the planning that goes into it, is still a tightrope walk — there is nowhere to hide once the lights go up. So when things began to go wrong for Taylor Swift about midway through her Wednesday night concert at the Prudential Center here, the question wasn’t whether she’d sweat, but if it would show.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: NBC Calls Cooper About ‘Today’ and Hearst Chief to Step Down
text: Reports of a surprising phone call from an NBC executive to CNN’s Anderson Cooper have fueled speculation about possible succession plans for Matt Lauer, the co-host of the “Today” show, which has had slumping ratings, Brian Stelter writes. NBC tried to quell the rumors, but three television industry insiders confirmed that Mr. Cooper was asked this month whether he would consider hosting “Today.” It is unclear whether Mr. Cooper might be interested in moving from “Anderson Cooper 360,” his nightly program on CNN, to a morning show on NBC, but rumors of the call come as NBC is finalizing plans to have Jimmy Fallon replace Jay Leno on “The Tonight Show.”

headline: Thursday Reading: How to Buy and Install a Generator
text: How to buy and install an electric generator, living the bed-and-breakfast dream, a slimmer keyboard for the iPad and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Tip of the Week: Beware of Tax Season Scams
text: The deadline for filing federal (and many state) tax returns is just a few weeks away, so the level of scam e-mail messages claiming to be from the Internal Revenue Service are likely to increase in the coming days. Remember, the I.R.S. does not initially contact taxpayers by e-mail or text message to request PIN codes, Social Security numbers or other financial data. Do not click on any Web links or open attachments included with these types of messages because you could inadvertently install malicious software on the computer. You can report suspicious mail by forwarding the messages to phishing@irs.gov and the agency’s site has a page with additional safety information.

headline: Broad-Based S.&P. 500-Stock Index Ends at Record High
text: The most widely followed barometer of the United States stock market rose to a new high on Thursday, exceeding its 2007 peak, while most of the rest of the world could only look on in envy.

headline: She Plays a Chimp Who’s Playing a Man
text: LONDON — On a rainy afternoon, Kathryn Hunter rises from a table in an upstairs rehearsal room at the Young Vic Theater and begins an extraordinary transformation. Her knees bend and her pelvis lowers. Her toes twist inward and her elbows out. Her arms seem somehow to lengthen and her chest broadens. Her brow furrows and her cheeks round.

headline: The Supreme Court, Throwing Curveballs
text: Cases concerning baseball seem to turn the minds of lawyers and judges to mush.

headline: Money and March Madness

headline: Search Warrants for the Lanza Residence
text: The search warrants for the house Adam Lanza lived in with his mother, Nancy, were released to the public on Thursday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: Wine spritzers were an indispensable cocktail-party accessory for many women in the 1970s and ‘80s. And they’re coming back, with better ingredients. – Patrick Farrell

headline: The Cynics of Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — I was talking last week to a senior official from the Congress Party in one of the capital’s colonial bungalows that are a much-envied perk of power when news arrived that the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (D.M.K.), a party from the southern state of Tamil Nadu and an important partner in Congress’s ruling alliance, had withdrawn support from the government. The functionary was gleeful. That reaction surprised me, but less so than the explanation for it: “There goes Chidambaram’s chance of becoming prime minister.”

headline: Newtown Killer’s Obsessions, in Chilling Detail
text: Inside the rambling, pale-yellow Colonial-style home in a Connecticut suburb, Adam Lanza lived amid a stockpile of disparate weaponry and macabre keepsakes: several firearms, more than 1,600 rounds of ammunition, 11 knives, a starter pistol, a bayonet, 3 samurai swords. He saved photographs of what appeared to be a corpse smeared in blood and covered in plastic, as well as a newspaper clipping that chronicled a vicious shooting at Northern Illinois University.

headline: Judge Eases Bail Terms for Pistorius
text: JOHANNESBURG — A judge on Thursday eased the unusually tight bail restrictions on Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee Olympic runner who is accused of murdering his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, on Feb. 14 in one of the most sensational cases in South Africa’s recent judicial history.

headline: Infected by Animus
text: Two days of oral argument in the Supreme Court about same-sex marriage show both how far this country has come in recognizing the rights of gay and lesbian Americans, and how much still needs to change.

headline: The Gun Report: March 28, 2013
text: Is it possible to commit cold-blooded murder, in broad daylight, on a busy Manhattan street full of witnesses, and even a camera recording the shooting? It is sure starting to look that way.

headline: C.D.C’s New Anti-Smoking Campaign
text: Terrie Hall, a former smoker from North Carolina, has become something of a national celebrity from her participation in the CDC's new anti-smoking campaign.

headline: One Streak Ends, 16 Are on the Line
text: Now that the Miami Heat’s winning streak has fizzled to an unsatisfying end, we can all go back to contemplating the N.C.A.A. tournaments’ rounds of 16 or contemplating an imminent baseball season or watching “Iron Chef” reruns or whatever else usually fills the time between spring supposedly starting and when it really starts. It was nice that the N.B.A.'s ludicrously long regular season threw in a reason to watch its most tortured portion for awhile — it was no Linsanity, but still — and now it has passed into instant history. Now the Heat can claim the streak was never really important and you can all push the pause button on your attention spans until the playoffs.

headline: After a Built-In Vacuum, 5 Things Parents Want in a Car
text: Until now, I’d only seen on-board car vacuums in two incarnations: a dog I once had, who would eat anything and was more than willing to stick her snout in places that I’d be afraid to put my hand, and a take-along Dustbuster that one neater-than-I-am friend keeps plugged in in her car — effective, but a little inconvenient in the front seat.

headline: Mitchel Thompson’s War
text: On Aug. 1, 1860, an article in the Chicago Tribune proclaimed, “Great doings in Warren County.” The reporter recounted the immense surge in political support for the Republican presidential candidate, Abraham Lincoln, in the northwest farm regions. At a flagpole raising near Monmouth, pro-Lincoln speakers fulminated by the hour to “enthusiastic shouts” from a large crowd. In neighboring Henderson County a flood of 5,000 people, including hundreds arriving by steamboat from Iowa, crowded into Oquawka for a Republican rally later that month.

headline: A Financial Self-Defense Guide for Older Americans
text: The board that oversees the certification of financial planners has developed a guide to help older Americans avoid fraud and abuse.

headline: 2013 New York Auto Show: Photo Gallery
text: Highlights from the New York International Auto Show in New York.

headline: New Era for British Financial Regulators Is About to Begin
text: LONDON – As most of Britain shuts down for the Easter holiday, workers at the Financial Services Authority will be busily putting the final touches to the largest overhaul of the country’s financial regulation in more than a decade.

headline: Christian Marclay’s ‘Things I’ve Heard’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A New Doctorow Novel
text: E. L. Doctorow, the author of “The Book of Daniel” and “Ragtime” among many other novels, has a work coming in early 2014, his publisher, Random House, said on Wednesday. Mr. Doctorow, best known for works of historical fiction like “World’s Fair,” which won the National Book Award for fiction, appears to be taking a new tack in the novel, “Andrew’s Brain.” In a news release Kate Medina, his editor, said: “It’s an of-the-moment novel whose main character, speaking from an unknown place and to an unknown interlocutor, unfurls his life, his loves and the circumstances that have led him to commit a mysterious act.” Besides the National Book Award, Mr. Doctorow has won two PEN/Faulkner Awards, three National Book Critics Circle Awards and the National Humanities Medal.

headline: Sprint and SoftBank Pledge to Forgo Huawei Equipment, Lawmaker Says
text: Sprint Nextel and its Japanese suitor, SoftBank, have assured lawmakers that they would not use equipment from China’s Huawei Technologies in Sprint’s cellphone network, the chairman of the House intelligence committee said on Thursday.

headline: Clip: ‘Wrong’
text: A scene from "Wrong," the new surreal comedy from Quentin Dupieux.

headline: Syria’s War Invades a Campus That Acted as a Sanctuary
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — More and more students at Damascus University were skipping classes. The whack and thump of shelling in the distance punctuated the hum of the downtown campus. Some students walked miles to avoid the security checkpoints that choke traffic.

headline: Elizabeth Strout: By the Book
text: The author of “The Burgess Boys” and “Olive Kitteridge” thinks the president should read Barbara Pym to give him “a few minutes to completely relax.”

headline: Twins No More
text: Back in the Reagan years two unprecedented things began happening to the US economy. For the first time ever, we began running large peacetime budget deficits; and for the first time ever we began running large trade deficits. In a famous analysis, Martin Feldstein pronounced them “twin deficits”, linking the external deficit to the budget deficit, a proposition that made sense at the time: the budget deficit was helping to drive up interest rates, and high rates led to an overvalued dollar.

headline: Last Year’s Victorious No. 15 Seeds Back Florida Gulf Coast
text: Sometime before Florida and Florida Gulf Coast tip off Friday night, before the next episode of the Eagles’ enthralling aerial show, Kyle O’Quinn will send a text message to Kenny Boynton.

headline: What’s the Greek for Corralito?
text: It’s now three years since I suggested a possible route to Greek exit from the euro: a banking crisis, followed by sharp limits on bank withdrawals similar to Argentina’s 2001 corralito, and then — with the panic argument against exit removed — reintroduction of a domestic currency.

headline: Keeping Score: Lillard Has Edge in Rookie Race
text: With just three weeks left in the regular season, there are plenty of interesting playoff races to keep an eye on. But another race worth watching is the one for rookie of the year: Damian Lillard of the Portland Trail Blazers, Bradley Beal of the Washington Wizards and Anthony Davis of the New Orleans Hornetshave separated themselves from the pack.

headline: Valentine Will Be an Analyst on SNY
text: Bobby Valentine, the former Mets manager, is returning to the Mets as a pregame and postgame analyst on SNY.

headline: In Former Pushkin Space, a New American: Betony
text: Two former colleagues from Eleven Madison Park — Bryce Shuman, who was an executive sous-chef, and Eamon Rockey, who was a captain and involved in Atera and Aska — have teamed up to create Betony, a modern American restaurant. They plan to open later this spring in the Midtown spot that briefly housed Brasserie Pushkin, a two-story space with a soaring front area and windows overlooking West 57th Street.

headline: Image of the Day: March 28
text: A demonstration seeking better educational and employment opportunities for the disabled in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: C.D.C’s New Anti-Smoking Campaign
text: A new ad from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Finding the Story
text: Nicole Bengiveno searches for the story while photographing the St. Patricks Day Parade.

headline: With Deal, Benckiser Seeks to Bolster Its Coffee Empire
text: Joh. A. Benckiser has quite the caffeine craving, it seems.

headline: Say No to the Dress
text: When I meet a young woman, sometimes one of my students, sometimes a baby sitter, always creative, a little insecure, I often think of the day I found my wedding dress.

headline: 36 Hours in Bangalore, India
text: Many tourists who find themselves in Bangalore, India’s third-largest city, are merely on their way to somewhere else: Goa, for instance, or Kerala. But there is reason to linger in this lively city of some nine and a half million people. As the capital of the State of Karnataka and India’s information technology hub, Bangalore has lots to offer: lush parks and gardens, a remarkably diverse restaurant scene, a raj-era palace and several beautiful churches, temples and mosques, not to mention temperatures in the 70s and 80s year round. Yes, the suffocating traffic can cause tempers to flare, but Bangaloreans are generally friendly and fun-loving. The stylish Koramangala and Indiranagar neighborhoods offer plenty of shopping, dining and night life, including dance clubs, sports bars and a jazz club. And if you like bowling, you’ve come to the right place.

headline: A Taste of Bangalore, India
text: Sample scenes from the country’s third-largest city.

headline: Using Ex-Smokers to Spur Others to Quit
text: In the last year, Terrie Hall, a former smoker from North Carolina, has become something of a national celebrity.

headline: Amid Crisis, Banks Reopen in Cyprus
text: The Times’s Liz Alderman surveys the uneasy scene in Nicosia; and a look at members of the country’s increasingly disgruntled Russian community.

headline: Sizzling in Helsinki
text: The Kallio district, once considered off-limits to visitors, now pulses with exotic cafes and inviting boutiques.

headline: MetroPCS: At Least One Proxy Adviser Likes Our T-Mobile Deal
text: The biggest proxy advisory firm around may have recommended that shareholders reject MetroPCS‘s planned merger with T-Mobile USA, but the cellphone service provider hasn’t lost hope yet. Another firm is on board with the deal.

headline: Taking Some Mystery Out of Blind Booking
text: For travelers willing to trade certainty for savings, Priceline, Hotwire and a new site called GetGoing are taking some of the mystery out of the opaque booking process.

headline: Reader Idea | Exploring Ethical Issues Through Times Reporting
text: It’s Reader Idea week on the blog, with four new additions to our long-running series. If you’ve taught with The Times and would like to see your idea featured, please write in and tell us what you’ve done.

headline: Brittney Griner, Me, and Four Amazing Years at Baylor
text: After watching the No. 3-seeded Baylor Lady Bears win the national championship in 2005, I knew where I wanted to go to college.

headline: John Malone’s Ziggo Stardust
text: John C. Malone’s latest swoop in the cable sector is true to form.

headline: A Play’s Love Woes Cut Close to Home
text: Nathan Lane was 21 and at a loss when he fell for another actor in a dinner theater production of “Guys and Dolls” in 1977. While Mr. Lane had known for years that he was gay, he struggled with self-loathing over his sexuality, and the art of flirting mystified him. Finally, on the last night of the musical, the other man asked him to go into New York for that summer’s big event, the blackout. “Yeah” was all Mr. Lane said, but it was enough. They ended up in the dark at a gay bar in Manhattan, and went on to date for a couple of years.

headline: Showmen Blazing a Trail
text: WHILE Douglas Carter Beane didn’t base “The Nance,” starring Nathan Lane, on any real-life figure from burlesque, he did draw on several performers for inspiration, from the Roaring Twenties to today.

headline: Breaking It Down: Anderson Vs. Tipsarevic
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — All points in tennis are not created equal.

headline: New Cable Cabals to Untangle
text: Season 3 of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” begins with satisfyingly crunchy sounds of slaughter and a haunting image: chubby Samwell Tarly, abandoned by his mates in the Night’s Watch, running in terror through the mists on the far side of the Wall.

headline: Remarks by President Obama on Gun Violence
