text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download and what entertainment is worth.

headline: Landslide Near Seattle Followed Years of Shift
text: The violent energy of the earth can sometimes feel predictable. An earthquake striking a steep slope of gravel or boulders creates an outcome that even a nongeologist could foresee. Volcanoes can literally move mountains.

headline: You Are Feeling Very ... Uncertain
text: AUSTIN, TEX. — Danny Boyle has always been something of a cinematic hypnotist. He has a knack for guiding moviegoers across disparate cinematic terrain using colorful, kinetic visuals and throbbing electronic soundtracks, conjuring immersive worlds that viewers easily fall into.

headline: Good News: U.S. Traffic Is Getting Worse
text: American traffic delays are rising for the first time in years. That’s an indication that the economy is getting healthier, according to an analysis by Inrix, a data firm.

headline: Infections Tied to Cognitive Decline
text: A new study adds to the evidence that chronic infection, known to be associated with vascular disease, is also associated with poorer performance on tests of mental ability.

headline: As Economy Heats Up, Traffic Backs Up
text: TRAFFIC is getting worse in the United States, according to a company that monitors driving time by tracking cellphones and GPS devices in cars and trucks.

headline: Not Buying (or Bankrolling) the Easter Bunny
text: When a friend of mine who knows that I’m a Santa Claus denier, a Valentine’s Day objector and a St. Paddy’s Day agnostic asked me what I thought about the Easter Bunny, I launched into a rant about traditions where we celebrate joy and wonderment by deceiving our children.

headline: Bentley Showcases Its Craftsmanship at an Atelier
text: With an almost Dickensian air of Bob Cratchit sitting at his tall desk, two craftsmen from Bentley’s bespoke studio in Crewe, England, occupied a space on Greenwich Street in Manhattan on Tuesday. They had been transported to Lower Manhattan to showcase the American introduction of the company’s new car, the Flying Spur sedan.

headline: Ayanbadejo, Kluwe to Be Honored for Equality Efforts
text: The former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue will present an award to players Brendon Ayanbadejo and Chris Kluwe next week, honoring their support of equality for the gay and lesbian community.

headline: Hit or Flop? Expert on Broadway Musicals to Write History Explaining Why
text: Jack Viertel, the artistic director of New York City Center Encores!, has signed a deal with Farrar, Straus & Giroux to write a book about the structure and inner workings of Broadway musicals and why some shows succeed and others falter, the publisher and Mr. Viertel said this week. The book, tentatively titled: “The Secret Life of the Broadway Musical: How Broadway Shows are Built,” is scheduled for publication in winter 2016.

headline: Syria, Iran and the N.R.A. Versus Everybody
text: It was always wishful thinking to expect that all of the United Nations’ 193 member states would approve the treaty regulating global trade in conventional weapons that was negotiated in New York this week. But the conclusion reached on Thursday was stark: On one side, opposing the new pact, were three of the world’s pariah states – Syria, Iran and North Korea. On the other side, favoring the new pact, was … everybody else.

headline: Many Film Languages
text: Images of Hollywood actors in non-English films.

headline: Bilingualism Steps Into a Leading Role
text: In his latest movie, a noir thriller called “Everybody Has a Plan,” Viggo Mortensen plays twin brothers, one a doctor in a midlife crisis, the other a ne’er-do-well mixed up in all kinds of shady business. In her newest offering, “In the House,” Kristin Scott Thomas is cast as an art gallery director whose marriage starts to teeter when her husband, a high school literature teacher, takes an undue interest in a pupil.

headline: Some Veteran Rockers Help to Pass the Torch
text: With Alice Cooper approximating Jim Morrison’s trademark alternation of growling intensity and meditative sultriness, and Robby Krieger reprising his vintage guitar solos, a starry band dominated by glam-metal veterans worked their way through the Doors classics “Back Door Man” and “Break On Through (To the Other Side)” on Thursday evening in Sioux Falls, S.D., as part of a concert to benefit the city’s new Brennan Rock & Roll Academy.

headline: Fresh Kicks
text: Vans, a favorite of surfers and skaters, goes for an Asian punk brightly colored look this season. The Kenzo designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim emblazoned the canvas kicks with motifs culled from their spring 2013 collection, which was inspired by a trip to Thailand. While the collection’s colorful leopard spots and bursts of floral prints may be a challenge to pull off on a head-to-toe look, the exuberant pops of pattern on these Vans feel just right. $125; openingceremony.us (beginning Monday).

headline: Weekend Fare
text: While many Easter workshops may be for children, Neuhaus, the luxury Belgian chocolatier at 500 Madison Avenue in Midtown, is offering one for adults, from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday and 9 to 11 a.m. Saturday. Guests will decorate their own chocolate Easter egg shells and choose pralines to take home in a houndstooth-wrapped package. The class is $75 a person and includes all materials and beverages. Call (212) 644-4490 to make a reservation.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Earth 2’ at No. 1
text: There is an embarrassment of riches on our hardcover and paperback graphic books best-seller lists this week.

headline: Who Wanted to Take the Case on Gay Marriage? Ask Scalia
text: WASHINGTON — Why did the Supreme Court agree in December to hear a major same-sex marriage case and then seem to think it had made a terrible mistake on Tuesday when it came time for arguments?

headline: Why Are Boomers Getting S.T.D.s?
text: Some time back, researchers writing in The New England Journal of Medicine decided to ask older Americans about their sex life and discovered something interesting: very often, they have one.

headline: Strikeouts on the Rise
text: Last season, teams struck out at a rate never before seen. Theories as to why hitters are striking out in ever-increasing numbers reflect changes in both pitching and hitting.

headline: In Paris, Mixing the Contemporary With the Classics
text: While many world capitals feed off the energy of modernity, Paris is loved because it represents an escape from it. So when most people visit the city, their agenda involves visiting monuments like the Louvre, the Hôtel de Ville and Notre Dame. The baby of the group is the Eiffel Tower, built in 1887.

headline: Hiking Beyond Borders in the Balkans
text: The seasons were changing fast, and the warmth I’d taken for granted had vanished as night mustered in the hills. I gathered the blanket around my neck and listened to the dogs barking below. It was now long past midnight, with only a few hours until the morning call to prayer.

headline: A Book Doctor in Dallas Patches Up Well-Loved Bibles
text: DALLAS — “We’ll find hair clippings,” Candice McKay, owner of the Book Doctor in Dallas, said last week. “And palm leaves from Palm Sunday. It’s not uncommon.”

headline: Into the Albanian Alps
text: Towering peaks, rustic inns and views that span countries on a trek through the Balkans.

headline: Guest Workers Are at Crux of Groups’ Deal on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top business and labor groups were near agreement Friday on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants, closing in on a deal that would eliminate one of the last significant obstacles to a new proposal for a broad overhaul of immigration laws, officials involved in the talks said.

headline: Why Strikeout Rates Are Soaring
text: As their strikeout totals piled up last summer, the pitchers for the Milwaukee Brewers hardly noticed. The team was struggling to reach .500, and the rotation had been in flux all year. It did not feel as if the pitching staff was closing in on the record for strikeouts in a season.

headline: Vegetables Make the Sandwich
text: Sandwiches are often about the meat or the cheese between two slices of bread, but with a simple shift of focus, a sandwich can be a healthful showcase for vegetables, as Martha Rose Shulman writes in this week’s Recipes for Health:

text: The Kia Sorento SXL V-6 at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

headline: Relative of Jailed Chinese Laureate Faces Fraud Charges
text: HONG KONG — The brother-in-law of Liu Xiaobo, China’s jailed Nobel Peace Prize winner, is likely to face trial soon on fraud charges that a lawyer for the family said on Friday lacked sufficient evidence and that supporters said appeared to be an effort to deter Mr. Liu’s wife from defying house arrest.

headline: Making Big Money, Finally, for Not Striking Out
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Jeff Keppinger is playing for his seventh major league team in 10 years. He has never reached double figures in home runs or stolen bases, has never played in the postseason and has never, until now, played on more than a one-year contract.

headline: On a Cold Night in Brooklyn … a Daredevil Bike Race
text: If you were just about to compete in a fixed-gear bike race, in the dark, in the cold, on a course with some very sharp turns and 30 or so other competitors, your nerves would show, right? At the Red Hook Criterium last year, the photographer Benedict Evans decided to find out. “The idea,” Evans, an avid cyclist himself, told me, “was to set up a kind of portable studio outdoors near the track, but it rained on the day, so I ended up renting the biggest U-Haul truck I could afford, covering the inside of it with black paper, driving it up next to the finish line and coaxing people inside it to be photographed. I figured that anyone willing to ride brakeless bikes around an intricate course in the dark of night would make for an interesting subject.” You can see some of his portraits here, among them that of Dan Chabanov, a bike messenger who has won three of the five races held so far.

headline: Investing as an Art Form, Not a Science
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at the investing prowess of doctors and lawyers — the people who often live in the fanciest houses in town and drive the most expensive cars.

headline: Mets Leave Camp Upbeat Despite Santana’s Injury
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A day after Johan Santana learned that he had retorn a capsule in his pitching shoulder, all but ending his career with the Mets, his agent insisted that Santana was not done pitching.

headline: Savage Versus Sumptuous in a Season of Viennese Opera
text: VIENNA — Performances of Wagner’s “Parsifal,” with its Christian themes and Good Friday finale, start to swell toward the beginning of the year and crest in the Easter season.

headline: Big Ticket | Terraced Duplex, Sold for $17.75 Million
text: A sprawling duplex co-op on prim Park Avenue that had been owned by Hassan Nemazee, who apparently lived a tad too large before being sentenced in 2010 to 12 years in prison for $292 million in bank fraud, was sold by the federal government for $17.75 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Cutting Up Fennel
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to cut up fennel to use both the bulb and the fronds.

headline: A Childhood Favorite Grows Up
text: The childhood pleasure of tomato soup with a side of grilled cheese had been enshrined in my mind since I’d last had it, decades ago. A tart, bright tomato soup and a crispy sandwich with an oozing interior: no wonder they are an iconic match.

headline: Judge Says Cambodian Statue Case Can Go Forward
text: A federal judge ruled Friday that the United States government has enough evidence to move forward in court with its effort to seize a 10th century Cambodian statue that Sotheby’s had hoped to sell for $3 million.

headline: For N.C.A.A., AT&T Calls on Pro Basketball Stars
text: A popular series of television commercials is getting stretched out, literally and figuratively.

headline: The Original Digital Pet Returns for a New Generation
text: Making the most of a recent nostalgia trend in technology that has brought back brands like Furby and Pac-Man, Bandai is reintroducing Tamagotchi, the digital pet from the 1990s, as a lifestyle brand called Tamagotchi L.I.F.E. (for Love Is Fun Everywhere).

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ and the Fantasy Author’s Challenge
text: Just in time for this weekend’s premiere of season 3 of “Game of Thrones,” John Lanchester has a fine London Review of Books essay on the show, the George R.R. Martin books, and fantasy fiction’s place in literary culture today. I recommend reading the whole piece (so long as you don’t mind significant spoilers), but I was struck by this meditation on fantasy’s longstanding segregation from more respectable forms of fiction:

headline: Grandfathers’ Age Linked to Autism
text: Older paternal age has been linked to autism in a man’s offspring, but now researchers have found that the older a man is when his child is born, the greater the risk for autism in his grandchild.

headline: Designer Fashion, but Only So Much
text: Bobbi Brown, 55, is the founder and chief creative officer of the makeup line that bears her name. A Chicago native and mother of three sons, Ms. Brown lives in Montclair, N.J., with her husband, Steven Plofker, a real estate developer.

headline: After Photo Goes Viral, ‘Dufnering’ Becomes a Thing
text: HUMBLE, Tex. – Everywhere you looked at the Houston Open, golfers were holding their poses Friday. Not their follow-throughs after textbook swings but their imitations of their fellow touring professional Jason Dufner.

headline: Movie Review | 'The Host'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Host."

headline: Shoe Tossed at Musharraf Misses Mark, Video Shows
text: Pakistan’s former military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, narrowly escaped being struck in the head by a shoe hurled at him outside a courtroom in Karachi on Friday, video of the incident showed.

headline: ‘Prince of Broadway’ Is Becoming King of Delays
text: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: Fennel Frond Pesto and More
text: In this week’s video I demonstrate how to dismember a fennel bulb. Then I use both the bulb and some of the fronds in a tomato soup recipe in this week’s column.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Withdraws I.P.O.
text: The stock market may be on a roll, but Toys “R” Us will not be joining the fun.

headline: A Last Chance for ‘Happy Endings’
text: The ABC comedy “Happy Endings” returns on Friday night after a two-month hiatus, with back-to-back episodes that may be the show’s last chance for salvation.

headline: The Emily Posts of the Digital Age
text: Are manners dead? Cellphones, Twitter and Facebook may be killing off the old civilities and good graces, but a new generation of etiquette gurus, good-manner bloggers and self-appointed YouTube arbiters is rising to make old-fashioned protocols relevant to a new generation.

headline: Obama Pushes Plan to Build Roads and Bridges
text: MIAMI — President Obama came to the congested ocean port here on Friday to promote his plans to rebuild the nation’s “raggedy” roads, bridges, schools and other infrastructure with a marriage of public and private investment.

headline: Her Gig Canceled After Tirade, Michelle Shocked Plays Outside in Protest
text: After the punk-folk singer-songwriter Michelle Shocked made remarks critical of homosexuality and same-sex marriage while performing in San Francisco two weekends ago, clubs around the country responded by canceling bookings they had made with her. But that hasn’t stopped her: Thursday night she turned up outside one such club with her face covered and her mouth taped shut to protest the way she is being treated.

headline: Movie Review | 'Renoir'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Renoir."

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, Iraq, North Korea and Kashmir.

headline: Free to Ride, Roam and Design Handbags
text: Flipping through a recent issue of The New Yorker, I noticed an ad for a handsome-looking bag in brown tooled leather. What caught my eye was the low-key design and dark hue but also the brand: the King Ranch of Texas.

headline: Against Top-Ranked Errani and Vinci, Raymond and Robson Keep Winning
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. – One more world No. 1 has been toppled at the Sony Open, this time on the women’s doubles side.

headline: Filing Shows Twisting Path to Three-Way Race for Dell
text: Though the race for Dell Inc. has narrowed to three contestants, many more arose over a month ago.

headline: Movie Review | 'Place Beyond the Pines'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Place Beyond the Pines."

headline: No Comment Necessary: Background Checks and Breakfast
text: Via Think Progress

text: A view of the day in sports, including Euroleague postseason basketball in Berlin and preseason baseball in Florida.

headline: Lessons Learned in Investing in Rental Properties
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at the pros and cons of investing in rental properties.

headline: Rental Investment May Seem Safer Than It Really Is
text: Investing in a tangible asset like real estate may seem to offer a greater sense of control. You can walk through a house, after all, which somehow feels safer than subjecting your savings to the whims of the stock market.

headline: Feeling For | Pucci Dragon Clutch
text: To celebrate this Sunday’s premiere of the third season of HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” unleash the dragons with a clutch worthy of a Khaleesi.

headline: The Coast Along Whidbey, Before and After the Earth Moved
text: A landslide that struck an island 50 miles north of Seattle sent the equivalent of 40,000 dump-truck loads of earth heaving toward Puget Sound.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 29
text: Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.

headline: Blood, Guts and Hair Spray
text: IT PROBABLY SEEMED LIKE a good idea at the time for the members of the British glam-metal band Wrathchild to be so peacockishly come-hither on the cover of their 1984 album “Stakk Attakk.” With songs like “Trash Queen” and “Too Wild to Tame,” no doubt they took pride in their toweringly teased locks, baby-doll lips and strappy S-and-M gear. But nearly 30 years later the image doesn’t quite scream Beasts of Metal. It more whispers, Lady Clown.

headline: Timeline: How Michael Dell’s Takeover Bid Got Hatched
text: Shareholders may still be irate over the $13.65 a share that Michael S. Dell has bid for the company that bears his name.

headline: Who Are the Best Voices in the History of Metal?
text: “Raining Blood” may not be “Harlem Shake,” but to Howie Abrams and Sacha Jenkins it might as well be. Slayer’s popular 1986 song is No. 4 on the list “Our Favorite Songs by the Best Metal Bands,” one of several indexes the authors compiled for “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists,” set for release this month by Abrams Image. The book features scores of compilations of bests (songs, drummers, bass tones), worsts (“10 Heavy Metal Fashion Faux Pas”) and the only-in-metal (“10 Illegible Black Metal Logos”).

headline: Students Nod to Forefathers of Styles
text: For a few decades now, some of the top ballet schools and companies of various nations have brought their foremost students and apprentices together in exchanges and public sharings. The results in performance can be enchanting, fascinating, perplexing, frustrating — sometimes all at once. On Tuesday, when the Royal Ballet School and American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company shared a program at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, all the young dancers were very appealing; some rose to their challenges with particular skill.

headline: Southern Town in Syria Is Seized by Rebel Fighters
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Syrian antigovernment activists reported the rebel seizure of a strategically important town in southern Syria on Friday only a few miles from the Jordanian border, which if confirmed would represent a new setback for government forces, who have already ceded territory to the insurgency in the north and east.

headline: Reimagining a Brawny Jeep for a Less Rugged Landscape
text: On Wednesday, Jeep came to New York, of all places, to take the wraps off a new S.U.V. with an old name: the Cherokee.

headline: Jeep Opts for Sleek
text: Boxy, rough-riding S.U.V.’s have faded in favor of car-based crossovers aimed at younger, more suburban customers. To keep up with that trend, Jeep gave its 2014 Cherokee a softer look.

headline: Another Sport Franchise for Ford
text: TESTED 2013 Ford Explorer Sport

headline: Fast-Food Union Organizers Get Some Historical Perspective
text: When Alvin Turner and Baxter Leach joined a strike in Memphis in 1968, they were two sanitation workers protesting the abuse of black employees and demanding higher wages and the recognition of their union. They recalled being beaten and assaulted with tear gas by the police during marches. But after more than 60 days, the strike ended with the city granting many of their demands.

headline: Something Borrowed From the Past
text: The latest wedding fashions are inspired by a couple who didn’t work out so well and by a television series that has been a resounding success.

headline: A Swagger Retooled for 1908
text: JEREMY PIVEN IS BEST KNOWN as the venal, tantrum-throwing superagent Ari Gold on HBO’s hit comedy “Entourage”; as an alumnus of the Piven Theater Workshop in Chicago, founded by his parents, Joyce and Byrne Piven; and as the center of a highly publicized 2009 breach-of-contract dispute after he left a Broadway production of “Speed-the-Plow” two months early, citing exhaustion and mercury poisoning. (Mr. Piven won in arbitration.)

headline: Drive by Wire, an Aerospace Solution
text: So long as their car moves when the pedal is pressed, there is little reason for drivers of newer cars to care whether electronics have replaced the physical connection between the accelerator and the engine.

headline: Beyond All-Wheel Drive, All-Wheel Steering
text: The notion of making vehicles turn better by steering all four of their wheels has inspired engineers for decades. The United States Army experimented with all-wheel-steering jeeps during World War II, and the benefits to maneuverability of rear-steering have long been known to firefighters assigned to hook-and-ladder trucks.

headline: Celebrating With Beer, Not Bubbly
text: Shrinking unemployment, healthy sales, shoppers flexing their tire-kicking legs: carmakers selling in the revived North American market have much to celebrate at the New York International Auto Show, which opened on Friday.

headline: A Big Gulp in the Czech Republic
text: A representative of the Guinness World Records measures a giant bottle of wine in Cejkovice, in southern Czech Republic. At more than two meters in height, and containing 200 liters of wine, it has been declared the largest wine bottle in the Czech Republic.

headline: A Few Thoughts on Her Shoes
text: It’s not only about the dress. For some brides these days, the shoes are commanding as much attention as the gown. Brides are kicking aside the classic white or ivory pumps in favor of bright pops of color, floral patterns, those bedazzled with bling, accentuated with feathers and lace, and even their own customized pair.

headline: Your Favorite Bowls
text: Consider the bowl, the most common of household objects. We asked readers to send images of their favorite bowls and tell us what makes them special.

headline: Vows: Vintage-Inspired Style
text: The wedding style guru Mark Ingram and the Styles reporter Bee-Shyuan Chang discuss the 1920s style wedding trend and offer ways to incorporate a little Daisy Buchanan into your wedding-day look.

headline: Wedding Gowns That Evoke A Bygone Era
text: Bridal gowns that recall the look of “The Great Gatsby” are growing increasingly popular this wedding season.

headline: The Pictures from the Week in Culture, March 29
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including performances by Taylor Swift and Sigur Ros.

headline: Bipartisan Rebuke for Republican Congressman Who Used Slur
text: Under pressure from Congressional leaders and advocacy groups, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, has apologized for describing Hispanic farm workers who picked tomatoes on his father’s ranch as “wetbacks” in an interview.

headline: Listening to the Leukocytes and Moving Beyond James Brown
text: Steve Coleman and Five Elements

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 29
text: More photographs.

headline: 'Game of Thrones' Fans Flourish
text: The Times's Dave Itzkoff on why a fantasy television show set in medieval times is catching fire with a broad audience.

headline: Ex-Schools Chief in Atlanta Is Indicted in Testing Scandal
text: During his 35 years as a Georgia state investigator, Richard Hyde has persuaded all sorts of criminals — corrupt judges, drug dealers, money launderers, racketeers — to turn state’s evidence, but until Jackie Parks, he had never tried to flip an elementary school teacher.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Ugly Photos, and Delivery by Google
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: In Relocating, a Bar Will Lose No Claim to Celluloid Fame
text: The Emerald Inn, the Upper West Side bar that was the setting for a scene in the movie “The Apartment,” is moving to the site of a bar that figured in another, much darker, movie, “Looking for Mr. Goodbar.”

headline: Fogging Up the Windows of a Big Store
text: “Mr. Selfridge” is an eight-part, roughly eight-hour mini-series about the American businessman who opened the revolutionary London department store Selfridges in 1909. It’s also a soldier in the current bloody war for period-drama domination between the British television networks ITV and BBC, whose combatants include “Downton Abbey” and “Mr. Selfridge,” on ITV, and “Call the Midwife” and “The Paradise,” on BBC. (Already dead: BBC’s flat-footed “Upstairs Downstairs” sequel.)

headline: The Rewards of Being Very Serious
text: A while back, before moving to Slate, Matthew Yglesias had what I considered a brilliant insight into the incentives facing small-country political leaders:

headline: One Woman, Multiplying Identities
text: It may not be entirely clear to you from the first episode why BBC America is billing “Orphan Black,” its new suspense series, as part of its “Supernatural Saturday” programming block, alongside “Doctor Who.” But by the end of the second episode, this tasty show starts to reveal that it is not just another identity-swapping story. Something creepily sci-fi is definitely going on.

headline: A Robot for Part of the Pit Crew
text: The Pentagon, in an effort to develop low-cost artificial hands, has built a robot that can take a tire off a car. Putting it back on is another problem altogether.

headline: Justin Bieber and Youth’s New Wilderness
text: Justin Bieber has had it rough of late. Even before this week’s news that his neighbor was accusing him of battery, the 19-year-old Canadian superstar endured a public breakup with his girlfriend, Selena Gomez; was photographed supposedly reveling with codeine-spiked cough syrup and marijuana, and was snubbed by the Grammys. He retaliated with a live-stream Internet performance that hit technical snags.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Modern Man
text: My late-in-life odyssey through current music began when Arcade Fire’s The Suburbs won the Grammy for best album, and I decided for some reason to give them a listen — and was shocked to discover that good music didn’t end in the 1970s. Since then I’ve found many bands I love, but I do keep coming back to AF — and I keep finding new depths in that album. Here’s a quiet one:

headline: Still Dancing Freely at 50, in 50 Birthday Duets
text: The number 50 figures prominently in the choreographer and teacher Lance Gries’s new video installation, which he created in honor of his 50th birthday. For it he asked 50 dancers to each join him for a 50-minute improvisatory duet.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a New Diabetes Drug From J.&J.
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first of a new class of medicines to treat diabetes.

headline: The Dark Stuff, Distilled
text: When Joseph Weisberg was training to be a case officer for the C.I.A. in the early 1990s, he soon learned that deception was a crucial skill, one that involved lying to his family on a regular basis.

headline: An Unlikely Jihadist, Denouncing Assad in Mandarin
text: BEIJING — The man in camouflage fatigues raised his Kalashnikov rifle and fired three shots into the air while trudging through a field of purple and yellow flowers.

headline: Europe’s Second Depression: A Correction
text: Aha — in my post on Europe’s policy failure, I somehow failed to notice that the new Maddison dataset provides per capita real GDP, which means that I should use per capita GDP in looking at the current crisis. And my point about dismal performance gets even stronger:

headline: What Dell Thought of Alternatives to the Silver Lake Proposal
text: Dell Inc. directors have repeatedly emphasized that they considered all potential ways to improve value for shareholders before accepting a $24.4 billion takeover bid by Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake.

headline: Taking Flight to a Land of Noodles
text: TETERBORO, N.J. — Before Sun Noodle held its first “ramen flight” here earlier this month, George Kao, the company’s sales manager and host of the event, was up until 1 a.m. studying his notes. The five participants in the combination culinary class and tasting probably would have shown up, though, even without the educational part of the program.

headline: Feeling Less Guilt and Doing Some Good
text: The first summer I ever earned any money, I started reading the utilitarian philosopher Peter Singer, who had a few ideas about how I should spend it. To Mr. Singer, since it is cheap to save lives in the third world, we are culpable if we have the cash and don’t help save them. “If you would save a child from drowning in a pond, even if it meant ruining your expensive shoes,” he wrote, “then shouldn’t you also save a child from drowning in poverty, for the cost of your expensive shoes?”

headline: Ex-Soldier Accused of Joining Terrorist Group in Syria Left Trail of Videos
text: As my colleague Scott Shane reports, a former American soldier was charged on Thursday with fighting alongside a rebel group linked to Al Qaeda on the battlefields of the Syrian civil war.

headline: Where the Recipes Call for Sharing
text: Traditional Vietnamese cuisine has the reputation of being one of the healthiest in the world. Considering in the growing popularity of foods that are not only tasty, but also healthful, Saigonese could not have arrived in Hartsdale at a better time. Cooking in this restaurant’s kitchen is about quick preparations of fresh ingredients with masses of dewy herbs (parsley, mint, sweet basil and cilantro). Few items are deep fried.

headline: Applause in Unlikely Places: A Conductor Who Rewrites the Rules
text: During the “Infernal Dance” of Stravinsky’s “Firebird,” which depicts the subjects of the ogre Kastchei spinning with such savagery that they drop in exhaustion, the music builds to vehement, searing chords. In his performance of the complete “Firebird” on Thursday night with the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, the second of two programs, Gustavo Dudamel drew such blazing colors, slashing attacks and sheer terror from the orchestra that at the climax of the dance some people in the hall broke into applause and shouted “Bravo.” This temporarily drowned out the transition that immediately follows: the powerful chords disperse to reveal mysterious, hushed sonorities.

headline: Emcee
text: An emcee at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: A Colorful Palette for a Multicultural Cuisine
text: Rooted in street food, chicken shacks and back-alley cebicherias, Peruvian food has won praise in recent years from such cosmopolitan chefs as Ferran Adrià and Dan Barber. And the king of Peruvian restaurants in central Connecticut is Cora Cora, where Hector Ludena and Luisa Jimenez take guests on a tour of their country’s vivid and robust cuisine.

headline: New Police Chief Confident He Can Handle Job
text: The first question was simple: What made you want to become a police officer?

headline: To Replace Old Cobblestones, Old-Looking Cobblestones
text: They have survived in Brooklyn’s northwestern corner for over a century — handmade and rounded, their shades weathered to a medley of noble grays — rattling the frames of carriages and Chryslers, buses and bicycles beside the waterfront.

headline: Making Robots Mimic the Human Hand
text: As part of a national research project to develop low-cost artificial hands, the Pentagon has released a video of a robot that can change a tire — almost.

headline: Reducing Gun Violence: What Works?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Charisma, Wealth, Flattery. How Can She Resist?
text: The actor, director and playwright Tyler Perry has long embraced religion in his films, but perhaps never more so than in his slack fable “Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor.” Adapted from his 2008 play, “The Marriage Counselor,” the movie inveighs against deviation from the church, monogamy and the righteous path of cooking meals for a husband.

headline: Questions for an Expert on North Korean Propaganda
text: Last Updated, Saturday, 12:35 p.m. As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, North Korea’s state news agency released the latest in a series of saber-rattling images on Friday, this time showing the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, studying what the agency called “plans to strike the mainland U.S.”

headline: Indictments in Atlanta Public Schools Cheating Scandal
text: A grand jury indicted Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta Public Schools, and 34 others on charges connected to one of the largest test-score cheating scandals in the country.

headline: Developing New Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Subversion, Cool and Collected
text: Luis Buñuel began his career as a filmmaker with a Dadaist determination to shock and outrage. He cast himself as the square-jawed dandy who, at the beginning of his first film, “Un Chien Andalou” (1929), impassively draws a straight razor across the eyeball of a compliant young woman without troubling to remove the cigarette from his mouth.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: The bailout in Cyprus was completed, and banks there reopened, albeit under tight capital controls; T-Mobile, now selling the iPhone, introduced a new billing plan; and a top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was arrested.

headline: Poor Baby: Daddy’s Got a Text Message
text: To the Editor:

headline: Italian Classics, Served With Fun
text: Chris Santoro has a sense of humor. The owner of Toro Pazzo, a year-and-a-half-old restaurant in Wantagh, Mr. Santoro said playfully that his name could be translated as “holy bull” in Italian, so he chose as the restaurant’s logo a snorting bull with a halo.

headline: Hollande Draws Bad Reviews as He Answers Critics on TV
text: PARIS — President François Hollande, low in the opinion polls less than a year into the job, went on national television for over an hour on Thursday night in what French commentators likened to an “oral exam” on his job performance.

headline: Nature’s Case for Same-Sex Marriage
text: BIOLOGY has returned to the nation’s highest court. It’s not Darwin’s theory of evolution on the docket this time, but the nature of sex. Defenders of Proposition 8, California’s ban on gay marriage, base their case on what they call the “objective biological fact” that procreation is an exclusively heterosexual process. Citing the 18th-century English jurist William Blackstone, they argue that marriage should be “founded in nature.”

headline: Roster Moves Leave Mets With Two Spots to Fill
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets made several roster moves Friday after they played their final home spring training game. Outfielder Marlon Byrd and pitchers Scott Atchison, LaTroy Hawkins and Scott Rice made the team, while Robert Carson and Omar Quintanilla were sent to Las Vegas, where the Mets have their Class AAA franchise.

headline: Celebrating a Writer Who Put Poetry in Pop
text: Among the countless songs written from a soldier’s point of view, none is more wrenching than Tom Waits and Kathleen Brennan’s “Day After Tomorrow,” a 21-year-old serviceman’s letter to his Illinois family on the eve of his homecoming. He reflects in a song that is beyond bitter:

headline: Silodor Open Pairs
text: At 12:30 p.m. on Thursday, March 21, Billy Cohen of Sherman Oaks, Calif., was getting ready to watch college basketball on his hotel room’s wide-screen television in St. Louis, the site of the Spring North American Championships.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,174 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A New Dance Move
text: An evolving dance move is performed in a Jamaican dance hall.

headline: Just Folk, Inspired by Hungary and Romania
text: Over the last decade, the duo known as a Hawk and a Hacksaw have been exploring the traditional music of Eastern Europe from a distinctly American folk-pop perspective. Though the accordion player Jeremy Barnes was formerly the drummer in Neutral Milk Hotel, and the violinist and pianist Heather Trost played on Beirut’s first two records, their inspiration now comes mostly from places like Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Macedonia.

headline: Jamaican Dancehall Dancing
text: Dancing at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Dancehall Fashion
text: Some new fashion at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Jamaican Dancehall Dancing
text: A woman performs a dance move at a party in Jamaica.

headline: Dancing in a Tree
text: Two party attendees danced in a tree at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Arriving at a Party
text: Revelers slowly trickle into a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Nominee for Energy Secretary Lists Assets and Posts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee for energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, is a consultant to the energy giant BP and a member of the advisory council and board of trustees of King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center, of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, among other positions, according to disclosure statements filed with the government and released on Friday.

headline: Dancing at a Jamaican Dancehall Party
text: Partygoers dance at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Oscars Group Asks for Advice
text: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is inviting its roughly 6,000 members to join what promises to be an unusual group discussion of something that has set off much private debate here recently: the Academy’s future.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Change of Tune in Caramoor’s Music Room
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — Nestled amid the stucco buildings on the sprawling campus of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, the Rosen House Music Room, known for the Renaissance artifacts collected by Caramoor’s onetime owners, Walter and Lucie Rosen, is a stately space where decorous string quartets and the like usually play. So when Caramoor hired the raucous roots group Spuyten Duyvil to entertain at a media event in the room this month, traditionalists found the choice less than wholly palatable.

headline: At Twain’s Home, an Era He Skewered
text: You would expect to be amused at an exhibition generously peppered with the wit and wisdom of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, the writer better known as Mark Twain. And the new show at the Mark Twain House and Museum, “The Gilded Age of Hartford,” does indeed deliver entertainment as it documents the rising fortunes and changing social framework of Hartford in the 1870s, ’80s and ’90s.

headline: Turin Shroud Going on TV, With Video From Pope
text: ROME — The Shroud of Turin, which since medieval times has been revered by many Christians as the burial cloth of Jesus, is about to make its debut on modern media platforms.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The New Man
text: The men’s fashion revolution is in full swing, with looks ranging from ’30s styles to a revival of grunge and mouth grilles.

headline: Ohio Fangirls Embark on a Perilous Quest
text: With “Geek!” the playwright Crystal Skillman and the troupe Vampire Cowboys fly high the freak flag of fantasy. An ode to fangirls and fanboys, the show, in Cowboys tradition, celebrates the universe of anime, comics, science fiction, manga and Hollywood effects spectaculars. It’s a milieu Ms. Skillman clearly knows well and depicts with affection.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Falling to Earth, Only to Witness a Pole Dance
text: It’s easy to be fascinated by our own dreams. Yet when the dreams of others are recounted to us, so much gets lost in translation. Or, to put it more plainly: suffering through someone else’s jump cuts and surreal metaphors can be tedious  as all get-out.

headline: Earnestly, Internationally in Search of Love
text: A romance that whirls halfway around the world, “Roundelay: A Comedy” skips back and forth from America to India, Kenya and the Caribbean as its multicultural characters either pursue love or run away from it. The Passage Theater Company’s production of R. N. Sandberg’s new play at the Mill Hill Playhouse in Trenton offers a pleasant, if somewhat hectic, sojourn with 10 individuals of varying ethnicities who all yearn for love.

headline: Focus on Healing Arts After Kidnapping Conviction
text: SANTIAGO, Chile

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: The Young Germans Who Stood Up to the Nazis
text: Jud Newborn, a Holocaust scholar who lives in Plainview, was doing research in Munich as a graduate student in the early 1980s when he became intrigued with the story of the White Rose resistance movement. The small, student-based group wrote and printed anonymous anti-Nazi leaflets in Munich and distributed them in that city and beyond before its key members were captured and executed in 1943.

headline: Hospitals Question Medicare Rules on Readmissions
text: It is no longer enough for hospitals to make patients healthy enough to leave. Now, as part of the Obama administration’s health care overhaul, they are spending millions of dollars to keep those patients from coming back, often acting like personal assistants to help them manage their post-hospital lives.

headline: From the Swinging ’60s, a Recipe for Farce
text: The eight sturdy doors that surround the living room of a Paris apartment in Marc Camoletti’s “Boeing-Boeing” are a good tip-off that a farce is about to ensue. So is the setup — one bachelor, three fiancées — which is outlined early on by the bachelor, an American architect named Bernard.

headline: The Harsh and Haunting Winds of Sept. 11
text: For many casual observers, the term “wind ensemble” will conjure up notions of earnest students huffing and thumping through Sousa marches and college fight songs. But aficionados, and those who have played in a university wind ensemble during the last 30 years or so, know that such groups now constitute a bona fide hotbed of opportunity for contemporary composers. Neo-Romantics, avant-gardists and postclassical eclectics have heeded the call, lured by generous commissions, multiple performances, and rehearsal time measured in weeks instead of hours.

headline: Blossoming Colt Stirs Up Dreams Set in Kentucky
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Itsmyluckyday stops while walking the shed row in Barn 74 at Calder Race Course to gaze at his reflection in the glass door that leads into the office of Eddie Plesa Jr., his trainer. He leans his head to the right and peers intently as if to say, “Is that really me?”

headline: Libya Arrests 2 Men in Attack on 5 British Aid Activists
text: CAIRO — Libyan security officials said Friday that they had arrested two men in the kidnapping this week in eastern Libya of five British humanitarian activists, at least two of them women who had been sexually assaulted.

headline: Women (and Men) Face Big Hurdles in Training for Marine Infantry Units
text: QUANTICO, Va. — A group of Marine second lieutenants, all men, stood before the ropes on an obstacle course. They looked exhausted, though the day was far from done. One by one, they took their shots at scaling the line. One by one, most of them dropped short of the top. They were already three hours behind the front-runners in their class.

headline: The Point Man of Syracuse’s Tournament Run
text: WASHINGTON — Gerry McNamara still participates in an occasional practice at Syracuse. Not far removed from his playing career, McNamara is the youngest assistant on Coach Jim Boeheim’s staff, so the onus often falls on him to get out there and compete.

headline: With Policy Moves, Quinn Defuses de Blasio’s Attacks in Race for Mayor
text: He has hammered her over the surging level of fines against small businesses, chided her for not demanding greater oversight of New York’s police and denounced her for failing to support a bill providing paid time off for sick workers.

headline: Suspect’s Death Puts Reward in Question
text: LOS ANGELES — In the midst of a frenzied weeklong manhunt, Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa put together one of the largest rewards in Southern California history: $1 million for information leading to the arrest and conviction of Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer who was wanted in multiple killings last month.

headline: Ohio State’s Best Shooter, or Maybe Its Worst
text: LOS ANGELES — According to ESPN’s statistics, Deshaun Thomas took 564 field-goal attempts this season. Not all of them were bad. It only sometimes seemed that way.

headline: Tonight, Tonight, Its World Is Full of Blight
text: Once again, “The Tonight Show” rears its hoary head in the headlines. (Unintentional word-play.)

headline: Quinn Accepts Sick Leave Deal
text: After blocking legislation for three years, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, agreed to a compromise that will eventually make thousands of companies give paid time off to sick workers.

headline: Two Ohio State Players Join Buzzer-Beater Club
text: LOS ANGELES — The club, among the most exclusive in N.C.A.A. tournament history, includes stars and unknowns, guards and post players, from universities with tradition and without. From Christian Laettner to Bryce Drew, James Forrest to Scottie Reynolds, they are linked by clocks dwindled and buzzers beaten and heartbeats elevated.

headline: Pyongyang Blusters, and U.S. Worries About Quieter Risks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — This week, North Korea’s young leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his underlings to prepare for a missile attack on the United States. He appeared at a command center in front of a wall map with the bold, unlikely title, “Plans to Attack the Mainland U.S.” Earlier in the month, his generals boasted of developing a “Korean-style” nuclear warhead that could be fitted atop a long-range missile.

headline: Nevada Legislator Expelled, Then Arrested, as His Life Unravels for the Public to See
text: LAS VEGAS — Nevada’s State Legislature this week voted for the first time to expel one of its own members, and the man was arrested later the same day.

headline: Sick-Pay Plan Called Blessing and Burden
text: The compromise reached on a sick-leave law for workers in New York City drew cheers on Friday from employees who have feared that catching a cold could cost them their jobs. But some employers complained that it would unfairly load yet another expense onto their shoulders.

headline: Marquette Reaping Benefits From Preseason Bootcamp
text: WASHINGTON — Marquette Coach Buzz Williams called himself cantankerous on Friday. He also conceded he had no compassion on the basketball court. One day earlier, he tried to convince reporters that he was not a good person to be around on game days.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 30, 2013
text: “The cheating had been going on so long. We considered it part of our jobs.”

headline: Devices Like Cable Boxes Figured in Internet Attack
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the aftermath this week of one of the most powerful attacks on the Internet, finger-pointing quickly ensued.

headline: A Cross-Cultural Passover
text: For the last five years, Toloache, a Mexican restaurant on 50th Street near Eighth Avenue, has welcomed the arrival of Passover by fusing Jewish and Mexican cuisines into a kind of south of the border Seder menu. Toloache’s chef, Julian Medina, grew up Catholic in Mexico City and converted to Judaism several years ago after marrying a Jewish woman. One way to honor his new tradition was to dream up Mexican riffs on classic Jewish soul food dishes (can you say, tacos de brisket)? The Passover menu, which will continue until April 2, filled the house one evening last week with curious cross-cultural diners and Jewish families — like the Katzes, from North Bellmore, on Long Island.

headline: The Attack of the Killer Surplus
text: It’s not often we stop to ask ourselves: “What’s going on with North Dakota?” But I believe this is the moment.

headline: Lawmakers and Relatives Want More Details Released About Newtown Gunman
text: Two weeks after the Virginia Tech massacre in 2007, Tim Kaine, then governor of Virginia, closed a loophole in the state’s gun laws that had allowed a mentally disturbed student to buy the guns used in the rampage, which left 33 dead.

headline: On Space Coast, Signs of Comeback After End of an Era
text: MELBOURNE, Fla. — The day after the shuttle Atlantis landed for the last time at the Kennedy Space Center on July 21, 2011, Angel Telles, a man with three master’s degrees, scooped up his white Mission 101 coffee mug and drove away from NASA after 24 years on the job there. The shuttle era had ended, and with it the jobs of 8,000 NASA and civilian workers who found themselves unemployed in the midst of a harsh economic downturn and a crush of home foreclosures.

headline: The Coach Who Fought Back
text: In 1966, Beryl Shipley, the basketball coach at the University of Southwestern Louisiana, recruited three African-Americans to play for the Ragin’ Cajuns. Although the school, now known as the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, had accepted black students since the mid-1950s, its teams remained segregated — as did every college athletic team in the state.

headline: Estimated Range of North Korean Missiles
text: Missiles currently in North Korean arsenal.

headline: Waterfront Plans Threaten Dream to Honor a Warship in Brooklyn
text: On the coast of gentrifying Brooklyn, the famous Civil War ironclad the U.S.S. Monitor is now caught up in another fierce battle.

headline: Zumba Instructor Admits to Running a Prostitution Ring
text: A Zumba instructor in Kennebunk, Me., pleaded guilty on Friday to using her dance studio as a front for a prostitution ring that involved scores of men in New England. The plea means that the instructor, Alexis Wright, will avoid a trial, as will the numerous clients who might have been called as witnesses.

headline: Wichita State Loose as Ohio State Looms
text: LOS ANGELES — Wichita State was watching highlights of Ohio State on Friday morning, when the whole team shared a big, hearty laugh.

headline: The Campaign to Outlaw Abortion
text: Anti-abortion groups have been trying to re-impose restrictions on abortion rights for 40 years, but the Legislature and governor of North Dakota have taken this attack on women’s reproductive health and freedom to a shocking new low by passing a bill that they must know perfectly well is unconstitutional by any reading of the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision and others since.

headline: Corrections: March 30, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Went in Tandem
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It has been a long, cold March with a lot of activity, and my brain is worn to a nub atop my brain stem. Maybe that’s why I found this one by Gareth Bain so tough. Or maybe it’s the diabolical cluing. Either way, it’s definitely Saturday, and in my opinion, Dr. Bain and Will Shortz are out for blood.

headline: Toyotas and Torch Songs
text: Al Lambert, Staten Island’s man of cars and song, can sell you a used Toyota by day and give you “Summer Wind” with his big band that evening.

headline: Strengthening the I.M.F.
text: Let’s face it: the International Monetary Fund is not widely loved. It has forced countries in financial distress to adopt counterproductive austerity policies, and it failed to anticipate the financial crisis. But in recent years the I.M.F. has helped stabilize the global economy, most recently by providing loans to troubled European countries like Greece and Ireland. That is why Congress needs to strengthen its governance and bolster its resources by ratifying reforms to the organization that were agreed to in 2010 by its 188 member countries.

headline: Provocateur Comes Into View After Cyberattack
text: Sven Olaf Kamphuis calls himself the “minister of telecommunications and foreign affairs for the Republic of CyberBunker.” Others see him as the Prince of Spam.

headline: Some Yankees Fans Have Gnawing Feeling That All Is Not Well
text: There is little that screams the words “damage” and “control” like a typically news-media-shy baseball owner suddenly making the rounds of sports talk radio and opening his door to quotation-hungry reporters. In a spate of recent interviews, Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ managing general partner, has given his personal assurance that his franchise remains committed to “fielding a championship-caliber team every year.”

headline: Relying on Hotel Rooms for Thousands Uprooted by Hurricane Sandy
text: Five months after Hurricane Sandy, more than 2,000 people who were displaced by the storm remain in hotels in New York City, leading some officials to acknowledge that the city had not been prepared for the challenges in finding them housing.

headline: New Cabs Could Avoid Hybrid Ban
text: Faced with a lawsuit aimed at blocking New York’s so-called Taxi of Tomorrow because it is not a hybrid, the Bloomberg administration has proposed a compromise: Some owners can buy hybrids, as long as they are big enough.

headline: China: Landslide Buries Workers at Mine in Tibet
text: A huge landslide buried 83 workers at a gold mining site in western China on Friday, setting off a frantic rescue effort, China’s state-run Xinhua news agency reported. The government said more than 1,000 rescue workers had been called in to stabilize the area and search for the victims, who had been working at a subsidiary of the China Gold Group Corporation. The authorities said the landslide occurred in Maizhokunggar County, about 45 miles east of Lhasa, the capital of Tibet. There were no details about casualties.

headline: A Ride Home That’s Not a Taxi, Maybe
text: As I was finishing dinner in Park Slope last Friday, I opened an app on my phone and arranged for a car to pick me up.

headline: Japan: Nuclear Plant’s Operator Cites Poor Preparation
text: The operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant acknowledged Friday that it had been ill prepared for the tsunami that swept over the site two years ago. “Though it was difficult to anticipate a giant tsunami, we should not simply blame nature for this accident,” said a report prepared by an internal task force of the plant’s operator, the Tokyo Electric Power Company. “We must sincerely accept that we were unable to draw on human wisdom to prevent it.” The acknowledgment was a reversal from the company’s earlier assertion that the waves were bigger than it could have predicted.

headline: Some Savers in Cyprus May Lose 60 Percent
text: LONDON — Big-ticket savers at the Bank of Cyprus may be forced to accept losses on their deposits that exceed 60 percent in order to keep the stricken bank afloat, bankers briefed on the negotiations said on Friday.

headline: Judge Rebukes 2 Lawyers Profiting From U.S. Disability Law
text: The lawyers drafted the lawsuits by the dozens, claiming that local businesses had violated federal law by not providing access to people with disabilities — and generating thousands of dollars per case in legal fees for themselves.

headline: Central African Republic: Bodies Found in the Capital
text: Volunteers have collected 78 bodies from the streets of Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, since rebel fighters seized control of the city last week, the Central African Red Cross reported Friday. Many of the bodies lacked identification documents, a Red Cross official told Agence France-Presse, and other medical officials said it was not immediately clear whether the dead were rebels, government soldiers, foreign soldiers or civilians. Hospitals in the capital are overflowing with rebels and others wounded in the fighting, above, officials said. A loose coalition of armed groups from the country’s northeast ousted President François Bozizé on Sunday; the rebels, who are reported to have child soldiers among their ranks, accused Mr. Bozizé of breaching the terms of a January peace deal. He first fled to Cameroon but has since requested refuge in Benin, news reports said Friday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 29, 2013

headline: A Prescription for Sick Workers
text: New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn has finally agreed to require businesses to provide paid sick leave for as many as one million workers. This is good news, although it will take at least a year for most employees to enjoy a basic benefit widely available elsewhere.

headline: Platitudes Loom After the Newtown School Carnage
text: HARTFORD

headline: Fighting to Join the Ranks
text: The latest chapter in the effort to incorporate women into Marine Corps ground combat units closed Thursday, after two women (and 12 men) were eliminated from a challenging course.

headline: France: Most Cities Postpone Plan for New School Hours
text: Most French cities are in no hurry to introduce a new government plan for an extra half-day of elementary school on Wednesdays and have elected to postpone the change until 2014, when it becomes mandatory, the Education Ministry confirmed Friday. The ministry estimated that the plan would affect fewer than 25 percent of France’s nearly six million public school children ages 3 to 11 in the coming school year. But several large cities, including Paris, will begin the half-day in September. For more than a century, the French school schedule has been punctuated by a midweek break, originally created for catechism studies. The new plan, which has drawn opposition from teachers and parents, calls for three hours of class time on Wednesdays while reducing the regular school day — which typically runs from 8:30 a.m. to at least 4 p.m. — by 45 minutes.

headline: Savoring the Mellower Music of Home
text: When Vernon Reid, guitarist in the band Living Colour, became a rock star, he bought a Victorian house in the St. George neighborhood on Staten Island. Now, as the band celebrates the 25th anniversary of its breakthrough album, “Vivid” — which the group will play at Irving Plaza on April 6 — Mr. Reid, 54, still enjoys the neighborhood’s mix of Fort Greene-style diversity with a maritime vibe. A composer as well as a musician, he lives with his wife, Gabri Christa Reid, 49, a choreographer and filmmaker, and their daughter, Idea Viola Reid, 9. They have three cats.

headline: With a Sniffle Here and a Steal There, Louisville Pulls Away From Oregon
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Oregon was the newcomer to the Midwest Region semifinals, joining three of college basketball’s blue-blood programs — Louisville, Duke and Michigan State — and, in somewhat self-deprecating fashion, the Ducks brought their lone N.C.A.A. championship trophy on the team plane here.

headline: Anyone Can Get a Table, Eventually
text: Jeffrey Tascarella, 33, is the general manager of the year-old restaurant the NoMad, at Broadway and 28th Street. He can be found on the restaurant’s floor from 10 a.m. to after 11 p.m. daily, solving problems and chatting with the regulars among the 250 nightly guests. He credits his first job in New York City, waiting on tables at Fiamma, a defunct SoHo restaurant, for his love of wine, fine dining and long hours.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Diversity Deserts
text: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: Coming Soon
text: Natan Dvir photographs giant signs in Midtown that advertise the imminent arrival of brand-name stores and transform the streetscape.

headline: Michigan Stuns No. 1 Seed Kansas
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The shot was not a pedestrian 3-pointer, a casual 3 from 20 feet 9 inches. This was a heave. When Trey Burke stepped back, he was at least nine feet beyond the regulation 3-point line. He was drifting and Kansas’ 6-foot-8 Kevin Young was jumping toward him. The chances of the ball going in were about the same odds many gave Burke and Michigan when they trailed by 14 with less than seven minutes remaining.

headline: Avenue of Dreams, and Hot Dogs
text: It was like “Attack of the 50 Foot Woman” everywhere, except the women weren’t exactly attacking.

headline: Richard Griffiths, Falstaffian English Actor, Dies at 65
text: Richard Griffiths, the rotund British actor whose stage career reached a pinnacle with his Tony-winning performance as an idealistic but tormented pedagogue in Alan Bennett’s play “The History Boys” and who achieved popular fame in the movies as Harry Potter’s mean-spirited Uncle Vernon Dursley, died on Thursday in Coventry, England. He was 65.

headline: Knicks’ Streak Hits 7 As Smith Stays on Roll
text: The chants were faint but audible.

headline: Teacher’s Vision, but Done New York City’s Way
text: At last year’s State of the City speech, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the creation of a public high school called the Academy for Software Engineering. The school would be part of an ambitious expansion of computer science education in the city, and Mr. Bloomberg called it the “brainchild” of a local teacher named Michael Zamansky.

headline: Finally Beaten in Florida, Haas, 34, Isn’t Stopping
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — One set into his Sony Open semifinal match against David Ferrer on Friday, Tommy Haas could almost taste his first Masters final since 2001. Haas was looking to end a memorable week in the Miami area in style.

headline: Dreams of a Harlem Jazz Rebirth
text: As another evening falls, the Lenox Lounge sits dim and lonely. Commuters pour out of the 125th Street subway station and onto Lenox Avenue, past its padlocked door. At Ginny’s Supper Club across the street, a mostly black crowd of men in suits and women in heels sips and sways as a band turns out a haunting rendition of John Coltrane’s “My Favorite Things.”

headline: As Home Opener Nears, the Battered Yankees Are Still Looking for Help
text: WASHINGTON — For almost a century, the Yankees have been a team accustomed to snatching the best players from other organizations, whether it was Babe Ruth, Catfish Hunter or Alex Rodriguez. But that is not the case this spring.

headline: Lessons Found in the Mud
text: If you know anything about New York City, you know that there is an insufficient number of preschool spaces for all the children needing to attend preschool, and that this is experienced by the parents who live here with varying degrees of garment-rending.

headline: Murray Shrugs Off Slow Start to Advance to Sony Open Final
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Andy Murray ensured that two of world’s top players would meet in the men’s final of the Sony Open by coming back to defeat Richard Gasquet on Friday night in the second semifinal, 6-7 (3), 6-1, 6-2.

headline: Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 29
text: Michigan shocks No. 1 Kansas in overtime, Florida spoils Florida Gulf Coast’s Run, Louisville smothers Oregon and Duke drops Michigan State.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 30
text: NEWS Sven Olaf Kamphuis calls himself the “minister of telecommunications and foreign affairs for the Republic of CyberBunker.” Others see him as the Prince of Spam. Mr. Kamphuis, who is actually Dutch, is at the heart of an international investigation into one of the biggest cyberattacks identified by the authorities. Because of his outspoken position in a loose federation of hackers, the authorities in the Netherlands and several other countries are examining what role he or the Internet companies he runs played in snarling traffic on the Web this week. Eric Pfanner and Kevin J. O’Brien report.

headline: Injuries May Affect Ticket Sales of Openers
text: The local forecast on Monday calls for a high near 60 degrees with a mix of sun and clouds. Not bad for fans heading to Yankee Stadium and Citi Field as the Yankees and the Mets open their seasons simultaneously in New York for the first time.

headline: Duke Pushes Out Michigan State
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Steven Izzo called it right. Two weeks ago, Steven, the 13-year-old son of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo, sidestepped family loyalty and picked Duke to defeat the Spartans in his N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. The Blue Devils validated his nerve Friday night by sending the Izzos home.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) SNOW WHITE AND THE HUNTSMAN (2012) Kristen Stewart, above, is Snow White, who seeks to usurp the evil queen Ravenna (Charlize Theron) with the help of the Huntsman (Chris Hemsworth) and a specific number of dwarfs (played by Ian McShane, Ray Winstone and Bob Hoskins, among others) in this darkened adaptation of the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, directed by Rupert Sanders. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said: “There is nothing cute about this movie. And that feels right. There is something exciting about how seriously ‘Snow White and the Huntsman’ takes its themes.” He added that Ms. Stewart’s Snow White was “part of an interesting new breed of warrior princesses — Katniss Everdeen is their current leader — whose ascendance reflects the convergence of commercial calculations and cultural longings. Long may they reign.”

headline: Nets Fade and Fall in Denver
text: DENVER — The Nets’ bid to ensure a winning road record for the first time since entering the N.B.A. in 1976 came up well short against the Denver Nuggets’ home dominance on Friday night.

headline: How the Cyberattack on Spamhaus Unfolded
text: A look at the attack and the defense in one of the largest known distributed denial of service attacks.

headline: Florida Ends Florida Gulf Coast’s Run
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Florida’s Mike Rosario seemed thwarted as he looked to make an inbounds pass with two minutes to play. The Gators were safely ahead, so a turnover at this juncture would have been meaningless.

headline: Fifty-One Years Across Town, but United in Misery for Six
text: In their 51 years together, the Mets and the Yankees have both been losing teams on only six occasions, and the last time it happened was way back in 1992. Since then, the Yankees have won five World Series and the Mets ... well, they’re the Mets, so they haven’t won any.

headline: North Korea Threatens to Close Factories It Runs With South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, reiterating that it considered the Korean Peninsula back in “a state of war,” threatened Saturday to shut down a factory complex it jointly operates with South Korea and that stands as the last significant symbol of cooperation.

headline: Dogs, Nets and Poverty – a Tough Combination
text: Dogs and developing countries are a rough mix — with the lack of neutering resulting in puppy population explosions and all manner of bad outcomes, from millions of dog bites a year in India to rabies outbreaks in Indonesia to fatal maulings in Mexico City. Learn more from Veterinarians Without Borders and the “Street Dog Welfare” page of Humane Society International.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The state government Thursday tabled a bill that seeks to regulate the functioning of private security agencies in the state, the Business Standard reported. Under the new proposal all such agencies will have to seek a mandatory license before they are allowed to operate in the state.

headline: Italian President Enlists Special Help on Political Deadlock
text: ROME — Italy’s president said Saturday that he would turn to a group of outside advisers to help him end the country’s political deadlock, after weeks of inconclusive consultations with political leaders failed to overcome ingrained divisions.

headline: Egypt Orders Arrest of Satirist Over Skits on Islam and Morsi
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s public prosecutor on Saturday ordered the arrest of a popular television satirist on charges that included insulting President Mohamed Morsi and denigrating Islam, the state news agency reported, a move that amplified criticisms that the Islamist government is moving aggressively to stifle freedom of expression.

headline: High-Tech Means of Production Belies Nostalgic Image of Maple Syrup
text: EAST MONTPELIER, Vt. — The rich, sweet tang of sap being boiled into maple syrup greeted tourists at Burr Morse’s sugar shack here this month — along with Mr. Morse, every inch the rural maple farmer in worn baseball cap and syrup-stained jacket, stirring the steaming evaporator with an old-fashioned dipper.

headline: Maple Syrup Takes Turn Toward Technology
text: Over the past decade technology has allowed maple farmers to offset the effects of climate change.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I must be getting better at these, because I’m definitely enjoying cryptics more. The variety of ways to clue an entry in a cryptic crossword gives your brain such a refreshing flossing that there is no way not to enjoy solving.

headline: Social Security, Present and Future
text: In the fight over the federal budget deficit, Social Security has so far been untouched. That may soon change.

headline: Boston College Faces Tough Road in Title Defense
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. – Besides Boston College, the East regional of the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament is not filled with historic powers. With the other three universities coming from lesser-known conferences, it could be easy to overlook the bracket.

headline: Who Can Bring the E.U. To Its Senses?
text: Cyprus finally got a revised bailout plan last week. It taxes big, uninsured bank depositors to pay part of the cost of restructuring the country’s two biggest banks while leaving the savings of smaller, insured depositors untouched. But just days before, Cyprus, with the blessings of the smartest bankers and smartest finance ministers in Europe, came within a whisker of adopting a truly reckless plan that would have taxed small savers, undermined deposit insurance and risked sparking disastrous bank runs elsewhere, notably Italy and Spain, the euro zone’s third- and fourth-largest economies.

headline: Resurrecting California’s Public Universities
text: Even before the recession hit, the public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of the nation’s students were suffering from dwindling state revenue. Their response, not surprisingly, was to raise tuition, slash course offerings and, in some cases, freeze or even reduce student enrollment. The damage was acute in California, whose once-glorious system of higher education effectively cannibalized itself, shutting out a growing number of well-qualified students.

headline: Immigrant Detainees and the Right to Counsel
text: DO immigrants who are incarcerated while their legal status is resolved deserve a lawyer?

headline: Heat’s Streak May Be Over, but Show Rolls On
text: NEW ORLEANS — If LeBron James seemed bothered by the lapse of Miami’s 27-game winning streak or the hard fouls — physical and verbal — he had absorbed in recent days, it was not apparent Friday morning. His hunger for victory or reprisal seemed outweighed at the moment by his hunger for lunch.

headline: Our Inconsistent Ethical Instincts
text: MORAL quandaries often pit concerns about principles against concerns about practical consequences. Should we ban assault rifles and large sodas, restricting people’s liberties for the sake of physical health and safety? Should we allow drone killings or torture, if violating one person’s rights could save a thousand lives?

headline: Decision on Coyotes Seems Near
text: The Phoenix Coyotes’ ownership situation, which has been unsettled for nearly four years, could finally be resolved soon. According to published reports and to officials familiar with the situation, the N.H.L. either will sell the Coyotes to the last in a long line of prospective buyers who pledged to keep them in Glendale, Ariz., or will decide as soon as next month to allow the team to relocate.

headline: Shawn Askinosie
text: Shawn Askinosie is a criminal defense lawyer turned confectioner. His company, Askinosie Chocolate in Springfield, Mo., makes highly regarded bean-to-bar artisanal chocolate with 10 percent of the profits shared with the company’s cocoa farmers in Ecuador, Honduras, the Philippines and Tanzania.

headline: Short of Money, Egypt Sees Crisis on Fuel and Food
text: QALYUBEYA, Egypt — A fuel shortage has helped send food prices soaring. Electricity is blacking out even before the summer. And gas-line gunfights have killed at least five people and wounded dozens over the past two weeks.

headline: In Brazil, Streets of Dancing Cars and Swagger
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — José Américo Crippa’s 1974 Chevrolet Monte Carlo boasts just about every feature that a lowrider should have, including dazzling chrome wheels, a sliding ragtop roof, a candy-apple red paint job and hydraulic pumps that enable the vehicle to bounce several feet in the air at the press of a button.

text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — One team was consistently ranked in the top five all season. The other is one game above .500 and barely snuck into the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament.

headline: An Arena’s Stunning Moments, From Floor to Ceiling
text: ATLANTA — The Georgia Dome, the host of the men’s Final Four this year, is 21 years old and adequate as a site for major sporting events. But because more money can be made with a new stadium, a path is being cleared for the dome’s extinction. So this is probably the last time a college basketball champion will be crowned at its climate-controlled environs.

headline: Hope Is All Around in New, Open A.L. East
text: In 10 of 12 seasons, from 1998 through 2009, the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox finished in the top two spots in the American League East. When they open the season this week at Yankee Stadium, there will be no undercurrent of divisional superiority.

headline: Need a Job? Invent It
text: WHEN Tony Wagner, the Harvard education specialist, describes his job today, he says he’s “a translator between two hostile tribes” — the education world and the business world, the people who teach our kids and the people who give them jobs. Wagner’s argument in his book “Creating Innovators: The Making of Young People Who Will Change the World” is that our K-12 and college tracks are not consistently “adding the value and teaching the skills that matter most in the marketplace.”
