text: Should it be legal for doctors to help end dying patients’ lives?

headline: N.L. Pennant Within the Nationals’ Grasp
text: For the last 13 years, more often than not, the path to the National League pennant has run through St. Louis. The Cardinals have appeared in seven league championship series since 2000, including the last two without the benefit of winning their division.

headline: Will Gays Be Punished for Success?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: King Cotton’s Long Shadow
text: Last month, researchers at University College London made public a database that describes in illuminating detail one of the largest government bailouts in modern history. In 1833, Britain paid 20 million pounds to compensate 3,000 Caribbean slaveholders for the emancipation of their slaves. The payments constituted about 40 percent of total governmental expenditures that year. Conversation about the database in Britain centered on the recipients of these reparations for slaveholders, among them the ancestors of George Orwell, Graham Greene and David Cameron.

headline: Introducing a Repurposed President and a Revamped Star
text: We know this baseball season will have breakout stars we never expected, injuries we never saw coming and — based on last year — about 100 no-hitters and perfect games. That all involves players. Here are nine new things to watch on the periphery of the game.

headline: Machines of Laughter and Forgetting
text: UNTIL very recently, technology had a clear, if boring, purpose: by taking care of the Little Things, it enabled us, its human masters, to focus on the Big Things. “Unless there are slaves to do the ugly, horrible, uninteresting work, culture and contemplation become almost impossible,” proclaimed that noted connoisseur of contemplation Oscar Wilde.

headline: Anger Over Plan to Sell Site of Wounded Knee Massacre
text: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D. — Ever since American soldiers massacred men, women and children here more than a century ago in the last major bloodshed of the American Indian wars, this haunted patch of rolling hills and ponderosa pines has embodied the combustible relationship between Indians and the United States government.

headline: Wounded Knee Up for Sale
text: This haunted patch of rolling hills and ponderosa pines has embodied the combustible relationship between Indians and the United States government.

headline: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Haas
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–The secret to David Ferrer’s success is a baseline strategy called the 2-1. It is a three-shot sequence that begins in the ad court by initially disarming the opponent with depth, then stretches him wider off the court with direction that opens a gaping hole in the deuce court for the player to finish the point.

headline: Yvonne Brill, a Pioneering Rocket Scientist, Dies at 88
text: She was a brilliant rocket scientist who followed her husband from job to job and took eight years off from work to raise three children. “The world’s best mom,” her son Matthew said.

headline: Hitched to an Aging Star: Anatomy of a Deal, and Doubts
text: Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera was convinced that Alex Rodriguez had made a colossal blunder.

headline: Labor and Business Reach Deal on Immigration Issue
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top business and labor groups have reached an agreement on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said on Saturday. The deal clears the path for broad immigration legislation to be introduced when Congress returns from its two-week recess in mid-April.

headline: Embracing a Mexican-American Subculture
text: A scene with roots in East Los Angeles has spread to places like Japan and New Zealand. Its devotees share a simple connection, beyond a few Spanish words: lowrider cars and bikes.

headline: If a Fund Turns on a Dime, Watch Your Dollars
text: LAST October, shareholders in the Willow Fund, a closed-end investment fund sponsored and sold by UBS, received some disturbing news: the fund, which had assets of almost $500 million in 2006, was being liquidated.

headline: An American Quilt of Privacy Laws, Incomplete

headline: Want to Know Me? Just Read My User Manual
text: This interview with  Ivar Kroghrud, the lead strategist at QuestBack, which specializes in feedback management, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Mr. Kroghrud, a co-founder of the firm, was its C.E.O. for 13 years.

headline: A Sustainable Budget Should Endure Any Storm
text: IN the national debate over fiscal policy, an important question is what the long-run goal should be. Representative Paul D. Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, has a plan to balance the federal budget in 10 years. When asked if he would do the same, President Obama demurred.

headline: Thomas McEvilley, Critic and Defender of Non-Western Art, Dies at 73
text: In 1984, when the Museum of Modern Art in New York opened its exhibition “ ‘Primitivism’ in 20th Century Art: Affinity of the Tribal and the Modern,” the reception was generally favorable. Then came Thomas McEvilley’s shattering review in Artforum magazine.

headline: On Being Catholic
text: An old friend and mentor of mine, Ernan McMullin, was a philosopher of science widely respected in his discipline.  He was also a Catholic priest.  I don’t know how many times fellow philosophers at professional meetings drew me aside and asked, “Does Ernan really believe that stuff?”  (He did.) Amid all the serious and generally respectful coverage of the papal resignation and the election of a new pope, I often detect an undertone of this same puzzlement.  Can reflective and honest intellectuals actually believe that stuff?

headline: Those Irritating Verbs-as-Nouns
text: “Do you have a solve for this problem?” “Let’s all focus on the build.” “That’s the take-away from today’s seminar.” Or, to quote a song that was recently a No. 1 hit in Britain, “Would you let me see beneath your beautiful?”

headline: Phil Ramone, Producer for Music’s Biggest Stars, Dies at 79
text: Phil Ramone, a prolific record producer and engineer who worked with some of the biggest music stars of the last 50 years, including Ray Charles, Frank Sinatra, Paul Simon, Billy Joel and Barbra Streisand, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 79. (Though it was widely reported that he was 72, public records and his family confirm that he was born on Jan. 5, 1934.)

headline: Still at a Trot, This Bull May Have Farther to Go
text: FOR the last four years, market watchers have bemoaned the muted economic recovery, with its sluggish growth, tepid job creation and continuing investor fears.

headline: Letting Down Our Guard With Web Privacy
text: SAY you’ve come across a discount online retailer promising a steal on hand-stitched espadrilles for spring. You start setting up an account by offering your e-mail address — but before you can finish, there’s a ping on your phone. A text message. You read it and respond, then return to the Web site, enter your birth date, click “F” for female, agree to the company’s terms of service and carry on browsing.

headline: Alford Is Hired as the Coach at U.C.L.A.
text: Eleven days ago, New Mexico announced a 10-year contract extension for Coach Steve Alford, who agreed to coach the Lobos until 2023. But on Saturday, U.C.L.A. announced that Alford would be its next coach, the latest man charged with returning the Bruins to glory.

headline: State-Wrecked: The Corruption of Capitalism in America
text: GREENWICH, Conn.The Dow Jones and Standard & Poor’s 500 indexes reached record highs on Thursday, having completely erased the losses since the stock market’s last peak, in 2007. But instead of cheering, we should be very afraid.

headline: Victory Strengthens a Case for the Derby
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Orb’s owners, the esteemed Phipps Stable and Stuart Janney III, declined to speak about the Kentucky Derby ahead of the Florida Derby on Saturday, insisting they had not yet caught Derby fever.

headline: Why Innovators Get Better With Age

headline: Setting Yourself Apart
text: I’M a first-generation American. My father was born in Poland and changed his last name when he came to this country. My mother’s family was from Sweden. My family owned two bakeries, and my siblings and I were expected to work in them. I started out cleaning the bakeries and made deliveries for the catering part of the business when I got my driver’s license.

headline: Fatigue May Be a Foe for Duke

Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona — will be on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” Business and labor leaders reached a deal on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants on Friday.

headline: McIlroy Battles Mental Mistakes
text: HUMBLE, Texas — At Redstone Golf Club on Saturday, Rory McIlroy stood over a five-foot birdie putt, which would have gotten him to four under for the day and inside the top 10 for the Houston Open.

headline: Special Features
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this is what a Sunday puzzle is supposed to be like. Great, crunchy fill, with little to no junk. Multilayered, with more than one surprise to uncover. And that extra surprise is what keeps you going through the longer Sunday solve.

About 11 minutes remained in Syracuse’s East Region final against Marquette, but Triche kept looking at the clock, wishing hard that the minutes would tick away.

text: Across the country, education reformers and their allies in both parties have revamped the way teachers are graded, abandoning methods under which nearly everyone was deemed satisfactory, even when students were falling behind.

headline: We’re One Big Team, So Run Those Stairs
text: AT 12:30 p.m. on a Tuesday, the chief executive of Datalogix was spider-crawling across a conference room floor. All around him, account managers and data analysts were thrusting 20-pound medicine balls overhead, while their Spandex-clad co-workers sprinted up and down the lobby’s carpeted staircase.

headline: Sweating It for the Company
text: Trainers at CrossFit Sanitas Boulder demonstrate how to perform various exercises. The heavy-duty fitness regimen is increasingly being offered at businesses to improve worker productivity and lower health insurance costs.

headline: 9-Year-Old Breaks Record for Youngest U.S. Master
text: A 9-year-old from Madison, Wis., became the youngest chess master in American history last weekend when his rating passed 2,200 after he won two games at the Midwest Open Team Chess Festival in Dayton, Ohio.

headline: New Ideological Battle in Pakistan: Traffic Circle’s Name
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — If ever a squabble over a street name could sum up a nation’s identity crisis, it is happening in Lahore, Pakistan’s cultural capital.

headline: Not Playing Her Best, Williams Is Still Good Enough vs. Sharapova
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Serena Williams now stands alone as the woman with the most Sony Open championships after storming back to defeat Maria Sharapova, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0, in Saturday’s final. It was her sixth title in the event, one better than Steffi Graf. She solidified her world No. 1 ranking by winning the last 10 games after being broken in the fifth game of the second set.

headline: A Wary Easter Weekend for Christians in Syria
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Torches flickered outside the church. Little girls wore their sparkly Easter best. Children bearing lanterns filed out through the heavy gilt doors, as worshipers carried an icon of Jesus and a cross covered with carnations.

headline: Santana to Have Shoulder Surgery Again, Almost Certainly Ending Mets Career
text: The Mets said Johan Santana would have surgery Tuesday on his left shoulder. Given the gravity of the injury — a tear of the capsule in the left-hander’s shoulder — there is no chance he will pitch this season.

headline: Shot Becomes a Youthful Vision Realized
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — His teammates have talked about framing a picture of the shot as a keepsake. For Michigan fans, it has already ascended into Wolverines lore, a thunderbolt fired from between the 3-point line and midcourt, one Trey Burke had always visualized growing up in Columbus, Ohio.

text: Is this about Bill Powers or U.T.’s tower?

headline: Christians in Syria Celebrate Good Friday With Hope and Fear
text: Easter weekend is usually the year’s most festive for Syrian Christians, but this year, it is infused with grave uncertainty.

headline: A Texas Senate Bill Would Revise the State’s End-of-Life Procedure
text: Texas lawmakers have grappled year after year over whether families or medical professionals should decide when to end a terminally ill patient’s life-sustaining care. This year, they seem closer to a compromise.

headline: Mets Make Final Preparations
text: Manager Terry Collins was in a jovial mood before the Mets played their spring training finale against the Baltimore Orioles. His roster was nearly set and despite a spate of injuries, two of his stars, David Wright and Daniel Murphy, appeared to be on the mend.

headline: Your State’s Gun Control Just Got Stricter? Come on Down!
text: Gov. Rick Perry speaks wistfully — almost lovingly — about a rifle he recently fired while he was at a range in Leander owned by the manufacturer LaRue Tactical. “I’m incredibly passionate about a well-made piece of equipment,” Mr. Perry said in a phone interview last week, “whether it’s an automobile or a weapon.”

headline: Klan Protests in Memphis Over Renaming of Three Parks
text: MEMPHIS — The Ku Klux Klan rallied in Memphis on Saturday to protest the City Council’s decision last month to rename three city parks that honored Confederate troops.

headline: Using More Than Skill, a Gator Grows Up
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The tattoos are the essence of Florida guard Mike Rosario, his testimonials. They cover his body, and he is not even sure how many there are — more than 60, he guesses. Rosario is the canvas for his story.

headline: ‘Cowboy Stuntman’ Was an Olympic Medalist, Too
text: The wood-paneled walls and shelves of Dean Smith’s modest home, about 20 miles south of Graham in rural Stephens County, are cluttered with photographs and memorabilia from a lifetime and then some. A visitor might think he had stumbled into the living room of a real-life Forrest Gump.

headline: A Game Forever Links Krzyzewski and Pitino

text: TAYLORSVILLE, N.C. — Sheri Farley walks with a limp. The only job she could hold would be one where she does not have to stand or sit longer than 20 minutes, otherwise pain screams down her spine and up her legs.

headline: A Clinton in ‘Transition’ Keeps Opponents and Donors Frozen
text: Hillary Clinton left the State Department nearly two months ago, but she still needs a staff to keep up with the considerable business of being Hillary Clinton. A half-dozen people now work for the former secretary of state and Democratic presidential candidate in a tiny corporate space on Connecticut Avenue in Washington, in what is called her “transition office.”

headline: Mother and Baby Critically Injured in Crash at Brooklyn Bus Stop
text: At least 10 people were injured, including a mother and her baby, when a car ran up on a sidewalk and rammed through a bus stop in Brooklyn on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Bob Turley, Pitcher With a Blazing Fastball, Dies at 82
text: Bob Turley, a Cy Young Award-winning right-handed pitcher whose blazing fastball bored in on baffled hitters like a dissolving aspirin and lifted the Yankees to a come-from-behind victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the 1958 World Series, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 82.

text: Emergency crews worked Saturday to contain several thousand gallons of crude oil that spilled from a ruptured Exxon Mobil pipeline in central Arkansas.

headline: Nets’ Promising Western Swing Ends With a Thud

headline: In Bitter Loss for Buckeyes, Something Was Missing: Them
text: LOS ANGELES — When Aaron Craft caught the ball on the right wing, with Ohio State behind by 6 and less than a minute remaining, the crowd was tense, the game’s outcome was uncertain, and the first half seemed so far away.

headline: Slain Texas Lawman Had Pledged to Hunt Down ‘Scum’
text: KAUFMAN, Tex. — After the daylight assassination of his deputy two months ago, Mike McLelland, the district attorney in largely rural Kaufman County, responded with a flash of angry bravado, denigrating the perpetrators as “scum” and vowing to hunt them down.

headline: The ECB and the Austerity Trap
text: Simon Wren-Lewis tries to show some sympathy for the devil: he tries to get into the mindset of European officials who defend austerity. And he gets at an important point in the process, although he may let the austerians off too lightly.

headline: A Word of Caution From Rubio on Immigration
text: Read an updated version of this post.12:45 p.m. | Updated As several of the senators taking part in a bipartisan effort to overhaul to the nation’s immigration laws appeared on the Sunday talk shows to sound an optimistic note, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a member of the group, offered a strongly worded note of caution. In a statement released by his office  on Sunday, the headline — in all capital letters — read: “No Final Agreement on Immigration Legislation Yet.”

headline: A Fighter for Tenants Relaces Her Gloves
text: It was 1959, and a painter and actress from Greenwich Village posted an “open letter to the people of New York” around Manhattan, warning that a plan by the formidable Robert Moses, then the city parks commissioner, jeopardized Shakespeare in the Park. Moses eventually dropped the plan. At the top of the letter, which Doris Diether still keeps, appear the handwritten words “start of my civic career.”

headline: Fresh Thoughts from Authors of a Paper on 11,300 Years of Global Temperature Changes
text: April 1, 12:17 a.m. | Update below |There’s been vigorous discussion here and elsewhere (e.g., Climate Audit and Skeptical Science) of the methods and findings in “A Reconstruction of Regional and Global Temperature for the Past 11,300 Years,” a recent Science paper by Shaun A. Marcott, Jeremy D. Shakun, Peter U. Clark and Alan C. Mix.

headline: The Child, the Tablet and the Developing Mind

headline: What's on Sunday
text: 12:30 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS (2009) Bill Hader, Anna Faris and Andy Samberg, among others, lend their voices to this animated comedy about an eccentric inventor, above, who creates a machine that can transform water into food. But the machine malfunctions and is accidentally launched into the atmosphere, where it begins to affect the weather, turning rain into cheeseburgers and a tornado into a swirling mass of spaghetti and meatballs. “Parents will enjoy tracking the endless stream of movie and television sendups,” Daniel M. Gold wrote in The New York Times, adding, “If the filmmakers opt to make only light statements about junk food, obesity and solid waste, they at least leave the audience sated on a single serving of inspired lunacy.”

headline: ‘G.I. Joe: Retaliation’ Has a Strong Start
text: “G.I. Joe: Retaliation” was a burly No. 1 at North American theaters over the Easter weekend, validating an unusual decision by Paramount Pictures to delay its release so that it could rework parts of the plot. “Retaliation,” which cost at least $130 million to make, took in about $41.2 million over the weekend, for a total since opening on Thursday of $51.7 million. Overseas, the movie — originally planned for release last summer — generated an additional $80.3 million in ticket sales.

headline: Maestro’s Steady Hand Helps Resurrect Rome Opera
text: ROME — The work was by Verdi. Three fine young singers held the Rome Opera’s stage. But the spotlight, one night last month, was unmistakably on the maestro in the pit, Riccardo Muti.

headline: Cranky Old Men
text: Shorter David Stockman:

headline: From a Tricycle to Many Vehicles
text: TALL AND STRIKING (imagine a more debonair, calmly coifed Edward Scissorhands) Joseph Keckler stood in the middle of a stage, rehearsing his new work, “I am an Opera.” “Then there’s a Minotaur,” he explained to an observer. “He turns out to be a delightful companion.”

headline: As Banks in Cyprus Falter, Other Tax Havens Step In
text: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Bloodied by a harsh bailout deal that drives a stake through the heart of this Mediterranean country’s oversize financial industry, Cyprus now faces a further blow to its role as an offshore tax haven: the vultures from competing territories are circling.

headline: Hagel Warns of Big Squeeze at the Pentagon
text: WASHINGTON — Ending his first month as defense secretary, Chuck Hagel invited six young enlisted personnel for lunch in his private Pentagon office. Without military or civilian aides, Mr. Hagel himself took extensive notes as the sergeants and petty officers poured out their concerns about pay, benefits, training and sexual assault — issues that would decide whether they make the military a way of life or just a way station in life.

headline: Israel Taps an Offshore Natural Gas Field
text: JERUSALEM — Israel moved closer to its goal of energy independence on Sunday as natural gas from a large offshore field began flowing into the country, a harbinger of important change that will benefit the country strategically and economically, officials said.

headline: TV Taps the Foreign Idea Factory
text: Ideas may not fall out of trees, but they do come in the mail from Sydney and Tel Aviv. Of the 100 or so pilot episodes being shot as candidates for the broadcast television networks’ fall lineups, at least a dozen are based on shows from Argentina, Australia, Britain or Israel.

headline: Inventive New Works Swoop In
text: All the works in the 30th anniversary season of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company at the Joyce Theater are set to classics of chamber music, played live. But where the first program is dominated by celebrated dances freighted with history, the second consists of two premieres created for and by the current company. In the older works the dancers look dutiful; in the new they look wonderfully like themselves.

headline: As Market Heats Up, Trading Slips Into Shadows
text: Wall Street is embracing its dark side.

headline: Baby Giraffe Draws Attention to Sanctuary
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — In February, the LEO Zoological Conservation Center proclaimed to the world the birth of a male eastern mountain bongo, a large African antelope. That did not get much notice.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the I.S.M. manufacturing index for March and construction spending for February (Monday); factory orders for February (Tuesday); A.D.P. employment and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for March and the trade deficit and consumer credit for February (Friday).

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: PBS to Show Block of ‘Martha’ Programs
text: Fans of Martha Stewart who since last fall have been tuning into her “Cooking School” program on PBS for advice on how to braise, roast and sauté are about to get some sweeter wisdom on how to handle the often overlooked stars of menus: baked goods and desserts.

headline: Dolan Says the Catholic Church Should Be More Welcoming to Gay People
text: On Easter Sunday, weeks after he helped elect a new pope for a church struggling with declining numbers and controversy over social issues, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said that the Roman Catholic Church could be more welcoming of gay men and lesbians despite opposing same-sex marriage.

headline: Social Marketing Drives a New York Renaissance
text: NEW YORK, New York, a wonderful town, according to the song — or, if you prefer the unexpurgated lyric from the Broadway version, a hell of a town. Either way, that was the sentiment back in the day when mad men ruled Madison Avenue.

headline: Murray’s Sony Open Title Is a Matter of Perseverance, and a Few Inches
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Andy Murray needed every bit of energy he could muster Sunday to capture his second Sony Open championship, defeating David Ferrer, 2-6, 6-4, 7-6 (1).

headline: Papers Worldwide Embrace Web Subscriptions
text: SERRAVAL, France — Newspapers, once reluctant to try to charge readers for access to their Web sites, have begun doing so in droves.

headline: Boeheim Maintains a Passion as Intense as His Defense
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Michigan Barrels Into the Final Four After a 20-Year Absence
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The scissors seemed awkward in their hands, and rightfully so. It had been 20 years since a Michigan basketball team had climbed a ladder this high, and as these Wolverines celebrated and carefully snipped away at the nets, they had proved worthy of creating a new legacy.

headline: Then Life Got in the Way
text: The principals in Meg Wolitzer’s heavily detailed new novel, “The Interestings,” are only in their midteens when they decide to give themselves the label of the title, hoping the nickname will stick for life. This is a bravely embarrassing move for Ms. Wolitzer. Surely she knows that self-dramatizing, narcissistic teenagers aren’t necessarily interesting, let alone Interesting with a capital I.

headline: Echoes of Languages No Longer Heard
text: The “Vanishing Languages” project by Kevin James, a New York-based trombonist and composer, is a rare hybrid of conservation effort and memorial, new music and ancient languages. Prodded by Unesco statistics that predict that by the end of the century half of the world’s 6,000 languages will be extinct, Mr. James spent months in the field tracking down and recording the last remaining speakers of four critically endangered tongues: Hokkaido Ainu, an aboriginal language from northern Japan, the American Indian Quileute from western Washington, and Dalabon and Jawoyn, aboriginal languages from Arnhem Land in Australia.

headline: Raging Against the Fates, With Intermittent Elegies
text: Visions of murder, catastrophe, transfiguration and desperate love issued from the Beacon Theater stage on Friday night, set to dirges, stomps and inexorable crescendos. Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds — along with a string ensemble, the backup singers Sharon Van Etten (who opened the concert) and Shilpa Ray, and a youth choir, the Harlem Voices — were midway through a sold-out three-night stand. Songs from their new album, “Push the Sky Away” (Bad Seed Ltd.), started and ended the set. In between they revisited material recorded over the last three decades.

headline: Discovery Expands Its Reach Overseas
text: Alana Thompson, the 7-year-old beauty queen known as Honey Boo Boo, has had some mishaps in child pageants in the Deep South, where her reality show on Discovery Communications’ TLC channel is based. But the chubby and charming contestant and her overbearing parents are big in Brazil.

headline: Spring North American Championships
text: ST. LOUIS — At the Spring North American Championships here last month the winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York City. They did well in the diagramed deal from the first session on the second and last day, when Wooldridge read the cards perfectly.

headline: Disco and Villains in 1983 Bollywood
text: In its first scene, set at the Funkytown Disco in Bombay — year: 1983 — “Himmatwala” loads on the period markers, with quick nods to Michael Jackson, Madonna and, of course, the reign of disco in a song-and-dance number (called “Thank God It’s Friday,” no less) full of flashing lights and silver-clad hoofers.

headline: Archaeologists of Vinyl Rejoice in Return Home
text: The Moving Sidewalks, in their first gig in nearly 44 years on Saturday night at B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, played some pretty nice gear for a band that never had a national hit. Tube amplifiers by Magnatone, the recently revived pre-’70s American brand, handsome in design, broad and deep in sound; custom-made Telecaster-like guitars with psychedelic blob patterns swirling on a small screen underneath the strings, as if iPads had been built into the instruments’ bodies.

headline: Nuzzling (or Is It Nudging?) Their Way Through a Duet
text: The choreographer Ursula Eagly and her collaborator, Abby Block, struck crooked poses in the middle of a pristine white floor at the Chocolate Factory on Thursday. They might have been innocent girls pretending to be trees, except that the discomfort of the posing, combined with their dazed and wandering eyes, suggested something awry.

headline: Could the Killings Be Connected?
text: With the murder of a Texas prosecutor on Saturday, less than two months after one of his assistants was killed, investigators say they can’t rule out a connection to white supremacist groups, and another prominent murder. Here is a timeline of those events.

headline: Laughing at Rappers, Who Laugh Right Back
text: It’s almost certainly too soon, and definitely futile, to be discussing what constitutes golden ages of any Internet pursuit, but in the area of hip-hop humor the peaks may have already been set.

headline: An Eyewear Company’s Simple Sell
text: The start-up Warby Parker is one of a number of new innovators that has decided to design, manufacture and sell its inexpensive products directly to its Web-savvy customers.

headline: Anthony Can Learn From Pierce’s Career Arc
text: Shaquille O’Neal is generally credited as the first to describe Paul Pierce as the truth, which eventually stuck as an uppercase nickname. But there were years before that when Pierce, upon consideration for membership in the fraternity of authentic N.B.A. elites, was dismissed as anything but.

headline: Islamist Fighters Slip Back Into Timbuktu and Are Repelled by French and Malians
text: PARIS — A small band of radical Islamist fighters battled French and Malian soldiers for hours in a firefight in Timbuktu on Sunday after infiltrating the Malian city overnight, Malian officials and witnesses said.

headline: Indies Grab the Controls at a Game Conference
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Game Developers Conference is the kind of place where controllers for the PlayStation 4, Sony’s forthcoming console, sit under glass like the Hope Diamond, and where designers and other industry professionals line up for hours to try the Oculus Rift virtual-reality headset, which has begun shipping as prototypes to those who paid $300 for a development kit.

headline: Game Developers Conference
text: Scenes from the gathering in San Francisco.

headline: E-Commerce Companies Bypass the Middlemen
text: When the founders of a start-up that sells eyeglasses online, Warby Parker, began investigating why designer glasses cost several hundred dollars, they discovered that everyone in the process was taking a cut: designers, manufacturers, brands, wholesalers and retailers.

headline: Smoky Voice Covers the Ground From Gloomy to Morbid
text: If an enormous sculpture is placed in a small room, or a miniature is marooned on a vast museum wall, the art can lose its impact. Particular genres of music also need to be performed in an appropriate space to be best enjoyed.

headline: Art Collector Buried After Three-Week Delay
text: Merton D. Simpson, the painter and influential collector of African art, was buried on Saturday in his hometown, Charleston, S.C., three weeks after his death at 84. The delay stemmed from bitter infighting among his family, friends and a court-appointed guardian.

headline: Calculating the Impact of Cyprus’s Bailout
text: WHAT are the implications of the huge losses — 60 percent — that the Cypriot bailout is imposing on the biggest depositors of that country’s two largest banks?

headline: Fool
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — No, I’m not calling you all FOOLs. And lest you think that Gary J. Whitehead is trying to insult us, please note today’s date. Yes, it’s April FOOL’s Day, and today’s puzzle is all about FOOLs and being FOOLed.

headline: Rates of A.D.H.D. Diagnosis in Children
text: Nearly one in five high school-aged boys has been given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

headline: Once a ‘Cuckoo’s Nest,’ Now a Museum
text: SALEM, Ore. — Nurse Ratched slept here.

headline: Egyptian Satirist Posts Bail as Authorities Press Case
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian television satirist who was summoned by prosecutors on charges that he had insulted President Mohamed Morsi was ordered to post bail on Sunday, indicating that the authorities were continuing to pursue their investigation of the popular host.

headline: Russians Selectively Blocking Internet
text: MOSCOW — The Russian government in recent weeks has been making use of a new law that gives it the power to block Internet content that it deems illegal or harmful to children.

headline: Treating Cancer Patients, and Costs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Should Small Knives Be Permitted on Planes?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scrub Away Your Worries
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Stockman
text: Not much more, I promise. As Mark Thoma points out, the verdict among everyone who knows anything is that Stockman’s piece, mysteriously given star treatment, was pathetic and embarrassing. It’s full of big numbers that are scary because they’re big numbers — we’ve run a current account deficit of $8 trillion. So? We have a $16 trillion a year economy; America’s net international investment position is a debt of about 30 percent of GDP, which isn’t that big; our balance of investment income is still positive. But it’s EIGHT TRILLION DOLLARS!

headline: Data Storage Player Prepares to Compete Overseas
text: LONDON — Box, an online business data storage and management company, plans to expand its sales force and team of developers by opening offices in Germany and France in coming months, building on its first overseas foray last summer in Britain.

headline: N.Y.U. and the Village
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pope Calls for ‘Peace in All the World’ in First Easter Message
text: VATICAN CITY — In his first Easter Sunday message, Pope Francis passionately called for “peace in all the world,” urging Israelis and Palestinians to “resume negotiations to end a conflict that has lasted all too long,” calling for an end to the civil war in Syria, and promoting a “renewed spirit of reconciliation” on the Korean Peninsula, where tensions have been rising.

headline: The Tar Sands Disaster
text: WATERLOO, Ontario

headline: New Disney Characters Make It Big in TV’s Preschool Playground
text: LOS ANGELES — Sorry, Dora. You’ve been dethroned.

headline: 2 Men in China Die of Lesser-Known Strain of Bird Flu
text: SHANGHAI — Two men have died here after contracting a strain of avian flu that had not been previously found in humans, Xinhua, China’s official news agency, reported Sunday.

headline: From Asylum to Museum
text: The hospital once known as the Oregon State Insane Asylum is one of only a few institutions around the world that house museums inside of still-functioning treatment facilitys.

headline: Disney Junior Finds Ratings Success
text: As Disney Junior’s ratings catch up to Nick Jr.’s, Brooks Barnes of The New York Times sits down with the Disney executive Nancy Kanter to discuss the success of Disney’s children’s programming.

headline: Rubio Says Immigration Bill Still Has a Way to Go
text: WASHINGTON — As several of the eight senators taking part in a bipartisan effort to overhaul to the nation’s immigration laws appeared on television Sunday to voice optimism about the negotiations, Senator Marco Rubio, a member of the group, issued a strongly worded message of caution.

headline: Tracking Cicadas, With Helpers
text: The 17-year Magicicada Brood II cicadas are coming, and WNYC and its nationally distributed “Radiolab” program will be there to welcome them — after a mad sprint to persuade hundreds of listeners in the next two weeks to build temperature sensors and stick them in the ground, from Virginia to Connecticut.
